docs.full_text: BARRY ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY. The Barry Astronomical Society have secured the services of Major-General H. H. Lee, J.P., Dina-s Powis, to open their winter session with a popular lecture. Among the general's many accomplishments must be in- cluded his scientific knowledge of astronomy, especially of the branch relating to the spec- troscope, an instrument, the development of which has played such an important part in modern astronomy. The lecture will be illus- trated by lantern slides, and experiments will also be made with the spectroscope. All in- terested in astronomy are given a free and hearty welcome.

docs.full_text: UNIVRRSITY COLLEGE OF SOUTH WALES AND MONMOUTHSHIRE. LECTURE AT SWANSEA. The first of a course of ten lectures on Astronomy," in connection with the University College of South Wales and Monmouthshire, was delivered at the Royal Institution, Swansea, on Friday evening by Professor H. W. Lloyd Tanner. There were nearly a hundred persons present. The lecture was a general introductory one, and, being extremely interesting, was listened to very atten- tively. Professor Tanner, during his course of local lectures, will treat of the astronomy of the ancients, the astronomy of the sixteenth and seven- teenth centuries, and modern astronomy. It is intended, if a sufficient number join, to form classes, and to have examinations at the end of the course. The professor was assisted in his lecture by lime-light illustrations.

docs.full_text: DEATH OF AN ASTRONOMER. Professor John Couch Adams, Lowndean Pro- fessor of Astronomy at Cambridge, died on Thursday at the Observatory there, after a long iiln?ss. The late professor was bora at Bodmin. Cornwall, in 1818, and was senior wrangler in 1843. In 1845 he discovered the existence of the planet Neptune by observations of the perturha- tions of Uranus, the same discovery being made almost simultaneously by M. Leverrier, a French astronomer. In 1858 he succeeded Dean Pencocke as Lowndean Professor of Astronomy, which office he has held ever since.

Astronomy has gained largely in popu- larity by Sir Robert Ball's talks to the people. docs.full_text: ASTRONOMERS' FATE. The Christmas course of illustrated lerturefe for juveniles at the Royal Institution wa& opened on Saturday by Sir David Gill. Sir David, who 9poke of Astronomy to tha Time of Newton," said that the Chinese claimed that there were talented aatronomers among them 4,000 years before Christ, They claime<y that even at that time their astrono- mers could predict eclipses, because they bad noticed that every 13 years eclipses occurred in the same order. Two thousand years JJ*C. they established a great observatory and ap- pointed a tribunal of astronomers, and history recorded that two astronomers were put tc» death for not predicting tin eclipse which cm off. Greek historians put down the origin of astronomy to the Chaldeans or Egyptians.

docs.full_text: No branch of science encourages specula- tion more than Astronomy. There is so much to learn, so little known, whilst the simplest child with its questionings may puzzle and confound the wisest. The most tantalising and also the most profoundly impressive of studies, Astronomy leads to many ques- tionings and fanciful jests. Life in other worlds was the subject under dis- cussion at the first meeting of the winter session of the Astronomical Society of Wales, at which it was declared that model science had arrived at the conclusion that the case was not proven." There isao knowledge that life such as ours exists in any other part of the solar system, but in the systems beyond, so vast and innumerable, what'? Here is room for speculation rather than discussion, for nothing is known and there is an ample field for fanciful opinion which, waking or dreaming, the human mind fails to do justice to.

Since the discovery of the fact that the axial position of many ancient temples was fixed by orientation in reference to the rise either of the 3an or of some prominent star, astronomers and those interested in astronomy seem to have been unable to regard them in any other light than as astronomical instiuments Even if primitive man were more stupid than the birds and beasts, and had no sense in himself of the change from winter to spring, and from cold to warm weather, a set of stakes set up would have answered the purpose of observing the sunrise just as well as these enormous stones- or better and the Builder" is disposed to think that pre-his- toric men had more common aense than some modern savants.

docs.full_text: HOLT AND FARNDON. ASTRONOMY.—A very intatructive lecture on this subject was delivered by Mr F. Fox, Mount Alyn, Rossett, at the Endowed Schools, Holt, on Friday night. After a few words of introduction by the Vicar of Holt, who presided, Mr Fox proceeded to explain the solar system, the transit of Venu*, &c., and by means uf the lamp and canvas he was able to elucidate his subject, 89 that those who were pI eviously unacquainted with astronomy were able to appreciate his observations. There was a large audience. 1 he body of the room was free. and a small charge was made for the reserved lIeat. Hearty thanks were arc >rded Mr Fox, moved and seconded by the Vicar uf Farudon and Mr J. T. Sheppard.

docs.full_text: Barry Astronomical Lecture Major-General H. H. Lee, R.E., J.P., on Tues. day evening, under the auspices of the Barry Astronomical Society, delivered a public lecture on Astronomy. Dr Percy Billups, F.R.A.S., pre- sided, and paid a high tribute to the keen intereac which the General took in matters astronomical. The lecture was exceedingly interesting and listened to with rapt attention—a fine feature being the lantern illustrations and the spectro- scopical experiments, in the latter branch of which the General is admittedly an expert. The great value of the spectroscope in the study of astronomy was lucidly explained by the gallant general, who was accorded a hearty vote of thanks at the cl

I may add that about 50 ladies and gentlemen, "froni Caergybi to Caerdydd," have already given in their names. All who take an interest in astronomy, whether they possess telescope* or not. are welcome.—I am. &c., ARTHUR MBE, F.R.A.S. 41, Hamilton-street, Cardiff.

docs.full_text: AN ASTRONOMICAL TRUST. I Quite the latest trust is in the realm of astronomy, if not of the air. Professor E. C. Pickering, of Harvard University, is projecting a combination of all the observatories in the world, so that their capital can be combined into one trust. The astronomy industry, according to Professor (Pickering, has a capital of 10,000,000dols. and enormous incomes1. There are observatories with too many men at work, and there are some with too few. There are also places with big funds at their command and some needing money. The new trust proposes to combine the funds', and to distribute them economically, and see that the full value of the money is received. The pro- posed combination is international in character, and provides for all countries. According to the plan, Havard College would be the custodian of the funds, and would be the custodian of the funds, and would see to the distribution of the funds. .————————————

docs.full_text: TELESCOPIC JOKES With a verdict for an injunction a.nd 40s. damages, Mr. Harry Tate, the well-known music-hall comedian, won an action before Mr. Justice Phillimore yesterday. The great question revolved around the alleged similarity between Astronomy," the author of which, Mr. William Fullbrook, was the defendant, and .Motoring," by Mr. Ha,rry Tate, the contention being that Astronomy" was a crib from Motoring." His Lordship first of all took an important step by disallowing the contention that sketches of this kind -were not within the law. Mr. FuHbrook's defence was that he had not copied Mr. Tate's sketch. He admitted that he had made up like Mr. Tate, but he had stated that he would give them an imitation of Mr. Tate. Most Of his jokes depended on a telescope.

The great question revolved around the I alleged similarity between "Astronomy", the author of which, Mr. Williaan FuUbrook, was the defendant, and Motoring, by Mr. j Harry Tate, the contention being that Astronomy was a crib from Motoring." His Lordship first of all took an important step by disallowing the contention that sketches of this kind were not within the law. Mr. Fullbrook's defence was that he had not copied Mr. Tate's sketch. He admitted that he had made up like Mr. Tate, but he had stated that he would give them an imitation of Mr. Tate. Most of his jokes depended on a telescope.

docs.full_text: AN ASTRONOMICAL TRUST. I Quite the latest trust is in the realm of astronomy, if not of the air. Professor E. C. Pickering, of Harvard University, is projecting a combination of all the observatories in the world, so that their capital can be combined into one trust. The astronomy industry, according to Professor Pickering, has a capital of 10,000,000dols. and enormous incomes. There are observatories with too many men at work, and there are some with too few. There are also places with big funds at their command and some needing money. The new trust proposes to combine the funds, and to distribute "them economically, that the full value of the money is received. The pro- posed combination is international in character, and provides for all countries. According to the plan, Harvard College would-be the custodian of the funds, and would see to the distribution of the money.

docs.full_text: EVENING LECTURE8 AND CLASSES AT THE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE, CARDIFF. We draw the attention of our readers to the fact that the evening lectures at the University College have again commenced. The first of the courses of lectures was delivered on Tuesday night. The lectures this term are in the following subjects :— Greek, Latin, English History, Graphic Statics, Astronomy, Geometrical Optics, Hydrostatics, Hydraulics, Elementary Chemistry, Anatomy, Welsh, French, and Music.

docs.full_text: BRITISH ASTRONOMICAL. ASSOCIATION. The annual general meeting of the above-named society has been held at Barnard's Inn, High Holbom, London, Captain Noble, lr.R.A^- (the president), in the chair, The total number of mem- bers now amounts to over 700 (including some half-dozen or more in the Principality), and it may be mentioned that ladies are eligible for election as members. The membership of the B.A.A., which in the short space of two years has taken its place as the leading amateur society, and has already done most useful and valuable work during the short period of its existence, is open to all persons interested in astronomy. It was founded to cecure the more thorough co- operation of astronomers throughout the country, and at the same time to meet the wishes and requirements of many who, though taking a high interest in astronomy, found themselves precluded by various causes from joining the Royal Astro- nomical Society. It is interesting to note that the present director of the solar section is a lady. Miss Brown, and that two otbers-Miss Gierke, the author of several works on astronomy, and Miss Evsritt—nremembei-8 of the council. The methods of the association include the arrangement of members for the work of observation in sections under experienced directors, the publication of a monthly journal, and the holding of Ineetings. not only in London, but also at provincial centres. The annual subscripton ia 10s. 6d„ with an entrance fee of 58. The new president is Mr. H. W. W. Downing, M.A., &c., superintendent of the "Nautical Almannc," and the secretaries are Mr. p. F. Duke, F.R.A.S., Hendon, Middlesex, and Mr. W. Schooling, F.R.A.S., River-court-road, Hammersmith, W. The meetings are held on the tat.t Wednesday in each month from October till June.

docs.full_text: MUSIC HALL ARTISTES. Motoring v. "Astronomy." The action brought by Mr Harry Tate, the well-known music hall comedian, to obtain an injunction restraining Mr Wm. Fullbrook, also a comedian, from continuing to present on the music hall stage a sketch called Astronomy," was before Mr Justice Phillimore on Tuesday. The ground on which the injunction was brought was that defendant's sketch was a crib from Mr Tate's sketch, entitled Motoring," which defendant denied. Mr JusticePhillimorerefused to assent to the contention of defendant's counsel that sketches of this kind were not within the law of copy- right. Defendant, when called to give evidence, ex- plicitly denied having in any way copied plaintiff's piece, and went at some length into the difference both in "business" and dialogue between the two pieces. He stated that Motoring was built up while he was engaged with Mr Tate, and that the suggestion of some of the characters and gags in the sketch originated with him. He admitted that he made up like Mr Tate when presenting his sketch, and told the audience that he would give them an imitation of Mr Tate, but said the resemblance extended no further. Most of the jokes in his piece were dependent on the presence of the telescope, as for instance, where the telescope is pointed towards a win- dow and be explains to the gazer That's Venus." On that an elderly man calls out, That's not Venus that's my wife taking a bath." A number of witnesses associated with the music-hall profession were called, and said that in thi-ir opinion the two sketches were quite distinct. Mr Justice Phillimore, in giving judgment, said he thought defendant had imitated plain- tiff's sketch, and granted an injunction re- straining defendant from performing Astronomy "in such a way as to infringe plaintiff's rights. Judgment was therefore entered for plaintiff for 40s damages and costs.

docs.full_text: Passing Pleasantries. This is the seventeenth time I've seen you in the dock," said a magistrate, looking at a prisoner sternly. Yes, for eight years now I've seen you sitting in the chair, but I've never thought of complaining about it!" replied the prisoner reproachfully. "Have you any letters for me?" inquired an old lady at a village post-office. No letters," replied the post-mistress. "Dearie me!" said the applicant. "I was expecting a letter or postcard from my daughter Martha, to say when she was com- ing. Well. there is a, postcard," said the post- mistress. "Martha is coming next Tuesday!" A traveller, recently returned from India, was giving his impressions. What a country that is!" he exclaimed; There everybody keeps dozens of servants. I bad four whose sole business was to look after my pipe. One brought it to me, another filled it, a third lighted it for me-" And the fourth ?" "The fourth smoked it for me. Tobaco,) never agreed with me!" A famous lawyer once asserted in the presence of several ladies that no woma.n could wrilte a letter without Putt-ing a post- script to it, .1Irs. X., annoyed at this asser- tion, said to the lawyer, My next letter, sir, shall refute you completely." A week after, the man of law received the promised letter, which he found very interesting, but at the foot of it he saw these words, after Mrs. X.'s signature, P.S.-Which is right now, yoa or I?" "My dear," said a gentleman to his young wife, where did all those books on astronomy come from ? They are not ours," "They are—it's a pleasant little surprise for you," responded the lady. You know, my dear, you said this morning that we ought to study astronomy; and so I went to the bookseller's and bought everything on the subject I could get." My dear, responded the husband, with emotion, I never said we must study astronomy. I said we must study economy!"

docs.full_text: DEATH OF AN EMINENT CHEMIST. Berlin, Wednesday.—Professor Robert Wil- belm Bunsen, the eminent chemist, died this morning. Heidelberg at the age of 88. Bunsen's greatest work dates back to 43 years ago, when, with his master, Professor Kirchoff, of Heidelberg) he shared the honour of laying the foundations of spectroscopic astronomy, to which we owe the whole of cur knowledge of the chemical constitution of the sun and stars. Bon- sen also made many other discoveries in ) chemistry, among them the charcoal pile which bears &is name. Born in 1811, he had a long and brilliant University career.

docs.full_text: I DEATH OF AN ASTRONOMER. Professor John Couch Adams, Lowndean Pro- fessor of A-stronomy at Cambridge, died on Thursday at the Observatory there, after a long I illness. The late professor was born at Bodmin, Cornwall, in 1313, and was senior wrangler in 1843. In 1345 he discovered the existence of the planet Neptune by observations of tho perturba- tions of Uranus, the same discovery being made almost simultaneously by M. Leverrier, a French astronomer. In 1858 ho succeeded Dean Peacocks I as Lowndean Professor of Astronomy, which > office he has held ever since. < 1

docs.full_text: I SERIOUS FIRE AT EDINBURGH. I Narrow Escapes, I I ASTRONOMICAL WORKS DESTROYED. I A fire broke out early this morning in a bou-e in Royal-terrace, Edinburgh, occupied by Mr Ralph Copeland, professor of astronomy at Edinburgh University, and Astronomer Royal of Scotland, and Mr Copeland and lus family had to escape by means of a ladder made of blankets and sheets. Much damage was done to the bouse, and tho valuable collection of astronomical works, bequeathed to the nation by the late Earl of Crawford, was slightly injured by water be- fore they could be removed from the burning premises.

docs.full_text: VAN, LLANIDLOES LECTURE.-The 1878-79 season of The Young Men's Improvement Class" was brought to a close on Tuesday, the 8th April, when Mr. A. Williams, Greenfield Villa, delivered a very interesting and instructive lecture on "Astronomy." The chair was taken by the Rev. P. Jones, Lanidloes. To illustrate his lecture, the lecturer showed some astronomical diagrams by the means of the oxy-hydroged lantern. Before the close of the meeting he also showed a few familiar objects common to every-day life, by means of the oxy-hydrogen microscope; and illustrated the chemical decomposition of water. Hearty votes of thanks to the lecturer and chairman brought the meeting to a close.

docs.full_text: GYFFYLLIOG. LANTERN LECTURE ON "ASTRONOMY." On Saturday last the Rev Silas Evans gave a Magic Latern Lecture on the Solar System and a peep into Star-land." Some 60 beautiful slides were exhibited including some half-a-dozen mechanical ones showing the orbits of the various bodies, the revolution of the earth around the sun, and the moon round the earth, ending with a large slide showing the orbits and motions of all the planets together. Comets, meteors, star clusters, and nebulae were also shown and explained; also eclipses and transits. Votes of thanks were were passed to the lecurer, proposed by Mr Davies, and seconded by Mr Bumby.

The lecturer, Mr. A. Taylor, H.M. Inspector of Schools, is well-known in the educational world, and has been a fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society foe the last twenty years. Mr. Taylor is acknowledged to be an authority on the spectrasoope, and has recently returned from America and South Africa, where he has superintended the laying of a couple of the largest telescopes in the world. An interesting evening is promised on Tuesday.

A fire broke out early on Tuesday morning in a house in Royal-terrace, Edinburgh, occupied by Mr Ralph Copeland, professor of astronomy at Edinbmgh University, and Astronomer Royal of Scotland, and Mr Copeland and his family had to escape by means of a ladder made of blankets and sheets. Much damage was done to tho house, and the valuable collection of astronomical works, bequeathed to the nation by the late Earl cf Crawford, was slightly injured by water be- fore they could be removed from the burning premises.

docs.full_text: DEATH OF PROFESSOR GRANT. T The death is announced of Mr Robert Grant, IjIj.u., .P.K.S., Professor of Practical Astronomy at Glasgow University. He was born in 1814, and was educated at King's College. Aberdeen, London, and Paris. During his reaidence in the latter city he attended the lectures of Arago at tho Paris Observatory, and also the lectures delivered by Le Terrier and other distinguished men of science at the Sorbonne. Dr Grant earlv acquired proficiency in the Greek, Latin, French", and Italian languages, and likewise in mathe- matics. Returning to England in 1847, he de- voted five years to the completion of an elaborate work which had long occupied his atten- tion viz. "History of Physical Astronomy. Published in 1852, it imme- diately gave its author a high scientific standing. In load he acquired experience in astronomical observation by a residence of some months at the Roya! Observatory, Greenwich and in 1859— upon the death of Professor J. P. Nichol-lie was appointed by the Crown Professor cf Astronomy in wn"OW University. He proceeded to Spain in 1860, as one of the astronomers of the Himalaya Expedition, to observe the total eclipse of the sun. which occurred on July 18th in that year. On this occasion ho had the satisfaction of Jbtain- m a good observation of the scarlet sierra indi- cative of a continuous envelope encompassing the sun-of which he was the first to announce the existence in his History of Physical Astronomy," having been led to that conclusion by an indiic- tive inquiry based upon a discussion of all the eclipses of the sun recorded in history. ID 1883 he published a catalogue containing the mean places of 6,4-15 stars, chiefly teleseopic, deduced from observations made nnder h s direction at the Glasgow University Observatory from 1860 to 1881. This catalogue has been extensively used by astronomers in connection with extra- meridional observations of comets and minor planets. Professor Grant was for some years president of the Philosophical Society of Glasgow.

docs.full_text: IN MEMORY OF A GREAT ASTRONOMER. Sir Robert Ball, F.R.S., Lowndes Professor of Astronomy at Cambridge University, unveiled a memorial tablet at Bath on Saturday on the house where Sir William Herschel discovered the planet Uranus. That event took place in the year 1781. Herschel communicated the tidings of his discovery to George III., and proposed to call the planet the Georgium Sidus, but the general body of astronomers preferred a classical name in keeping with the rest of the planetary nomenclature. Herschel as an observer has never been surpassed. The existence of binary stars, and the definite ascertainment of the revolution of Saturn's rings were among his achieve- ments.

Hole, of Cardiff (who, it will be remembered, sent us an interesting account of the last great solar eclipse) writes from San Francisco, having just arrived from the Lick Observatory, where he has interviewed Professor Schaeberle, head of the United States Eclipse Expedition- Mr. Hole says the photographs obtained of the phenomenon number 57 in all, and ten of these embody the finest results ever secured in this department of astronomy. Our corre- spondent is full of praise of Professor Schaeberle, whose theory of the corona, he says, is fully confirmed. He also writes enthusiastically of the Lick Observatory. Mr. Hole intends returning home via British North America.

docs.full_text: "OBSERVATIONAL ASTRO- NOMY," Ot Observational Astronomy" is the title of a book which will prove interesting, not only to the amateur telescopist, but to readers generally. It is just the book for a beginner, containing, as it does, a quantity of matter seldom, if ever, found in ordi- nary astronomical works. It is an attempt to pro- vide an inexpensive treatise which, while forming a stepping-stone to a practical acquaint mcewith the scenery of the heavens, gives, in simple terms, the results achieved by the latest research in those de- partments most, affected by the amateur. To this end Mr. Mee, an eminently safe guide we may say, has treated the subject unconventionally, and mathematics are eschewed, the author occupying himself chiefly with describing the aspect and physical condition of the orbs about us. Conciseness and accuracy have been the aim throughout, and the numerous refe- rences to other sources of infermhtion cannot but increase the usefulness of a little volume which, when read in connection with a good elementary tixt-book, will lay open the way for the student to become familiar with a more purely scientific treatment of astronomy as a whole. The author's style has considerable chnrm, and his presentation of his subject shows a clear conception of what is likely to be tppreciated, while, for the book itself, much has been done in the way of appearance, some of the numerous illustrations being remarkably good. It may alflO be mentioned that the work includes a memoir of the late Prebendary Webb, who did so much for observational astronomy. The notice is the fullest and best extant, and will nave especial interest for Welsh readers generally, because Mr. Webb lived and died at Hay, and to Cardiff readers in particular, because his father was once Vic <r of St. John's. In the preparation of his useful little work, Mr. Mee has had the advantage of being assisted by some of the best authorities living and a fact of no small impor- tance is that the book has been well printed, and the illustrations are unusually numerous and excellont. "Observational Astronomy: A Book for Beginners.' By Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S. With illustrations. Price 2s. 6d. Messrs. Daniel Owen and Co. (Limited), Cardiff.

docs.full_text: "OBSERVATIONAL ASTRO- NOMY," "Observational Astronomy" is the title of a book which will prove interesting, not only to the amateur telescopist, but to readers generally. It is just the book for a beginner, containing, as it does, a quantity of matter seldom, if ever, found in ordi- nary astronomical works. It is an attempt to pro- vide an inexpensive treatise which, while forming a stepping-stone to a practicalacquaintancewiththe scenery of the heavens, gives, in simple turms, the results achieved by the latest research in those de- partments most affected by the amateur. To this end Mr. Mee, an eminently safe guide we may say, has treated the subject unconventionally, and mathematics are eschewed, the author occupying himself chiefly with describing the aspect and physical condition of the orbs about us. Conciseness and accuracy have been the aim throughout, and the numerous refe- rences to other sources of information cannot but increase the usefulness of a little volume which, when read in connection with a good elementary tixt-book, will lay open the way for the student to become familiar with a more purely scientific treatment of astronomy as a whole. The author's style has considerable charm, and his presentation of his subject shows a clear conception of what is likely to be appreciated, while, for the book itself, much has been done in the way of appearance, some of the numerous illustrations being remarkably good. It may alf-o be mentionod that the work includes a memoir of the late Prebendary Webb, who did so much for observational astronomy. The notice is the fullest and best extant, and will Itave especial interest for Welsh readers generally, because Mr. Webb lived and died at Hay, and to Cardiff renders in particular, because his faiher was once V)C"r of St. John's. In the preparation of his useful little work, Mr. Mee has had the advantage of being assisted by some of the best authorities living and a fact of no small impor- tilnce is that the book has been well printed, and the illusfratiens are unusually numerous and sxcellent. "Observational Astronomy A Book for Beginners.' By Arthur Mee, F.R.A.8. With illustrations. Price 2s. 6d. Messrs. Daniel Owen and Co. (Limited), Cardiff.

docs.full_text: A SCOTCH PROFESSOR'S HOUSE IN FLAMES. Narrow Escapes. A lire broke out early this morning in a house in Royal-terrace, Edinburgh, occupied by Mr. Ralph Copeland, professor of astronomy at the Edinburgh University, and Astronomer Royal of Scotland. Mr. Copeland and his family had to escape by means of a ladder made of blankets and sheets. Much damage was done to the house, and the valuable collection of astronomical works be- queathed to the nation by the late Earl of Craw- ford were slightly injured by water before they could be removed from the burning premises.

docs.full_text: HANDSOME BEQUESTS TO II GLASGOW. Mrs. Isabella Elder, of Glasgow, who died on November 18, by her will left about L125,0001 for charitable purposes. The prinoipaJ. bequests are R50,000 as an endowment'fund to the executive committee of the Cottage Nurses' Training Home at Govan, and £5,000 to the governors of the Glasgow and West of Scotland Technical College, the income of which bequest is to be applied to providing popular lectures on astronomy. The testa- trix also provides for the institution of a fund to be known as The Elder Fund for Indigent Widow Ladies," and she leaves to the Corporation of Glasgow a number of pieces of sculpture and paintings.

docs.full_text: The late Dr. Andrew Common. F.R.S., was one of the many examples of eminent men who are not at all successful on the platform. Like the soldier, ''deeds not words" should be their motto. Dr. Com- mon spent himself and his wealth for the advancement of astronomy. His kind- ness was shown locally on more than one occasion—notably when he sent a fine mirror of his own make to the Cardiff Exhibition. His sudden death is a serious loss alike to mechanical and physical science.

docs.full_text: IS MARS INHABITED P In his fourth lecture to juveniles on "Astronomy Old and New" at the Royal Institution, London, on Saturday, Sir David Gill dealt with the planet Mars. "I have never myself seen the canals which certain astronomers have spoken to having seen," said Sir David, "but granted all that, I fail to see the remotest proof of habitation by man. I do not deny the existence of some kind of animals very different from our- selves, but I sec no proof of the work of any human beings on the enormous scale which has been talked about."

docs.full_text: FIRE GOD'S TRIP TO EARTH In a memorial to the Empress Dowager of China, the Pekin Board of Astronomy (says the "Pekin and Tientsin Times") declared that there were no revolutionaries in the city, but that the recent epidemic of fires was caused entirely by the visit of the god of fire to earth from heaven. The board reported that the god of fire would be on earth for 100 days, and that the Government need not pay any attention, to the occurrences, which would certainly cease when the god returned to heaven.

docs.full_text: IS MARS INHABITED ? In his fonrth lecture to juveniles on "Astronomy Old and New" at the Royal Institution, London, on Saturday, Sir David Gill dealt with the planet Mars. "I have never myself seen the canals which certain astronomers have spoken to having seen," said Sir David, "but granted all that, I fail to see the remotest proof of habitation. by man. I do not deny the existence of some kind of animals very different from our- selves, but I see no proof of the work of any human beings on the enormous scale which has been talked about."

docs.full_text: SNAILS AS DELICACIES. One thing which the English visitor to Paris detests, according to a French news- paper, is the edible snail, which is becoming a greater favourite among the Paris gour- mets. Returns show that in 1907 560,000 kilo- grammes of snails passed through the markets in the French capital. A similar quantity wa.s consumed last year, and the returns up to the present indicate that the quant-ity eaten will be still greater. There seem to be fashiions in g-astronomy as well as in millinery, so we learn that the frog is becoming less popular-in fact, few are ea-ten to-day.

docs.full_text: I YOUTHFUL ASTRONOMER Every twenty-four hours the dust of four hundred million meteors falls to the surface of the earth. Many extraordinary and little- known facts such as the above are contained in "The Romance of Modern Astronomy," by Hector Macpherson, jun., one of the latest additions to the Library of Romance," issued by Seeley and Co. Mr. Macpherson, who has already contributed a great deal of expository matter to astronomical science, describes in simple but exact language the wonders of the heavens. He is still a youth as one counts years—his age is 22-but his sound reasoning and intelligible explanations are those of a mature scientist.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMICAL LECTURE. I An interesting lecture on The Birth and Death of World6 was delivered by Mr. Joseph McG&be at the Albert Hall, Swansea, on Saturday evening. The meet- inr» trOfi Ti olrl f 4-h.o. there was a good attendance. The lecture was illus- trated by a number of superb slides of the planets, the moon and other celestial bodies. During the last ten years, said the lec- turer, astronomy h°'-l ogress than any other science. 1" ■ i. 1 dis- covered that there are between 1,0!1(I ind 2.000 million stars. Each of these is sup- posed to be a world like our own world, in their cradles, and in the prime of thejr life. Astronomy traces the development of the star from a thjn. cloud-like matter that gradually cools. In its prime it has a temperature of 3.000 degrees centigrade. Much, more interesting data were given by the lecturer. who outlined the further cooling of the bodies until they Gink to the temperature of the sun, and even- tually cool. Examples of these three phases can be eoen in the moon-a goad world; 'Jupiter, in the intermediate stage; and the sun, in its stage of white heat. When the bodies become absolutely cool they might perhaps fall from their places an$by the impact another world is born. The chair was taken I* Mr. D. J. Morjan.

docs.full_text: DINAS. ENTERTAINMENT.—A pleasant and instructive enter- tainment was provided in the Zoar Chapel for the in- habitants of this place, on Tuesday evening the 20th instant, in the shape of popular lectures on the Holy Land, natural phenomena, and astronomy, illustrated by large and beautiful dissolving views. The views were hired from Mr. Cox, late of Skinner-street, London. The lecture on the Holy Land was delivered by the Eov. H. W. Hughes, Dinas, and those on the phenomena and astronomy, by Mr. J. E. Jones, British School, Dinas. As this entertainment was got up more especially for the benefit of the Sunday Schools, all Sabbath scholars were admitted on the payment of one penny each,—the general price of admission being 3d., and reserved seats 6 J. The attendance was not large, probably from there being anniversary services held at the Independent Chapel on the same evening. As the means of spending a leisure hour in enjoyment as well as instruction are so meagre in this neighbourhood, a treat like the above should be considered a boon, and patronised accordingly. On Wednesday evening a "imilar entertainment was to be given, consisting of a lecture on the Pilgrim's Pro- gress, to be delivered by Mr. H. Hughes, and illustrated in the same manner as on the preceding evening.

docs.full_text: -< A FAMOUS ASTRONOMER. The story of Sir Robert Ball's life is one of de- termination to succeed. He is now 60 years of age, and has been a hani worker since his boy- hood days, yet ha is still an .tivo man. His love of tho stars was first inspired by an American work. The Orbs of the Heaven. When h3 read that book he was a boy in Dublin, being Irish born, and he stayed in Ireland long enough to sit in a Professor's chair and to become I Astronomer Royal. Then, in 1892, he came to England, where he bas sine'* Jived and moved, and had his being at the Observatory at Cam- bridge. People are understanding more and more of astronomy every day, Sir Robert Ball thinks. The greatest development) of the 19th century in astronomy, he believes, is the dis- covery that the elements of the heavens are the sa,me as the elements of the earth. But be is sceptical of Tesla. and his message from Mars. He ia not hopeful, says the King he will be qoite satisfied if the new century brings him a t-leacope which will take him just; a little nearer ¡ heaven,

docs.full_text: A NOTED ASTRONOMER. Professor Copeland was born near Wood. plumpton, Lancashire, in 1837. and in early itfa spent several years in Australia. After study- ing astronomy 0.1 GottineD University be was appointed assistant at the Ruyal Observatory there, andabortl. afterwards he joined the second Arctie expedition, which was the first to winter on the north-east coast of Greenland. On his return Dr. Copeland v.-a ,i appointed Astronomical The Late Prof. Copeland. aeniBtaut to the EZLLI of ltrssg at lisitr Castle, Ireland, and in 1874 he became assistant at the observatory of Trinity College, Dablib, going two years later to Dunecht, Aberdeenshire, as assistant to tbe Earl of Crawford. He was chosen .to observe the transit of Venus in 1874 in Mauritius, and in 1882 iin Jamaica. In 1889 be was appointed Astronomer Royal for Scotland and Professor of Astronomy in the University of Edinburgh. He planned and superintended the erection of the Royal Observatory at Blackford bill, where he died. At various times he had undertaken journeys to Norway, Iudja. and Spain to observe solar eclipses.

docs.full_text: DEATH OF SIR WILLIAM HUGGINS. FAMOUS ASTRONOMER'S CAREER. Sir William Huggins, the eminent astro- nomer, died on Thursday a.t a nuTsing home in London after a day's illness. He was in his eighty-seventh year. Sir William was born in London, and edu- cated at the City of London School. His in- terest in astronomy developed at an early age, and in 1856 he built the private observatory at Tulse Hill from which most of his scien- tific investigations have been directed. Sir William was unquestionably the greatest liv- ing authority on spectroscopic astronomy, to which science the greatest part of his life was devoted. He was ably assisted in his re- searches by his wife, who collaborated with him in the Atlas of Representative Stellar Spectra," published four years ago. It is due to Sir William Huggins's inex- haustible patience and great ingenuity that we have learnt not only the constitution of the most distant stars, but of comets, which he has shown to consist largely of blazing carbon. The astronomer's work met with its reward. He was President of the Royal Astro- nomical Society from 1876-8, President of tha Royal Society from 1900-5, and President of the British Association in 1891. Most of all, however, he prized the fact that he was one of the twelve great Englishmen selected by King Edward as the original members of the Order of Merit.

docs.full_text: THE SUNLIGHT. "As clear as daylight" expresses in ordi- 1I:&ry language a maximum of plainness and obviousness. Nevertheless, daylight is one of Hut most complicated and capriciously vari- able of all natural phenomena, remarks a writer in a contemporary. Almost everybody you meet will tell you that daylight and sun- light are inferewfc mwnoes for the same thing. They think they know that much of astro- nomy, any way. But astronomy does not teach anytfiing of the kind. Astronomy simply telle 118 that the sun in the primary cause or source ef dayiigkt, but it does not say thai daylight and sunlight are identical. In fact, they differ almost as much as do water and wine. But the degree of difference varies. Daylight is a mixture of two kinds of light, andl its quality is ootttiamiiy changing, as everybody who has ever had anything to do with photo- graphy knows. The' proportions of the two kinds of light that make daylight are not tI. same from hour to hour, and hardly from minute to rciaute. lie clear weather, under an open sk-v, with the sun high in the hearens, daylight ia almost entirely sunlight. A white surface exposed to an unobseured sky reoeivee directiy from the sun 85 per cent. of the light thaffe illumines it, and only 15 per oeot. from other parts of the sky dome. docs.full_text: TRICKS OF THE ANCIENT. I The priests of ancient Babylonia and Egypt were able t-o work miracles and pre- dict with accuracy future events, for they had a very considerable knowledge of astronomy, enabling them to forecast eclipses and other happenings in the skies. Where magic tricks were concerned, they had developed elaborate apparatus for just ouch purposes. Most jealously guarded was all knowledge of astronomy, and in this connec- tion it is worth remembering that the ancients .worshipped the sun, moon, and stars as gods. Many think that the famous Tower of Babei. principal among the temples of Babylon, was probably crowned by an astronomical observatory; and there seems to be good reason for believing that the Babylonian priests invented some sort of telescope. Knowledge of the mechanical arts was much more highly developed in ancient time-s than we are accustomed to imagine. The use of steam for power is considered a verv modern invention, yet it was so em- ployed long before Christ was born for operating trick machinery in temples, though only in a small way. In the temples of Greece and 5iome such machinery was an indispensable part of the installation. Re- mains of it sufficiently suggestive have been found in the ruit's of some of them. An early Greek physicist, not a priest, describes in detail the mechanical means by which many feats of sacerdotal magic were accom- plished.

docs.full_text: Penmaenmawr. SUCCESS.—Mr J. E. Phillips, who is at pre- sent serving his articles under Mr W. Parry Jones, at the Medical Hall. successfully passed the preliminary examination of the Pharma- ceutical Society, held in December. TEMPERANCE.—A meeting of the local branch of the Women's Temperance Union was held at the English Presbyterian Church on Tuesday evening. Mrs Phillips, Paradise Crescent, presided over a very fair attend- ance. From the observations made it would appear that the branch is in a very healthy condition. LLOYD GEORGE'S VISTT.-The Right Hon. D. Lloyd George. M.P., was the guest of Col. C. H. Darbishire on Friday evening. The gallant colonel sheltered the "Grand Old Man" many a time in years gone by, and the "Grand Young Man" was no mean successor to the privilege. Lloyd George left on the 11-35 a.m. train on Tuesday for Hale, where he spoke in the evening. ASTRONOMY.—Col. C. H. Darbishire con- tinues to run his free entertainments at the Co-operative Hall on Saturday evenings, and they continue to attract packed houses. Last Saturday night the principal item of the pro- gramme was a singularly interesting lantern lecture on astronomy, given by Mr Caradoc Mills, of Llanrwst. Mr Mills dealt with his subject in a masterly manner, and several of his slides were copies of those used by Sir Robert Ball at Colwyn Bay a week ago.

docs.full_text: A DISTINGUISHED ASTRONOMER. The Rev. Charles Pritchard, D.D., F.R.S., fellow of New College and Saviiian Professor of Astronomy in the University of Oxford, died on Sunday even- ing at his residence in the Keble-road at the age of 85. Dr. Pritchard, who was the oldest professor in the University, was born in 1808, and graduated B.A. in 1830 as fourth wrangler at St. John's College, Cambridge, of which society he was elected fellow. He has written many treatises which have been pub- lished in the Transactions" of the Royal Astro- nomical Society an^ he also wrote the article The Star of the Magi" in the Biblical Dictionary. He was e'ected President of the Royal Astronomical Society in 1866, Hulsean Lecturer at Cambridge in 1867, and Saviiian Professor of Astronomy in this University in 1870. It was at his^urgeat request that the University built the New Observatory in the Parks. In 1880 he was awarded the gold medal of the Royal Astronomical Society for his Uranometria Nova Oxonirnsis," and was elected honorary fellow of St. John's College, Cambridge. In 1380 Professor Pritchard was elected a fellow of New College. He was at the time Headmaster of the Ciaphaui Grammar School, and was Select Preacher at Cambridge in 1869 and 1881, and at Oxford in 1876-77.

docs.full_text: THE LATEST IN ASTRONOMY. IT was the most natural thing-in the worl: for the President of the British Association to select as the subject of his inaugural address the science of astronomy and the rapid progress which it has made within the last twenty or thirty years. The name of Mr WNIXAJTF HTJGGIKS has long been almost a synonym for astronomy and its cognate branches, and the thoroughness and fresh- ness with which he handled the srubject last night only served to prove the great advantage to be derived from having the chair occupied by men famed for their knowledge of some particular branch of, science, and. permitting them to deal in their own way with their favourite study. It was no without some degree of reproach fulness that the distinguished President referred to the fact that his favourite science, had for a long timebeen excluded from the place of honour at the annual meetings of the Association. It-is, now one and thirty years since the late, Lord W ROTTESLEY occupied the-chair, andun. the interval be- tween then and now the whole afield of astronomical study-has been retraversed, re-surveyed, and, so to speak,, du up afresh, and made to-yield treasures, far be-- yond the most daring anticipations- of earlier times. The discoveries of ther, spectroscope, and the recent application of photography have almost revolutionised astronomy. The one has enabled'the observer to form what seemed to be-sound conclusions* as, to the composition of stars, planets, and other celestial bodies, while the photographic machine has afforded ,.suel" accurate pictures of 'the firmament^and^of! the faces of some of: the'nearer^luimnarxes"' uraimries- as to have added very materially to-.the," knowledge previously possessed. The-great; value of a good photograph isdts;perfectiqjif and the facilities which it offers -tot the observer when clouds or brilliant*; arm- shine prevent him from resorting to' the telescope and other instruments.- Not only so, but the photographic lens-sees, as it were, more than the assisted human eye is as yet able to-see. It prints upon the sensitized plate-stars which the most power- ful telescopes have not yet brought within the range of human vision,, so that the astronomer is now able to study the photo- graphs of many bodies of which he has not otherwise been able to catch one glimpse. In short, the spectroscope and the camera have become the gateways, to entirely new fields in the region of astronomy, and the fields which they have opened up are only be- ginning to be surveyed, so that there is: reason to expect that within the next' ten or twenty years other astounding discoveries, will be made. This is all the more remark- able, because, astronomy,- being the oldest of all the sciences, has often beenaupposed to* be the most complete. For centuries, we may' say, nothing was expected from a further study of i than perhaps the occasional dis- covery of some wandering comet or a planetary moon. The earlier astronomers had their own notions as to the composition of the heavenly bodies. Some regarded the sun as a solid body at a hieh temperature throughout others regarded it as a solid body which might be perfectly cool, but surrounded by an atmosphere of fire others, again, imagined it to be mere luminosity without solidity. The stars were generally handed over to the poets to get from them whatever description their unfettered fancy might choose to give them. Comets were taken possession of by some of the more fanciful theologians who deemed them fitting places for the departed spirits of the damned. The modern astronomer has already made, and is not unlikely to make still more, havoc with these strange fancies. The spectro- I p scope has gone far to prove the unity of the universe, or, in other words, to show that all the spheres have emanated from one source, and that they are linked together in one harmonious whole. In the address de- livered last night by Mr HUGGINS there was perhaps less of the poetry of the spheres than his predecessors in the chair would have indulged in. The brilliant bodies which shine in the sky at night are still to a large extent unknown. The most powerful instruments man yet possesses can only carry us a little way into the knowledge of what they are, but what has recently been discovered has, so to speak, brought them a great way nearer us than they were before, and has warranted discussions upon their constitution and their chemical composition in which previous occupants of the chair of the Association would never havedreamtofenter- taining. The great value of the address delivered last night is that it places upon record within short compass the exact position now occupied by the science of astronomy. Those who have not much time to devote to that brilliant study have only to read the address in order to have a tolerably accurate idea of what the astronomer has discovered, and those who take an interest in the science and have made themselves somewhat familiar with the principal discoveries of recent observers will readily unite with the President in the eloquent sentences with which he closed an address of great ability and of considerable beauty. Astronomy," said Mr HOGGINS, "the oldest of the sciences, has more than re- "newed her youth. At no time. in the past "has she been so bright with unbounded aspirations and hopes. Never were her temples so numerous, nor the crowd of her votaries so great. Since the time of NEWTON our knowledge of the phenomena "of nature has wonderfully increased, but man asks, perhaps more earnestly now than in his days, what is the ultimate reality behind the reality of the percep- tions ? Are they only the pebbles of the beaah with which we have been playing ? Does not the ocean of ultimate reality and truth lie beyond 1"

docs.full_text: THE LLANGEFNI SHAKESPEARE SOCIETY. The usual fortnightly meeting of the above society was held at the Cafe on Monday, the 25th of August. The subject chosen for tye evening was Shakespeare as an astronomer, on which an excellent paper was read by Mr Jenkins, the Bank, Llangefni. Mr Thomas, Post Office, was in the chair. Mr Jenkins, after a few preliminary remarks, said that the subject was a novel one, but withal an interesting and a thoroughly substantial One. Shaltepeare's claim to fair astronomical qualifi- cations was far from a pedantic one. On the whole, of course, it would be more accurate and consis- tent with fact to say that his astronomy had more sentimental than scientifi ccolourings. It would not be difficult for him with xis extraordinary powers of receptivity to assimilate the popular astronomy of his time; but astronomy at this period of its development was so hopelessly confused with astrology and superstition that it would be unfair to expect from him thorough accuracy in matters of detail. He was not equipped with the more modem weapons of Differential Calculus and Astronomical apparatus. His sphere in this department corresponded more nearly to that of Miss Herschel, who modestly described her share in the work of her illustrious brother, as "minding the heavens." The music of the spheres" is a very familiar and characteristic conception of the poet. It was probably originated by the great philosopher Pythagoras, that fountain-head of mystical and mathematical lore. It seems that Pythagoras was of a musical turn of mind, at least from a theoretical point of view, and went even so far as to suppose that the motions of the stars were set to music, and that their distances one from the other corresponded to the intervals between the different notes in what is known in music as the diatonic scale. Shakespeare gives expression to this highly poetic idea:— There's not the smallest orb which thou beholdest, But in his motion like an angel sings, Still quivering to the young ey'd cherubim. Shakespeare's universality of knowledge is proverbial. In his essay on Shakespeare, Emerson remarks that" great men are more distinguished by range and extent than by originality." These qualifications are certainly present in Shakepeare. In his biographical sketch, Rossetti witnesses to this "We have in him the technical phraseology of law, medicine, chemistry, navigation, music, necromancy, printing, and astronomy." In this connection he has one passage of special interest and significance: Not from the stars do I my judgment pluck, And yet, methinks, I have astronomy." (Sonnet 14) From the lines which immediately follow, it is quite clear that Shakespeare himself was not a believer in the vagaries of astrology, a science which was generally accepted as true in the dark- ness and ignorance that prevailed in his time. Proceeding, the lecturer gave a graphic and detailed account of the minutiae of Shakespeare's astronomical knowledge, comparing step by step his quasi-poetic observations with the more accurate and scientific knowledge of to-day. One quotation must suffice, one of the best known and most familiar stars is the Pole star. It was the great astronomer Thales that first recommended the use of this star in navigation, and for centuries it has answered every purpose of the mariner. Hence the Pole star became the emblem of constancy. This is evidenced by the following lines, On thine unaltering blaze The half-wrecked mariner, his compass lost, Fixes his steady gaze." And by the proud boast of Caesar in the Senate But I am constant as the northern star." But from a strictly astronomical point of view, the Pole star is not so fixed and unmoveable. In due time it must undergo a considerable change of position, and will be practically useless for pur- poses of navigation. Shakespeare again was fully conscious of the Reign of Law among the celestial bodies :—Troilus and Cressida (Act 1. Scene III). "The heavens themselves, the planets, and this centre Observe degree, priority and place," etc. To the student of astronomy, the references and observations of poets and novelists are more pop- ular and intelligible than accurate and scientific, and most poets are singularly unhappy in their speculations in this direction. Tennyson is an exception to this rule; but the exceptional accuracy of his astronomical ideas must be accounted for by something more than mere chance or coincidence. He must have been a very careful student of that science which provided him with so much inspiration. In conclusion, a most inter- esting and scholarly account was given of the substance of the great poet's references to celestial bodies and phenomena, stars, planets, sun and moon, together with a running criticism of the same in the light of subsequent research. To the poet, the lover, the musician, astronomy is one thing, and perfectly real. To the Astronomer Royal, to enthusiastic scientists, to men of figures, lines, and angles, astronomy is another thing, and equally real.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMY v. ASTROLOGY. Some odd communications are received by Mr Christie, the Astronomer Roya!. on the subject of the studies which engage him in his official capacity. It seems that many persons are still unable to distinguish between astronomy and astrology, a circumstance which is doubtless due to the wide diffusion of such publica- tions as "Old Moore's Almanac." Here is a specimen letter which Mr Christie has communicated to a contributor to Casscll's Saturday Journal. Dear Sir,—Will you kindly rum my planet and send full particulars I was born-. I am sending three stamps, as I do not know your charge. If it is not sufficient, kindly let me know, and I will send the difference." The writer must have been rather surprised at the answer he got to this generous offer. It was as foUows The Astronomer RoyalJ requests me to state that he is not able to rule the planets. Persona who pretend to do so are rogues and vagabonds." Another correspondent has dis- covered a supposititious planet Vulcan which pulled the earth 20,000,000 miles out of its course last January and February another, whose orthography leaves room for improvement, has found out the theory of the universe I" and yet another announces as his own discovery the fact that the earth is a sphere elongated polar. wards.

Mr Williams Quoted many passages of Scripture relating to the heavens, and showed how tbe sacred writers, intelligently road, were in accord with the truths of modern astronomy. A cordial vote of thanks was accorded Mr Williams, on the motion of Mr Mee, who snid Mr Williams had dealt carefully and judiciously with an admittedly difficult subject seconded by Mr Norman Latter, and supported by the presi- dent. Some conversation afterwards took place on the proper motion of Arctnrus, in which Messrs Williams, Geo. A. S Atkinson, G. Southey, and Captain Jutsum tool: part. Mr Atkinson manipulated the lantern.

L: Kichardi ea d fLat Ivlr (Jeorge was an ardent Cym:odor, and had road an intercsing paper at one of th lI1ctlngg. lle was a man who fiLled an important place in the life of the town. Mr- Powell then delivered an inter- esting address on "The History of Astronomy and Welsh Astronomers." He pointed out that astronomy was one of the oldest of sciences, and one reason for that, undoubtedly, was that much of the science could be studied without the aid of any instruments. Many thought otherwise, and were of opinion that a telescope and an obsenratory were required for the study cf astronomy, but that wa" not the case. Much could be done with the eye alone, with some strong common snse behind it (laught?r). This was proved by what the old astronomers had done. Mr. Powell then traced the way in which the constellations had been mapped out, and dealt with early astronomy, traditionally as well as in old historic documents; also the tes- iimonv of the ancient observatories, the PHIL" mids, the heat-hen temples, etc. The constella- tions whicb known to the ancients wero known to people living above 38 degress north latitude. The names given to the con- steliations, too, showed that they were given by those who well knew the lion, the bear, the horse, sheep and goats, the bow and arrow, and the spear, but who did not know the ele- phant, the camel, the tiger, and the crocodile. They were not inhabitants of Europe or Asia, and thus must have been residents of Asia Minor—Armenians—along the banks of the Euphrates. The lecturer dealt with the careful manner in which these ancients traced the cclyptic through the signs of the Zodiac. In this connection he gave some interesting illus- trations of the references to astronomy in the Book of Job, and also dealt with the connection between astronomy and the "Goreedd, as illus- trated by Stonehenge and other stone circles. He then dealt with Welsh astronomers, of I whom he gave brief histories. Robert Recorde (of Tenby) was one of the first to accept the Copernicus theory, who also issued the first arithmetic in English; and Sir William Lower, of Trefcnty, near St. Clears, and his friend, Mr. John Protheroe. Sir William Lower was the first- Welshman to use a. telescope, and I some interesting particulars of his lite were given. John Harris, a brother of Howel Harris of Trevecca, was also a diligent student of astronomy; and so was Nathaniel Piggot, of Llantwit- Major. Reference, too, was mad? to William Norbury, of Merthyr; the Rev. Mr. Webb, Vicar of Cardiff, father of the Rev. T. W. Webb, a renowned astronomer; Admiral Smith, scientific advisor to the late Marquis of Bute; Sir George Everest, or Brecon, and others. Eleazar Roberts, of Liverpool, still happilv alive, also had written a book in Welsh on agronomy. OtK-er living Welshmen were referred to who touk a deep interest in astron- omy, among them being Thomas William Jones (Arfonwyeon), as well as Mr. Edward Roberts, who bad taken a prominent part in the preparation 01 the "N-nV-ical Almanactc" T. E. Heath, Roberta, of Liverpool, and others. The lect/j-er then gave a very inter- esting account of various planets, and the way in which, with the aid of the spectroscope, composition of not merely the planets, but also the fixed stars, had been discovered. Some interesting p&n.iculars of the recent comet and of Hallev'r C.,U,\C,t. brought a very interesting address to a cicm—Al- interesting difcussron followed, in the 'iourse of which the Chairman, Mc65rs. J. Griffiths, E. Thomas, W. R. Wil- liams, R. Williams, and the Rev. J. R. Dewi Williams took part.—On the motion ef Mr. J. Jones. Abornanfc, seconded oy Mr. T. J. Howell, f, oordial vote of thanks was accorded Mr. Powell for his address.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMY IN WALES. The Proposed Society for Wales and Monmoutnshire. docs.full_text: ASTRONOMY IN WALES. The Proposed Society for Wales and Monmoutnshire. A preliminary meeting of friends of this movement was held at Paul's Schoolroom, Neville-street (by kind permission) on Fri- day evening. On account of the inclemency of the weather the attendance was small. Mr. Arthur Mee, F.RA.S., was voted to the chair, and produced a mass of correspondence with persons in various parts of Wales and Mon- mouthshire interested in astronomy, heartily approving of the society and identifying them- selves with the movement. The chairman also reported that the membership was already about 50 strong. The constitution of the society was discussed at much length, and. in the course of the evening, Mr. R. W. Atkin- son, B.Sc.. president of the Cardiff Natura- lists' Society, looked in, and expressed the svmpathy and good wishes of that body. Sub- iect to the approval of the general body of members, Mr. Mee was elected president, and Mr. N. Lattey, Dinas Povvis, secretary and treasurer. A committee was also formed, which will meet shortly to select vice-president, draw up rules, and complete the arrangements, prior to the holding of the first general meet- ing.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMY AT NEWPORT. USKSIDERS ENTHUSIASTIC AND TALK OF A PUBLIC OBSERVATORY. Newport has. from the commencement, been a tower of strength to the Astronomical Society of Wales, and the local members are already preparing a plan of action for the coming winter. One or two observers lr-re telescopes of con- siderable power, which i.hey are cheerfully placing at the disposal of their fellow-students, and in some enthusiastic quarters a public observatory is talked of! On Wednesday even- ing there was a good attendance of members and the general public at the Town-hall to hear an address from the president of the ''parent" society on "Lunar charting and delineation." The Hev. Arthur J. Jenkins (vice-president), who has worked most earnestly for the furtherance of the Newport branch, was in the chair, and spoke of the progress astronomy was making in Wales and Monmouthshire. Mr. Arthur Mee then delivered his address, which was illustrated by maps and photographs, including fine speci- mens from the Mount Hamilton and Paris ob- servatories, and the admired enlargements of Professor Dr. Weinek, Monsieur Prinz, and Herr Jvrieger, which were afterwards carefully inspected by the audience. A vote of thanks to the lecturer, m.ved by the chairman, seconded a at F" White and a similar compliment to Mr. Jenkins, closed the proceedings.

The lecture was the second of a series on ''Recent Progress in Planetary Astronomy." and dealt in an able and lucid manner with Mars, tlvt planetoids, and the giant planet Jupiter. Saturn and the planets exterior to him were included in the syllabus, but it is to be hoped Mr. Wiiitmeil wiH on a future occasion describe them as pleasantly as he did the ones abovE- mentioned. Mir. Whitrnell does not. like some lecturers, content himself with a mere popular rechauffe, the result of a skimming of two or three text-books: but displays his own most exact and intimate acquaintance with his subject, and leaves his audience with matter on which to ponder at their leisure. His lecture on Thursdav night was further elucidated by an excellent series of lantern views and* a number of I models from the Higher Grade School: the lantern being manipulated by Mr. James Waugh, M.A., and Banting.—At the close a cordial vote of thanks was accorded ) Mr. Whitmell. on the motion of Dr. Vache'l, seconded by Mr. T. H. Thomas and sup- ported by the Chairman. There was a laroe and appreciative audience, and the societt continues to exhibit most satisfactory 8'jgns of progress. c

docs.full_text: TRANSIT OF MERCURY. The Rare Phenomenon Visible in Wale This Afternoon. Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S.. writes:—That somewhat rare phenomenon, a transit of Mer- cury, took place this afternoon, commencing a few minutes before four o'clock, unfortunately near to sunset. With an opera-glass or non- inverting telescope (protected, of course, by a darkened glass) Mercury was noted as a tiny black dot just inside the left edge of the sun, and a third of the way from top to bottom. I shall be glad, as I mentioned in my astronomical notes of Tues- day. to correspond with any persons interested in astronomy who would assist, in the formation of a working sooiety at Cardiff. Several friends have already expressed to me their interest in such a movement, and we have a number of gentlemen here identified either with the Royal Astronomical Society or the Uritish Astronomical Association, whilst the n'imber of the general public interested more or less in the soience must be large, judging' from the continuous run that exists on the astrono- mical works at the Cardiff Free Library. Let it not be thought that only those having tele- scopes would be eligible: such a society as I have named would welcome all having an inte- rest in astronomy, no matter what their instru- n ental means.
docs.useguidelines_cy: Nid yw statws neu berchnogaeth hawlfraint yr adnodd hwn yn hysbys.

docs.full_text: STUDYING THE SKIES. MR. WHITMELL TALKS OF PRO- GRESS IN ASTRONOMY. The usual meeting of the Cardiff Naturalists' Society was held at. the Oueeu-strtet-hall on Thursday evening. Mr. R. W. Atkinson, B.Sc. (the president), occupied the chair, and there was a, good attendance. Mr. Charles T. Whitmell, M.A., read a paper on "Recent Progress in Astronomy, illustrated with a series of excellent lantern slides and lunar photographs. Mr. Whitmell dealt ably and comprehensively with the condition of Mer- cury, Venus. and the Moon, also referring in all interesting manner to some problems con- nected with our own earth as a planet. At the close of the pappr. a cordial vote of thanks was accorded Mr. Whitmell, on the motion of the Chairma.n. seconded bv Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S.—Mr. E. Seward. F.R.I.B.A., then read a lucid report as delegate to the corresponding societies committee of the British Association.—On the motion of the Chairman, a hearty vote of thanks was accorded Mr. Seward, and the meeting closed. _n_

docs.full_text: Astronomicai Society of Wales. The adjourned annual meeting was held last evening at the Y.M.C.A.. Station-terrace, Cardiff. Mr. Norman Lattey. the president- elect. in the chair. The report, and accounts for the year were presented. From the latter it appeared there were 135 members, many living in England, and two so far away as India. Seven candidates for membership were adopted. The proposal of a life subscrip- tion was discussed, and, on the motion of the Rev. W. E. Winks. F.R.A.S.. it was decided to submit, Fame to the general body of members. Various questions were gone into. including the purchase of a lantern. A most able paper, read by Mr. Arthur Mee. was contributed b' Mr. W. E. Plummcr, F.R.A.S.. director of the Bidston Observatory, on the subject of astronomy as a popular pursuit. Mr. Plummer dealt with the theme in a lucid and masterly manner, making as a special feature the I encouragement of those who have a desire to observe yet, possess no instruments. The paper was listened to with deep attention, and at, the close, on the motion of Mr. Winks. seconded by tb: president, a. hearlry vote of I thanks was accorded Mr. Plummer. On account- of the lateness of the hour the president's address was deferred. At the next meeting an address will be given by Mr. A. Taylor. H.M.I.S., entitled "Recent Research in Spec- troscopic Astronomy."

docs.full_text: I COMEDIAN AGAINST COMEDIAN I Harry Tate Accuses Another of 'Cribbing' Harry Tate, a well-known comedian, sought an injunction from Mr. Justice Philli- more in the High Court yesterday to restrain William Fullbrook, also a comedian, from continuing to produce a sketch called "Astronomy," on the ground that it was an infringement of the copyright of the plaintiff s sketch entitled Motoring." Harry Tate said that, although a property motor was the principal object in his sketch, and a telescope the principal object in that of the defendant, the characters and business" in the latter were obviously "erdbbc-d" from his piece. At one time defendant worked with him, and he was with him when he was producing Motoring." Having heard the defendant was producing this piece, "Astronomy," and that it had a singular resemblance to Motoring," he went to see it at the Hollo- way Empire on the 31st of March last, and a.t the conclusion of the p4erformanee requested defendant to cease its production, as it was an infringement of his right. Mr. Walter Pink, who wrote the book of Motoring," also gave evidence to the effect that the pieces were practically iden- tical. Bid you," asked Mr. Hohler in cross- examination, "laugh at any part our our piece?" No," returned witness emphatically, "I was too much annoyed. I swore." The case was adjourned.

docs.full_text: "OBSERVATIONAL ASTRO- NOMY," "Observational Astronomy" is the title of a book which will prove interesting, not only to the amateur telescopist, but to readers generally. It is just the book for a beginner, containing, as it does, a quantity of matter seldom, if ever, found in ordi- nary astronomical works. It is an attempt to pro- vide an inexpensive treatise which, while forming a siepping-stone to a pructicalacquaii.tincewitlithe scenery of the heavens, give-. in simple terms, the results achieved by the latest research in thosH de- partments most affected by the amateur. To this end Mr. Mee, an eminently safe guide we m:iy say, has treated the subject unconventionally, and mathematics are eschewed, the author occupying himself chiefly with describing the aspect and physical condition of the orbs about Uti, Conciseness and accuracy have been the aim throughout, and the numerous refe- rences to other sources of information cannot but increase tho usefulness of a little volume which, when road in connection with a good elerneutary t-xt-boolf, will lay open the way for the student to become familiar with a more purely scientific treatment of astronomy -is a whole. The author's style has considerable Charm, and his presentation of his subj ct shows a clear conception of what is likely to be appreciated, while, for the book itself, much has teen done in the way of appearance, soma of the numerous illustrations being remarkably good. It may aLo be mentioned that the work includes a memoir of the late Prebondary Webb, who did so much for observational astronomy. The notice ia the fullest and best extant, and will have especial interest for Welsh readers generally, bocause Mr. Webb lived and died at Hay, and to Cardiff readers in particular, because his father was once Vic ir of St. John's. In the preparation of his useful little work, Mr. Mee has had the advantage of boing assisted by some of tha best authorities living and a fact, of no small impor- tunes is that tho book has been wall printed, and the illustrations are unusually numerous and excellent.

docs.full_text: MR. POPHAM'S VERY POPULAR LECTURE ON ASTRONOMY. On Wednesday evening the above gentleman, whose know- ledge of the sublime science of Astronomy is profound and scientific; and whose mode of communicating such know- ledge is peculiarly facile and popular, delivered a lecture on Creation, illustrated by a panoramic view of the heavens, at the great room of the Town llall; on which occasion it was creditable to the"taste of the town, to find an overflowing audience. It is gratifying to find that a study of all others so well calculated to elevate the imagination and exalt the mind, and to reward with demonstrative information as to the wonders of nature, has so many admirers amongst us; and we are quite sure that if men of genius and inventive faculty who could display and explain the wonderous harmony and mys- terious fitness of the celestial machinery, as indicatin" the sovereign economy ot the great Creator—-Astronomy avou 1 d be a subject of still more general cultivation even among the humbler classes of society. ° The illustrations of Mr. Popham, executed in the highest style of art, and worked upon philosophical principles, convey such clear proofs of astronomical principle to the humblest capacity, as is calculated to make a lastiug impression on the memory. The leading phenomena of the solar system the doctrine of the seasons—the planets and their diilerent satellites—the cause of eclipses—cause of light and heat, &c. &c, are all most familiarly, and indeed, beautifully explained and illus- trated by ingenious diagrams, nearly all the features of which met with a very cheering reception on the part of the n udience. The magnificent planetarium at the close attracting the wondering ga/.e of the entire company. Os homini sublime dedit coduni qne tueri." The astronomical entertainment of the evening was fol- lowed by a charming series of dissolving (lioi-aiiit of sacred, classical, and artistic scenery, some ot which were indeed exquisitely beautiful,—for instance, the Chapel of the Holy Cross—the Uuins/>f Balbec—the Ship on Eire—Shakspere s House &c.,—the effects of light and shade being really won- derful The whole concluded with the wonders of the Chrouiatrope, which sent the audience away in a high tone °f\V^understand Mr. Popham and his coadjutor artists are on a rapid tour through the principality.

docs.full_text: Oxford University Extension Lectures. Those who attended the course of University Extension Lectures on Astronomy last spring -will be glad to learn that the local Committee I have arranged for a course of six lectures on 1 Physical Geology" to be delivered by the Rev. E. C. Spicer, M.A., P.G.S. (New College, Oxford), commencing on Monday, January xoth. As there may be some doubt as to what Physical Geology" really is, it may be of guidance if we give the subject of the lecture as set out in the syllabus. Lecture I. deals with The Earth's Crust Lecture II., Earth movements Lecture III., Earthquakes and volcanoes" Lecture IV., "The work of water Lecture V., The work of ice Lecture VI., Scenery." The lectures (which will be illustrated) should attract large numbers, and will, we hope, be as great a success as the astronomy lectures. The following reports on the Astronomy Lectures and on the examination held at the close of the lectures, have been received by the Local Committee:- Lecturer's Report: It is satisfactory to find that the University Extension Lectures have met with so good a response after being- dis- continued for some years. The interest aroused was clearly shown not only by the numbers present at the lectures but also by those who stayed to the class. Six students sent in some good work regularly, and one of them made excellent use of a telescope in sketching lunar formations, while another made a telescope for himself. Those who organised the course may feel confident that they may embark on another next year with every prospect of success; especially if they emphasize the fact that the lectures do not by any means exhaust the whole opportunities offered the exceptional chance of personal guidance from an expert is probably of greater value than the lecture."—J. A. Hard- castle. F.R.A.S. Examiner's Report: A good set of papers. All the questions (except number 6, the easiness of which was perhaps misleading) were answered well by at least one candidate, including the harder ones at the end. The candidates have made a real acquaintance with the sky, which should be a permanent possession, and I was glad to find them ready to discuss such matters as the Daylight Saving Bill."—H. H. Turner, New College. The successful candidates were Evelyn D. Graham, Winifred K. Graham, Frank L. Raw- lins, Winfred Rose and Evelyn M. Whitehead. + —

docs.full_text: NOTES AND COMMENTS. THE establishment of an Astronomical Society for Wales is one of the signs of the times. We wish the society every success. Our ancestors were famed for their skill in astrology. They had names of their own for the principal stars and con- stellations. To them the Milky Way was Caer Gwydion, and the Cassiopea constellation was Llys Don. The old Welsh name for the Corona Borealis was Caer Arianrod, while the rainbow was called Bwa Arianrod. In recent times Wales has not contributed much to the science of Astronomy. There are a few names, however, which deserve to be mentioned. Far and away the most important is that of Arfonwyson, a young man from the hills of Eryri, who worked his way up to the second post in the Greenwich Observatory. His promising career was cut short by death in his iJoth year. Had he lived he would undoubtedly have attained to great eminence in the world of Astronomy. Dr. Rees (Gwilym Hiraethog) had paid considerable attention to this sciencs, and his lecture on it was at one time enormously popular. There are two Welshmen now living who enjoy a high reputation as astronomers. One of them is Dr. Isaac Roberts, a retired Liverpool merchant. He is a native of Holywell in Flintshire, but now, for climatic reasons, has taken up his residence in the South of England. The other is Mr. Kleazar Roberts, who for many years acted as chief clerk in one of the Liv erpool police-courts. He has written much on Astronomy for the Welsh magazines, and was one of the pioneers of the Solfa system ill the Princi- pality. Mr. Jenkins, a native of Cardiganshire, but now a Llangefni banker, is a younger student of the science, and has done much, by means of lectures, to popularise the results of recent research. Mr. Mee, of the Wtxlcrn Mail, who is I at the liCLid of the movement, will find himself supported from many and various quarters, and lie deserves all the success we can wish him. Should not there be also a Geological Society yn ngwlad y brvniau ?" We clothe our hills and valleys with ) a halo of anient patriotism. The time has come to make them the subjects of scientific study. Even from a merely commercial point of view it would be a most desirable thing to initiate our young people into the mysteries of slate and coal forma- tions.
