Wholesale, H. McLaren, Trecynon. LECTURE.—On Monday evening the Rev. Peter Price, B.A., Dowlais, de- livered a lecture on Dr. Barnardo" at Bbenezer Welsh Cong. Chapel. The chair was occupied by Councillor L. N. Williams (Ap Carw Coch), and there was a good attendance. The proceeds were in aid of David Morris, 3, Clive- place, who, owing to illhealth, has been unable to follow his: employmenc for some time. WEDDING.—At 'Siloa Chapel, Aber- dare, on Saturday, January 18, in the presence of the Registrar^ by the Rev. J. Grawys Jones, Mr. Philip Evans, 5, .Harriet-street, and Miss Rachel Anne -Jonee, the second daughter 4 of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Jones, 38, Windsor-street, Trecynon, were united in matrimony. The wedding party and friends were en- tertained to brea,kfa6t at the bride's parents' residence. ASTRONOMY.—On Saturday evening to a large and highly interested audience, Mr. W. R. Williams, B.Sc., of the Aber- dare County School, gave ail address on 'the above subject at the Public- Hall. Mr. Williams related the story of the heavens in a manner which was under- standable, entertaining, and instructive. He took. his audience on an imaginary lunar trip and showed by means of ex- cellent lantern slides, the wonderful craters and the tall mountains of the liiooii. A journey to Mars was equally interesting. Mr. Williams dealt briefly with the hypotheses concerning' the geo- graphy and population of the sister planet—whether it was irrigated by means of canals, and whether it was in- habited by numan beings. The lecturer strongly advised his hearers to take up the study -of astronomy. They would -find-it an agreeable pastime and an in- teresting pursuit. Mr. Edgar Palmer was the lantern manipulator. On the T motion of Mr Henry_J<W M.E., Dyllae, seconded by Mr H- H- Evans, M.E., Bwllfa Mr. Williams was accorded the thanks' of a delighted audience, Mr. Williams, responding, moved a vote of thanks to the chairman, Mr Morgan Morgan, who is himself an enthusiastic student of astronomy. Mr. J. Prcwle seconded the vote, which was carried.

docs.full_text: "OBSERVATIONAL ASTRO- NOMY," a Observational Astronomy" is the title of a book which will prove interesting, not only to the amateur telescopist, but to readers generally. It is just the-book for a beginner, containing, as it does, a quantity of matter seldom, if ever, found in ordi- nary astronomlca.) works. It is an attempt to pro- vide an inexpensive treatise which, while forming a stepping-stone to a practical acquaint nice with the scenery of the heavens, gives, in simple turms, the results achieved by the latest research in those de- partments most, affected by the amateur. To this end Mr. Mee, an eminently safe guide we may say, has treated the subject unconventionally, and mathematics are esqhewea, the author occupying himself chiefly with describing the aspect and physical condition of the orbs about, us. Conciseness and accuracy have been the aim throughout, and the numerous refe- rences to other sources of information cannot but increase the usefulness of a little volume which, when read in connection with a good elementary tixt-book, will lay open the way for the student to become familiar with a more purely scientific treatment of astronomv as a whole. The author's style has considerable charm, and his presentation of his subject shows a clear conception of what is likely to be appreciated, while, for the book itself, much has teen done in the way of appearance, some of the numerous illustrations being remarkably good. It may al,o be mentioned that the work includes a memoir of the late Prebendary Webb, who did so much for observational astronomy. The notice is the fullest and best extant, and will nave especial interest for Welsh readers generally, because Mr. Webb lived and died at Hay, and to Cardiff readers in particular, because his father was once Vicir of St. John's. In the preparation of his useful little work, Mr. Mee has had the advantage of being aasieited by some of the best authorities living and IL fact of no small impor- tance is that the book has been well printed, and the illustrations are unusually numerous and excellont. I "Observational Astronomy: A Book for Beginners.' By Arthur Mee, F.K.A.8. VVilh illustrations. Price 2a. 6d. Messrs. Daniel Owen and Co. (Limited), Cardiff.

docs.full_text: STAR (xAZ±jJtiS IN SESSION. X ey Hear Mr. Whitmell Expound the Latest Planetary Discoveries. The monthly meeting of the Astronomical Society of Wales took place at the University College, Cardiff, on Friday evening, and was tile best attended and most interesting that has been held since the formation of the society. The president (Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S.) occupied the chair. After the reading of the minutes, a number of candidates for mem- bership were elected, bringing the roll of the society up to about 120. A number of per- sons were also proposed for membership. It Was decided to defer for the present the engagement of an eminent astronomer to de- liver a lecture at Cardiff. Various donations of books were reported, and Mr. Patterson was appointed custodian of the society's litera- ture. A short notice of Mr. John Jones, Bangor, was read from the pen of Mr. G. P. Jenkins, F.R.A.S. -Air. Jones (known locally a., "John Jones, Seryddwr"}sjs^ £ working man, now four score years old, who taught himself astronomy, and, amongst many other accom- plishments, made himself two large telescopes M: Jenkins's paper will appear in the next number of the society's "Journal." Obser- vations of the recent solar and lunar eclipses and of the remarkable aurora were reported, and an interesting discussion ensued, in which Professor Lloyd Tanner, F.R.A.S.. the secre- tary (Mr. Lattey), and others took part. Mr. Chas. T. Whitmell, M.A.. was then called upon to read a paper on "Recent Progress in Planetary Astronomy," which was delivered with lantern illustrations. Mr. Whitmell dealt specially with Mercury, Venus, the Earth, the Moon. and Mars.-The President, in inviting discussion, said he had never listened to a paper more closely packed with interesting and suT~estive points. It was a. veritable intellectual and astronomical treat. —Professor Tanner moved a vote of thanks to Mr. Whitmell, dealing lucidly with several points mentioned in the paper.—The Rev. G. St. Clair seconded in a thoughtful speech, and the Rev. Arthur J. Jenkins (Newport) and Mr. Powell supported the motion, which was carried amid warm a^nlause.—Mr. Whitmell suitably responded. It was announced that at the next meeting a pa~er will be read by Mr. G. P. Jenkins, F.R.A.S., on "The New Astronomy," with lantern illustrations. —————————tfi

docs.full_text: POPULAR ASTRONOMY. •—- i EXHIBITION AT CARDIFF MUSEUM. A large and interested company attended the opening of the exhibition organised by the Astronomical Society of Wales at the Cardiff Museum on Thursday morning, among-st those present being the president (Mr. T. E. Heath. F.E.A.S.). the Lord Mayor (Mr. Illtyd Thomas). Mr. Albert Taylor, F.R.A.S., Major-general Lee, F.R.A.S., Coun- cillors Kidd and Good, Dr. Charles Va-chell, Mr. T. H. Thomas, the Rev. W. docs.full_text: THE BRITISH ASSOCIATION AT BRADFORD. Tho Bradford meeting of the British Associa- tion will open at 8 o'clock on Wednesday evening next with the inangural address of Sir William Turner at St. George's Hall, as presi- dent, and the various sections will meet for business on the following morning. There will be in all, it is expected, about 1,000 scientists present, including many foreigners. The nine sections are to meet aa follows:—Mathema- I tical and Physical Science and Astronomy, the .Friend3' Meeting House; Chemistry, the Gram- mar School; Geography, the Church Institute Economic Science and Statistics, the Saioon of the Mechanical Institute Mechanical Science, the Lecture Hall of the Mechanics' Institute; Anthropology, Hallfield Baptist Sebool; and Botony, the Friends' Meeting Honae. Every preparation has been made for the convenience and comfort of the visitors, whose headquarters will practically be the Bradford Grammar School, At the Technical College there is to be an exhi- bition, including specimens of Bradford products.

docs.full_text: AN ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY FOR WALES. Although there are numbers of people in Wales and Monmouthshire who take an interest in astronomy, nothing has, as yet, be en formed in the nature of a. society, though such local associations are found in many other parts of the kingdom. An attempt in this direction is now being made, and already names are being received from all parts. Readers who would care to join the society are requested to write to Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S,, 41, Hamilton- street, Cardiff. It is hoped to call a meeting shortly, when a programme will be decided upon. Meanwhile, readers would do well to note that, while the possession of a. telescope is desirable, it is by no means essential, all that will be required of members being that they should have an interest in the science.

docs.full_text: HALFPENNY NEWSPAPER SCI ENCE. Mr. Arthur Mee, lecturing at Newport on Monday evening, on "Are there Folk in Other Worlds," attacked some members of the Lon- don halfpenny press for the unscrupulous stuff they published on astronomical matters. In their feverish search for sensation they deliberately misinterpreted facts about (say; Mars or Satnrn, and said flippant things which deceived the multitude, but made the writers supremely ridiculous in the eyes of those in the know. Provincial newspapers were far more careful in these matters. The methods he alluded to were copied from America, where the cheap press never told the truth except by accident. As for some of the London halfpenny sheets, eight out of ten of the things they said about astronomy were false and the other two-tenths were garbled and exaggerated. This sort of thing did not hurt science, but it had a very had effect on the people at large and refcavftad advance of knowledge.

docs.full_text: DEATH OF AN M.P. Mr. E. J. C. Morton, M.P. for Devonport. died at Amberley, Gloucestershire, on Friday night. Mr. Morton had represented Devon- port since 1892, and was at one time secretar, to the Home Rule Union. He was born in 1856. and was educated at Harrow and Cam- bridge. He was called to the Bar in 1885. and was a member of the North-eastern Cir- cuit. He was also one of the university extension lecturers on astronomy. The news of Mr. Morton's death was received in hia constituency on Saturday from Miss Morton. Mr. Morton had been suffering for a. long time from dropsy, and not long since was a patient in St. Thomas's Hospital, London. The news of Mr. Morton's death has caused deep regret in Devonport. The Conservative candidate for the constituency is Mr. J. Lockie, of Stone- house, who was defeated by Mr. Morton at the last general election by a narrow majo- rity.

docs.full_text: A NEW OCCUPATION FOR THE FAIR SEX. That romantic astronomer, Camilla Flam- marion, pending that he arranges a system of planetary telegraphy between our Urania and Mars, advocates a new vocation for the superabundant fair sex. Recapitulating the marvellous discovery of Professor Huggins in spectra-astronomy, he asserts that the pierc- ing and patient eyes of ladies are eminently fitted for reading and photographing the messages sent. by stars we cannot see into prisms, whose light bands tell the threshold secrets of infinity. A French astronomer testifies to the aid he received from his bureau of young ladies he had employed to measure the photographs of the passage of Venus. There are in France 16,000 young ladies holding college diplomas seeking occu- pation, and who would ask nothing better than to he engaged either in c-lestial or terrestrial matrimonial duties.

docs.full_text: SCHOLARSHIPS AT OXFORD SUCCESS OF A MONMOUTH STUDENT. STUDENT. It was announced on Saturday night that the Henry Skymner Mathematical Scholar- ship at Balliol College, Oxford, had been awarded to Robert Petrie, of Monmouth Grammar School. The scholarship is of the value of £90 a year, and tenable for five years. provided that the scholar resides at Balliol College, oonducts himself to the satis- faction of the college, and continues the study of mathematics or natural philosophy or astronomy. Mr. Petrie distinguished him- self by coming out first in order of merit amongst the senior candidates in the Oxford local examinations in 1902 and 1903, this being the first occasion that any candidate had secured such success.

docs.full_text: THE. APPROACHING TRANSIT- OF MERCURY. Mr H. H. Turner, secretary to the Royal 1 Astronomical Society, writes:—"Oa November 10th there will ba a transit of Mercury over the sun's disc. Under favourable conditions the ingr&ss will be visible shortly before sunset in ingress will be visible shortly before sunset in these islands. Conditions improve as we go 1 west, and by crossing the Atlantic the whole transit may be observed. The phenomenon is not an imposing spectacle like a total solar eclipse, nor of such sensational interest as a transit of Venus but it has a considerable im- portance in astronomy of precision, a.nd a certain I popular interest as resembling a transit of Venus, which can never again be seen by those now living. The next transit of Venus wro take place in the year 200$: but there wiil be transits of liercury in 1907 and 1914."

Inspector of Schools, delivered an interesting and highly-instructive lecuure to the members of the Cardiff Naturalists' Society at the Queen-street Public Hall on Thursday evening, entitled, Recent Progress in Astronomy." ARMY AND NAVY VETERAN'S' SOCIETT.—A meet- mg in promotion of this new society is called for to-night at the Griffin Hotel, at 8 o'clock. All Crimean and Indian Mutiny veterans, non- commissioned officers who have served under the colours resident in the neighbourhood, as well as naval veterans, are invited. Books of rules have been prepared and are ready for distribution.

MR. FRANCIS GALTON, after considerable investiga- tion, declares that the average of female stature in the upper and middle classes has risen nearly 2in. in 50 years. Nothing strikes a foreigner more than the number of tall, finely-developed women to be seen in the London parks during the season. The average is from 5ft. 6in. to 5ft. lOin., whereas 50 years ago a woman of 5ft. 7in. would have been considered tall. M. docs.full_text: TRAMS AND ASTRONOMY. j In consequence of representations made by the Astronomer Royal, the electrification of the over. head system of the horsed tramways between Bereford-square, Woolwich, and the Free Ferry has been temporarily suspended, owing to the fact that the Astronomer Royal objects to the overhead wires as likely to interfere with the working of the instruments at Greenwich Observatory. It will be recollected that an objection waa raised to the generating station at Greenwich on the ground that the high chimney obstructed the work of taking observations. The scheme fot connecting Eltham and, Woolwich by an electric tramway service has been also hung up for a con- siderable time because of the Astronomer Royal's objection to the overhead system of traction which it was proposed. to adopt.

docs.full_text: AN ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY FOR WALES. TO THE EDITOR OF THE CAMBRIAN." SIR,-A movement is on foot to establish an Astronomical Society for Wales and Monmouth- shire. There ure hundreds of people in the dis- tricts named who take an interest in astronomy, and who would be glad of some common bond of union. If those who like to join an organisation such as I have named will communicate with me I shall be very happy to add their names to the already growing list. The posses-ion of a telescope is desirable, but not essential. Much can be done without it. The Society would, of course, embrace meteorology, ani it is hoped to work it on such lines as to make it interesting, as well as helpful, to all its members.-I am, &c., ARTHUR MEE, F.R.A.S. 41, Hamilton-street, Cardiff.

docs.full_text: A FAMOUS WELSHMAN. MEMORIAL TO ROBERT RECORDE AT TENBY. It was reported at a meeting of the Pem- brokeshire Association for the Preservation of Ancient Monuments at Haverfordwest on Monday that Mr. Owen Thomas, the well- known London sculptor, had presented a memorial to Tenby Church of Robert Recorde. an eminent Welshman, who was born in Tenby about 1510. Recorde was the first original writer on arithmetic in English and geometry: he introduced the knowledge of algebra into England, was the first writer on astronomy in English, and the first person .in the country to adopt the Copernican system. The memorial takes the form of a portrait medallion. Reccrde was physician to King Edward VI. and Queen Mary, but died in prison in 1558.

docs.full_text: BARMOUTH- NARROW ESCAPE.—A correspondent writes to say that he entered a chapel not far from Barmouth, a few Sundays ago, and was somewhat alarmed to hear that this earth of ours had just narrowly escaped destruction. The preacher, whose hair was not grey, told the story in the following way :—"Some time ago Venus was travelling (he meant the planet Venus) upon the track of the earth, and astronomers said that if it continued in that course it would come in violent contact with the earth. But, my friends," he continned, "Vemis did not move one inch out of its course; and the earth did not move one inch out of its course, and—there was no collision." These young men would be all the better if they were kept in that course where amongst other things they learn astronomy.

docs.full_text: BRITISH ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY. TO THE EDITOR OF THE CAMBRIAN." SiK,—Will you be so good as to insert the subjoined in your valuable columns, and so bring the claims of the new society before the scientists of Swansea ? There are many, doubtless, amongst your readeis who take an interest in astrouomy, or who possess small telescopes, and would like to turn them to account. The new society is intended to fill a gap which has never yet been satis- factorily tilled in England—to do for the.amateur what the Royal Astronomical Society does for the more advauced or professional astronomer.—Yours &c., ARTHUR MEE, F.R.A.S. Llanelly. THE BRITISH ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETL-This Society has been formed to secure the more thorough co-operation of astronomical observers throughout the country, and at the same time to meet the wishes and requirements of many, who, though taking a high interest in astronomy, have found them- selves precluded by one cause or another, from joining the Royal Astronomical Society. Its leading features are as follows —Membership —Open to all persons interested iu astronomy, ladies as well as gentlemen. Head-quarters—o be fixed in London. Entrance Fee-Five shillings. This is optional ior all members joining before January 1st, 1891. Annual bub- scriptioiz -Half-a-guinea; or members may compound by a single payment of six guineas. Object-The association of observers, especially the posse sors "f small telescopes, for mutual help, and their organization in the work of astronomical observation. The circulation of current astro- nomical information. The encouragement of a popular interest in astronomy. Methods—The arrangement of members for the work of observation in sections, or departments of observa- tion, under experienced directors. The publication at short and regular^ intervals, of a journal containing reports of the Society's meetings, and of its observing sections; papers by members; and notes on current astronomy. The holding of meetings, not only in London, but also at provincial centres, wherever the number of members justifies, it, and the members themselves desire it. PROVISIONAL COMMITTEE.— T. W. Backhouse, F.R.A.8., Rev, John Bone, F.R.A.S., D. Booth, Miss Brown, G. Calver. F.R.A.S., H. S. Criswick, F.R.A.S., Gr. T. Davis, Â. Y. W. Downing. M.A., F.R.A.S., P. F. Duke, F.R.A.S., T. G. docs.full_text: DRIVING TO TOWN TO SEE THE ECLIPSE. They appear to have some curious notions in Wiltshire of what may be called the geography of astronomy. It was announced in a Devizes paper that the eclipse of the moon would be visible from that town. Just before the hour at which the shadow would strike the face of our satellite, a farmer, accompanied by his wife and family, drove into Devizes from his homestead. On being inter- rogated as to the meaning of this unwonted night visit, the yeoman proudly aunounced that he had come with .the missus to see the eclipse. The worthy man resides j ust three miles from Devizes, and really believed the eclipse would not be visible outside of that town.

His name was Teiti, and he left his whole fortune-with the exception of some befjuests to faithful servants, to pen- sion funds, and to a children s hospital—to the Academy of Sciences for scientific researches in astronomy, the exploration of the earth, and physics and cheir.isiry. This he did, as he said in his will, "for the greater glory of God, that men and women may become happier by being more cultured and educated, and also for the simplification of medical science," whatevfsr that may mean. docs.full_text: SIR DAVID GILL. I MAN WHO HELPED TO CATAL03LE THE STARS. Sir David Gill, K.C.B., late Astronomer-Royal at the Cape, died in London this morning. Deceased, who was born in 1843, held many scientific distinctions, tie was born at Aberdeen, and graduated at the University there. Devoting him- self to the studv of astronomy, he took a prominent part in many expeditions j oi' observation, and was for a time en- gaged in the making of a. pli-otogi- catalogue of the stars. He was also engaged in important colonial survey work, and was the author of numerous scientific works. It would require almost t small volume to enumerate the distinctions which were conferred upon Sir David at one timo or another. He was a, voluminous writer on scientific subjects.

docs.full_text: LLANELLY. The Biitish school on the hill, was examined on Tues- day evening last, at the Baptist chapel, Darenvelar. The following gentlemen tookpart in questioning thechildren, and the young men of the night school :-Mr. Harris, agent, Mr. Harry, grocer, and the Rev. D. Richards, Siloam. The subjects in which they were examined were geography, English history, grammar, mental arithmetic, and astronomy. There were about 600 persons present, who were much pleased with the answers given by the several classes. Messrs. R. Jones, and W. Miles sang several duetts, which gratified the audience very much. Tke above school is supported by the liberality of J. and T. Powell, Esqrs., with other gentle- men and friends in the neighbourhood and the efficient manner in which it is conducted reflects great credit upon Mr. and Mrs. Rosser, the master and mistress,

He had very little doubt but that as time went on they would probably find that the sun contained nreciscly the satoe elements that the earth was made of. The sun seemed to be a huge body of compressed gas. Whenthat gas began to solidifv they would be at least in the period of beginning to get cool, but at present he be- lieved—he did not know and nobody knew— that that gas was profcably m a kind of viscous condition which was not fish, flesh, or good red herring.

W. Dyson. I the son of a Free Church minister, Mr Dyson, who is in his 43rd year. had a brilliant career at Qunbridge (Second Wrangler, Smith's. Prizemae, and the first Isaac Newton student for research work in mathematical and gravit- ational astronomy). By vacating one post as Astronomer Royal to accept another, Mr Dyson creates a record, as no other of the three Astronomers Royal has ever held more than, one such post.

docs.full_text: THE SCIENCE AND ART DEPART- MENT. The Lords of the Committee of Council on Education are of opinion that the subject of physical geography, as no'v defined in the Science Directory, is not one towards instruction in which the special aid of the Scienee and Art Department should be continued. At the same time, their lordships propose to allow payments for the next two years for those students who have already been under instruction by any science teacher in physical geography, but not for any others, nor for any examination held after May, 1878. The new subject (physiography) will embrace those external relations and conditions of the earth which form the common basis of the sciences of nautical astronomy, geology, and biology, as treated in the Science Directory.

John Davies, of Cardiff, delivered a lecture in an eloquent and forcible style, upon The events of the last few years," with a view to raise a fund towards the support of the English cause lately com- menced at Zoar. There was a good attendance, pre- sided over by Dr. Davies.—Two other lectures upon the Astronomy of the Bible," are to be given a.t Tabor next week, by an eminent minister of the Calvinistic body, towards a somewhat similar object. TOWN-HALL.—This place, different to others of less note, has been heretofore without any hall to hold pub- lic meetings, concerts, lectures and entertainments. We hear however, that such a building, intended also to comprise accommodation for the instruction and amuse- ment of the working class after hours of labour, is in contemplation. There is too much agitation respect- ing a market place.

docs.full_text: POOL QUAY. LECTUR. -On Tuesday evening the Rev R. J. Roberts gave a most interesting and useful lecture on Astronomy in the Schoolroom to a capital com- pany. He was assisted by the Rev W. T. Davies, Curate of Welshpool, who managed the magic lantern. The views of the planets, &e., were very good, and the persons present seemed greatly inter- ested in the rev. lecturer's description of the Starry Heavens." At the close of the lecture a miscellaneous entertainment was given by Mrs Roberts, Miss Troughton, Miss Hole, the Rev Davies, and Mr Pugh, consisting of pianoforte pieces, songs and readings, all of which were greaIv appreciated. A hearty vote) of thanks to the Vicar, the Rev Davies, and the performers, closed a very pleasant evening's entertainment.

He worked under Ilobei i, Stephenson, and as resident engineer had eonirol of the construction of the Brittannia and Conway bridges. For many- years he was chief engineer to the Electric Telegraph Company. He patented a hydianlie graving-dock, a hydraulic canal lift, and was inventor of the block system ot i ail way signalling. He constructed tbe famons harbour of Caliao in Peru, and carried out engineering works in various parts of the world. Reiiiing, in 1876, he settled down at Marlow. Deceased was a student of astronomy, and was a Fellow ot the Royal Astronomical and Metero. logical Societies.

docs.full_text: PERSONAL. The King has approved the appointment of Mr Andrew Henderson Leith Fraser, C.S I., to be Lieu- tenant Governor of Bengal, in sucession to the late Sir John Woodburn, K.C.I. The Lord Lieutenant of Ireland has intimated his intention of conferring the honour of knight- hood on Dr Charles Bent Ball, Reigus Professor of Surgery in Trinity College, Dnblin. Dr Ball per- formed the recent operation for appendicitis on the Countess of Dudley, from which she is happily recovering. He is the youngest son of the late Dr Robert Ball, the Lowndean Professor of Astronomy at Cambridge University, who was knighted in 1886. Dr Ball is an honorary Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons of England.

docs.full_text: It would appear that the valuable art of lithography is neither of European origin, nor of so recent a date as is generally conceived. It has been practised for ages in Thibet, both at Djacchii-loumbo and H'lassa. In the former town especially it has been ap- plied for the purpose of publishing an anatomy of the human frame in sixty plates- It will be news to most of our readers to learn, that the arts and sciences, to the extent at least of what is known and practised of them in China, are disseminated throughout Thibet, and that the principal Chinese works in history, astronomy, physic, and other branches of human knowledge, have been translated and published in that extensive depend- ency of the celestial empire.

docs.full_text: laCdD*—■— The First Cyclist. I A learned German has been trying to dis- cover who was the first man who rode a wheel, and has detected him in the person of Triptolemus, the mythical pioneer of agriculture among the Greeks. A certain Roman writer, who was librarian to Augustus Cseser, wrore a book on astronomy, in which he described Tripto- lemus as having been inspired by the goddes Ceres with the idea of extending the culture of corn in Greece. In order to enable him to travel rapidly from place to place the goddes obligingly provided him with a single wheel, across which he used to stride. Ihis, we learn on the authority of Travel," is the authentic history of the first cyclist.

docs.full_text: AN OBSERVATORY FOR CARDIFF. All those who are interested in the cause of science gladly hail the efforts now being made to construct a grand observatory at Cardiff. It is highly consoling to find a keener interest being taken in scientific studies in Wales. Seeing that the matter is seriously considered in the Welsh metropolis, it augurs well for the future success of this proposed scheme in furthering a practical knowledge of astronomy in the principality. By means of its recent achievements, Cardiff has recently surprised both neighbours and strangers alike. In Wales there are at present several symp- toms of a vigorous awakening in the wide field of science. Let us trust that there will soon be built an observatory which will be the pride not only of Cardiff, but of the whole of Wales.

docs.full_text: Dinas. The mortal remains of David Richards,. widely known as Dai Aberdare," were laid to rest at the Llethrddu Cemetery on Wednesday last. Sixty years ago, he was one of the best known athletes in the country. He was acknowledged for many years to be the fastest three iniles runner in England and Wales. Many of his feats were accomplished in Bristol and Bath and the sporting centres of England. The burial rites were performed by the Revs. T. E. Griffiths (vicar Llan- fair-ar-y-bryn) and J. Pugh (carate). The funeral was well attended. Special services were held at Bethania Chapel on Sunday last. The officiating, minister was the Rev. T. Esger James, Maesteg, who delivered excellent sermons. On the following Monday evening, the, rev. gentleman delivered an highly in- structive lecture on "Astronomy." The Daylight Comet and Halley's Comet re- received special attention. The lecture wasvell attended.

docs.full_text: DISCOVERY OF SMALL PLANETS. In none of the applications of photography to astronomy have the results been more immediate or more evident than in the discovery of the small bodies which move in orbits between those of MTars and Jupiter. From the observation of the first of these, Ceres, in 1801, until the end of 1891, 321 had been discovered by the comparatively laborious method of eye observation. From that time photo- graphy has been pressed into the service, and no fewer than 44 have been fouud within the last 15 months. Professor Charlois, of Nice, reports the finding of six during the last week, a feat which would have been considered unparalleled at the beginning of the century.

docs.full_text: TECHNICAL INSTRUCTION IN FLINT- SHIRE. Arrangements are being made for the estab- lishment of classes to be held during the next winter months, in fourteen centres in the county. The subjects selected, comprise chemistry, geology, physiography, mathematics navigation, nautical astronomy, drawing, cookery, and agriculture with field experiments and dairy demonstration. The courses will be under the Science and Art Department, and will be carried on from the middle of October to the end of April. Inaugural meetings will be held at different centres at an early date. On the 15th October, a public meeting will be held at Holywell; on the 12th October, a lecture on coal will be delivered by Mr. A. W. Lucas, at Flint Town Hall.

docs.full_text: AN AUSTRALIAN A.^RONOLII^. Mr. David Ross, of Melbourne, Australia, has just discovered a second new comet. Although engaged in discharging his duties on the staff of one of our Australian banks, he finds time not only to study the heavens to such good ac- [ MR. DAVID ROSS. count, but also to make his own telescopes. He occasionally lends these instruments to his friends, and other beginners, in the study of astronomy. Other determination of the place of the new southern comet has come to hand. It appears that it is now just within the reach of observers in the British Isles. Its north- ward motion causes it to set later by about five and a half minutes every evening, while the sun sets later, evening by evening, by not quite two minutes. The time, therefore, during which the comet can be observed in the western sky after the sun has gone down is at present slowly in- creasing.

docs.full_text: On November 10 there will be a transit of Mercury over the sun's disc. Under favourable conditions the ingress will be visible shortly before sunset in these islands. Conditions improve as we go west, and by crossing the Atlantic the whole transit may be observed. The phenomenon is not an im- posing spectacle like a total solar eclipse; nor of such sensational interest as the transit of Venus; but it has a considerable im- portance in astronomy of precision, and a certain popular interest as resembling a tran- sit of Venus, which can never again be seen by those now living. The next transit of Venus will take place in the year 2004; but there will be transits of Mercury in 1907 11 an4 1914. U. ,I

docs.full_text: ARE WE AN INTELLECTUAL NATION P The Saturday Review writes :-We are not an intellectual nation. From time to time we produce great intellects: we have as good a, record in that respect perhaps as any nation but there is no people who care less for and appreciate the great men they have produced than the English none, for instance, know its classic writers as little as we do oars. We are the sort. of people who would pooh-pooh astronomy, if we could not make nee of it in navigation. This, indeed, we do in all deparments of soience. Theory, and research, and scientific method are undervalued, because we have not sufficient appreciation of their importance as the groundwork of successful practice.

docs.full_text: THE Times Paris correspondent gives a sketch of the scheme which has been sanctioned by the Supreme Educational Council for girls' secondary education. The entrance age is twelve, and during the first three years all the lessons, four per diem, are obligatory, the chief subjects being the French language and literature, English and German, geography, arithmetic, elements of science, drawing and singing, with sewing and gymnastic exercises, twice a week; zoo- logy in winter, and botany, accompanied by botanising walks in summer. In the fourth and fifth years, French and modern languages, ancient history, astronomy, and cosmography, domestic economy, and animal and vegetable physiology are obligatory, while ancient literature, elements of Latin, mathematics, physics, singing, and drawing are optional. We thus perceive that France is now devoting as much attention to the solid education of both sexes as we are now doing ourselves.

docs.full_text: THE COMING ICE AGE. SIR ROBERT BALL, who was lecturing this time last year in Cardiff, has just been elected to the Lowndean professorship of astronomy and geometry at Cambridge. Sir Robert is a typical Irishman, with a mellow brogue and possesses remarkable adeptness in illustration. In some of his books for children this quality is rather strained. Nevertheless he is very lucid, and does not use words of whose sense he has only a faint glimmer, and his audience none at all. In his last book, The Cause of a Great Ice Age," he attacks his subject with transparent clearness. He prophesies the return of these Arctic conditions, but he does not specify the date. He stops short at that. Nevertheless here we are burning all our coal" hen we shall want it later on.

docs.full_text: I FEBTINIOG. A correspondent writes :-On Tuesday last, through the instrumentality of Mr. Owen G. Williams, (Owen Glyndwr) the celebrated and popular lecturer, Mr. J. G. Jones, from America, gave one of his instructive lec- tures (illustrated by a powerful phantasmogorian appa- ratus), at the new Market Hall. The attendance was very satisfactory, and the lecture on Astronomy was at- tentively listened to by the audience. The views exhi- bited were of a very superior character, and the lecturer was quite at home" with the subject. Thanks are due to Owen Glyndwr for the unexpected treat. We heartily hope he will be able again to persuade his friend to pay ns another visit, as he will be most warmly welcomed by all. I

docs.full_text: BETHESDA. I LITERARY SOCIETY.—The first meeting of the Glan- ogwen Literary Society was held at the National School- room, on Saturday evening, the 19th instant. The chair was taken by the Rev. J. Williams, vice-president, who, after making a few introductory remarks, called upon the secretary (Nir. Elias P. Williams, jun.) to read an essay on "The Church as the Body of Christ, after which an auimated discussion took place. The Rules were read over by the secretary, and a resolution was passed approving of them. Mr. Owen, schoolmaster (who is the treasurer) gave notice that at the next meeting he would read an essay on "The Physiology of Man." The different subjects to be treated in the society's meetings are to comprise Divinity, Physiology, Astronomy, Geography and History. The Meetings will be held monthly.

docs.full_text: TECHNICAL INSTRUCTION IN FLINTSHIRE. Arrangements are being made for the establishment of classes, to be held during the next winter months, in 14 centres in the county. The subjects selected comprise chemistry, geology, physiography, mathe- matics, navigation, nautical astronomy, drawing. cookery, and agriculture, with field experiments and dairy demonstrations. The courses will be under the Science and Art Department, and will be carried on from the middle of October to the end of April. Iuaugural meetings will be held at different centres at an early date. On the 15th October a public meeting will be held at Holywell; on the 12th October, a lecture on coal will be delivered by Mr A. W. Lucas, at the Flint Town Hall.

docs.full_text: NARBERTH. THE MARCH FAIR was held on Tuesday last, when a large supply of fat stock was on offer, which went off readily at high prices. There were also a great many store beasts in the Fair, which changed hands well. Cows and calves were scarce, with a good demand, which had the effect of making them very dear. Store sheep were not in much enquiry, it being early in the season, and the bite of grass quite short. The supply of horses was limited, but good animals were eagerly sought for. The Pig Fair was held on the following day. Mr. Hemming delivered his lectures on Astronomy and Electricity on Monday and Tuesday evenings in last week, at the Rutzen Arms Hotel. The audience we hear was of the thinnest, and but little satisfaction ex- pressed with the treatment of the subject.

docs.full_text: THE Times Paris correspondent gives a sketch of the scheme which has been sanctioned by the Supreme Educational Council for girls' secondary education. The entrance age is twelve, and (luring the first three years ail the lessons, four P''r tre obll«atory- the chief subjects being the i rench language and literature, English and German, geography, arithmetic; elements of science, drawing and singing, with sewing and gymnastic exercises, twice a week; zoo- ¡ 10;,C,- in winter, and botany, accompanied r by botanising walks in summer. In the fourth and fifth years, French and modern languages, ancient history, astronomy, and cosmography, domestic economy, and animal and vegetable physiology are obligatory, while ancient literature, elements of Latin, wat,heiiatics, physics, singing, and drawing are | optional. We thus perceive that France is now devoting as much attention to the solid education of both sexes as we are now doing ourselves.

docs.full_text: A FATHER was telling hia little son about the wonders of modern science. Look at astronomy, now men have learned the distance of the stars, and, with their spectroscopes, what they are made of.-Yes, said tbe boy, And pa, isn't it strange how they found out all their names? My dear, said a petulant author to his wife, who asked him a civil question, why do you persist in dis- turbing me when you see that 1 am wrapped in thought?—Because, she replied, I'm afraid you'll take cold.-Take cold?—Yes; when I find you are only wrapped in thought I don't care if it is summer time; but such covering is entirely too thin for this season.

docs.full_text: APPLIED ASTRONOMY. He took ice out to see the stars, That astronomic bore; He said there were two moons near Mars, While Jupiter had four. I thought, of course, he'd whisper soon What fourfold bliss 'twould be To stroll beneath that fourfold moon On Jupiter with me. And, when he spoke of Saturn's ring, I was convinced he'd say That wall the very kind of thing To offer me some day. But in a tangent off he went Todoublestars. Now that Was most suggestive, so content And quite absorbed I sat. But no-he talked a dreary mess, Of which the only fraction That caught my fancy, I confess, Was mutual attraction. I said I thought it very queer And stupid altogether. Forstarstokeepsoverynear And yet not come together, At that he smiled, and turned his head I thought he'd caught the notion. He merely bowed good night, and said Their safety lay in motion.—Century.

On Monday the 15th inst., the Loid Bishop of St- David's held a confirmation Service at the Pari:h Church before a crowded congregation, the vicar presented 18 candidates all from ths parish of Roch and Nolton and ranging in ages between 14 and 47 yeas. The two addresses given by the Bishop were most appropriate and instructive. LECTURE.—On the 17th, Rear Admiral Stokes Rees, C.B., now residing" at Hilton delivered a most intetesting lecture on Astronomy, at the schoolroom, the lecture was illustrated with many diagrams made very carefully by the lecturer, the proceeds were given in aid of the Roch and Nolton District Nurse Fund. A. W. Massy, Esqr., J.P., was chairman. +

docs.full_text: DEATH OF A FAMOUS ENGINEER. Mr Edwin Clarke, M.I.C.E., died at Cromwell Rouse, Marlow, late on Monday. He was born at Marlow in 1814, and became one of the lead- ing English engineers. He worked under Robert Stephenson, and as resident engineer had control of the construction of the Britannia and Conway bridges. For many years he was chief engineer to the Electric Telegraph Company. He patented the hydraulic graving dock and the hydraulic canal lift, and was the inventor of the blook system of railway signalling. He constructed the famous harbour of Callao in Peru, and carried out engineering works in various parts of the world. Retiring in 1876, he settled down in Marlow. Deceased was a keen student of astronomy, and was a Fellow of the Royal Astronomical and Meteorological Societies.

docs.full_text: CHEPSTOW. DISTINGUISHED VISITOBS.-In the beginning of the week the Lord Chief Justice of England and Lady Coieriige made what was intended to be a flying visit to our town, but they have been so charmed with the beautiful and picturesque scenery, as well as the excellent accommodation and entertainment afforded at Mr Garrett's Beaufort Hotel, that they are still here, and are to be seen day after day driving to and from the various places of interest in the neighbourhood, ASTRONOMY.—On Thursday a deeply interesting lecture was delivered in the Welsh-street School- room by Dr. Thain Davidson, of Islington subject, A Trip to the Remotest Star." The large room was nearly filled. Mr Geo. Dewdney occupied the chair, and was supported by the Rev. J. Hall Stephens and Mr Edwin Ellis, chairman of the Chepstow School Board.

docs.full_text: THE SCIENCE AND ART DEPART- MENT. The Lords of the Committee of Council on Education are of opinion that the subject of physical geography, so now defined in the Science Directory, is not one towards instruction in which the special aid of the Science and Art Department should be continued. At the same time, their lordships propose to allow payments for the next two years for those students who have already been under instruction by any science teacher in physical geography, but not for any others, nor for any examination held after May, 1878. The new subject (physiography) will embrace those external relations and conditions of the earth which form the common basis of the sciences of nautical astronomy, geology, and biology, as treated in the Science Directory

After the little ups and downs preliminary to the final choice ot the Conservative party, it was obvious to allude to the survival of the fittest and to natural selection," whilst Dr. Kenny playfully talked of a "missing link" having been found between town and university. docs.full_text: ASTRONOMY IN WALES. The monthly meeting of the Astronomical Society of Wales was held on Wednesday eveziing at Captain Jut suit's Nautical Academy, Mr James Waagh, M.A., president, in the chair. Signer D. Conta, of Newport, read a paper on the great telescope of the Exposition, which he saw when in Paris. He also exhibited an -1 observa- toire de salon," produced by a well-known firm of French scientific publishers, which shews all the principal phenomena of the heavens in a novel and interesting manner. On the motion of the President, seconded by Mr Lattey and sup- ported by Mr Mee, a hearty vote of thanks was accorded Signor Conta, who has been one of the staanchesb friends of the society during the term of its existence. Some miscellaneous matters were also discussed.

docs.full_text: ARE WE AN INTELLECTUAL NATION ? The Saturday Review writes :-We are not an intellsctual nation. We are the sort of people who would pooh-pooh astronomy, if we oould not make use of n in navigation. This, indeed, we do iu all dcp-wrmenis of science. Theory, and research, haci scientific method are undervalued, because we have not sufficient appreciation of their importance M the groundwork of successful practice.

docs.full_text: Brother Jasper's Sermon. The statement of one of the witnesses in the famous Madagascar Millions case concluded on Tuesday, that the earth is flat, recalls a sermon by Bro. Jasper, an eccentric coloured missionary, on the fallacies of modern astronomy. After an eloquent passage, in which he proved to his own satisfaction that the sun rises and sets, he proceeded thus: Dey sey de earth is roun'! Dat ain't so, bredren it can't he so, for de Book o' Revelations, chapter vii., verse 1, reads. An' I saw four angels standin' on the four corners o' the earth.' An' now, bredren an' sisters, we is livin' on a fo- cornered earth, an' ef de earth is got fo' corners, how in de name o' Gawd ken it corners, Ef de wor is roun' an' turn be roun'? Ef de wod' is roun', an' turn over ev'ry night, how we hoi' on? Is we got claws on our feet like woodpeckers?

Chambers, the well-known writer oil astronomy, addressing the British Astronomical Å.8sociat.;(" ;'L Sion College in London the other even- ing, elaced^that the total solar eclipse of May 28, 1800, would offer special opportunities to observers in this part of the world. The central line of totality crossed almost through the centre of Portugal and Spain. It touched first the coast of Portugal, a few miles below Oporto, and came out at the other end near Barcelona. He could not say much with regard to the astronomical features to be expected to arise, but it would be somewhat coincident with a minimum period of sun spots. The duration of totality would be a little above the average, and May would offec advantages as regarded the probability of a good sky.

docs.full_text: Bairy Astronomical Society --0-- A meeting was held at the Y.M.C.A. on Thursday night last for the purpose of forming the above society. Dr. Percy Phillips, an ardent and distinguished astronomer, presided, and ably reviewed the usefulness of a local centre, the needs of the many gentlemen interested in astronomy, and the fact that there are at least a dozen Celestial glasses in the district, which, he thought, gave proof of the success of the project. A provisional council was appointed. A hearty vote of thanks to the chairman was proposed by Rev. J. Dynvant Wil- liams, and seconded by Mr. Caley. Mr. W. Beddoe was the convener of the meeting, which was highly successful.

docs.full_text: Barry Astronomical Society :0: Inaugural Lecture. A large number Of *ladies and gentlemen attended the inaugural lecture of the Barry Astronomical Saciety at the Y.M.C.A. on Tuesday evening, when the well-known South Wales astronomer, Mr A. Taylor, H.M.I., F.R.A.S., Penarth, delighted his! auditors by his interesting facts relative to the celestial world. The lecture was well- illustrated by lantern-slides, and starting first by explaining the mechanism and working of a telescope, he afterwards gave an interesting summary of the features of the most noted of the bodies in space. His exposition of the comet formation-with special reference to Halley's comet was much enjoyed. The Society now has a fairly large membership, but all interested in astronomy are welcomed.

docs.full_text: History is always said to repeat itself, and the discussion respecting the begin- ning of the new century is by no means introduced for the first time in the annals of the world. According to the "Daily Chronicle," a London paper of the first week of IKOtI alluded to "the recent hot disputes in France and England respect- ing the beginning of the nineteenth cen- tury." We are also told that the famous Joseph Jerome Lefrancais tle Lalajide, who was then professor of astronomy at the University of Paris, had taken an active part in the discussion, and he had pronounced in favour of January 1, 1801. His decision, we are assured, was generally accepted as correct on both sides of the Channel. The "Chronicle" adds "The same ridiculous question was agitated I in 1700."

docs.full_text: ￼ EDITORIAL COMMENTS. The approach of the November meteor- shower will give the public at large an opportunity of doing a little observation which will not only bo interesting to those who take part, but even of considerable value to astronomy. Most celestial sights arc only to be properly observed by the aid of a telescope, but any person with average eyesight, ordinary intelli- gence, and a little trouble can do useful work in the recording of meteors. We learn that the Astronomical Society of Wales is organising a band of workers for the November shower, and we have no doubt there are many of our readers who would like, if pbssible, to do something towards the collection of results. It is to be hoped clouds will not interfere with the display of the 14tk-10th inst., which there is every reason to hope will be worth watching.

Sir,—I notice in your paper of this morning that the Franklen Evans Telescopo has been referred to another committee, this being, I think, the third committee in as many weeks! It may possibly not have struck the corpora- tion that in choosing a site they shoifld consult a few people who have a practical knowledge of astronomy. There are such in Cardiff. though the council in its wisdom may not be aware of it. If that telescope is bungled and botched after the time-honoured plan. there are persons about who, like the Cornishmen of old, "will know the reason why"!—I am, &c„ &c„ 4. OBSERVER. Jan, 4,

docs.full_text: Whatever may be the drawbacks of modern civilisation, no one can, at any rate, complain that knowledge is not freely disseminated. There are few subjects with which people oannot familiarise themselves if only they take a little trouble. It ia not now, as formerly, a question of finance. The latest advance that we know of in Cardiff is the establishment of a course of educational lectures on elementary astronomy, which we owe to the activity of the Astronomical Society of Wales. Professor Tanner, F.R.A.S., will give the first lecture of the series on Thursday night at the Cardiff Higher Grade Schools, and we notice that the public are cordially invited. Thus it is that all subjects, even in the heavens above, are brought easily and pleasantly within reach I of the people.

docs.full_text: "AN HOUR IN THE MOON." Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S., delivered his lantern-lecture, "An Hour in the Mooti," before the St. Andrew's Presbyterian Guild on Tuesday evening. Mr. J. Balmer occupied the chair, and, together with the lecturer, made sympathetic reference to the illness of the pastor, the Rev. J. Douglas Watters. Mr. Mee repeated his lecture on Thursday evening at Trinity Wesleyan Church, Penarth. Mr. E. H. Ede, B.A., presided over an attentive audience. A vote of thanks was moved by Mr. Tregaskis, and seconded by Mr. H. Nor wood Atkins, who spoke of the new edition of the lecturer's "Observational Astronomy," recently issued by the "Western Mail." Mr. Mee, in acknowledging the vote, said Mr. Atkins was one of the few amateur observers who had the skill and patience to construct bia own telescope. He had ground his own mirrors, and the instrument was a decided success.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY OF WALES. The final meeting of the society's session was held at Captain Juisnm's Nautical Academy, St. Mary-street, Cardiff, on Wednesday even. ing. A number of new members were elected. The president (Mr. James Waugb, M.A.) read a paper on "The Astronomy of Milton." He dealt in an able and interesting manner with a somewhat recondite topic, viz., the cos- mogony of "Paradise Lost, and read various quotations illustrative of his remarks. The paper was diversified at times with flashes of humour, which greatly pleased the audience. At the close disoussion took Dlace, when Miss Bathurst, Miss Hagerty, Messrs. A. A. Williams. George A. S. Atkinson, George Southey, Arthur Mee, Norman Lattey, D. B. W. Powel, Captain Jutsun. and the presi- dent took part. A hearty vote of thanks was accorded Mr. Waugh and also to Captain Jut- sum for the use of his pleasant and convenient meeting room.

docs.full_text: CARDIFF TELESCOPE AGAIN, Mr. Good at to-day's meeting of the Cardiff Corporation found fault with the provisions made by the telescope.—Mr. Lloyd Meyrick thought that to spend £35, as proposed, was not worthy of the corporation. There was no provision in the town where the young men of the town or the students at the college could study astronomy, and it would not be too much to spend £150 on the matter. He proposed that the suggestion to erect a two- room observatory at a cost of £150 should be adopted, and that the offer of Mr. Arthur Mee and others to give periodical demonstra- tions should be accepted. Mr- Veall seconded. Mr. Walter Blow supported, and thought that the corporation ought to go the whole hog." Mr. Lloyd Meyrlck'a amendment w&e car- ried.

docs.full_text: A MIT JIAN AT NEWPORT, An old man of 74. James Burns by name, stood in the dock at Newport County Police- court on Saturday to answer a charge of theft of some clothing from a clothes line at Risca. He had only been arrested at a common lodging-house at Abergavenny late on Friday night, so a remand was granted. By the description of the police Burns was tattooed on his body and limbs, the subjects ranging from pagan mythology to the Crucifixion, and including navigation, botany, and astronomy among the sciences, while the "little blind god and lord of all—Love," illustrated by a pretty maid, found a prominent place on the old man's bosom.

docs.full_text: OXFORD SCHOLARSHIP. Won by Monmouth Student.! It was announced on Saturday night that the Henry Skynmer Mathematical Scholar- ship at Balliol College, Oxford, had been awarded to Robert Petrie, of Monmouth Grammar Sohool. The scholarship is of the value of L90 a year, and tenable for five years, provided that the scholar residee at BaUiol College, conducts himself to the satis- faction of the college, and continues the study of mathematics or natural philosophy or astronomy. Mr. Petrie distinguished him- self by coming out first in order of merit amongst the senior candidates in the Oxford local examinations in 1902 and 1903, this being the first occasion that any candidate had secured such success.

docs.full_text: KILLED BY READING. I Mr. H. J. Baker, a young Philadelphia student, has just died from the effects of excessive reading of serious books. He was found sitting in his bath dead, with a copy of Benjamin Kidd's "Social Evolution tightly gripped in one fiand. Baker was reputed to he the greatest reader in America. He got through 1.000 books every year, chiefly on such subjects as sociology, geology, geometry, astronomy, and the occult sciences. Kidd's "Sxial Evolution and Darwin's "Descent of Man" were his favourite works, and he kept a dozen volumes of this sort going all the time. His devotion to reading led to neglect of exercise and health, as a result of which he developed heart disease and vertigo. SL-T ,58

docs.full_text: KILLED BY READING. Mr. H. J. Baker, a young Philadelphi student, has just died from the effects of excessive reading of serious books. He was found sitting in his bath dead, with a copy of Benjamin Kidd's "Social Evolution tightly gripped in one Band. Baker was reputed to be the greatest reader in America. He got through 1,000 books every year, chiefly on such subjects as sociology, geology, geometry, astronomy, and the occult sciences. Kidd's Social Evolution" and Darwin's Descent of Man" were his favourite works, and he kept a dozen volumes of this sort going all the time. His devotion to reading led to neglect of exercise and health, as a result of which he developed heart disease and vertigo.

docs.full_text: EARLY RISING BILL Mr. Dobson's Bill "to promote the earlier I use of daylight in certain months yearly," the second reading of which will be moved in the House of Commons on Friday, was issued yesterday. Its provisions are ;-(1) From 2.0 a.m. on the third Sunday of April to 2.0 a.m. on the third Sunday of September in each year local time shall be one hour ahead of Greenwich time' in Great Britain and of Dublin time in Ireland. For the rest of the y..r local time and Greenwich time shall be the same. (2) A reference to summer time in any Acts or deeds (unless otherwise stated) shall be to the "summer season time" established above. 3 Greenwich time for astronomy and navigation shall remain unaltered.

docs.full_text: THAT MESSAGE TO MARS I To the Editor of the Evening Express. I Sir,—'With reference to the note which appeared in the Evening Express on April I 20 last, stating that Professor Pickering was about to make an effort to communicate with the inhabitants of Mars (if any) by an appa- ratus consisting of mirrors, which should be really by July of this yefLl" in order to take advantage oif the fa-vouraible apposition of that planet in August. I have been con- tinuously reading the Evening Express, but have not, unfortunately, come across a para- graph referring to the scheme. I write to ask .that., should any persona hear of the reeult of the plan, they immediately inform the Evening Express, in order that the result may be published for the benefit of aJI persons interested in astronomy.- I am. &c., Aiig. 9. A OWMPARC ASTRONOMER i A?g.9.

docs.full_text: I THAT ELUSIVE COMET To the Editor of the "Evening Express." Sir,—I notice a paragraph in the "Evening Express" of to-day's date stating that Halley's Comet was observed here by a num- ber of persons this morning between 3.30 and 4.30. As one interested in the study of astronomy, I write to correct this error. Haney's Comet is not now visible, and will not be seen again until it appears east of the 6nm and becomes an evening 8tar-tihs will be about the beginning of next week. It was the planet Venus the people saw, and I think I am correct in stating that many more have fallen into the same error of taking it to be the comet.—I am, &$., the oomet,-I am, &r ASTRO. Porthcawl, May 16.

docs.full_text: I AN ANCIENT CLOCK The Mayor of Exeter attended in state a sriecia.1 service at the cathedral last evening, and set going an astronomical clock recently restored. The clock is of greart. antiquity, portions of it being referred to in the Patent Rolls of 1317, and tie original works must date back some 265 years before Galileo first discovered the synchronous vibrations of a penduium while watchi^* the swinging of a chandelier in the Cathedral of Pisa. The dial is arranged on the Ptolemaic system of astronomy, the earth being represented as a central hemisphere the centre of the solar I system, and the sun by a fleur-de-lys revolving around it.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY OF WALES. The Astonomical Society of Wales opened its session on Thursday evening, when the members were received at the residence of the president-elect, Mr. James Waugh, M.A., New- port-road, Cardiff. The following officers, etc., were electedPresident, Mr. Waugh; vice-pre- sidents, Mr. Carslake Thompson and Professor Tanner; librarian, Mr. George A. S. Atkinson; editor, Mr. Arthur Mee; secretary, Miss Graham Hagarty; treasurer, Mr. C. M1 Hensman; other members of the council, the Rev. W. E. Winks, Messrs. N. Lattey, D. B. W. Pawel: D. Conta (Newport), and A. A. Williams. A hearty vote of thanks was accorded the retir- ing president (Mr. Carslake Thompson) for his valuable services during the past two years, on the motion of Mr. Atkinson, seconded by Mr. Williams. Arrangements were made for a series of monthly meetings and short ad- dresses, promised by the followingMr. Thompson, The Leonids of 1899; Mr. Mee, "How Big Does the Moon Look?": Mr. A. A. W HHams, "Biblical Astronomy"; Miss Hagarty, "Meteorites, Their Chemical Comprsition"; the president, "The Astronomy of Milton"; The transference of the society's books to the care of the Free Library was discussed, and a committee formed to close the matter. It was mentioned in the course of the meeting, with regret, that, after seeking the advice of two members of the society, the Cardiff Town Council had gone directly counter to such in its selection of a final site for the Franklen Evans telescope, viz, the southern end of Catha,va Park, where the instrument wou'd be a mere peep-show, and its full powers never available.

docs.full_text: THE HISTORY OF UNIVERSITY EXTENSION. A lively interview with the inventor and patentee of University Extension, Professor J. Stuart, M.P., appears in the current number of the Student, a little journal supported by promoters of the movement in the north of England. In a brief chat, in the bustle of the Lobby of the House of Commons, the member for Hoxton managed to tell his interviewer all about the origin of the idea and its development. I was always," he said, more or less mixed up in schemes for the improvement of women's education. Of course at that time women had no chance of approaching the Universities. A number of ladies also interested in the subject of women's higher edu- cation asked me, in 1867, to deliver a course of lectures to governesses on the method of teach- ing. Chief among these ladies were the members of the North of England Council for the Higher Education of Women, whose presi- dent was Mrs. Josephine Butler. I pre- ferred to give a course upon some definite subject, which might serve as a model for others, and Astronomy was the subject chosen. For eight weeks I lectured on astronomy once a week to these ladies at four centres, Liverpool, Leeds, Sheffield, and Manchester, the number of students being about 600 in each place." This was the beginning, and after the ladies came lectures to working-men at Crewe and Rochdale, until in 1871, having worked out an organised scheme "approved in actual practice as efficient," the pioneer and his friends were able to in- duce the University of Cambridge to appoint a com- mittee to give definite shape to the proposals. Such was the origin of the movement, in connection with which, during 1892-3, 931 courses of lectures were delivered, attended by 104,460 persons, under the auspices of the chief English and American organisa- tions,

docs.full_text: GLIMPSE INTO INFINITY. SWANSEA" PRINCIPAL S LECTURE ON THE NEBULAR HYPOTHESIS. We are, it seems, a. manifestation of electric.i' energy." Those are good words, and harmonious. That the man who knows what they mean hasn't yet been born doesn t matter. Principal Trevor Owen, in his lecture at the Royal Institution, Swansea, on Monday evening, conducted a.bout thirty of the S" ansea Scientific Society into the region of primeval infinities "The Nebular Hypothesis" of how the material universe came to be—"a working hypothesis with strong probability in its favcur, and which practically explains every- thing that is known about astronomy"— was opened up to receptive minds by the professor with wonderful clearness- He be- gan with a. reference to Sir Wm. HerschelL the" real pioneer of modern astronomy, whose main lifework was to map out the heavens," a.nd conveyed much information, particularly as to the spectroscope, that nineteenth century marvel, by means of which actual knowledge though in infinitesi- mal doses, may be had about the composi- tion of sun and stars. Not the least suggestive items were the photographs of nebulae, in which, assuming the nebular hypothesis to be correct, we can see steilajr systems in all the various stages of their life. When dead, they are dark. But may be the real value of soch lectures as these is that they arouse interest and lead on one here and there to that patient, continuous study which is necessary to ap- propriate for our own mental benefit even the faint glimmerings of knowledge which modern astronomers can give as to the in- finite universe of which we ourselves, our world, and our sun are inconsequential atoms'. Mr. Pontifex, chairman, proposed a vote of thanks to the professor, seconded by Mr. H. A. Chapman, and carried.

docs.full_text: NOTICES TO CORRESPONDENTS. "ÜOURAGE.-YoU do not seem to be over- stocked with it. or you would have put your name to your communication. A few dictionary lessons would not be out of place. "CteiTic."—\ou seem to think that Pro- testantism, Roman Catholicism, Non- conformity and other sects are relig- ion. They are manifestations of religion, just as Mars or Saturn or the sun are not astronomy, but only the material for astronomy, just as a quarry, or a mine or a sea beach, or an eroded mountain side are not geology. Religion i a theory of life and existence. Th:s is only my definition. The subject is too com- plicated for full treatment in a note of this kind. "Taxiesin."—I have frequently been asked to print what appears in this column in a volume. There are several diffi- culties in the way. First, I do not think the book would sell. Second, the volume would consist of about twelve thousand pages. Third, the cost of production would be too great for me. If a. volume of five hundred pages were produced somebody would have to decde which of the twelve thousand pages should be selected and which rejected and I am no judge of the relative worthlessness of what I write. The verse I have printed would make three or four volumes! The job is altogether too big for me. "Workmhw."—You are only waking up now about workmen's houses. I had built some houses for working men in 1868 and have been more or less at the job ever since. I, at any rate, have not neglected that subject. "Voter.—It not my business to bell the cat. There are well-known ways in which you can take action.

docs.full_text: SPECTROSCOPIC ASTRONOMY. The last of the Tvndall Lectures has been delivered at the Roval Institution in London by Dr. W. Huggins, F.R.S., on the subject of the instruments and methods of spectroscopic astronomy. Con- tinning his remarks upon the telescopes used for stellar work, the lecturer described the means bv which it was possible to evade the difficulties caused by their imperfect achromatism, and mentioned the new Jena glass, which was said to be per- fectly achromatic for the whole range of the spectrum. He proceeded to speak of the variations in construction necessary according as the spectro- scope was intended for the observation of a planet or nebula, which had sensible magnitude, or of a star, which had none. A description followed of the ultra-violet spectroscope in use in the lecturer's own observatory; this had an Iceland-spar prism and quartz lenses. A number of photographs of important spectroscopic telescopes were thrown on the screen and some of their chief features shortly noticed. The progress of our knowledge of the solar spectrum wai next briefly sketched and the achievements of the chief workers mentioned. Special attention was devoted to the apparatus and results of Professor Langley, who, by means of his bolometer, had been able to map out the lines existing in the dark part of the spectrum. The publication of his charts of this invisible region, which makes up three-fourths of the whole, Dr. Huggins said, were being eagerly looked forward to, not only as a matter of academic interest, but also because they would be of importance i4 meteorological predictions.

docs.full_text: BARRY ASTRONOMICAL NOTES. The Barry Astronomical Society evi- dently means to ju/stify its existence this isesision. It is an institution formed purely in the interests of general edu- cation, its primly object, of course, Mug to promote the study of the Heavens. Latterly, the Society has somewhat broadened its basis, and lec- tures and addresses on any scientific fciibjectt are welcomed. The presenta-j tion of a large reflecting telescope, ajid the provision of aji Observatory, have Contributed largely to the success of th", Society. For the public convenience the Ob- servatory situated at the top of Ty- newydd-iroad is open oin two evenings & week, namely, Wednesday and Satur- days, from 7.30 to 9 p.m., wet evenings excepted. On these occasions two mem- liefls are in attendance, one to manipu- ia,tp the instrument whilst the other de- 1 ivers a short address on an astronomi- bal subject. The result so far has been gratifying. It is intended on these oc- casions to cover as far as possible the whole field of po-pular astronomy. On Saturday, November 6th, a short history of astronomy was given, to be followed later by a paper on The Solar System," illustrated by dia- grams prepa;rod by the members them- selves. A number of visitors have nJ- ready put in an appearance on these evenings, and splendid views of the uioon and Jupiter have been obtained. iWhen viewed through a good telescope the effects are surprising to many, Especially the moon. The old man and hits bundle of sticks give place to volcanic craters, lofty mountains, deep valleys, and spacious wastes, and a feeling of awe steals over one as one views in miniature a world of such ilesolation and solitude. Jupiter of- fnrds another most interesting subject for observation, especially in point of I kview of its satellites, four of which aM ^isifole through the telewope.-Lumm.

docs.full_text: DEATH OF THE HUSSIAN CONSUL.-Chevalier Krehmer, Russian Consul-General in this country, died suddenly on Saturday morning, at his residence in Chester Terrace, Belgravia. M. Krehmer was in perfect health and spirits on the previous evening, and his death is sup- posed to have arisen from disease of the heart. The deceased had only just attained his fifty-fourth year, Owing to the suddenness of the visitation, a coroner's inquest will be held. DEATH OF VISCOUNT ST. ViXCENT.—We have to announce the death of the venerable Viscount St. Vincent, one of the three senior members of the House Peers. His lordship expired on Sunday morning last at Meaford-hall, his seat in Staffordshire, in the 93rd year of his age. DEATH OF PKOEESSOR NICHOL.—Dr. Nichol, professor of astronomy in the Glasgow University, died on Monday afternoon from congestion of the brain. His last public appearance was on the 27th of May, in the City Hall, Glasgow, when he acted as chairman for M. Kossuth. The professor was born in 1804. His father was a bookseller in Montrose, and Mr. Nichol's first venture in life was as schoolmaster of Dun. in the neighbourhood of that town, when he was only sixteen years of He afterwards studied for the Church, and was duly licensed as a preacher. Literature and science; however, soon diverted him into a course more suitable to his faculties, Having obtained a professorship from Lord Melbourne's ministry, lie distinguished himself by his various popular works on astronomy, The Archi- tecture of the Heavens," The Solar System," "The Planetary System," "The Planet Neptune," &c.; and by" his lectures on the same class of subjects, he was the first to make the public familiar with what is called the Nebular Hypothesis."

docs.full_text: PLEASURE CRUISES TO NORWAY. Pleasure trips over to Norway are becoming more and more fashionable, and doubtless there is no more enjoyable way of spending a sum- mer's holiday. The Orient Steam Shipping Com- I pany have made arrangements for running two or three well-known ocean boats on these excur- sions during the present season—the Garonne and the Chimbovazo, both of which vessels are fitted up with every modern luxury and convenience. To assist intending tourists an admirable pamphlet containing illustrations of the Fjords and picturesque mountain scenery, for which Norway is so famous, has been written for the I use of the passengers by Lieutenant George T. j Temple, R.N., F.R.G.S., and several contribu- tions on astronomy by J. Norma.n Lockyer, Kq F.R.S., and Grenville A. J. Cole, Esq., F.R.S., on astronomy and geology respectively. Such a pamphlet, we should imagine, judging from the copy forwarded us, should be an inestimable boon to the tourist who may be comparatively ignorant of the customs, institutions, and classical history of the Land OF the Midnight Sun," for it has been well sa.id that to know what to observe, when and how to look for it, and to be able to recognise it when seen is one of the most important qualifications of the traveler." The pamphlet describes the depar- ture from Tilbury,the configuration of the climate of Norway, the various points sighted along the coast, with illustrations of Bergen, Gudvangen, the Nserodal, Meraak, Molde, Romsdal, and Raft Sund, with admirable maps of the country, in eluding a geological sketch map. Tbe pamphlet is something more than an ordinary guide book, and would well repay anyone for its perusal.

docs.full_text: In a bilingual country like Wales there is no reason why English periodicals should not have an occasional article in Welsh, for it must be understood that it is as much a literary language as English, and not the- gib- berish or jargon some of our English friends and oertain Anglicised Welshmen would have us believe. In the October number of that interesting little publica- tion, the "Cambrian Natural Observer," the organ of the Astronomical Society of Wal(, Mr. R. Kenrick, of Aberystwit.h, contributes a short article which is written in Welsh on lunar eclipses. Nir. Kenrick is an EngHshman who has actiuired a knowledge of the language, and writes it in a way that puts many a Welsh- man to shnme. His article may be cited as a proof that Welsh is capable of ex- pressing scientific thoughts, though it lacks the precision ai:d fulness of English. It is by no means the first time, however, that an astronomer has made use of Welsh, as a reference to the excellent cata- logue of the Welsh department of the Car- diff Fre;, Library will show. The late Mr. Josiah Thomas Jones, 01 Aberdare, pro- duced a very big vs y ef a'r Ddaear"—a combination of astronomy and geography—-in Welsh, and Mr. J. W. Thomas ("Arfonwyson") also brought out a small work on astronomy. Mr. Thomas was for years in the Royal Observatory, and was a very respcetable astronomer. Other scientific works might be !Ilontioncd, so that the idea that Welsh is only the lan- guage of theology and poetry is quite erroneous.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMY AT CARDIFF, LECTURE BY THE SctEV. T. E. ESPIN. SPECIALLY SET FOR THE EVENING EXPRESS. The Rev. T. E. Espin, M.A., F.R.A.S. (direc- tor of Wolsingliam Observatory, Durham) paid a v it to Cardiff on Tuesday, and delivered a lantern address before the Astronomical Society of Wales. Thcve was an appreciative audience at the Higher-grade School, over which Mr. James Waugh, M.A., presided. Letters of ajxjlogy for unavoidable non-atten- dance were received from the lie v. Canoa Thompson, Mr. J. Tatham Thompson 'president Cardiff Naturalists' Society), Signor Conta (Newport), &c. Mr. Espin's address dealt plea- santly with his observatory and its work, which, by the way, is entirely in the realms of sidereal astronomy. The history of the observatory was outlined, and then a series of slides shown deal- ing with discoveries among coloured and variable stars and stellir spectra. Mr. Espin held the close attention of his audience from first to last, but the interest was specially intense when he referred to an observation made a few nights back of an obscuring medium in R.A. 4h. 26m., N. Dec. 500 44". The actual existence of this remarkable phenomenon has been abundantly confirmed. After the lecture a number of ques- tions were asked and answered, the participants being Miss Rule, the Pev. W. E. Winks, Mr. G. A. S. Atkinson, B.Sc., Mr. Norman Lattey, and Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S. A hearty vote of thanks to Mr. Espin was moved by Mr. Mee, who spoke of the honour conferred on the society and on Cardiff by the visit of Mr..Espin, whose name was a familiar and honoured one through- out the scientific world. The Rev. W. E. Winks seconded in a giaceful speech, and the motion was carefully adopted. The lantern was manipulated by Mr. G. A. Banting. Mr. Espin, daring his stay at Cardiff, was the guest of the Rev. W. E. Winks.

docs.full_text: DEATH OF AN EMINENT ARTIST. SENOR LUIS FALERO PASSES AWAY IN LONDON. All Cardiffiiang who are lovers of art will learn with great regret of the decease of Senor Luis Frt-lero, whose admirable pictures created a sensation when exhibited «ime time ago in the Welsh metropolis. Whrn Senor Falero's "Nightmare" was shown here, there was a pleasant gathering of local Bohemians, aaid) the distinguished artist was feted, and made a pleasant speech. More recently several ex- ouisite nude studies from Senor Falero's brush I were shown at the Cardiff Exhibition. The "Times" of Wednesday says:—The Spanish painter, Senor Luis Falero, died last Monday in the University College Hospital, at the age of 45. A fortnight ago he was removed from his house in Fellows-road to the hospital to undergo a serious internal ope- ration. The operation was successful, but a relapse occurred last week. Throughout his illness hiis wife, who was an Italian lady, nursed him at the hospital. Senor Falero was a native of Toledo. He resided for some time in Paris, but came to London eeveral years ago, and took up his permanent abode here. Among his numerous works many be mentioned 'Double StaTS," "Le Cauchemar," "Marriage of a Comet," "The Dream of Faust." and I "Unto a Better World." Many of his pic- tiires, 'nost of which have been reproduced, are in the United States, and especially in New York. He was very learned and particu- larly well versed in astronomy. Flammarion's Popular Works on Astronomy are adorned by Seror Falero's illustrations- He made a con- siderable reputation by allegorical pictures of the star He exhibited frequently at. the Royal .Academy.
