docs.full_text: ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY OF WALES. The adjourned annual meeting of the Astronomical Soc*pty of Wales was held at Captain Jutsum's Nautical Academy, St. Mary- street. Cardiff, on Wednesday evening, the President rMr. James Waugh. M.A.) in the chair. Letters of apology for non-attendance were read from Miss Hagerty (the hon. sec- retary), Mr. J. Glenelg Grant, and the Rev. W. E. Winks.—The Treasurer (Mr. Charles M. Heus- man. Lloyds Bank. Penr.rth) presented his annual statement.—TI12 Secretary's report showed an increase in membership, and spoke of the more general recognition of the society's work. Some twenty-live associates, members, and correspondents had contributed to the journal ("The Cambrian Natural Observer") during the year on various matters connected with telescopic, photographic, and naked eye observation, a? well os meteorology. The society's library had been placed under the care of the Cardiff Free Library, as iti fh-i case of the collections of the Cardiff Naturalists and other bodies, and the works would, therefore, be more easily avitilabl^ for reference by the meiiiberia and (under certain restrictions) by the general public. After the adoption of the reports the meeting: proceeded to the discussion of the various accounts received of the Leonids, the lunar eclipse Dec. 16. the brilliant meteor Jan. 4. &c. Eight new members were elected. Papers were arranged for on "Biblical Astronomy," by Mr. A. A. Williams; "Taking the Moon's Likeness," by Mr. Mee: "The Chemistry of Meteors." by Miss Hagerty; "The Astronomy of ,Milton;" by the Rev. J. Waugh, Ac. Mr. Wil- liams showed a beautiful globe of Mars, which he had constructed himself, and photographs of. the lunar eclipse by Messrs. Wiliiam3 and George A. S. Atkinson were exhibited. An album of photographs and drawings by mem- bers and associates was also placed upon the table.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY OF WALES. The Rev. W. E. Winks, F.E.A.S., read a charming paper before the Astronomical Society of Wales at the Y.M.CA.. on Wednes- day evening; subject. "How I began to take an interest in astronomy." Mr. Norman juattey, the society's president, occupied the chair. At the outset there was some couversa- ^ejecent sun-pillar," in which the President, Messrs. Winks, G. Caralake lTiomp- Atkinson, and Arthur Mee took Part. The phenomenon had been reported by members of the society at Cardiff a ewport, and Llanelly. Mr. Winks' reminis- cences were related with much quiet humour, which the audience greatly enjoyed. He said he received his first astronomical lesson from his mother when a very little boy. Later on, in 1858, he made sketches a j ?J«ervations of Donati's comet, n i j t* them still. He strongly advised beginners to read all the works on astronomy they could, and to observe with the naked eye and thereby gain general familiarity with the heavens. Then when they ca^ne to purchase a telescope they would be in a position to properly appreciate the instrument. Mr. Winks' paper rendered his audience reminiscent, and the President told how as a boy in India his mother had pointed out to him Orion in all his glory; and Mr. Mee related his first astronomical experience when in 1866 his mother (who, he rejoiced to say. was still spared, and a member of the society) roused him from sleep to see the great star-shower of that year. Mr. Carslake Thompson also had some interesting memories, mainly of the comets of the fifties. He seconded Mr. Mee's motion that a hearty vote of thanks be accorded Mr. Winks for his delightful paper. Mr. Winks had brought to the meeting a beautiful little Dollond telescope, and Mr. E. T. Pritchard showed a small instrument which he had constructed himself, and which was examined with much interest by the members.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY OF WALES. The Astonomical Society of Wales opened its session oil Thursday evening. when the members were received at the residence of the president-elect, Mr. James Waugh, M.A., New. port-road, Cardiff. The following officers, Ac., were elected:—President, Mr. Waugh; vice-pre- sidents, Mr. Carslake Thompson and Professor Tanner; librarian, Mr. George A. S. Atkinson; editor, Mr. Arthur Mee; secretary, Miss Graham Hagarty; treasurer, Mr. C. M. Hensman; other members of the council, the Rev. W. E. Winks, Messrs. N. Lattey, D. B. W. Powei, D. Conta (NeNvport), and A. A. Williams. A hearty vote of thanks was accorded the retir- ing president (Mr. Carslake Thompson) for his valuable services during the past two years, on the motion of Mr. Atkinson, seconded by Mr. Williams. Arrangements were made for a series of monthly meetings and short ad. dresses, promised by the following:—Mr. Thompson, Tho Leonids of 1899; Ur. iiee, "How Big Does tlhe Moon Look?"; Mr. A. A. Williams, "Biblical Astronomy"; Iliss Hagertv, "Meteorites, Their ChemicaJ Composition"; the president, "The Astronomy of Milton"; The transference of the society's books to the care of the Free Library was discussed, ani a committee formed to close the matter. It was mentioned in the course of the meeting, with regret, that, after seeking tlhe advice of two members of the society, the Cardiff Town Council had gone directly counter to guch in its selection of a final site for the Franlclen Evans telescope, viz, the southern end of Cathays Park, where the instrument would be a mere peep-show, and its full powers never available.

docs.full_text: I STUDY OF ASTRONOMY SIMPLIFIED. I In an age when so much is talked and written about the value of education and its elevating influence, it seems hard to explain why so little attention is given to astronomy. Of all branches of secular instruction astronomy is surely the most sublime and elevating, and in the very nature of things it ought to have a special attraction for all who value knowledge for its own sake. No doubt, one explanation of the comparative neglect of astronomical studies is that they have not a high com- mercial value, and that in this commercial country youths or men who value knowledge for its own sake are in a very decided minority. We are inclined to believe, however, that this fascinating study would be much more generally taken up than it is were it not for a pre- vailing impression that no knowledge of astronomy worth having can be picked up without interminable re- search, enormously-expensive instruments, and special opportunities for investigating peculiar celestial phenomena. If it were commonly known what an amount of marvellous and interesting knowledge an attentive observer can acquire by the aid of the naked eye, and how largely that can be supplemented by the help of a cheap glass, even an opera glass, there would soon, probably, be ten times as many amateur astronomers as are now to be found amongst us. It is a slow and difficult task to persuade the public that the study of astronomy is not only a delightful pursuit, but also one open, in a large degree, to almost every moderately-educated man with eyes in his head. Of all who have endeavoured to popularise this delightful science, and interest young men in its cultivation, we do not know one who has laboured more disinterestedly, or who deserves greater credit, than Mr Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S., Cardiff, formerly of Llanelly. In addition to his writings in the Western Mail, his lectures before young men's societies, and other work of that nature, he has published some concise treatises, including" Ob- servational Astronomy," which must have removed mountains of difficulty from the path of would-be students. His latest booklet, the smallest and cheapest of the lot-it is only 3 £ d.—will probably do more than all the rest to multiply the number of star-gazers. This little work, which is named Observation without Instruments Hints for Young Watchers of the Heavens," is a rare compendium of information, advice, and suggestiveness. There is, in the form of frontispiece, a very striking "Naked-eye study of the full moon," reproduced from the celebrated drawings by Eugene Antoniadi, of Paris: and this is followed by a series of chatty, simple, and untechnical paragraphs on The Points of the Compass," Apparent Movements of the Heavens," "Day and Night-The Seasons." The chapter on "The Constellations" is a model of simplicity and brevity. A fifth-form elementary school- boy who reads it carefully should acquire the will and the power to make himself intelligently familiar with the aspect of the heavens and the more notable changes which come over it through the diurnal and annual motions of the earth. It is a great deal if one can only name and point out the principal constellations, and stars of the first magnitude, and this will be easy for every sensible reader of the chapter to which we are referring. The other chapters, which are as pithy, comprehensive, and instructive as the foregoing, deal with Stars, Clusters, and Nebulce," "The Sun," "The Moon," The Planets (what an amount of information about them in less than sixty lines !), Meteors and Comets," "Eclipses, Conjunctions, &c," "Meteorology," and Note on Small Instruments. We should like to see this little book widely circulated, especially as those who once read it will be sure to treasure it. Anyone who doubts this can judge for themselves by expending the small sum of 3id. We observe that the printers are Messrs Lennox Brothers, West Bute-street, Cardiff, but copies may be had direct, and post free, from the author, Mr Arthur Mee, Tremynfa, Llanishen, near Cardiff.

docs.full_text: WELSH ASTRONOMERS. INFORMING LECTURE BY MR. ARTHUR MEE. I Mr. Arthur Mee delighted a large number of the members of the Cardiff Cynunrodorion I on Friday evening with an illustrated lecture on Welsh Astronomers." Mr. Mee said that, despite such note- worthy names as Principal Griffiths, Sir William Preece, and the late Richard Roberts, the great inventor, science wag not the Welshman's forte, the bent of his mind lying rather in the direction of religion, poetry, and metaphysics. Still, Wales had done something for astronomy, as he hoped to show. The recent study of Stonehenge a.nd other ancient monuments raised by our anoestors long centuries before Christ had oonvinced Sir Norman Lockyer that they were built with astronomical intent; and the speaker believed that the attainments of the anoient Britons both lD astronomy and astrology went even beyond the lines marked out by Sir Norman. One of the greatest names on the bead-roll of Welsh science was that of Robert Re-corde, a native of Tenby, who died in 1558, who was the first man in this country to embrace the Ooper- nioan system, the first to introduce algebra into England, and the first English writer on arithmetic, geometry, and astronomy. In the early years of the seventeenth century Slir William Lower and John Protheroe were in Cairmarthenshire making telescopic obser- vations contemporary with those of' Galileo himself. The eighteenth century produced a number of Welsh astronomers and mathematicians, including Rittenhouse, the American philoso- pher, who was of Welsh extraction. At the same time, there were lowly, but earnest, observers like Norbury and others at Mer- thyr, whose story had been so well told by Mr. Charles Wilkina. After referring to the former connection with Cardiff of those dis- tinguished astronomers, Admiral Smyth and the Rev. T. W. Wehb, and to the long scientific reoord of the Penllergaer family, Mir. Mee dealt with Afonwyson and other Welsh assistants at Greenwich, and then referred in turn to Mr. Eleazar Roberts, old John Jones, the working man scientist, of Bangor, and the late Dr. Isaac Roberts, tha.t great pioneer in the realm of celestial photog- raphy. The lecturer spoke of the Astrono- mical Society of Wales (of which he was the prinoipal founder) and the workers more or less closely identified with it. such as Arch- deacon Broce, the Rev. W. E. Winks, General Lee, Mr. T. E. Heath, the late Mr. Carslake Thompson, the late Mr. A. A. Wil- liams, the late Dr. Franklen Evans, Mr. Albert Taylor, Mr. Norman Lattey, Mr. Taliesin Jenkins, Mr. Ernest Madge, Miss Hagerty, and many others. Various por- traits and pictures of instruments were thrown upon the screen; also some of the pplendid celestial photographs secured by Dr. Isaac Roberts, who, it was mentioned, had remembered his fatherland in a prac- tical way by leaving a princely sum to be divided between the University Colleges of Cardiff, Bangor, and Liverpool. In proposing a vote of thanks to Mr. Mee. Dr. Prichard, vice-president of the society, referred to him as the most versatile mem- ber of the society, and incidentally suggested that Mr. Mee should paiblish in book form tihe poetical sketches which appear froan time to time, in "Wales Day by Day" in the Western Mail."

docs.full_text: THE APPROACHING TRANSIT OF MERCURY. Mr. H. H. Turner, Savilian Professor of Astronomy at Oxford, wrote last week to the papers pointing out the present facilities for proceeding to America should any enthusiastic astronomical amateurs desire to do so in order to observe the transit of the planet Mercury over the sun's disc which will occur on the 10th of November next, but can be seen only very partially in this country, as the sun will set at Green- wich little more than a quarter of an hour after the Shenomenon has commenced. It will (observes Mr. V. T. Lynn, B.A., F.R.A.S., writing intheifcAo) be 10 years before another occurs, and it may be of interest to recall to mind those which took place when telescopic astronomy was in its infancy. The first ever seen was predicted by the illustrious Kepler w about to take place on the 7th of November, 1631, and was observed by Gassendi at Pai is, though the Sun was from time to time obscured by clouds which effectually prevented the Professor of Astronomy at Amsterdam from seeing it at all. Kepler himself had been gathered to his fathers the year before. He had predicted, also, a transit of Venus, to take place about a month after that of Mercury, which was not seen, as it occurred whilst it was night in Europe. One which took place eight years afterwards was, as is well known, observed by Horrox and his friend Crabtree in Lancashire. Those of Mercury occur more frequently on the whole, but the next after 1631 was in 1644, and could not be seen. The next was due on the 3rd November, 1651, and an enthusiastic young Englishman named Jeremiah Shakerley, finding it could not be seen in Europe, travelled to Surat in India for the purpose of seeing it. Nearly 10 years later, on the 3rd of May, 1661, another took place, which was partially observed by several astronomers, both England and on the Continent. But the first, which was watched all through from be- ginning to end, was that of the 7th of November. 1677, observed by Halley (who, more than 40 years afterwards, became the second Astronomer Royal in succession to Flamsteed) at St. Helena, whither he had gone to observe the stars of the Southern Hemi- sphere. It was this observation which led him to suggest those of future transits of Venus as the best means of determining the distance of the Sun; that planet coming on those occasions very much nearer ua than any other. This does not apply to Mercury, which when nearest is more than double the distance of Venus in the same position the phenomenon, however, is of considerable interest in itself, so that the position of that of November 10 next, visible in this country (just before sunset) will be eagerly looked for by those possessed of moderate telescopes, and in America, in places where the sky is clear, an oppor- tunity will be afforded of witnessing the whole.

FAILURES IN NORTH WALKS.-Public Examma- tions.—Tuesday, 6th November, at the County Hall Wrexham, David Roberts, Tymawr-penygaer, Llan- fihangel G.M., Corwen, farmer, Benjamin J Dodd, Y Faelfa, Rhos Ruabon, boot dealer and draper, John Edward Joseph Davies, Tyn y pant, Cerngy- druidion, farmer and medical assistant. CHURCH HISTORY.—Continuing the course, on Tuesday evening, the class discussed the period and events which led up to the reformation, the president shewing from the text book and other sources that the reformation was not the act of of Henry VI LIt but was the outcome of the feel- ing and wish of the people and of the church, as shown by the action of Convocation, and that Henry was only one actor, and by no means the chief in the great events that transpired. The reformation on the Continent, originated by Calvin and others, was touched npon, and its bearing and influence on the English Church considered. Next week s discussion will be on the suppression of the monasteries and the results. DJSATR OF A CLFKGTMAN.—The Kev John Myddelton Evans, M.A., of Exeter Collego, Oxford, youngest Bon of the late T Evans. Eiq., solicitor, Denbigh, dud at Linwood, Torquay, on the 25th day of October, 1888, aged 51. He was at one time curate to Archdeacon Boyd, of Ripon, and afterwards vicar of Esholt, near Shipley, Yorkshire, which living he recently resigned from ill health. He married hie cousia, Miss Anne Jane Keaisley (half sister to Mrs H R Marsden, Castle House); and leaves a widow and three daughist s. He was an i.,ueleto Mr J Parry Jones, town clerk. It may be mentioned as an interest- ing fact that he preachcd his first sermon in St David's Church, in Denbigh. He was buried yesterday at Torquay. ASTRONOMY.—ON Friday evening, at the Town Hall, the first of the series of lectures on Astronomy, to be given by Professor Gray of I Bangor Cellege: during the winter months, took place. there being a large audience, this lecture being free- Dr J Lloyd Roberts presided and suitably introduced the lecturer. He also re- e ~a in the previous courses of lectures held in S ?rtLn shewed that as compared with the the town,the c0)lege lecturers in other townTthose at Denbigh compared most faVour- Rblv a8 regards attendance and general success. Be then touched upon the subject of astronomy, arging that it would be useful to many m^ds as helping them the better to unuerstand tne great ness of the Creator, and would tend to strengthen their faith in Divine things. There was no reason whatever why science should be regarded as antagonistic to religion, but rather properly understood it tended to prove and uphold religious faith and teaching. Professor Gray then pro- ceeded wjth his lecture, giving introductory particulars as to the early systems and beliefs with regard to the heavenly bodies. He gave particulars as to the better know of these and their relative action on each other. His lecture was well illustrated by dissolving views, and this system of illustration will be adopted throughout the course.

docs.full_text: LORD AND LADY POLTIMORE have arrived at Nice, where they will stay till the beginning of May. A YOUNG American gentleman, named Bacon, has met with his death at Ventnor under somewhat exceptional circumstances. He and his father on Friday of last week had been for a long ride, and, while leisurely descending a hill, the youth's pony stumbled, pitching the rider head foremost to the ground. He was conveyed home insensible, and four doctors were brought into consultation, including Dr. Victor Horsley, specially summoned from London, who performed an operation, but death ensued from fracture of the skull and compression of the brain. TH. enormous increase of the rates and taxes paid by railway companies is attracting attention. One railway, which used to pay JE62,000 in the half-year, has for the last six months paid no less than £ 101,438. The increase is, of course, almost exclusively in the local rates. SIR ROBERT STAWSLL BALL, who has just been appointed Professor of Astronomy at Cambridge, is every inch an Irishman-his dark hair and eyes, his mobile cheeks, full rich voice, and ready talk. He was born in Dublin just 51 years ago, and early in life devoted himself to scientific studies. He was edu- cated at Trinity College, Dublin, and when 25 years of age was appointed Lord Rosse's astronomer at Parsonstown. In this post he very soon distinguished himself, and honours followed. In 1867 he became Professor of Applied Mathemathics and Mechanism at the Royal "College of Science of Ireland; he was made a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1873, and the degree of LL.D. was conferred upon him by the Dublin University, and the following year he was appointed by that University Professor of Astronomy, with the office of Astronomer Royal for Ireland. He was knighted in 1886. He has written severe ) popular treatises, and many magazine articles on astronomy, and has lectured on a hundred popular platforms, expounding the wonders of the heavens i to the common people of the earth. Every year Sff* R. Ball lectures at Cambridge for two months with- out missing a single night, and as his lecture fee is 20 guineas, the addition to his income is by w, means inconsiderable. It remains to be men whether he will continue this work as a Cambridge professor. The feeling in Cambridge is, on the whole, one of disappointment at his selection. There is a perma- nent objection to a professor not a Cambridge man, and though Sir Robert Ball will be welcomed per- sonally, at the risk of being considered ungracious, it is hardly too much to say that Cambridge men would have prefered one of their own number —Pall Mall Gazette. LADY HENRY SOMERSET, when she was in New York, drew a startling picture of drunkenness in England among women and working men, which conveyed an impression that the evil was greater in England than in America. By such as are acquainted with the slums of London and those of New York, and who also understand the wide difference between a working man and a loafer, her ladyship s remarks were considered incorrect and indiscreet. According to a recent speech, we are told she is sorrowfully amazed at the poverty to be found in New York, and the condition of its slums! Lady Henry Somerset also describes "homes in America equal in wretched- ness to the dens of East London! If foreign travellers visiting New York and other large cities in the United States would dive beneath the surface by visiting tenement houses, prisons, and asylums before painting their own country red, it would be better for what American politicians are pleased to tt-r the "pauper labour of Europe.Sheffield Independent.

docs.full_text: LLANGOLLEN SCIENCE LECTURES OPTICS AND ASTRONOMY. The sixth lecture, the last of the course, in connection with the above was delivered by Mr. E. B. H. Wade. B.A., in the Assembly Room, Llan- gollen, on the 8th inst. It dealt with the pro- gress of Optics and Astronomy in the Nineteenth Century. This century, he said, has seen the wave theory of light firmly established, in spite of the great reputation obtained by the rival theory of Isaac Newton. The success of the former theory is a result of Young's discovery of the principle of interference by which two waves may extin- guish each other as often as the crest of one concides with the trough of another. Starting with this idea, Young succeeded in making two streams of light conflict in such a way as to pro- duce darkness, and under circumstances which left no doubt that the cause of darkness was the meeting of crest and trough. The difficulty that light, unlike other wave motions such as sound, travels in very accurate straight lines, was removed by an appeal to the same principle of interference. Fresnel develeped the theory very ably, and from his study of the phenomena of polarization observed when light travels through Iceland Spar, came to very definite conclusions as to the form of the luminous wave. In the case of sound we have a pulsating movement to and fro along the line of' advance of the sound, a movement which can only in a scientific sense be described as a wave. But in light the waves are supposed to be across the direction of advance, like sea waves, except that sea waves move only in the vertical plane, while waves of ordinary light are not confined to any particular plane. The peculiar form of light known as polarized light, however, is characterised by waves moving in one plane only. One of the most important advances made in the century in connection with both Optics and Astronomy is the development of Newton's lustre experiment culmin- ating in the modern spectroscope. It is found that when the light from any substance (say common salt heated in a spirit flame) is filtered through the prism suitably adjusted, it takes up a definite place in the spectrum, and no other sub- stance has the power to emit light which will oacupy the same place in the spectrum. We have thus a delicate test for common salt and other substances in the position which their light occupies in the spectrum. We can assert that the yellow light of a gas lamp is due to other things than common salt, for it sends yellow to other parts of the spectrum. The last enables us to assert that the sun and stars are composed in the main of substances with which we are already acquainted with on earth. The spectra emitted by burning magnesium, were shown by a spirit lamp with salted wick, and by various pyrotechnic combinations, which were thrown on the screen at the close of the lecture.

For the last two or three weeks lectures have been de- livered for the benefit of this institution, upon various sub- jects, by the different clergy o! the town. On Thursday evening, the Oth inst., a lecture (which we hope is the first of a course) was given hy Air. Howe1!s. t:i:or. on ,nJticaIAstr()lIo!uy." Mr. H o wells is certain I y deserving (If commendation for thus breaking the ice and giving encouragement to other art! ;is of the town to follow his example. In a inaritime place like Milford lectures delivered on Nautical Astronomy. &c., are of incalculable benefit to the seaman, especially the young sailor; and it was with im- pressions of this natu'-e that we visited the lecture-room, hoping to have our darkness enligh.eiied by bearing and being shewn the conncction arid importance existing bet wen x the knowledge of astronomy and the navigation of a ship; but, we must confess, that in this we were disappointed, for beyond a description of the signs of the zodiac, and a few abstruse remarks upon some 01 the planetary bodies, the lecture was wound up by facetious anecdotes. VVe are, how- ever, in hopes, now that Mr. Howells has got over his virgin lecture, to hear him explain in a future lecture the benefits derivable from a knowledge of astronomy in navigating ships, and in what manner thev are connected. We flatter our- selves that Mr. H. is competent to the task. We cannot close our brief remarks without referring to the unenviable position of the Chairman during the evening, and the lorcible manner in which we were struck with his simi- larity of appearance to that of a bashful and crest-fallen schoolboy. We have heard that "the chair cannot nr," such generaUy may be the case, but, in this instance, our chaii, who had evidently forgot his position, was not breathing his own atmosphere, for his looks bespoke unutter- abtethings. W e really felt very serry for his predicament, ,tllll would have rendered him assistance had we been able. Upon a vote ol taanks being proposed and seconded for his efficient services, tongue and bl'.Ù1 had forgot th"ir office, ex- h hr ti lift our homo for the space of five or ten minutes before that auditory over whom he presided a monumental statue of a cadaverous expression. The risible propensities of the assembly could no longer be suppressed, amidst the cheers of which an evolution of thanks came from the chair of an expression of the pleasure it would give him to see the •'speech" in print. After this oration a graceful reticade movement again placed the "chair" upon his throne,"and thus was terminated this ludhrous scene. On Thursday evening next the Bev. Mr. Liovd will de- liver a lecture on "The tendencies of the cheap literature of the day to elevate the masses of the people." docs.full_text: B-KETCH OF THE ARCH DRUID. (3Y ItlOiilEN.) Those who have the pleasure of knowing Myfyr Morganwg, Pontypridd, who ia the present Gwyddcn, the generic name of the chief priest of ancient Bardism, from a period eo remote that in comparison with it the arrival of Julius Csmar in Britain is but a modern incident, admit that he IS the most interesting character now dwallia.? within the circuit of the four seas. He is, alas! very old; 80 winters have now passed over hia venerable head, leaving hia hair and flowing beard aa white as wool. Even in boyhood he was regarded as remarkable. Aged people tell me that when he was a youth at home, watching his father's flocks on the slopes of Mynydd y Gaer, above Pencoed, his remarkable characteristics were discussed in the then thinly populated hamlets of Glamorganshire, and it appears that his earliest studies were mathematics and astronomy. It will be hardly credited, but it is nevertheless perfectly trua, that, dwelling in a farm he use in a remote Welah district, where English was but rarely heard, he mastered the I4 nglish grammar without the aid of a tutor. And this acquired knowledge served as a key to enable him to unlook the treasures of English literature. lie then mastered Euclid, passing over Pons Asinorum without any pedagogic assistance, revelling in Bolitude among the problems of the Greek SAGE, for he stateB that this study was a source of infinite enjoyment to him. The movements of the planets early attracted his notice, ard a penny almanack, which his father bad bought at Bridgond, afforded him delight as supplying a key to understand the movements of the heavenly shining orbs. When only 18 years of age he had suiffciently mastered astronomy as to be able to COMVJOSE an almanack from his own calculations, and this almanack is still in existence in manuscript. A cantury hence, when this extraordinary Welshman's oouutrym-n will have sufficiently advanced to be able to JI appreciate hia publisher; works explaining the old philosophy of the British Druids, to whosn, according fo the lcv. D:. Stukeley, the Pytha- geieans, Platonists, and Greek philosophers letrncd tbe beat things they knew," the Webh lad's almanack, as well as some other relios of that period in his career, will be as highly prized as the SimkeBperian manuscripts illustrating the studies of the immortal Bard of Avon during his early loutb, that profoundly interesting period before his intreduction in tho parlour of Charlecott to Sir Thomas Lncy as an offender against the gataa laws. The old bard'a mind continues as active aa when the problems of Euclid were his pastime, and the study of astronomy was his delight. In politics Lord Beaconsfield is hia favourite loader, During the Turko-Russian war "the divine figure from the North" was, iu his eyee, 30 seoond Moloch; or, to employ a Druidical figure, the reprt Bontative of Avagddu. and every movement cn the part of the British Cabinet, intended all obstacles in the way of the march of Russia, towards the Bosphorus, was viewed by him with much satisfaction.

docs.full_text: Ctub and Society Gossip. A MUSIC-HALL SINGER'S SALARY. Yvette Guilbert, the Parisian music-hall singer, earns £10,000 a year. it JE200 A CONCERT. M. Paderewski, the pianist, is receiving L200 a concert in the United States, and his entre- preneurs are understood to be earning a large profit by bis recitals. LORD BLANDFORD. Young Lord Blandford, in behalf of whom the application was made on Tuesday to compel the Duke of Marlborough to contribute towards his support, is at present being educated at Cambridge. He will be 21 on November 13 of this year. He is a pale, weak-looking young man'of quiet habits and some promise. MR. DE COBAIN. Mr. De Cobain is (eays the Star) remarkable in appearance; he is medium-sized, stout even to corpulence, brown, sandy hair scrupulously divided at the middle of his head, brown eyes, slight whiskers, and sallow complexion. He always wore in the House a double-breasted frock coat, which was invariably closely buttoned, and he never, either winter or summer, was without a white carnation in his breast, which was quite as conspicuous as Mr. Chamberlain's now forsaken orchid. LITERARY TEAS." While English ladies of birth and breeding are acquainting themselves with the refinements of music-hall entertainments, aristocratic German ladies are indulging in literary teas," for which there is quite a rage just now. It is to be hoped, however, that this intellectual form of dissipation will not become too madly popular over here, as the prospect of having to discuss muffins and Ibsen at the same time is appalling. Our German sisters have at least the most delicious confectionery in the world (home-made, by-the-bye) with which to cheer themselves up. DOCTORS AND LITERARY MEN. Mr. James Payn, in his letter to the New York Independent, complains jthat the bull's eye of the surgeon is now being turned on the literary man. "The American physicians have begun it. 'The literary worker,' they eay, 'should take a light breakfast, nothing at noon, and the evening meal when his work is done.' Worse advice to any one who knows the real demands of literary work it is impossible to conceive; but the futility of any advice at all on such a subject is obvious. There is nothing in which men's minds vary so much as in the conditions they find favourable for literary composition. Some write like Thackeray, by fits and starts, some like Trollope, with the regularity of clockwork. some by day, some by night, some fasting, some exhilarated by gin-and-water (like Byron), some stimulated by tobacco (like Tennyson); there is no sort of rule for general guidance." SIR ROBERT BALL. Sir Robert Stawell Ball, who has just been appointed professor of astronomy at Cambridge, is (the Pall Mall Gazette declares) every inch an Irishman—his dark hair and eyes, his mobile cheeks, full rich voice, and ready talk. He was born in Dublin iu«t fifty-one years ago, and early hn lii miself to scientific studies. He was educated at lnnity College,and when twenty- five years of age was appointed Lord Rosse's astronomer at Parsons- town. In this post he very soon distinguished himself, and honours fol- lowed. In 1867 he be- came professor of applied ii ;i t h e mati c s and chrism at the Royal liege of Science of Ire- tid; he was made a Fallow of the Koyal Society in 1873, and the degree of LL.D. was con- ferred upon him by the Dublin University, and th- io ■. -a year he was appointed by that univer itv professor of astronomy, with the office of Astronomer Royal for Ireland. He was knighted in 1886. He has written several popular treatises, and many magazine articles, on astronomy, and has lectured on a hundred popular platforms, ex- pounding the wonders of the heavens to the common people of the earth.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMY WITHOUT A TELESCOPE. Mr. Maunder, of th Royal Observatory, Greenwich, continues his helpful series of popular articles on "Astronomy without a Telescope," in the April issue of Know- ledge." Dealing with the Northern Stars, Mr. Maunder says: "To us in England, with our high northern latitude, the stars which never set are the first the study of which we should undertake. They are, al- ways present, they cover more than one- third of the entire sky visible to us at anv moment. They include many conspicuous ttars, and form an admirable guide to the constellations beyond the circumpolar re- gion. Constantly revolving round the pole they fcrm, as it were, a magnificent dial plate, marking at the same time the progress both of the night and of the year. ATHE chief guiding stars for the northern heavens aro the well-known Plough, the scarcely less distinctive little W of Cassicpeia on the op- posite side of the Pole, and the two great brilliants between them on the right hand and on the left, Capella and Vega. All these are continually visible for Scotland and the North of England; for the southern part of our island Vega is lost for a short time when due north." The writer does not dis- dain the poet's aid, by whom Polaris is figured thus:- "Where yonder radiant hosts adorn The northern evening sky, Seven stars a splendid glorious train First fix the wandering eye. To deck great Ursa'3 shaggy form Those brilliant orbs combine And where the first and second part There see Polaris shine. Between the two bears it is easy to trace out the irregular winding line of fairly bright stars. This is the Dragon the Serpent of the following lines from Aratus — et Between these two, liko to a river s branch, A mightv prodigy, the Serpent twines Its bending vast around; on either side His coil they move and shun the dark blue eea • But o'er the cne his lengthy tail is stretched, The other's wrapped in coIl..

docs.full_text: 44 ROBERT RECORDE, The first original writer on arithmetic in English -the first on geometry—the first who introduced the knowledge of algebra into England—the first writer on astronomy in English-the first person in this country who adopted the Copernican system -the inventor of the present method of extracting the square root—the inventor of the sign of equality-the inventor of the method of extracting the square root of multinomial algebraic quanti- ties-of these claimants for fame and the respect of posterity, unite in Robert Recorde physician to Queen Mary, a native of Tenby, in Pembroke- shire, and a man whose memory deserves a much larger portion of fame than it has hitherto met with.Connection of Wales with the Early Science of England, by James Orchard Halliwell, p. 5. Wood writes-H Robert Recorde drew his first breath among the Cambrians, but in what county I cannot find. The Ha MSS., 6250, agrees with Halliwell in fixing Tenby as his native place." -11 It is melancholy to reflect," adds Halliwell, that so much genius and learning should have been subjected to the baneful influence of poverty and imprisonment." Recorde died in extreme penury. The following quaint specimen of his writings, extracted from one of his medical works, may not be unacceptable to the reader,-like the bards of his native country, he conveved his multifarious information to the public through the medium of verse:- "A fox in craftiness exceedeth most men, A dog in smelling hath no man his peer; To foresight of weather, if you look then, Many beasts excel man-this is clear. The wittiness of elephants doth letters attain, And what cunning doth there in the bee remain! The nightingale, the linnet, the thrush, the lark In musical harmony pass many a clerk. The hedgehog of astronomy seemeth to know, And stoppeth his cave when the wind doth blow; The spider in weaving such art doth show, No man can him mend or follow I trow; When a house will fall the mice right quick Flee thence before man can do the like."

docs.full_text: SUDDEN DEATH.-Thomas Thomas, a miner, in the prime of life, died very suddenly on Wednesday last. He lodged with Thomas Yaughan, at Lwydcoed, with whom he quarrelled on the previous evening, and left the house, being at the time in a state of intoxication. On the following morning ha was found in a field not far distant, dangerously ill. He was immediately taken home, and expired a few hours, afterwards. ACCIDENTS.—On the evening of Monday last, John Evans met with an accident while at his- work, at Bwllfa- dare colliery, by which his thigh and arm were both broken. The poor fellow was conveyed home without delay, in the most intense agony but under the care of his medical attendant he is progressing as favourably as the circumstances of the case will admit. On the following day, Evan Thomas, a miner, living at Llwydcoed, broke hi3 thigh by a fall of coal, but we are glad to add that he is in a fair way for recovery. LECTURE AT SALEM CHAPEL.—A lecture was recently delivered in the above chapel, by the R. Wm. Rees, of Liverpool, in Welsh, on the Inquiries of the human mind into the works of God." The rev. lecturer, after a few and appropriate remarks on the works of God in general, confined himself to the investigation of the human mind in one particular direction, viz., astronomy. Having made some interesting observations, showing the importance of this exhaustless subject, he went on to prove from the examples of Job, David, Amos, &c., that the study of the heavens was not only prompted by reason, but also authorised by Scripture. He then pro- ceeded to trace the history of astronomy, which he di- vided into three periods. The first period was the anti- historical, in which man discovered the causes of the eclipses of the sun and moon—the spherical form of the earth &c The second period embraced the fruitless endeavours of the sages of Greece and the scholars of Alexandria, to explain the revolutions of the orbs of Heaven, on the supposition that the earth was the centre planet. The third was the modern period, which con- tains the researches of Copernicus, Galileo, Kepler, and Newton. It is, however, impossible to give an adequate idea of the lecture in a short summary. The rev. lec- 1 turer evinced a thorough knowledge of the subject, lie was happy in his illustrations and not only made him- I self understood by a mixed audience, but even succeedea I in making his lecture popular, and in the highest degree I interesting. The lecture gave general satisfaction and we were happy to see the spacious chapel well filled.

docs.full_text: STAR-LIT SKIES-MARCH. Mercury is a morning star this month, and Venus is gaining in brilliancy and is conspicuous in the western sky towards the end of the month up to nearly II p.m. Mars is still visible, and Jupiter is with us from sunset until early dawn. Saturn is in conjunction with the Sun on the 20tb, and afterwards becomes a morning star. His rings are still closed. Of the stars, Arcturus has made his appearance in the E. The handle of the plough points to him. Capella is in N.W., and Vega, which is circum- polar and never really sets, although lost to sight through the haze of the horizon, may be seen late rising in the East. The Southern aspect is one of unsurpassing beauty. There are no fewer than nine stars of the first and second magnitude all visible, Capella, Castor, Pollux, Procyon in the little dog, Regulus in Leo, or the Sickle, the majestic Sirius under Orion which contains Betelgeux and Rigel and further away the ruddy Aldebaran which is the eye of the Bull. Has it ever occurred to any of us what insignifi- cant atoms we all are compared with the vast magnitude of the distances between our own planet and the distant Suns ? So immense are these distances that in our own actual mileage the figures are quite bewildering, and convey no adequate idea of what the true position really is. It is customary to employ, in astronomy, as a fixed unit for stellar distances, the distance traversed by light in one year. Now it is well known this travels 185,000 miles per second, consequently a ray of light from the nearest known star-Alpha Centaurai-takes 4t years to span the heavenly abyss and this run out gives the stupendous total of 24,750,000,000,000 miles Sirius; perhaps the best known star in the htaveni-—« ecause it 's the brightest-is double that distance, and the light we see nightly from him left him over 9 years ago Ca.n we grasp or comprehend what these wonders mean ? I Astronomy owes much to Bradley for his memorable discovery of the Aberration of Light." This resulted in many unknown wonders being revealed to us. And now the grand discovery has beeu made by Kapteyn that a great part of space, so fur as we have any visible knowledge of i., id occupied by two majestic streams of stars travelling in opposite directions, and the amazing truth has been deciphered that the stars of both streams are alike in design, chemical constitution, and in process of development." Truly may we be permitted to ask-" When will wonders cease ?"

docs.full_text: MR RICHARD PROCTOR AT CARDIFF. THE PLANETS. This formed the subject of Mr Proctor's second lecture at the Tredegarville Chapel, and which was delivered on Thursday evening to a very large audience, although the weather was most unfavourable. The lime-light apparatus had been got into working order, and the views were excel- lent. The lecture embraced some of the salient points of that given on Wednesday evening. This became necessary to explain the views of the sun which could not be seen on the pre- ceding evening, but which were as per- fect as they well could be on Thursday. Mr Proctor gave a glance on (the solar system, its division into families, and then passed on to notice the giant planets. His views on the planets Saturn and Jupiter were no doubt novel to many, and calculated to induce his audience to read for themselves, and make the science of astronomy a study. This seems one of the great advantages of these lectures. Much was explained last evening that could only have been arrived at by long study. At the same time, there was something so interesting in the description he gave, so much that was really wonderful in the character and constitution of the whole solar system, that those who listened could not fail to have their minds awakened, and their thoughts turned to the investigation of a subject which has always been regarded as beyond the comprehen- sion of those who are not gifted with considtr- able mathematical knowledge. Mr Proctor's re- marks v,va]d seUus audience thinking for them- selves, and when he had done that he had achieved a great task, for there is no science so full of interest, once its study is commenced, as that of astronomy. For whatever purpose Mr Proctor has been brought to Cardiff, the office bearers of the chapel have served a good one in bringing before so many persons the most recent and the most carefully studied views on the harmony displayed in the worlds around us, and how wonderfully each works sub- servient to one great whole. They were also cal- culated to remove many absurd notions held re- specting the sun, the earth, and the planets of the uuiverse.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMY AND METEOROLOGY. At first sight it lappears very strange that while astronomy and meteorology, probably the two oldest sciences, have occupied the attention of mankind from the earliest ages, the former, dealing entirely with other worlds than our own, has long ago attained the dignity of an exact science, while the latter, the Itady of the atmosphere in which we live, is still in the embryo state. Centuries before Aristotle wrote L-in treatise on meteorology the anoients had drawn up empirical rules, based on the appearance of the sky, the flight of birds, the behaviour of animals, and so forth, intended to guide them to a foreknowledge of weather changes. The sole claim to popularity of I truay modern annual publications is to be found in the persistency with which their authors pretend to be able to predict the weather of every day for a whole year. But this is not by any means a modern idea, as identically the same thing was done in Egypt 30 centuries ago, and it is very likely that the ancients were even more successful than their modern imitators. Of quite a different origin are the weather forecasts which now ap- pear daily in the Press. Those valued friends of the almanaok maker, the moon and the stars, have within the past 30 or 40 years been dethroned, and an entirely new method of studying atmospheric fluctuations has been adopted. Whether the official forecasts so familiar to everybody are any better than those favoured by past generations is a question about which there are many opinions, but this in itself is but a small matter in reality, for meteoro- logists tell us that the public demands forecasts, while science is still at a loss to explain the causes of the changes which affect us. The work commenced by Redfield 60 years ago is still in the experimental stage, but sufficient bas been accomplished to revolu- tionise our ideas of the subject; and, while we cannot oontrol the vast forces which are generated in astorm, it is found possible to lessen the danger by improved construction of buildings and by the proper manoeuvring of ships. The advance which has been made in our knowledge of the circulation of the wind in storms has enabled seamen to so skilfully manage their vessels that all the money ever spent on meteorological research has been more than repaid by the saving of life and property in one yea.

docs.full_text: ABERGAYENNY. SUCCESSFUL CASE OF AMPUTATION OF THE THISH UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF CHLOROFORM.—On Friday, the 27th of April, M. W. Hansby, Esq., surgeon, Abergavenny, assisted by W. Hill, Esq., surgeon, performed this operation on a man of the name of John Havard, a labourer, residing at Clytha Hill, who has been suffering for a length of time from a diseased, knee-joint, and every means used to prevent amputation being necessary, but without effect. The operation was periormed in the presence of F. C. Batt and G. Foote, Esqrs., surgeons,' of Abergavenny. Havard states he never experienced the slightest pain in the removal of the limb, and is, we are glad to hear, doing well. THE IHON TRADE.—The state of trade on the hills still con- tinues to be in a very depressed state, and there appears not the slightest probability, at present, of an advance in the price of iron. This certainly looks very bad, and must be very dis- couraging to the employer as well as the men. We hope that now the weather has become more settled, we shall experience a revival in trade. WE are happy to state that the weather has taken a decided change. During the last week it has been extremely fine and beautiful. We had our doubts, that in consequence of the se- verity of the weather, much injury would have been done to the wheat and early fruit; but we learn, from good authority, that the grain in this neighbourhood looks well, and has been but slightly injured. ABERGAVENNY READING AssoCIATION.-On Friday, the 27th ultimo, the first of a series of lectures of the present season, on behalf of the above institution, was delivered in the Free Gram- mar School, by E. Y. Steele, Esq. The talented lecturer's sub- ject was Light, its important Laws and Properties." The lecture was illustrated by diagrams, which must have given the lecturer a vast deal of trouble in getting them up. The lec- turer exhibited great talent, and a thorough acquaintance with his subject, which was listened to with the deepest attention and interest. At the close of the address he was loudly ap- plauded, and thanks were voted unanimously to him. ON Monday, the 1st instant, Mr. Po ph-im, whose celebrity is spread far and wide as a lecturer on astronomy, again paid us a visit, after an absence of ten years, and delivered a most inter- esting and instructive lecture on astronomy, in the Cymreig- yddion Hall. We are glad that the good folks of Abergavenny have not forgotten Mr, Popham's former visit, and that he was so well supported on this occasion.

docs.full_text: MR CARADOC MILLS ON THE WONDERS OF ASTRONOMY. ENTERTAINING LECTURE AT HOREB, LLANRWST. (BY OUR LLANRWST CORRESPONDENT). Mr. Caradoc Mills entertained an appreciative audience, on Thursday evening, at Horeb Chapel, Llanrwst, with a truly delightful illustrated lecture entitled Other worlds than ours; or, the wonders of astronomy." This was Mr Mills' first public appearance in the capacity of lecturer, and his grasp of the difficult subject and his finished style produced a most favourable impression on the audience, who followed his every word with the closest interest, Mr Mills ts to be congratulated upon his well-deserved success. He spoke in Welsh for an hour and a quarter without the aid of notes. His language was simple yet graphic, his delivery distinct and pleasing, and the dis- course was illumined bv occasional flashes of humour which lent it an added interest. The success of the lecture was heightened by the able manner in which the oxy-hydro lantern was manipulated by the rising young scientist's father. The proceeds of the lecture are to be presented to Mr J. R. Jones, the conductor of the Juvenile Prize Choir, and a member of Horeb Chapel, who is leaving the town next week. THE CHAIRMAN'S ADDRESS. The chair was occupied bo Mr. D. J. Williams, of the Council Schools, who in a short speech said he was pleased to see so many present to show their good feelings and wishes to Mr J. R. Jones, who is leaving to take up a better position in England. He (Mr Williams) was very sorry to loose him from his school, as lie had been with him for many years, and was a good teacher. He hoped the change would be beneficial to him in every respect. (Applause). He would also remind them that Mr Caradoc Mills, the lecturer, was an old scholar from his school, and that gave him a double interest in the meeting that evening. The meeting opened with the singing of the old hymn, "Newyddion Braf," &c., and during two short intervals in the lecture Miss Williams (Bradford House) rendered the song Ora pro nobis with good effect, whilst Miss Jones (of "The Bull") rendered a solo, Nearet-, my God, to Thee," very sweetly, Mr R. R. Owen accompanying on the organ. The usual votes of thanks having been accord- ed, the meeting terminated with the singing of the appropriate hymn, "Duw mawr y rhyfeddodau maith.

docs.full_text: The Daily Newt also has the following, on ZadkitVg Almanack See what people are expected to read and to believe in this age or science. ZadkicVs Almanacks will now be found on the counters of nearly every bookseller in London, and they would not be there unless there were people to buy them-not poor and uneducated people merely, for they are found in shops into which these but seldom enter, the shops of the rich and well-to-do. In this almanack it is declared in the most strenuous manner that the received, or Copernician, system of astronomy is a fable. In sober truth," we are told, none but a man educated to the idea, could for a moment imagine that this enormous globe of earth, which is.25,0Q0 miles in circumference, is forever hurry- ing away through space at the mean rate of 68,000 miles in an hour, which is over 1,133 miles in a minute. If we had not been educated to believe in this absur- dity, we should scout the first man who asserted it to us as a madman. The more we examine the question, the more we see its ridiculous nature, and perceive that the truth is found only in agreement with the solemn assertion of God's word." The truth is that the earth is stationary, that it is the centre of the solar system, that it is only 365,006 miles from the sun, that the moon is but 32,828 miles distant, that the sun is not nearly so huge a body as the men of science vainly imagine, that it is only 3,407 miles in diameter, and that the diameter of the moon is not more than 301 miles. The Scriptures are invoked in the most solemn manner to prove the falsehood of the modern astronomy; there are elaborate unintelligible calculations to show the unsoundness of the Newton- ian philosophy; and to make assurance doubly sure we are shown from astrology that Newton was bound to go wrong and to mislead the world in the fatuity of his reason. When such nonsense as this finds a sale in the shops of London to which people of education resort, perhaps the less we say the better of the stu- pidity of those who resisted and persecuted "the starry Galileo."

docs.full_text: DEATH OF SIR GEORGE AIRY Six months after the completion of his 90th year, Sir George Biddell Airy, the seventh Astronomer Royal, has passed away. He died at Greenwich, at half-past six on Saturday evening, after a few mouths' illness. He had a fall in the summer, and received an injury which involved a surgical operation. This seemed to be successful at the time, but he has been gradually sinking ever since. Sir George Airy's name is one that has never come prominently before the general public, though for 65 yearii it has been a familiar and honoured name in the great world of science. So far as we know, the only work by him which has a professedly popular stamp is a little book en- titled Popular Astronomy," which has passed through numerous editions, but which is really intended" to explain to intelligent persons the principles on which the instruments of an obser- vatory are constructed." Tho fact is, the late Astronomer-Royal's mind was rigidly scientific, wo might almost say rigidly mathematical. Any scientific problem or scientific theory, or indeed, any application of science which could not be made to squara with his lSevemly mathe- matical tests, ho was api to regard with distrust. It may be remembered that in the early stages of construction of the Forth Bridge he wrote at considerable length to prove that no bridge built upon the principles which were being applied could possibly stand. But in the peculiar position which Sir George Airy had to fulfil as Astronomer Royal, these little failings probably leaned to virtue's side. The great business of his iife was to deal practically with mathematical astronomy, to reconstruct a great observatory, and to carry out its chief object—astronomical observations on mathematical lines. This, his great life-work, he accomplished with a masterly completeness that left nothing to bo desired. Sir Georgo Airy was born at Alnwick, North- umberland, on July 27, 1801 he was educated at private schools at Hereford and Colchester, and at Manchester Grammar School, from which he passed in 1819 to Trinity College. Cambridge, as sizar. Ho was elected scholar in 1822, graduated as Senior Wrangler m 1823, and was elected a Fellow of his college in 1821. --1,-1'81

docs.full_text: THE SWANSEA RAPHAEL. The art critic of the Westminster Gazette says:— There are few thmgs more difficult in the art world than to establish the genuineness of any newly-discovered masterpiece, especially if the find occur in any part of Italy or in the provinces of England. This is as it should be, for the enthusiasm of the picture-hunter generally carries him away, and in spite of all his lniLa-fides he is usually a very untrustworthy and wholly unsatisfactory picture-finding witness. His predisposition in favour of miracles and picture-dealing marvels is unlimited, and any scepticism on the part of others is Bet down, not to prudence born of experience, but to envy not unmixed with ignorance. The latest discovefY- which may, of course, be genuine—is the sudden appearance at Swansea (of all places in the world) of a Raphael, representing the reconciliation of astronomy, philosophy, and theology, which is valued at no less a sum than £12,000. The dis- covery of the picture, or of its value, has been attended by that of its history and pedigree. It was painted "for one of the Popes;" it was in Spain "for a long period," and was 200 years in the family of the lady who was astute enough to buy it, but not astute enough to discover it till the other day, when someone else did it for her. The story is vague enough. But has it not occurred to anybody that Raphael executed a commission tor Pope Julius II., a ceiling for the Camera della Segnatura, in the Vatican, in which astronomy, philosophy, and theology also appeared, but not so much in '■ reconciliation as in medallions ? Before any-, body pays down £ 12,000 for the new chef d'eeuvre, he would do well to compare it with the works I have named (which have been duly engraved by Audran and by Morghen), and apply a few of the tests that may be suggested to him by the shrewder and more scholarly of" the picture dealers and experts.

MEETING OF THE TECHNICAL I INSTRUCTION COMMITTEE. s The ordinary meeting of the Technical Instruc- tion Committee of the South Wales and M n- tnouthdiirt; University College was hakl on $Tuesday evening, Mr Councillor Iicèll's presiding, '—The Secretary (Mr Ivor James) reported that r lo far he tiad received no reply irom Lord I Windsor as to whether his lordship would be I wi] 1 Intr to undertake the annual distribution of I)rize.s and certificates to the students.—On the motion of Co-ucillor Munn, it was decided that the distribution should take place on the 3rd of January instead of on thu 10th, and that the Park-hail bs eng;ig-ed fur that night if possible.— | A letter was read from Capt. Short, teacher of navigation and nautical astronomy, asking whether or not separate fees would be charged for navigation and nautical astronomy.— It was decided to charge one fee only this year.— A letter was rend trom Mrs Austin with regard to classes, in art needlework, the matter being deferred until the committee had fully decided as to what t-iiould be done i!l the women's depart- ment of the college.—The Chairman said he was "staggered" at the congested state of the women's department. They Lad certainly twice If cot three times as many students as they had room fur, and he thought the tiyio had arrived when a small committees should be appointed to take into consideration tli,) advisability of form- ing a complete women's department, and to report at the next meeting the desirability or not of building new premises, or of finding a building for the purpose.— A committee was appointed as suggested.—In the absence of Councillor Andrews, Mr Principal Tones moved, and Councillor Grossman seconded :—"That day students of tho college shall not be eligible for tho ordinary gold, silver, and bronze medals awarded by the committee to students who are or have been attending the evening classes, and that in future a special medal be awarded the best student of the year, who is a student in the evening classes, or a Undent of the technical school attending the classes of the higher technical Oepartuieilt. docs.full_text: "OBSERVATIONAL STIIO. I NOMY. "Observational Astronomv" is the title of a book which will prove interesting, not only to the amateur telescopisi, but to readers generally. It is just the book lor a beginner, containing, as it does, a quantity of matter seldom, if ever, found in ordi- n" ry astronomical works. It is an attempt to pro- vide an inexpensive treatise which, while formin" a stepping-stone to a fracticalacqunirtancewith the scenery of the heavens, gives, in simple torms, the results achieved by the latest research in thosa d". partments most affected by the amateur. To this end Mr. Mee, an eminently sale guide we may say, has treated the subject unconventionally, and mathematics are eschewed, the author occupying himself chiefly with describing the aspect and physical condition of the t-i bs about us. Conciseness and accuracy hav«* been the 111111 throughout, and the numerous refe- rences to other sources of information cannot but increase tlie usefulness of a little volume wh.es when read in connection with it good elemeniarr bxt-book, will Iny open the way for thf s' udent to become familiar with a ni(ii-o purely scientific treatment of astronomy HS a whoW. The author's style has considerable c ii.rm, and his presentation of his subject shows a cie-ir coucepti.m of what is likely to be iipprecinted, while, for the book itoelf, much has teen done ill the way of appearance, some of the numerous Illustrations being remarkably good. It may aho be mentioned that the work includes u memoir of the lato Prebendary Webb, who did so much for observational aBtronomy. The notice is the fullest and best extant, and will have especial interest for Welsh readers generally, because Mr. Webb lived and died at Hay, and to Cardiff readers in particular, ubcause his father was once Vicar of St. John's. In the preparation of his useful little work, Mr. Mee has had the advantage of being nutated by some of the best authorities living and fact of no small impor- tance is that the book has been well printed, and the illustrations are unusually numerous and •^cellent. "Observational Astronomy: A Book for Beginners." By Arthur Mee, F.R A..?;;iilh M' 2.. Sd..d Co. (LImited), Cardiff.

docs.full_text: REVIEWS. "Journal of the Astronomical Society of I Wales—Almanaa 1835. Price 7d. A perfect boon to amateur astronomers. Would that something of the kind might have fallen into the hands of the writer when this queen of the sciences first began to fascinate the youthful mind! Here are the results of careful work by expert observers, well acquainted .vith the sub- ject, and keenly alive to the needs anddemandi) of the inexperienced amateur, greedy for in- formation, and ready to accept competent guid- ance. Such a reader will find his way made plain for him, and plenty cf delightful work, well with n his reach. cut out for him. We have, first of all, a Calendar, wholly astrono- in leal-qutie a novel and unique feature in this line of tin rigs. Then follow notes on Sun, Moon, Planets, Satellites, Eclipses, Star Showers. Comets, Stars. Nebuloe, Star Clusters, and, in short, all department* of observational astronomy. Some cf these are of exceptional value in so cheap and handy a form as this for they have been compiled by the most com- petent hands. No better authorities, in their several departments, could liave been relied on than Mr. W. F. Denning, F.R.A.S., and the Rev. T. H. FouTkes, M.A. who have, with their customary courtly, contributed to these pages. Scattered about the book are very valu- able hints as to books to be consulted, and. M the end. the possessor of a telescope will tind a valuable little table, indicating the power? to be expected in instruments varying from two to ix in aperture. The process-block frontispiece, prepared by Daniel Owen and Co., at the office of the "Western Mail," is an ex- quisite re-production of one of the greatly- admired Pariti photographs of the moon in the firsts quarter. docs.full_text: "OBSERVATIONAL ASTRO- NOMY," "Observational AstronomyM is the title of a book which will prove interesting, not only to the amateur telescopist, but to readers generally. It is just the book for a beginner, containing, as it does, a quantity of matter seldom, if ever, found in ordi- nary astronomical works. It is an attempt to pro- vide an inexpensive treatise which, while forming a stepping-stone to a pr.icticalacquaintincewithtlie scenery of the heavens; gives, in simple terms, the results achieved by the Ititest research in those de- partments most, affected by the amateur. To this end Mr. Mee, an eminently safe guide we may sav, has treated the subject unconventionally, and mathematics ,re eschewed the author occupying himself chiefly wil II describing the aspect and physical condition of the orbs about us. Conciseness and accuracv have been the aim throughout, and the numerous refe- rences to other sources of information cannot but, increase the usefulness of a little volume which when read in connection with a good elementary text-book, will lay open the way for the Student to become familiar with a more purely scientific treatment of astronomy as a whole. The author's style has considerable chnrm, and his presentation of his subject shows a clear conception of what is likely to be appreciated while, for the book itself, much has been done ill the way of appearance, some of the numerous illustrations being remarkably good. It may nl-o be mentioned that the work includes a memoir of the lato Prebendary Webb, who did so much for observational astronomy, The notice is tho fullest and best extant, and will have especial interest for Welsii readers generally, because Mr. Webb lived and died at Say, and to Cardiff readers in particular, because his father was once Vicar of St. John's. In the preparation of his useful little work, Mr. Mee has had the advantage of being assisted by some of the best, authorities living and a fact of no smalt impm- tance is triat the book lias been well printed, and the illustrations are unusually numerous and I excellent.. "Observational .A gronomy: Å Book for Be«lDnerfl. By Arthur Mee T\K.A..S. With illustrations. Price 2s. 6d, Messrs. Daniel Owen and Co, (Limited), Cardiff. J

docs.full_text: To the Editor of the "Evening Express. Sir, — I was muc-h pleased to sec "Inquirer's" letter in your columns of Tuesday, because it voices a sentiment which is none the less general for being hi.thpl"to unexpressed. Thou- sands take a deep and increasing interest in astronomy, and are always ready to pay atten- tion when the wonders of the universe n.re portrayed in anything approach:ng an attrac- t've form. Yet. though lectures are delivered and ulidcs shown, and though hooks on astronomy are well nigh as numerous as the fiti.rs, the public telescope is conspicuous by its absence. People may iisten and read, but they must not look a.t the wonders for them- selves Cardiff is an example of most Eng- lish towns in this particular, but they manage tilings better elsewhere. Take, for instance, Germany. At Berlin there is a fine. public olbservatory (the Vrania S»ternwarte), wirh excellent instruments, to which the public have aocsss on paymeni., of a quite insignificant fee. This institution is well patronised, but t'he poor Cardifnan must needs peep through a small street telescope or go without. Tno.-c of us who possess instruments are constat*1 ly pestered with appl'col ions for a. nearer view of the heavenly bodfes. and there is little doubt that if a good telescope were provided in i proper hands it would not want, for patronage. Fine instruments are. to be obtained very cheaply nowadays, and £ 100 would provide Cardiff with a reflector of large dimensions and first quality performance, whilst another £ 50 would pro- ¡ bably cover the cost of a suitable "house." I commend this matter to our educational authorities and to Cardittians at large, and 1 see no reason why that which is done on a big ",<,ale at Berlin should not be done, ait leact in a small way. at the Metropolis of Wales. Hoping other readers will "ive the benefit of their views,—I am. &c.. ART it cii MEE, F.R.A.S. ART it cii MEE, F.R.A.S. President Astronomical Society of Wale- Cardiff.

docs.full_text: POPULAR ASTRONOMY. A y EXHIBITION AT CARDIFF MUSEUM. A large and interested company attended the opeffiing of the exhibition organised by the Astronomical Society of Wales at the Cardiff Museum- on Thursday morning, amongst those present being the president (ilr. T. E. Heath. F.R.A.S.), the Lord Mayor (Mr. Ilityd Thomas.), Mr. Albert Taylor, F.R.A.S., Major-general Lee, F.E..A.S., Coun- cillors Kidd a.nd Good, Dr. Charles Vachell. Mr. T. H. Thomas, the Rev. W. Dovey, Mr. James Waugh, Mr. G. F. Mason, MT. John Ballinger, Mr. John Ward, Mr. A. J. Harris, Mr. Isaac Samuel, Miss Hagerty, Mrs. J. M. Lewis, Miss Kidd. Miss Francie, Mr. and Mrs. C. H. Parsons, the Rev. W. L. Powell (Caer- philly), Mr. D. Hawkins (Porth), and Mr. Arthur Mee (the hon. :ecretar-TI, who is a most enthueiairtic worker on behalf of the society. The President said that, as the nominal head of an increasing society, he had much pleasure in asking the Lord Mayor to declare the exhibition open. They were greatly indebted to the Royal Astronomical Society a-nd others who had contributed to th-o exhibition. The Lord Mayor, in declaring tho exhibi- tion open, said that, at an ex-chairman of tho art gallery and museum committee, he wa,s very glrtd to find that ytirh good ure was being made of their building. It showed that the museum was not. merely, intended lor the purpose of ho wring curiosities, but loi general educational advancement. His lord- ship referred particularly to the work of Jjr. Albert Tayior. Mr. Heath, Mr. Arthtir Mee, and Councillor Kidd, who were enthu- 5wt.ic members of the society. Major-general Lee proposed a vote cf tJianks to the Lord Mayor, and Mr. Albert i ay lor, in seconding, said that a remarkable feature of the exhibition was the enormous amount of work shown by the amateur astronomer. Most of the pioneer work in attronomy had been dene by amateurs, and he was pleased to see that the Cardiff-Council was to the trout in assisting the amateur by maintaining the public observatory on Pcnylan Hill. ?ea,r, hear.) The Lord Mayor, in. reply, said the oor- poration were anxious to assist the students of astronomy in every way at the observa- tory, but they had to be sparing with the ratepayers' Mon-tty A detailed description of the principal erhioits has already appeared in these column3, and it is hoped that gocil use will be made by the publio of the opportunity now afforded them, for a fortnight or eo. of seeing what is interesting in the practical study of the queen of sciences, even to the most superficial observer.

Yes, for eight years now I've seen yo'u eitting in the chair, but I've never thought of ootnplaimng about it!" replied the prisoner reproacht ull y. "Have you any letters for me?" inquired an old lady at a Yjllage post-oHiee. "No letters," replied the post'mistreaa. "De.arie .me!" said the applicant. "I was expecting a letter or postcard from my daughter Martha, to say when she was com- dns. Well, there is a tpoatoa.rd," said the post- mistress. Martha is coming next Tues-da-y!"
