docs.full_text: REVIEWS. UNDER SUSPICION.— By Edith Stowp. London: T. Fisher Uuwiu, 26, Paternoster Row, 1887.—Price 6s.— This handsomely issued novel is an artintic study of aristocratic and plebeian life in the Principality of Wales, and the story, which is unflagging in human and scenic interest, is ably told us in a prologue and thirty chapters. Tho' the plot is laid in wild Wales, the authoress does not weary us with Welsh scenery, but whisks us off with her characters on their jouruejs to Rome, Paris, Marseilles, Genoa, &c., and we visit not only the Tycoch Colliery, wheie a catastrophic explosion takes place, but also go to a Ball in distinguished company, take a voyage in the "Europa,"&e. The book does not easily lend itself to exerptiug, and it would be unfair to give a synopsis of the plot, so we must refer our readers to the volume 0 itself, which reflects high credit both upon authoress and publisher. The tale is one of the most vivid and realistic ever published with Wales as its scene de theatre, and, since there is a generally awakening interest in Wales and all things Welsh we predict for it a must encouraging popularity. CUIRU FYDD."—North Wales Liberal Federation. The Land Question and Lund Bill. With special reference to Wales. By B. A. Jones, 13.A., Barrister-at- Law. Price Is. Hughes and Sun, Hope street, Wrex- bam.—This is an excellent shilling's worth of well- thought out and well-expressed matter relating t:> the agncultuial position of Wales, past, present, and future, and we commend it to all who wish to inform themselves on a. subject of such general and pressing interest. The contents of Mr Jones's useful and suggestive book we refer to at some length in our leading aiticle of this week. KNOWLEDGE, AN ILLUSTRATED MAGAZINE OF SCIENCE. LITERATURE AND ART.-This magazine, which is edited by the well-known and learned Mr H. A. Proctor, stands in the very forefront of our serial liteiature for real breadrli and depth of original information on the sublets treated upon, and for variety and interest of the contents. We heartily commend it to the attention of all readers who can appreciate tho difference between mere verbal compilation and common-place, sensational story-telling, and new thought, tersely expressed, touching the greatest problems of existence. THE SEAL OF THE SNAKE.—A secret in seven coils. By R E. Francillon. Being Gr.mt and Uo.'f Christmas annual for 1887.—Mr Francillon is always artistic and picturesque as well as deeply interesting, and in the work before us he has more than maintained his previously won reputation. The story is divided into s'vcn chapters or coils and each one introduces us to strange characters, in strange scenes, but all are described with .a felicity of touch which cannot fail to charm the reader, who is carried on Irom beginning to end of the story with ever- increasing euthralln.er.t under the plot. We run very little risk when we say that this is the best Christmas story of the current year, and we commend it to all who care for a. seasonable story, well concerned and well told. CASSELL'S ILLUSTRATED ALMANACK FOR 1888.-This popular publication has just been issued, and fully comts up to the high standard of pist years. It is profusely and excellently illustrated with splendid woodcuts. It also contains, besides the useful calendar (which, by the way, is very ingeniously inserted in illustrations, descriptive of the seasons), many pages of valuable general information, viz the names of the Koyal Family, the members of both Houses of Parliament with their political leanings, memoirs of some of the leading lights who have joined the majority during the past year, together with the most salient facts concerning a few of the leading men of the day, postal and telegraphic information, &c. It also contitius a complete list of the fairs which are to be held during the year in Great Britain. This will make the almanack a valuable hand-book to cattle dealers, manufacturers, &c. The eclipses, movable feas-ts, law terms &c., are all noticed and dated, so that altogether this year's almanack will be welcomed in many households as a reliable, useful and entertaining acquisition, the price (6d.) bringing it within the reach of all classes. OUR DARLINGS. — John F. Shaw and Co., 48, Paternoster Row. London, KC.-The completed volume of chis excellent treasury for children (edited by Dr Barnardo), has arrived, and without doubt is a most gratifying addition to the literature which is now published for the benefit of children. We have often drawn attention in these columns to the good work of love in which Dr Barnardo has been for many years engaged among poor street boys and girls how he rescues them from sin and shame, trains them in his commodious and comfortable homes at 18 to 2G, Stepney Causeway, London, E., and then when they are fitted for the struggle of life by having learnt various trades and occupations, are drafted off to Canada and elsewhere to take their part as industrious and honourable members of society in our colonies. Our Darlings is another means by which Dr Barnardo succeeds in doing good by pro- viding healthy, wholesome literature for our little ones. The magazine under notice is a large, well illustrated one, contains countless stories on all sorts of subjects, and is bound to give satisfaction to those who are fortunate enough to secure copies. It is not only sure to entertain our little mites who delight to gaze at the pictures, but will also entertain our juveniles of riper .-ge by the abundance and excellence of its literature. This year's volume commences a new series and contains hundreds of well-executed full-page illustrations, coloured and plain, together with countless smaller ones, well calculated to interest readers of all ages. It also contains a charmingly succinct history of "Britain's Queen," (by Pearl Fisher), from the birth of her Majesty at Kensington Palace, to the memorable ceremony at Westminster Abbey on the 21st June last; a serial story "Dickie's Secret," (by Catherine Shaw); Joss," a tale by Mrs Stanley Leathes while it fairly teams with short stories on almost every conceivable subject connected with birds, beasts, and reptiles, domestic pets, and pets that are not domestic, the stories and tales being written in a style that is sure to bring pleasure to all. We should like to enumerate many of the excellent merits of the handsome volume, but the space at our disposal forbids it. A coloured frontispiece, "An Unwelcome Guest," is most amusing. A little baby boy, whilst enjoying his plate of porridge on the grass, accompanied by little bunny, is disagreeably surprised by a great ugly green frog, who, unobserved, approaches, and suddenly leaps upon the plate, anxious, no doubt, to participate ia the feast. The expression which overshadows the child's features directly he sees the state of things, must be seen to be appreciated." It is one which many mothers (and father; too) would say is true to the life and is bound to amuse. Another exquisite coloured plate shows two little boys, in the defth of winter, giving their little sisters a sleigh ride over the snow. A third pourtrays a little one, with her feeding bottle, keeping company with the chicks. A fourth discovers a bright-faced lad, accompanied by his dog, on his return home from the woods, well laden with liolly for the Christmas decorations. The other coloured plates give an excellent portrait of Her Majesty the Queen; My Bunny," (a little girl nursing her pet rabbit); He won't bite," (an uninviting mastiff held by his little mistress); "Let me do some," (the little bouncing baby hOlY, whe is anxious to help mother on washing day); We are both getting old," (the old clock-maker taking grandfather's clock abroad and soliloquising); "Velvet and Fur," (a beautiful little child dressed in velvet nursing her little pussy cat); "Mother's darling," (depicting a nursing mother and her babe). The lettrr press, also, is on a par with the illustrations for clearness and excellence, and altogether the latest vol ume of Our Darlings" is a most welcome publication, and will make one of the most highly-prized presents which can be made at this season of the year. We commend it to parents who have the interest of their little ones at heart. It is also well bound in an illustrated cover, and does great credit to the publishing house of Messrs F. Shaw and Company, as well as to the editor. A NEW WORK ON ASTRONOMY is about to be issued by Richard A. Proctor, the author of the articles on Astronomy in The Encyclopedia Britannica' and in The American Cyclopaedia,' which will deserve atten- tion. Its chief object will be to present in popular yet scientifically sound form those views of the heavenly bodies which are included in what, in his last poem, Tennyson calls the New Astronomy.' The life histories of worlds and suns will be dealt with the planets will be studied as illustrating the stages of our own earth's life, while the record of our earth will be considered as illustrating the life histories of the planets. The sun will be studied as the one star we can examine, and thus as telling us all we know in detail about the nature of other suns and the stars will be considered as throwing light upon the probable past and future of the ruling and life-giving centre of the solar system. While thus the general characteristics of the new astronomy will he presented, points of detail in which the astronomy of to-day differs from the astronomy of a quarter of a century ago will be fully considered (for the first time) in th" forthcoming volume. Amoisg these points may be specially mentioned. 1. Changed views as to the structure of our galaxy, from the uniformity formerly imagined to a variety of forms, arrangement, and move- ments akin to what is found in the solar system, but on a much grander se,ile. 2. New views as to the sun's condition and surroundings, opening with Kircboff's interpretation of the solar spectrum, but including many details and discoveries relating to the sun's surface, vaporous envelopes, the sierra, the coloured flames, the corona, and the zodiacal. 3. Changed views, now generally adopted, as to the condition of the various orders of bodies — giant planets, terrestrial planets, moons, asteroids, &c.—attending on the sun. 4. The recognition of the moon as presenting the history of our earth's past as well as future life-even of stages of vulcanian history whose records in the earth's case have long since been destroyed by denudation. o- Kecent ideas respecting comets and meteois, by which all orders of both classes of bodies are included under one theory of volcanic ejection from swns and planets when in the sunlike stage of their careers. It is proposed, further, to present in this treatise, full explanations of several matters which have been insufficiently or inexactly dealt with in all except one or two books on popular astronomy. Among them are 1. The tides, correctly dealt with in no treatise on popular astronomy except Lord Grimthorpe's 'Astronomy without Mathematics,' the old incorrect explanation being given in most books, and even in Herschel's admirable' Outlines,' while a new and equally incorrect explanation (the centrifugal fallacy) appears in some recent treatises. 2. The precession of the equinoxes, as a case of gyration which is not explained accurately and sufficiently in any treatise on popular astronomy. 3. The discovery of Neptune, correctly but not popularly dealt with by Professor Grant in his admirable History of Physical Astronomy,' and explained fully in Herschel's Outlines,' but nowhere else properly dealt with, most of the so-called explanations of the perturbations of Uranus being altogether erroneous. The book will direct special attention to the departments of research in which astro- nomical work is now specially needed, endeavouring to attract towards profitable observation the many workers who are now wasting time in multiplying observations such as once bad special value, but now, having achieved j their purpose, possess none.

docs.full_text: THE ASTRONOMER ROYAL AT THE MANSION HOUSE, IN LONDON. On Saturday evening the Right Hon. the Lord Mayor entertained Sir George Biddell Airy, the Astronomer Royal, at the Mansion House, on the occasion of the freedom of the City having been voted to him, when a number of gentlemen distinguished in science and the learned profession were present to do him honour. After the loving cup had been duly circulated, and the loyal toasts honoured, General Sir W. Codrington and Admiral Sir A. Milne responded respectively for the Army and Navy. The Houses of Parliament were acknowledged by Lord Talbot de Malahide for the House of Lords and Lord A. Russell for the House of Commons. The Lord Mayor, in proposing, as the toast of the evening, the health of his distinguished guest, Sir George Airy, the Astronomer Royal, said the Cor- poration of London had often in past times conferred the honour of the freedom of the City upon men who bad distinguished themselves in the Army and Navy or by their learning and public services, and they had now determined-he thought very wisely-to confer that honour upon Sir George Airy as a man distin- guished for his scientific learning and for his devotion to scientific pursuits. So far as the City of London was concerned, no greater honour could be conferred upon any public man. Men in the Army and Navy, upon whom the freedom of the City had been bestowed, had all, more or less. distinguished themselves for their valour and the great victories they had achieved, and it could not be forgotten that those victories had been gained at the cost of many lives. But, in the ease of Sir George Airy, his victories had been over want of knowledge, and, while they had re- sulted in the greatest advantage to science, they had tended to save rather than to sacrifice human life. (Cheers.) He was Senior Wrangler at the University of Cambridge, and soon afterwards assumed the charge of the Observatory there, putting it in order in such a way that it had ever since prospered. It was now forty years since he succeeded to the office of Astronomer Royal, and he had during that long period, strenuously devoted himself to render his office a national institution, serviceable alike to science and to the public interest. Among other public objects, he directed attention to telegraphic time signals, and devoted a large amount of time and attention to the variation of the compass with refer- ence to iron ships, by which he had confered great benefit on society, and especially on the Navy and the Mercentile Marine. (Cheers.) He had taken three voyages abroad to observe total eclipses of the sun, and the last public duty which had devolved upon him in that respect was that of making preparations for the observation of the transit of Venus. To preparations for that great event he had devoted more than five years of his life (cheers) and in that way he not only found out the proper stations, but also prepared those who went to those stations for taking observations with accuracy. The Lord Mayor thought that a man who had rendered such services to his country and mankind could not be too highly honoured; and the Corporation of London had conferred upon him, in consideration of tho-ie services, the freedom of the City, the highest distinction it was in their power to bestow. (Cheers.) The freedom having been voted, the Cor- poration was now only waiting the completion of a golden casket in which to present it, and meanwhile it was his pleasing duty to offer his congratulations and those of the company to Sir George as a guest of the evening, and to propose his health, accompanied by the expression of a hope that he might long be spared to confer fresh obligations upon science and humanity. (Cheers.) The toast was received with enthusiasm. Sir George Airy, in reply, said that he hardly knew how to answer to a toast proposed in such flattering terms and with such an accurate knowledge of facts by the Lord Mayor, and which had been received with such cordiality by th9 whole company. He thought he might say that he felt the honour the Corporation had done him more than any he had ever received, and for this reason, that it had come from a body among whom he had one or two personal acquaint- ances. That honour had come to him from an official source, from a body perfectly^ independent, butwho at the same time possessed sufficient knowledge of all the duties pertaining to his office to enable them to understand and appreciate them, and all the cir- cumstances under which he stood related to the country. He therefore felt extremely the honour the corporation had determined to confer upon him. He might, perhaps, be permitted to allude to the position which th 3 Corporation of London had always held in his mind. It was the greatest and oldest of the muni- cipal bodies in the country, and he could scarcely ex- press his sense of the value and great importance of those bodies in this country and in all ages. They had always been the guardians of the inner life of England and of all political progress. (Cheers.) It was a remarkable fact that, in past times, from the Emperor Trajan downwards, it was always found that whenever absolute monarchs aimed at raising their power to a state of despotism their first effort was to suppress municipalities. England was, in his opinion, much indebted to her municipal institutions for the liberty she now enjoyed, and he earnestly hoped that the people of England would oontinue attached to those insrttutrlons; that whatever changes were made in the future they would be in no way detrimental to what had proved so useful and valuable in the past; and that the Corporation of Londen would long stand untouched in all its essentials. (Cheers.) Adverting to the position of men of science in general, he said it would be found in all cases associated with something utilitarian, and it was most fortunate that it was so. That was particularly the case with the office which he now held. He was not an astronomer more than he was a navigator; and in the office he held he had not to attend to astronomy simply, but to astronomy and navigation. He was proud to say he was oonnected with an establishment, which for two centuries had undoubtedly contributed very much to | both astronomy A,-cl navigation, and which could now boast of an observatory well-known throughout the world—an institution which was maintained in a state of steady, respectable celebrity and rising fame, which no other astronomical institution had ever enjoyed. In the next place, he would say, that, although science did possess that utilitarium character, still in every branch of it, and more particularly in astronomy, it mast be founded on an education of the ftrictest order, suoh, perhaps, as'could be scarcely attained in England except at the University of which he was proud to be a member. It must, further, be founded on a severe course of education and a general knowledge of the history of astronomy, and with a determination to make something out of it. More than any other science was the study of astronomy connected with the past and with the future. Astronomy of the present day was only perfecting what was commenced many years ago, and many things connected with astronomy, so far as they had gone up to the present, would not be fully developed for many years to come. It had been agreed by common consent that the astronomy of modern days commenced in 1750, or there- abouts. A great step in advance was made at that time and what had been done ever since was really executing what was then conceived. The fact was that the full meaning of astronomical discoveries was not fully understood till the lapse of many years after they were hit upon. So it was in the past so it was at present, and so probably it would be in the future. What was done in 1750 was only now fully understood, and what was being done now might pro- bably not he entirely appreciated till the year 2000. Therefore it was essential that in the study of astro- nomy we hail to look both to the past and to the future. There was in this particular nothing similar in other sciences. Though as a rule navigators had but a poor knowledge of astronomy, it was wonderful how readily they came to understand it when they were called upon to put it to a practical test in the navigation of their vessels. As a proof of this, Sir George instanced the case of a captain of a vessel who had found, to his own great surprise, that on the strength of instructions he received, he made a most ac- curate correction of his compasses on astronomical principles. As another proof of the value of this study, the Astronomer Royal referred to a difficulty which was experienced at one time as to the drawing of a straight line in connection with military movements. It arose in this way. In consequence of the Ashburton Treaty two points were defined in reference to certain rivers, with an interval of between 60 and 70 miles be- tween them. It was ordered that a straight line should be drawn between those points. The question was how to trace that straight line from one point to the other. He, Sir Geoige, undertook to do it by astronomical problems, and he trained men of the Royal Engineers to do it astronomically. Officers were placed at the Royal Observatory to learn his methods, and they knew perfectly well what to do. The object was to go the least round-about; and they were able to lay down a rule in a certain direction, and to carry a line through forests and swamps, where the foot of man had never been before, and to carry it over 64 miles. In the end they found they were right within the breadth of a match-box. (Cheers.) After some further references to what had been accomplished by means of the study of astronomy, Sir George came to the conclusion that, after all, men of science were not so different from other men as was generally supposed. One thing they certainly did not differ in, and that was a due appreciation of such an honour as that which the Corporation of London had conferred upon himself. As he had said, he highly valued the compliment, and he begged to thank the Corporation, through the Chief Magistrate of the City of London, for the handsome manner and the circum- stances in which it had been conveyed to him. Sir George, on resuming his seat, was much cheered. The Lord Mayor, in a few appropriate sentences, proposed The Learned Societies, connecting it with the name of Dr. Hooker, President of the Royal Society, who, in reply, referred, in highly compli- mentary terms to the noble part the Lord Mayor and Corporation had played in the preservation of Epping Forest. The Health of the Lord Mayor was after- wards proposed by Mr. Cunliffe Brooks, M.P. The Corporation and'Sheriffs of London followed, to which Mr. Alderman Cotton M.P., and Mr. Sheriff Ellis briefly replied.

Tite-pleamnt London suburb of Tulae Hillis soon to lose some of the valuable instruments by the aid of which Sir William Huggins has, with the assistance of Lady Huggins, revolu- tionised the aciexice of stellar astronomy. They are two fine astronomical telescopes which the Royal Society lent to Sir William about 1870 to assist him in his observations of the heavens, and which he is handing back to the Royal Society, because he thinks the time has come when Cambridge University Observatory can utilise them more prefitablythan he can. One Sir wmialn irugging. I reason for giving them up now," said Sir Wil- liam to an interviewer, is that we seem to get fewer dear, fine nights nowadays. I expect it is the expansion of London and the increased number of factories which have affected the at- mosphere so much that even on what appear clear days the upper atmosphere is found to be obscured by thin vapours and tiny smoke par- ticles." Sir William, though 84 yeas of age, does not yet intend giving up work, but will continue his researches in his chemical and physical laboratories, which, with the little ob- servatory, stand in the quiet garden behind his modest villa at Tulse Hill.

At the close ihe Chairman expressed deep regret at the forth- coming removal of Mr. Whitmell. Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S. Next Friday night will take place the second of the series of educational lectures on elementary astronomy.

All who have seen Richard Gianthony's charming and persuasive play, "A Message from Mars," and many others who have heard it spoken of in enthusiastic terms, will be delighted by the visit of Mr. Mouilot's principal company to the New Theatre, Car- diff, on Monday next, and all the following, week, with a matinee on Saturday at 2.30. The probability of communicatitng with the glowing planet Mare is much more pro- bable in these days than it was when this play was written. Astronomy teaehee u? daily, and the press is daily teaching us. that there is a.ir in Mars, canals in Mars and flowers in Mars, we know; why not human beings? Anyhow, the company at the theatre next week is prepared to prove this fact. and, if you doubt our word, come asd see for yourself. But, after all, Mars is not really vital to the object of the story, which is to furnish, in a surprising and kindly way, a much-needed lesson for the people of our own sphere.

docs.full_text: A CURIOUS WELSH BOOK. About 50 years a.go there was published in. Llanidloes. Montgomeryshire, a remarkable contribution to Welsh literature in the form of a book which explained in Welsh the prin- ciples of astronomy and geology. The author of the book was Edward Mills, who came from a distinguished Montgomeryshire family. By trade he was a weaver, his knowledge of as- tronomy and geology being obtained by study in his spare hours. The most curious part of the book is the illustrated plates explaining the solar system There are in all 86 plates. the work of the author's own hands. He made his own tools, which, although crude, succeeded in illustrating exactly what he wished to explain. The illustrations, showing the circular and other motions, were made out of tin, cut type high, and bent to the desired shape by home made tools. The maps of different parts of the world were also done in the same manner, a long ribbon of tin being twisted and turned over and over again, until a faithful representation of the country he desired to illustrate was obtained.

Mr. Mee (who illustrated his remarks with. nearly 90 lantern alideo), said that, no doubt, the mighty telescope of th. future would be constructed on tbe reflecting rather than, the refracting prin- ciple. America, which had for many yeaxo taken a lead in this matter, had been very; suspicious of the reflector till the late Dr- Common's great instruments went over there and the scientific Uncle Sam was convinced against his will. Now Dr. Common's scienti- fie assistant and adviser was Mr. Albert Taylor, (at present one of his Welsh inspectors of schools),, and it was bO who made the great five-foot mirror that helped to convert American astronomers. It was pleasant to think that a scientific matf living in their midst, and who took a deep interest in the Penylan telescope and the Astronomical Society of Wales, had a haf" in moulding the future of the which would have so mighty an influence oJ) the astronomy of the coming age.

docs.full_text: I LATE SIR HENRY BESSEMER. The late Sir Henry Bessemer's house was a feature of South London. A prominent object in the grounds was the famous observatory, erected many years ago at a heavy expense, astronomy being a hobby of Sir Henry's. The grounds ex- tend from Heme Hill to Dulwich Grove, and form a most attractive and beautiful estate. The pri- vate gardens are well kept, and there is an orna- mental lake of great beauty, to which herons and other rare birds are occasional visitors. For many years Sir Henry allowed the public access to his gardens, but this privilege was withdrawn, except in a few rare cases, owing to the damage done by a heedless crowd some years since. Sir Henry spent the evening of his life in retirement, and rarely left his beautiful home. It is worthy of note that the Prussian Patent Office refused to grant Bessemer a patent, and that no royalty was received from either Belgium or from France. Despite this, however, Sir Henry is credited with having received over £1,000,000 from his invention, besides profits from being himself a successful manufacturer. Sir Henry has occupied himself with several other inventions since the completion of his steel process, amongst them being the designing of a hydraulically worked arrangement for keeping the saloons of steamers level, so as to minimise sea-sickness.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMICAL NOTES. Astronomy hae during the past few days been deprived of two eminent names. Schiaparelli, of Milan, will go down to all time as the disooverer of the so-called "canals" of Mars, though he never intended to describe them as such, the word "canal" being a stupid mistranslation of the Italian term he used: I highly prize a letter he wrote me many years ago upon the subject. Dr" Galle," of Berlin, did his great work I no less than sixty-five years ago, when he 1 discovered Neptune. He it was who picked it up at the instance of Leverrier, the great French mathematician. Our English Adams was also on the track of Neptune, but, thanks to the stupidity of the then Astronomer Royal, he missed it. They are hardly likely to repeat a blunder like that at Greenwich! These two great names are a etuxmbling- blocK to many English people. Galle is pro- nounced something like "Golly," and Schiaparelli like "Sekkaparailly," with the accent on the railly' —a difficult word, though, after all, not so bad as the astronomer Jedzrejewicz, whose name I feel myself wholly incapable of tackling. ■ A. M.

docs.full_text: Å Swiss clockmaker, M. Noll, has (according to CasselFs Magazine) constructed the most wonderful timepiece in the world. It will be on view at the Paris Exhibition next year. It represents the front of an Early Renaissance building, and is 15ft. high. Besides telling the time, it marks the seasons and the Church festivals, which are heralded by choral and instrumental music, as well as the song of birds. Every hour there is a procession of the Twelve Apostles before the figure of Christ, and every morn- ing and evening monks are summoned from their cloisters to chant by the sexton, who tolls the bell. Astronomy is also illustrated by a representation of the earth and moon in their orbits, and other celes- tial phenomena. docs.full_text: PEMBROKE DOCK. DEATH.—The Rev. W. A. Edwards, whose resig- nation from the pastorate of the Congregational Church, Meyrick Street, Pembroke-Dock, was ac- cepted onlv on Thursday evening last week, died at his residence, Prospect Place, Pembroke-Dock, on Wednesday morning, aged 64 years. de- ceased was a native of Aberdare, ana previous to accepting the pastorate of the Meyrick Street Church, which he did in succession to the Rev. Charles Goward in 1874. was istor of the Con- gregational Church at Ebbw Vale. He had suf- fered from a spinal complaint for four or five years, but was able to attend to his ministerial work until about six month ago. When in health he took an active interest in all connexionol move- ments, and he was for a long time secretary of the local Church Aid Society. He was an elo- quent preacher. A great deal of his leisure was occupied with the study of astronomy. He was for 18 years a vice-president of tne Pembroke- Dock Liberal Club. docs.full_text: IS Jewish Lecture in Swausea. Mr. Hyman Goldberg presided at Su-iday's meeting of the Swansea Jewish Literary So- ciety at the King's Minor Hall. The lec- turer for the night was Mr. E. Eilpem, of the London School Board, who had ^'ourneyod specially to Swansea to speiak upon "The j Wit, Wisdom, and Women of the Talmud." The speaker kept a large audience entranced with liis excerpts from the great Jewish book of teaching. He instanced many examples cf its wonderfjl insight into human nature, the grasp cf many s.-ienees, such as medi- cine and astronomy—including many things fondly imagined by moderns as beiug latter- day invention. In the Talmud. also, was the same theory ventilated as that of Dar- win's in his "Origin of Species. Nothing was new under the sun. One striking char- acteristic of the Talmud was its belief in the virtue and wisdom of woman. It was writ- ten in a time when woman was very lowly regarded, and it teamed with instances and examples of feminine astuteness and good- ness. The lecturer, in conclusion, appealed to the local Jewish colony to unite in their, common welfare, and the mesting closed with hearty votes of thanks.

docs.full_text: A SELF-MADE ASTRONOMER. A Singular Career. A remarkable figure has disappeared from the I scientific life of England. Mr Lanizdon, the self-made M'trOJlOmer," as he was known I throughout Devonshire, was the son of a farm labourer. His education was acquired in the Sunday school. However, he was a, young fellow of remarkable diligence, and while work- ing in Jersey as a blacksmith he obtained an excellent knowledge of French. He sought many vocations, but at last he settled down as a porter in the employ of the Great Western Railway Company, Bristol being the scene of his first year's service. How his thoughts were directed to astronomy was a mystery he .him- self could never understand. However, all his life became centred in tho astronomical science. A man or resource, he, being unable to purchase the necessary tools, made them. While still a switchman, he produced a telescope five feet long and six inches iu diameter. This inspired his inventive genius, and he soon produced an equatorial reflecting tolescope and a remarkable camera fitted for instantaneous photography. Presently Mr Nasmyth's attention was directed to him, and ho showed him bow to make his tools. The railway man was never rendered ambitious by his success. He obtained a singular reputation in the astronomical world, and he became known as one of the most accurate of onr observers but he remained through it all a railway man, and he died station-master at Silverton, a quaint little place near Exeter.

docs.full_text: IS THE WELSH SUNDAY CLOSING ACT A FAILURE? TO THE EDlrOR OF "THE CAMBRIAN." SIR.—I was extremely amused last week with the remarks in your Gossip of the Week" column upon the Welsh Sunday Closing Act. The writer seems as ignorant of the results of this monstrous measure of monumental madness as the proverbial cow is of astronomy. In language as absurdly childish as ignorant, he endeavours to prove that Sunday Closing, instead of being an unmixed evil, is an unmixed blessing. I challenge the accuracy of his figures as to the num her of people summoned and convicted for offences against this iniquitous Act, and unless he accepts this challenge I shall deem it my duty to publish the actual figures. Sunday Closing has created more deceit and lying than even the most bitter opponents of the Act ever dreamt of. It has made more unhappy homes than half-a-dozen unjust measures put together. Cardiff has spoken v;ith no uncertain voice on this question, and I feel sure that were Swansea to get up a plebiscite the verdict would be the same as in Cardiff. When such unfair and inaccurate state- ments are made, as have been made in your Gossip of the Week upon Sunday Closing, it is time someone took up the other side. This, I trust, will be done by an abler pen than mine. Hoping my challenge will be accepted, I remain, yours truly, ANTI-HUMBUG. Hafod, Swansea, May 22nd.

docs.full_text: SIR ROBERT BALL DEATH OF EMINENT ASTRONOMER WII VISITER SWANSEA. At the age of 73, Sir Robert Ball, the eminent aistronomer, passed away at the Observatory, Cambridge, yesterday. He was born in Dublin in 1840, and graduated at Trinity College. He saw Donati's comet in 1858, and on Nov. 13th, 1866, he witnessed the famous star shower, which only lasted for a couple of hours in the middle of the night. He was at that time working with Earl Ro-se, whose celebrated 60ft. telescope, with a 6ft. aperture, thougi2 built in 1845, was the Jargest in exis- tence until 1905. In 1883 he witnessed the gorgeous sunset which he attributed to the cubic miles of pumice dust vomit- ted, into the air by the Krakatoa erup- tion After his first appointment he mounted two 6teps at a time. A mathematical professorship at Dublin was followed by his appointment as Astronomer Royal for Ireland. In 1892 he left his native city to become Lowa- dean Professor of Astronomy and Geo- metry at Cambridge. Sir Robert's lecturing tours at homl and in America were planned when he was at the Irish observatory, and it was there that the majority of his books were written. During his lecture tours he visited Swansea on more than one occasion. He gave up lecturing three years ago.

docs.full_text: Before very long a medallion of Robert Recorde, with a suitable inscription, will be placed in Tenby Parish Church. Robert Re- corde was "The first who wrote an arithmetic in English, the first who wrote on geometry in English, the first who introduced algebra into England, the first who wrote on astronomy and the doctrine of the sphere in English, and finally the first Englishman (in all probability) who adopted the system of Copernicus," Court physician to Edward VI., and to his successor Mary. Recorde was versed in many arts and sciences. More than 350 years have passed since Recorde's death, and he has been without a memorial in the town of his birth. The medallion is the work of Mr Owen Thomas, sculptor,, of London, himself an old Tenby boy, and is executed from a painting of Recorde which is in the possession of the Rev. W. Done Bushell. Mr Thomas expressed a wish that the tablet should be placed in the old church, with which lie was associated in his boyhood, and the Rector has given his consent to this being done.

docs.full_text: To the Editor of the Tenby Observer. SIR,-Having made astronomy my favourite study for the last thirty-five years, you may natu- rally suppose that I took a deep interest in observing the total eclipse of the moon on Saturday evening last, and I must say it was in every way a grand sight. The sky was clear, the moon shone brightly, and was surrounded by thousands of stars which twinkled in all directions. Presently the dark shadow, professed to be that of the earth, began to cover the eastern side of the moon, and in half an hour's time the whole "disc was obliterated, and there was immediately a profound darkness. Could not all have exclaimed "Wonderful are thy works 0 Lord." And now for the sake of your less scientific readers, I have just thought that the following extract from a standard and popular work would afford them pleasing and instructive information and that you would therefore be pleased to insert it.—Yours, &c., A CONSTANT READER.

docs.full_text: SIR DAVID CILL. Death tf Eminent Astronomer. Sir David Gill, K.C.B., late Astronomer-Royal at the Cape, died in London on Saturday. Deceased, who was bot-n in 1843, held many scientific distinctions. He lY horn at Aberdeen, and graduated at the University there. Devoting him- self to the study or astronomy, he took a prominent part in many expeditions of observation, and was for a time en-, gaged in the making of a photographic catalogue of the stars. He was also engaged in important colonial survey work,.apd was tire author of numerous scientific works. docs.full_text: A RAPHAEL "IN SWANSEA. VALUED AT £12,000. Information reaches us that one of the most valuable paintings in the world is at present in the possession of Mrs. Vignolles, wife of the manager of the London and Midland Bank, being none other than The Reconciliation: Philosophy, Astronomy, and Theology," which was paiuted by Raphael for one of the Popes. It has been viewed by the best known English art connoiseur in the trade, and by him its minimum value is placed at £12,000, at which figure ho is prepared 'to treat as its reserve price. There is a history attaching to the painting, which was for a long time located in Spain, and has since been 200 years in the family, from whom Mrs. Vignolles acquired it. We understand that Mr. Vignolles is willing— even anxious—to afford his fellow-townsfolk an opportunity of viewing this magnificent specimen of the great Italian master before it is removed to London, and it has been proposed that it shall be exhibited in the Public Library gallery i but this we believe will not now bo done, a more suit- able room being required.

Her i-zice was of a deep bronze colour, her black hair was tightly knotted beneath a little battered 6traw hat, and her t'kirt barely reached her knees. She called at his house with a collecting card and produced a number of quaintly worded appeals, end a diploma of honour designed by her- selr The dark colour of her face and hands," the sergeant declared, is due to dye. Her left arm is disfigured, and on it she wore a man's boot." The chief constable created a sensation by declaring that the n-oman must under- go medical examination, as there wai doubt regarding her sex. At her home, ho said, was an altar, a coloured picture of the Cress surmounted by an ikon, numerous candles and several lighted oil lamps. Phillips, who professed to be a Servian, had carried on some kind of healing. A remand was ordered.

docs.full_text: AN INDIAN ASTROLOGER. The Punjaubee press has been recently lamenting the death of Kanh Singh, a distinguished native scholar. He once occupied the post of Astronomer- in-Chief to the late Maharajah of Cashmere. He translated several works in astronomy from English, Sanskrit, and Arabic, and he had perhaps the finest astronomical library in India. He was so much esteemed as an astronomer that the Maharajah was anxious to build an observatory for him, but was pre- vented by the great expense. He wrote an analytical work on Urdu grammar, and also some lyrical pieces. He has left behind him an autobiography which cannot fail to be interesting. During the mutinies of Delhi he was in command of a native force, and showed himself to be both a loyal and a brave subject of the Queen. Subsequently he took an active part in prison, educational, and other reforms in the native State of Puttiala, as Well as in the Punjaub. The history of Kanh Singh, who, although a Sikh warrior by birth, gained so many laurels in the walks of peace, is full of instruction. It is worthy of remark that he gave to an American missionary the credit of his education.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMER'S SUDDEN DEATH. Professor Roberts, F.R.S., the distinguished astronomer in charge of Crowborough Observatory, Ion the Sussex side of Tunbridge Wells, died suddenly on Sunday afternoon on going indoors from the Observatory gardens. The deceased, who was seventy-five years old, was the author of many scientific works. Dr. Roberts was born in Denbighshire in 1829. A large part of his life was devoted to practical investigations in geology, microscopy, spectrum analysis, astronomy, and other kindred branches of science, He was the author of several papers on geological and astronomical subjects. For several years he pursued stellar photography with powerful instruments specially constructed for the purpose, and succeeded in adding considerably to the knowledge of the stars, clusters and nebulie. He devised a method and a machine by which the stars that have been photographed can with accuracy be engraved directly from the negatives on copper plates for the purpose of printing; the machine is also adapted for measuring the positions and magni- tudes of the stars. In 1870 he was elected a Fellow of the Geological Society, and of the Royal Astronomical Society in 1882. In 1890 he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society, and was also A member of other learned bodies.

docs.full_text: VARIABLE LATITUDE. Among the most important researches which astronomers have in hand is an in- vestigation of that period of minute oscilla- tion of the earth's axis, which gives rise to the phenomena of variable latitude. Upon co-ordinating several hundred Indian Ocean determinations with corresponding results of the Berlin Observatory, Professor Foer- ster, of Berlin, finds that beyond doubt the latitude in Berlin during the period in- creased by one-third of a second, and in- creased in the Indian Ocean by exaetly the same amount. As long ago as 1876 it had been put forth that irregular motions of the earth's axis to the extent of half a second may be produced by the TEMPORARY CHANGES OF SEA LEVEL, due to meteorological causes. Professor Foer- ster points out the need of four permanent stations for regular and continued observa- tions of this change in latitude, and so to de- termine the causes of those variations, which have hitherto been put down to irregularities in observations. Not only is the research of the first importance in respect to the funda- mental observational work in astronomy, but it has exceeding interest in connection" with tidal, meteorological, and geological observa- j tions and speculations.

docs.full_text: ANTARCTIC EXPEDITIONS. The boom in Antarctic expeditions has been practically marked and realised by the launch- ing of the two vessels. English and German, intended for exploration of the vast southern territory of ice. The Gauss is a German ship, and the Discovery a British one. Every- thing that shipbuilding art and science can suggest to enable these missioners of science to resist the conditions likely to be en- countered in an antarctic voyage has been made available in their construction. The scientific equipments of the vessels will not be less perfect than the various details re- lating to build and sailing. The general public are slow to appreciate the great value to science which such expeditions are calculated to represent. There are many details relating to astronomy, geology, physics, meteorology, and other departments of research which can only be authoritatively settled by the knowledge gained from expedi- tions of this kind. The interests of all sciences ire so clearly interwoven, that the advance of one often means the forwarding of all; and the expectation that the Antarctic expeditions will throw light on many problems of physical science, is at least a fair inference drawn from aur experience of research in the opposite region of the world.

docs.full_text: GOVERNMENT PATRONAGE OF SCIENCE.—It is stated in the official report of the British Association that Government has assigned £500 for the purpose of reducing the enormous mass of observations on the heavenly bodies, accumulated since 1750 at the Greenwich Observatory, which have hitherto been per- mitted to remain a rich but unexplored mine of facts, of the ut- most importance to the future progress of Astronomy. It is also stated in the same report that Governmant hs, ordered that the trigonometry survey of Scotland be resumed in the early part of next year. A NEW BLISTER.—The blister is raised in the following manner :—The surgeon cuts a piece of brown paper of the size and shape of the surface which he intends vesicating. This being well damped or moistened with water, is placed on the limb affected, a smoothing-iron (such as is used by washerwo- men), being previously well heated is applied over the moistened paper this plan produces a visicated surface almost instanta- neously, being effected by the steam generated by the contact of the hot iron and moistened paper. This method of blister- ing, being more speedy and less painful than that commonly adopted, it now generally used in all cases where It is a maitter of important to produet immediate vweationi—ImetU

docs.full_text: CHEPSTOW. On Wednesday last, a lecture on astronomy was delivered in the National School-room, by Mr. Hemming, which, owing to the unfavourable state of the weather, failed to attract a large company. On Friday, Mr. Hemming repeated the lecture, which afforded great satisfaction to the audience he has since visited Abbey Tintern. where there was a good attendance of the working class, with whom Mr. H. is quite at home his manner of delivery, assisted by various dia- grams, seemed to be properly appreciated bv the sons of toil. He is proceeding through Monmouthshire', and there is but little doubt of his success, especially as his terms for admission are very moderate. Upwards of £150 were expended among the drapers of Chepstow during the past week, in supplying the members of the clothing club with warm and comfortable clothing. There is a good and useful society established in the town, to aid and encourage the poor in the act of saving a trifle weekly, to be laid out in such necessaries asjare required for the winter season. There is a dangerous custom prevalent in this town,—that of setting fire to the soot in chimnies, instead of having them properly swept at intervals. Among other nuisances that are in the course of removal here, it is hoped that this dangerous practice will receive a check. Parties neglecting to cleanse their chimnies on proper occasions are amenable to taw but they are not allowed to do so at the risk of their neighbour's property.

docs.full_text: EBBW VALE. FIRE.—On Friday evening, at eight o'clock, a fire broke out on the premises of Messrs. E. and W. Evans, grocers and drapers, of Mount Pleasant House, Ebbw Yale. Fortunately for the proprietors, a man who was passing the shop observed the smoke in the shop, and gave an alarm to the inmates of the house. Mr. Evans, who happened to be in, with the aid of some others, very soon succeeded in putting the fire out. The fire is said to have arisen from a young lad having left a burning candle on a sack of flour. The only damage done was the burning of one sack and one oask of flour, a sack of oatmeal, and a few empty sacks. docs.full_text: ABSEGAVEUNY. THE FLAT WORLD.—O11 Monday and Tuesday, the lfitli and 17th instant, a person named Goulden, in his perigrina- tions through the country, as an enlightener of the public mind upon the I'.rr'vs of M.idcni Astronomy, took Abergavenny in his course, and hired the Cymreigyddion Hall, issued hand- bills, inviting an audience to hear his denunciations of modern science, and then engage in a promiscuous discussion on the merits of his hypothesis—which was, in fact, a revival of those antiquated views of Astronomy, entertained by our ancestors, which science has exploded. After going through a rhapsody which he designated a lecture, in which he en- deavoured to prove that the world was a fixed plane or disc, and not globular—that the sun was a body moving in an elipsis over its surface at the height of lUoO miles, and that the inoou moved round the snn in concentric circles; that the stars were all so many luminous specks in the heavens— none of them more than 4000 miles from the earth. His theory was that the earth was round like a wheel, the nave of which would represent the North Pole, and the felloes the South—that from the North extended, in every direction, im- mense shoals of Ice, and that from the Periphery shot forth continents of Ice and unknown lands—midway between these was the Equator. Such was the audacity of this empiric in science, that he denounced, as ignorant, Newton and Boyle, as well as Dr. Chalmers and Sir John Herschell- and had the impudence to assert in his bills, that a paper drawn up by himself on this subject, had been read before the Royal Astronomical Society in December Jast. In a discus- sion which followed the delivery of his nonsense—his igno- rance of the nature of the liubject was exposed by some well- timed and appropriate questions put to him by a gentleman present (a mere youth,)—and to prove that lie was a mere babbler upon what he presumed to be a lpcture-he talked largely of wliat Sir John Franklyn said and did when traversing the Southern Seas. Though he failed to convince his audience that the world was Hat, he did his best to prove that those who had any thing to do with him in Abergavenny, were not so sharp as they ought to have been—for he managed to leave the proprietors of the hall, his landlord, the printer, and the bill-sticker minus. Mr. Owen delivered a very interesting lecture in the Cymreigyddion Hall on Wednesday last, on Scripture His- tory and illustrated his theme by a vast variety of dissolving views. He will also deliver lectures on Astronomy on Thurs- day and Friday, May o and 4, in the same place; when it is hoped there will be a large attendance. It is annoueced that Mr. Popham, F.A.S., late of Win- chester college, who has lately been lecturing on Astronomy 111 1 ontypooi, Newport, Cardiff, Merthyr, and Tredegar, will visit our town on Monday, the '.50th instant. He brings with him, astronomical apparatus of the first order; and after an absence of ten years (for ten years ago he lectured in the old church to large and delighted audiences on the same subject) the face of an old friend is looked for with somewhat like pleasing anticipations and from what is said of his improve- ment, in the art of lecturing, disappointment is out of the question. CEICKHOWELL.—On Monday evening last, a meeting was held at the Calvinistic Methodist chapel, for the purpose of petitioning the Legislature, in favour of arbitration, instead of war. Arthur Gabell, Esq., was called to the chair; and the meeting was addressed by the Rev. John Lloyd, Wes- leyan minister; F. Franco, Esq., surgeon; E. Parry, Esq., surgeon and several other gentlemen. The meeting was well attended, and at the close nearly all the parties present signed the petition. After a vote of thanks to the chairman, for his able conduct in tho chair, the meeting separated.

docs.full_text: GERMAN BOOK PUBLISHING. The official account of the publishing trade in Germany shows that during the year 1880, the num- ber of new works or new edition published within the Empire was 14,941. This includes 300 maps. The increase on the previous year was 762 and for the three years 1878-80 the increase over the production of 1877 was 1,016, or a little over 7 per cent. Educational literature of all kinds in 1880 included 1,950 works politics, law, and statistics, 1,557 theo- logy, 1,390; belles leltres, 1,209; "works for the people," 657 philosophical, 125 map, 301; medical and veterinary, 790 the natural sciences, 787; litera- ture for the young, 496; antiquities, ancient classics, and Oriental philology, 533; modern languages and old German literature, 506 history and biography, 752; geography, 356 mathematics and astronomy, 201; military science and the management of horses (they are included in the same category), 353; trade and manufactures, 583 architecture, mechanical en- gineering, railways, mining, and shipbuilding, 403; forest culture, hunting, &c., 112; domestic economy and farming, 433; the fine arts and stenography, 627 freemasonry, 20 miscellaneous, 423.

docs.full_text: A FATHER was telling his little son about the wonders of modern science. Look at astronomy, now men have learned the distance of the stars, and, with their spectroscopes, what they are made of.—Yes, said the boy, And pa, isn't it strange how they found out all their names ? WELL, doctor, is there any improvement in my con- dition this morning?—Hardly, my friend; I am afraid you'll have to be thinking of the great change. You do, of course, sometimes consider the certainty of death ?—Oh yes, doctor that thought strikes me every time you enter the room. UXCLE JACK, who is short-sighted, returns from a long walk, and, being somewhat thirsty, drinks from a tumbler he find on the table. Enter his little uiece Allie, who instantly sets up a yell of despair. Uncle Jack: What's the matter, Allie?—Allie, weeping: You've drinked up my aquarium and swallowed my free tadpoles! SMITH, to a friend who applied for a position an letter-carrier Think yer got the persishon?—Friend Got it? No. The first question they axed me was how fur it was from London to Constantinopul; an' I told 'hem if that was going to be the round I'd give it up.

docs.full_text: SCHOOL LIFE IN CHINA. Schoolboys who are inclined to complain of the hard lines, as thej consider then!, that fall to their share, should lead about the almond- eyed learners in the Flowery Kingdom, and then rejoice that they have such an easy time of it in comparison. The Chinese school children have instilled into them at an early age habits of hard, steady study. At the age of five a boy begins his schooling. At daylight he rises and after dressing as quickly as possible, he starts break- fastless to school. He is assigned a task, and after it is completed he is allowed an hour for breakfast; again, later, lie has an hour for luncheon, but he is at his study for nearly twelve hours a day, seven days in the week. All this time, when lie is not reciting his lessons, he is studying aloud at the top of his voice. He is under the eye of his master both in school and on his way to and from school. The lad is taught rudimental astronomy, physics, and natural history, but greater stress is put upon writing and his literary studies. "A Thousand Letters," a poem, is the study that forms the backbone of his literary educa- tion. In it are taught the duties of children to parents and all such matters. Whatever the study may be, history, classics, or science, every lesson is learned and repeated word fo word.

FOHSTBR, of the Observatory in Berlin, says, in his report of the years 1894-5, that in June and July illuminated clouds are seen under almost the lame circumstances as during the nine years since the eruption of Krakatao. The fact has been ascertained through the corresponding photographs taken at different German stations. Director Forster com- plains that the weather at Berlin was very unfavour- kble, and that the astronomical world in general takes almost no trouble about this really important and remarkable phenomenon—important becauso it belongs to a place between meteorology and astronomy. THE Snowdon Railway, when completed, will be similar to the latest of the Swiss mountain railways, the gauge being 2ft. 7iin" no gradients steeper than I in 5t, and the sharpest curves having a radius of four chains. The system to be adopted will be the rack," composed of solid double cast steel u cogs," and the locomotives driving with two double pinions, four teeth, therefore, being in gear at the same time. The length of the line is 4 5-8 miles, and the road will be provided with terminal stations at Llanberis and the summit, with intermediate stations at two pQInt. on the route. docs.full_text: A SATURDAY SERMON. Even though the rniud be a porfecfc stranger to the science of astronomy of these enlightened times, the heavens present a great and an elevating spectacle—an immense concave reposing upon the circular boundary of the world, and the innumerable lights which are suspended from on high moving with solemn regularity along ltt surface. It seems to have been at night that IJbt piety of the Psalmist was awakened by thic contemplation when the moon and stars wen visible, and not when the sun had riien in bit strength, and thrown a splendour around hint which bore down and eclipsed all the leaser glories of the firmament. And there is much in the scenery of a nocturnal sky to lift the soul tc pious contemplation. That moon, and theat stars, what are tbey ? They are detached from the world, and they lift us above it. We feci withdrawn from the earth, and rise in lofty abstraction from this little theatre of human passions and human anxieties. The mind abandons itself to reverie, and is transferred in the ecstasy of its thoughts to distant and unex- plored regions. It sees Nature in the simplicity of her great elements, and it sees the God ot Nature invested with the high attributes of wisdom and majesty. DB. CHiUfm.

A letter was read from Archdeacon Bruce, in which he offered tire society a valuable gift of books ffom his astronomical library. The volumes include some by Admiral Smytb. which have a special interest not only because they are I now vory soatce, but because Smyth (an ances- tor of Baden-Powell's) resided for some time at I Cardiff. The admiral was the first antbor who really ga.ve an impetus to .'maieur observational astronomy in our islands. Amongst the other valuable books are work" in French, German., and Italian, the whole constituting a gift of the atmost importance to the praotieai observer. The Chairman commented warmly on the generosity of Archdeacon Bruce, and a hearty vote of thanks, was accorded him on the motion of Miss Rule, saconded by Mr Conta, of Newpoxt. It was decided to take sacb measures as would place the arcbdeacon's valuable gift, as I well as the rest of the society s property, in permanent. keeping at Cardiff Central Library for convenient reference by tho public. It may be added that the fine telescope geuerousiy presented to Cardiff by Dr. Frunkton Evans (and which, it is hoped, will by and by be erected at Cathays Park) was once the property of Archdeacon Bruce. j

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY OF WALES. The AsirL'onouiiCiii Society ut Wales commenced its half session at the University College, Cardiff, on Friday evening. Mr Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S., presided. A large number of ladies and gentle- men were elected members of the society, and five candidates were proposed. Mr Charles T. Whitmell, M.A., H.M.I., submitted and ex- plained an interesting model of an equatorial stand, which he had devised himself, and which was practically tested by the members outside the building. Mr Whitmell also gave some interesting data, such as the length of the local degree, the time taken by the sun in apparently sweeping across Cardiff and the like. A discussion ensued. A short paper on "Solar Observation," con- tributed by Miss E. Brown (director solar section, B.A.A.), was read and much appreciated, and, in the course of the conversation that followed Mr Waugh (headmaster, Cardiff Higher Grade School) mentioned that he was in the habit of getting his elder scholars to observe the sun through the school telescope, and plot down on ptepared discs the progress ot the spots from day to day. The scholars took much interest in the work. A series of drawings by members was handed round, and observations reported, includ- ing a meteor seen in Pembrokeshire, which made a crackling noise. Professor Tanner kindly con- sented to give members who dasired it an insight into the elementary mathematics of astronomy. It was mentioned that the Cardiff Exhibition authorities would like a telescope and house to figure amongst the exhibits next year.

A PARENTS" PLEA. My little boy is eight years old. He goes to school each day He doesn't mind the tasks they set— They seem to him but play, He heads his class at raffia work, And also takes the lead At making dinky paper boats— But I wish that he could read. They teach him physiology. And oh, it chills our hearts To hear our prattling innocent Mix up his inward parts. He also learns astronomy And names the stars by night— Of course he's very up-to-date. But I wish that he could write.. They teach him things botanical. They teach him how to draw. He babbles of mythologv And gravitation's law" And the discoveries of science With him are quite a fad, They tell me he's a clever boy. But I wish that he could add. -Life.

docs.full_text: To the Editor of THE JOURNAL, SIR,-If any of your astronomical readers had been up and about at 3 o'clock on Tuesday morning last, they would have seen a really grand sight, which I myself saw by chance. I happened to be awake at 3.20. on the morning in question, and, looking out of my window, saw what appeared to me to be an enormous ball of fire, which seemed to be very agitated before it settled down, in a few minutes, into a steady glare. The star, or whatever it was, appeared in the north-east; it had none of the appearance of a comet, but still had a kind of forked tail. At about four o'clock it suddenly seemed to divide, and then the whole disappeared in a second, leading the other smaller stars in the field looking ashamed of themselves. I know nothing about astronomy myself, and cannot tell what it was but having had my night rest disturbed (for which I disturbed others in the house), I should at least like to know what had disturbed it. Perhaps some of your readers can enlighten me. I am yours, etc., F. W. C. Llanstephan Vicarage.

docs.full_text: THERE is a belief current in all parts of India that a certain snake, called Shesh Nig, when it attains the age of 1,000 years, has a precious jewel formed in its head. This jewel, it is affirmed, possesses the quality of sucking up the poison of the deadliest snake, if applied to the wounded part. FORMERLY the problem was:—Given the welfare and advantage of the few, how best to reconcile these with the welfare of the many; it now is: Given the welfare of the many, how best to secure the advantages of the few. The new astronomy transferred the centre of the world from the small earth to the mighty sun; the new sociology transfers the centre of social life from the small group of idlers to the mighty mass of workers.-George Henry Lewes. BETWEEN those two blessings, health and money there is this difference--money is the most envied but the least enjoyed; health is the most enjoyed but the least envied and this superiority of the latter is still more obvious when we reflect that the poorest man would not part with health for money. lyt »U

docs.full_text: STAR ON FIRE. Professor Pepper, in his recent lectures at the Royal Polytechnic, stated that Dr. Bedford has propounded entirely new theories of astronomy, which are most pro- found and very interesting, and well worthy of being studied and very interesting, indeed, these theories must be, to all who were at all alarmed at Professor Pepper's intimation that our world might be destroyed at any moment by some comet falling into the sun, and so increasing its heat as to burn us all to death. In support of this terrifying suggestion, he quoted the opinion of Sir Isaac Newton, that Aucke's comet was getting nearer to the sun at every revolution, and would ultimately fail into the solar orb and produce the said awful result; but, for the consolation of the superstitious, Professor Pepper advised his andieace to read Dr. Bedford's theo ries, which are quite opposed to the great mathemati- cian's opinion. The doctor sturdily disbelieves in the possibility of the destruction, of our earth by an erratic comet, and explains the uttef impossibility of any csi- Vision of ths .ae&estial bodies.

docs.full_text: ANTARCTIC EXPEDITIONS. The boom in Antarctic expeditions has been practically marked and realised by the launch- ing of the two vessels, English and German, intended for exploration of the vast southern territory of ice. The Gauss is a German ship. and the Discovery a British one. Every- thing that shipbuilding art and science can suggest to enable these missioners of science to resist the conditions likely to he en- countered in an antarctic voyage has been made available in their construction. The scientific equipments of the vessels will not be less perfect than the various details re- lating to build and sailing. The general public are slow to appreciate the gi eat value to science which such expeditious are calculated to represent. There arc many details relating to astronomy, geology, physics, meteorology, and other departments ot research which can only be authoritatively settled by the knowledge twined from expedi- tions of this kind. The interests of all sciences are so clearly interwoven, that the advance of one often means the forwarding of all: and the expectation that the Antarctic expeditions will throw light on many problems of physical science, is at least a fair inference drawn from our experience of research in the opposite region of the world.

docs.full_text: Death of the Rev. Owen Williams, Carnarvon. The Welsh Wesleyan body have sustained a great loss in the death of the Rev Owen Williams, who died at his residence, Bryn Aber, Carnarvon, on Tuesday night, after a few days illness. A paralytic seizure on Fri- day morning rendered the condition of the rev gentleman practically hopeless from the beginning. He was in his 78th year, and was one of the oldest ministers in the connexion; he was also at one time among the most powerful preachers on theWelsh circuits. Mr Williams was a native of Llanddyfnan, Anglesey. He enteied upon the work of his first circuit in 1856, and be- came a supernumerary in 1890. His published works included a Welsh edition of the New Testament, which he bad translated direct from the Greek. Besides theology his favourite studies were law and astronomy. His library was made up largely of law books. He sat for several years on the Carnarvon Board of Guardians and the Carnarvon School Board, of which he was vice-chairman% and he was also a member of the Free Lib- rary Committee. A man of an independeofc turn of mind, his opinions were always highly prized by ministers and laymen in the Wesleyan connexion. He leaves a widow with whom much sympathy is felt,

docs.full_text: CRIMEAN DEMONSTRATION AT GLASGOW.—A soiree in honour of the Crimean victories took place in the Glasgow City Hall on Thursday. The movement originated with that portion of the middle and working classes who were unable to take part in the recent banquet, at which the Duke of Hamilton presided. Dr. Nichol, Professor of Astronomy in the University, occupied the chair, supported by Professor Blackie, 'of Edinburgh, some of the city councillors, and other gentlemen of public note in the town. All the speakers on the occasion were favourable to the vigorous prosecution of the war, while the chairman censured the policy of the Peace party. Mr. David Smith, late one of the city magis- trates, eulogised the courage and perseverance of the allied forces; and Professor Blackie pointed out how closely the interests of literature and science, and of all free thought, were involved in the success of the war. The Rev. Mr. Crosskey delivered an energetic address on The alliance between France and England;" after which Mr. R. Bucha- nan spoke to the sentiment No war with America," and towards eleven o'clock the proceedings were brought to a close with a vote of thanks to the chairman.

docs.full_text: --+- PROFESSOR OLMSTED, who died on the 13th, at the age of sixty-eight, was one of the scientific lights of America. He had held the professorial chair of Natural History and Astronomy in Yale College, New Haven, in the State of Connecticut, thirty-three years. He was for seven years, and when young, professor of chemistry in the University of North Carolina. The first geological survey of a state was that of North Carolina, which was projected by Professor Olmsted. He wrote much, being a contributor to SillimmUs Journal, the first scientific periodical of the United States. MR. RICHARD CRAWSHAY.—We have to re- cord the death of Mr. Richard Crawshay, the eldest son and representative of the late William Crawshay, the well-known ironmaster. Mr. Crawshay derived from his father a large share in the great ironworks at Cy- farthfa, Merthyr Tydvil, but of late years had retired on a very ample fortune. The deceased gentleman, who had attained his seventy-third year, and retained his re- markable vigour of mind and bodily energy, had rambled for some miles on Sunday last in the beautiful grounds of Ottershaw Park -his seat in Surrey—when suddenly be complained of slight pain in his chest, and leant against a tree as if to breathe more easily; but he glided down insensible, and almost immediately expired of apo- plexy.

WRIGIIT.-Allother old Peninsular officer, intimately connected with the county of Devon, has passed away. Captain William Henry Wright, of the 4th 'Dragoons, who died a few jiays ago at Lympstone, at the age of 83, entered the army in 1801. He obtained his troop in 1808, served throughout the Peninsular war under the Duke of Wel- lington, and was present at the advance and retreat from Madrid, the advance from Portugal, and at the battles of Talavera, Albuhera, Busaco, the siege and assault of Badajos, the advance and battle of Salamanca, the battles of Yittoria, Ortlies, and Toulouse, besides various minor affaii's. He was presented with the freedom of the City of Exeter in 1813, whilst still in Spain-a distinction which had also been conferred on his father, as colonel of the Exeter regiment of volunteers, which he was instrumental in raisipg. Captain Wright received, the I Peniasular medal wtgh six clasps, iin.18:1S.

At the close of the meeting a vote of thanks to the lecturer was proposed by the Chairman (Mr Joel James), and seconded in the vernacular by Miss Davies, Glancleddau. Death. It is with deep regret that we record the death and funeral of Mrs Harriet Thomas, wife of Mr Joseph Thomas, of 4, Ayron terrace, Ferndale, late of Jordanston Hill, which took place on the 1st and 4th inst. respectively. Deceased who was well- known and popular at Jordanston Hill, and was also highly respected at Ferndale, though her residence was not- of a lengthy character at the latter place. She was but 44 years of age, and the cause of death was consumption, the painful disease being borne with forti- tude. Mrs Thomas was the daughter of the late Mrs Ann Reynolds, who was buried but a fortuight previously, and a sister to Mr Wm Reynolds, Postmaster, Blaenllechau by whom a very beautiful wreath was sent. The funeral was a very large and representative one, Pembrokeshire friends being present in strong numbers. We .extend our sympathy to Mr Thomas and children and all relations in their bereavement.

docs.full_text: SCRIPTURE ILLUSTRATIONS.—No. 228. -40 MATTHEW- XI. 2. For we have seen his star in the east and are come to worship him." It is here natural to enquire how The wise men could know this to be His star, or that it signi- fied the birth of a kuig It has been supposed by many that they learnt this from the prophecy of Balaam, Numb. xxiv. 17. It is certain, as Suetonius, and Tacitus inform us, that an ex- pectation prevailed through the east that about that time a kin should arise out of Judea that should rule over all the world.—Dr Whitby. Probably this star or light was of the nature of what the Jews call the Shechinab or Divine Glory, the appearance of which is mentioned in Mathew xvii. 5.-Bishop Pearce. Perhaps it was the same "Glory of the Lord" or miraculous light which "slione round about the shepherds," which may have appeared to the Magi on the same night, at a great distance, diminished to the size of a star.—Dr. Halts. It was plainly some new appearance, which they, whose profession led them peculiarly to the study of astronomy, had observed in the heavens.-Bishop Porteus.

docs.full_text: LORDGRIMTHORPE'S DEATH.-Lord Gnm- thorpe died at two o'clock on Saturday morning at his seat near St. Albans from heart failure. He is succeeded by his nephew, Mr Ernest Beckett, Conservative member for the Whitby division of Yorkshire. Deceased was well known for his restoration of St. Albans Cathedral and other churches in the neighbourhood, and was the author of several publications on clocks, architecture, and astronomy. A HUNTSMAN'S MEMORIAL.-The golf course which has been laid down on Ellerbeck Common, near Caldbeck, in memory of John Peel, the famous Cumberland huntsman, was formally opened last week by Mr. Banks, of Highmoor, Wigton. Golf links seem a strange memorial to a sportsman of renown, but they may be a means of attracting some people to "John Peel's country." On the fringe of the Cumberland hills, to the north of Skiddaw, the course is laid at the foot of Brae Fell and High Pike. Within 10 minutes' walking distance is the house at Greenrigg where Peel was born in 1777, and equidistant is Rutbwaite, which was Peel's home for 45 years. The course covers over 100 acres The nearest railway station is six miles off, and whether this isolation will prove a blessing to the Calderbeck Golf Club remains to be seon.

docs.full_text: I ♦ I Abergawenny Man and the New Star.—Mr. ) Arthur Mee writes in the Western Mail The question who actually saw the New Star first is still unsettled. Mr. Owsn, of Aberga- venny, informs me that he noticed it with the naked eye on Friday evening, but being very busy did not pay any further attention to the matter. Mr. Owen and his brother both take great interest i- L astronomy, and have an. ex- cellent telescope. Had they reported at one what they saw the honour would have fallen to Monmouthshire, for the star was not officially recorded till the following night. It i3, however, o recorded till the following night. It is, however, of scientific interest to know that it was cer- tainly visible before then." We learn that it was Mr. Edwin Owen who observed the star. He was casually looking at the heavens and noticed a star which at the time he took to be Altair, though it struck him that it was more brilliant and up earlier than Altair. Had he been observing a little later, when Altair was visible from the garden, or had he been in a less encloesd space and had a more extensive view of the heavens, he would at once have realised the significance of the appearance and would have had the honour of being the first to officially report it. The star has during the past few days lost a good deal of its former brilliance. A.

docs.full_text: BRITISH SCHOOL EXAMINATION.—The annual exa. mination of the children in the British schools, in this city, took place on Thursday evening last, in the Halhs Assembly Room, Dean-street, in the presence of a good gathering of their ftienrls, and the supporters of the school. The Rev. Jno, Phillips was voted into the chair, ptevious to the commencement of the proceed- iugs, The examinath"1 was conducted partly by the muster, Mr. John Edmunds, and the pupil teachers under him. The programme comprised Reading, Grammar, Eng nh History, Arithmetic, (mental and ordinary), the phpieal Geography of Turkey. reltive History of the Turks and Russians, generul Geography, llecitations and Astronomy. The children were put thtoi.gh their facings with good tact, and generally tie- quitted themselves with credit in the various departments. Specimens of penmanship, drawing, an,1 also of needle- I woik were handed round the room, and appeared to be well executed. The proceedings were varied by reci- tations and singing, which added to the interest of the evening. The examinations in geography and astro- nomy were conducted with the aid of the magic lantern, Ihe maps and tliagiams exhiuited befng painted on the glasses by the pupil teachers. 'I he examination through- out appeared genclally satisfactory tothe audience. In conclusion the chairmlln congratulated the audience on the pleasant evening which they had spent; he was sure they were well gratified, and hoped that the exa- mination would bring the school into notice, and induce parents to send their children into it for instruction.
