docs.full_text: I DR. COOK'S RECORDS. Startling allegations against Dr. Cook are made in the columns of the "New York Times," which announces that it has com- municated to Copenhagen University affi- davits sworn by George Dunkle, an insurance broker, and August Loose, a sea captain, in which they allege that they agreed, in return for the sum of 4,000dols., to furnish Dr. Cook with certain astronomical and other observa- tions, to be laid before the University. The men declare that they make the revelation because Dr. Cook only paid them 260dols. Captain Loose declares that he supplied twenty-four altitudes for latitude sights and a chart covering the entire route from Svartevaag to the North Pole. In the chart he marked down all the points which the ex- plorer was assumed to have reached in his Po)ar journey, and he made sixteen observa- tions such as could be taken at the Pole. Besides the foregoing observations, Cap- tain Loose and Dunkle, it is stated, provided a set of books on navigation and astronomy and a number of navigation charts. Dr. Cook has not yet had any chance of denying the allegations, and his place of con- cealment remains a secret.

docs.full_text: THE BISHOP OF EXETER ON ASTRONOMY. The Bishop of Exeter presided at a lecture delivered in Victoria Hall, Exeter, by Mr. Proctor, on the Solar System. At its conclusion he remarked that it was one of the greatest gratifications a rational being could enjoy to hear the works of God so described. Such studies as these gave man a fuller and deeper sense of the majesty and power of the Father whom all worshipped, and a deeper sense of the greatness of liim who had created these things and allowed us to enjoy a knowledge of them. He trusted that, as time went on, studies of this character would flourish, and that God would unveil more and more of the greatness of His works, and more and more allow the minds of men to partake of the enjoyment of His wonderful majesty. The discoveries of recent years were wonderful, and the sights now revealed raised man in the scale of being, making them better under- stand themselves and Him who was the source ef all things,

docs.full_text: LITERARY Å=D SCIENTIFIC ￼ POPULAR. LECTURES ON ASTRONOMY.—I>y the late M. Arago, translate; with Note. by W alter Iy lve y* Esii. 15. A., of Trinity College, Dublin. I iit-h Edi- tion, revised up to the present time, by the Rcy. L Tomlinson, )'LA.; Routlcdge, Farnngdon-strcct. 18.51. English popular science scarcely needed the transla- tion of a foreign work on elementary astronomy, Sir John Ilerschei's book, which lays a thorough founda- tion for the theory of Astronomy, together with Dr. Lardner's, which incorporates all the amusing part of astronomical observation, by describing the physical constitution of the different worlds, nearly exhaust all that can be required on tho subject. X enrthclcss, the distinguished name of M. Arago may lead some per- sons to prefer this book to some of our English works but thev will find it better adapted for a school treatise than for the perusal of those who, having acquired a general knowledge of the subject, wish to extend it by the help of the lucid exposition of a great French as- tronomer. The book is loss diihonlb OJK! less thorough than Sir John Ilerschei's work, which is almost too difficult for a mere begiuner and it is much less com- prehensive and minute than Dr. Lardner's. It is, how- ever almost too technical for the class of readers for whom it is designed, and we arc somewhat disappointed that the great characteristics of French learning lucid exposition and happy arrangement-scarcely seem, to characterise the work before us in any remarkable de- gree. If any of our readers should unwarily havc pur- chased this cheap little book for railway perusal, and feel aggrieved at not finding in it the amusing qualities of Dr. Lardnel"£ works on the same subject, we recom- mend him to turn to the portion on the comets, which he will probably pronounce readable even in a railway carriage. Indeed, the study of comets is quite an ex- citing science. The planets, which were wanderers" (as their name implies) to the ancients, are quite dull and domestic to us. Everybody knows what they can do, and where they must go. The planets are only tame omets—those whose physical nature has assumed a permanent shape, and whose orbit is so strictly in. variable that little more interest can be felt on their account by the gazers after celestial wonders. Comets, M. Arago defines as celestial bodies which describe an eclipse of such an eccentricity as to cease to be visible during a part of their revolution." Etymolo- gically they are hairy stars, and, in point of fact, they arc the Esaus of the Heavens—so eccentric in their habits that no one knows when a comet may come first within our field of observation, though it may have been scouring the sky as long as the earth has been turning on her axis, and so liable to material changes of constitution that occasionally they are scarcely to be recognised on a second arrival. For in- stance, there is one little comet discovered in 1770, which, from the attractions to which it has been sub- jected, had so changed its orbit that no one knew it again when it came back. The same irregular star has since changed its path so much at every revolution, owing to the powerful influence of Jupiter upon it, as to baffle the vigilcnce of our astronomical watchmen and quite evade identification. The story of comets,—what they are, what they might do, what they may have done, what their tails acet may do, and may have done,—is quite the romance of astronomy. We have very little accurate know- ledge," says *-Af. kra-o, "respecting the tails of comets." Indeed, Hcrschel says, "There is beyond doubt some profound secret and mystery of nature concerned in, the phenomenon of their tails." This is the definition of the different parts of a comet:— "The widens of a comet is the central point, which is more or less lustrous. The nebulous light surround- 1 I ing the nucleus is called in French the elicvalure, or the hair. The lumi nous trams by h comets are ac- l mnmous rams >y,11e most etg are ac- companied, were formerly called beards or tails, ac- cordingly as they preceded or followed the comet in its line of march. At present they are called tails, what- ever be their position. "Lastly, the nucleus and the chovelurc together, constitute the head of the comot."

docs.full_text: llitrraturt WELDON'S PENNY HOUSE OF COMMONS, pub- lished by Messrs. Weldon and Co., WineOffice court, Fleet-street, is a marvellously cheap production. For a penny the purchaser can obtain a handy little pamphlet, printed with good type on capital paper, giving the names and politics of each member of Par- liament, the county, university, borough or city, that he represents, with the number of the electors and the populations of each constituency in the years 1861 and 1871. These simple facts are the highest praise that could be awarded to so cheap a produc. ti@n, which is certain to have, as it well deserves, a broad-cast circulation. THE DAY OF REST.-The current number of this magazine commences the new year with a decided improvement in the style of its woodcuts, several of the ill-drawn and defaced German blocks being re- placed by newer designs from an English, pencil. Mr R. A. Proctor, whose books on astronomy are deser- vedly famed, contributes a couple of articles on "Light" and" Space" which will be found well- worthy of perusal. Mrs. Fllen Ross, the author of a "Candle Lighted by the Lord," commences a pro- mising sorial story entitled "Dora's Boy;" while Airs. O'Reilly contributes the opening chapters of The Story of Ten Thousand Homes in a very in teresting style. The stories and essays are all com- menced with tke January number, thus forming a convenient opportunity for fresh subscribers to obtain this excellent periodical.

docs.full_text: PHOTOGRAPHY AND SCIENCE. Tennyson's words, tho fairy tales of science," applied by him to the discoveries made in the natural world more than hctif a century ago, are most aptly descriptive of the information furnished by Prof. Dewar, in his lactures on "Chemical Action of Light," delivered to juveniles at the Royal Institu- tion. Professor Dewar, in his concluding exposition, chiefly dwelt on certain phenomena in connection with some solid bodies after their subjection to the action of light. Brilliant and successful as was the series of experiments performed to illustrate one of the most remarkable discoveries in the pro- gress of modern science, those points in the lecture were not more interesting than the lecturer's state- ments respecting the beautfulj practical applications which had been made of the discovery. It had, and would, greatly enlarge the resources of photographic art, and facilitate the arrangement for taking photo- graphic pictures, and would be of peculiar value in etching and printing processes. In drawing attention to the more recent and subtle developments in photo- graphy, Professor Dewar took occasion to point out its services as an auxiliary in the investigations of the student of science. This feature in the history of the art was fully illustrated by the lecturer, who indi- cated the obligations of science to it, respectively in astronomy, electricity, optics, and even physiology, as evidenced in the" photo" pictures which have been obtained of minute organisms in living bodies, and believed by more than one eminent scientist to be germs of disease.

docs.full_text: OLD WORLD MOROCCO. News travels monstrously fast in Morocco. Before the stranger has entered the gates of the city every man knows on what business he is come, and wha horse he is riding. Even the wretched prisoners wjj shout up questions as one looks down upon tnem through the bars, great and small, herded together in a foul and filthy den, walking restlessly about like bears in a pit. And we sit sipping our green tea, cup after cup; pale green tea sweetened and scented with mint and violets. And no one knows, writes a correspondent of the Pall Mall Gazette from Tangier, how matters will end. Difficult it is to grasp the extreme age of their civilisation, and how much we have learned from them. And yet their level, always the same, has been none too high. Great warriors they were, and from them we have our astronomy and our medicine. But now, where in days gone by the pillars and arches of the gates were of curious marbles and precious /metals, we find still the Same form, the same design btrti the doore Of the Pacha's house are of plaster of Paris,

docs.full_text: THE OLDEST PICTURE-BOOK. I The oldest picture-book of all was designed nearly 5000 years ago by a people dwelling somewhere between Ægean and the Caspian, which domesticated the bull, the sheep, the goat, the dog, and the horse which hunted the bear, the lion, and the hare, and used the bow and the spear. Yet a people not merely nomadic, but either maritime themselves or at least acquainted with the ocean and with naviga- tion. They had made not a little progress in astronomy, for they had determined the length of the year, and had carried the science of observation so far that they could recognise the position of the sun relative to the various ecliptic group of stars. Their religion, says a writer in the Nineteenth Century Magazine, involved the erection of altars and the rite of sacrifice. They were acquainted with stories of the Fall and of the Deluge substantially the same as those preserved to us in the early chapters of Genesis, and they devised many of the constellations to give appropriate and permanent record of them, no doubt because they were included, as with ourselves, in their sacred history. The people was an organised one, having some definite and recognised authority, whether king, priest, patriarch, or Council does not appear; but of that authority the work of constellation-making received beyond doubt the express sanction.

docs.full_text: SIR ROBERT BALL, LL.D. THE Gilchrist Lectures in Llangollen have brought prominently under notice at the very first stage of the series a noted scientist and astronomer in the person of Sir Robert Stawell Ball. This gentleman was born on July 1st, 1840. His scholastic career was a distinguished one, and gave healthy promise of the matured and popular lecturer we listen to with so much interest to-day. He entered Trinity College, Dublin, in 1857, and in 1861, after a dis- tinguished undergraduate course, took the degree of Bachelor of Arts, obtaining at the final examination two senior moderatorships (with gold medals), one in mathematics, the other in experimental and natural science, and being elected to the mathematical studentship of the year. His first important step in an astronomical career was in 1865, when he became the late Lord Rosse's astronomer at Parsonstown. In 1887 he was appointed to the Professorship of Applied Mathematics and Mechanism in the Royal College of Science, Dublin, an institution founded for the purpose of giving instruction in such branches of science as are applicable to the industrial arts. His first work, Experimental Mechanics," published in 1870, contained the substance of a special course of evening lectures delivered in that college for the benefit of artizans and others who were unable to attend the ordinary classes. In 1872 he took the degree of LL.D., and in 1873 became a Fellow of the Royal Society. In 1874 he was elected Andrews' Professor of Astronomy in the University of Dublin, and Royal Astronomer of Ireland. In 1876 he published his "Theory of Screws," which attracted much attention by its originality, and the mathematical powers ex- hibited in it. The author gave an account of the theory, under the title of "A Dynamical Parable," to the British Association at Man- chester, and this has been translatod into Italian and Hungarian. It was principally for this work that he received the Cunningham Gold Medal of the Royal Irish Academy, which was awarded to him in 1879. It was in the year 1884 that he published an elaborate treatise on astronomy-his pet subject-in which he gave a popular exposition of the most recent develop- ments of science. The year 1886 was a memorable one for him, inasmuch as his attain- ments had become so far recognised in the world of science that he was rewarded with the dignity of knighthood. The object to which Sir Robert Ball has principally directed his observations as Astronomer Royal is the in- vestigation of Annual Parallax. Attention was first attracted to his abilities as a public lecturer by an address dellvered at the opening of the Midland Institute in Birmingham, entitled "A Glimpse through the Corriders of Time." He has since become well known by his lectures on astronomy in various parts of the United Kingdom. He has for many years lectured, chiefly to artizans, under the auspices of the Gilchrist Trust; and this is a work in which he is understood to take special pleasure. A little volume, Starland," published in 1889, contains the substance of a course of lectures delivered two years before to young people at the Royal Institution. He has also published a singularly interesting and learned work, In Starry Realms." Sir Robert Ball's genial temper and frankness of character, and, it may be added, the vein of kindly humour with which he is endowed, have made him a general favourite, as was witnessed the other night at Llangollen. In addition to the other offices mentoined above, he is president of the Zoological Society of Ireland, scientific adviser to the Commissioners of Irish Lighthouses, a member of the Council of the Astronomical Society, a vice-president of the Royal Irish Academy, a member of the Council of Trinity College, Dublin, one of the trustees of the National Library of Ireland, an honorary Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, and an honorary member of the Cambridge Phil- osophical Society. In 1892 Sir Robert Ball was appointed Lowndean Professor of Astronomy and Geometry in the University of Cambridge. This is surely a record to be proud of; and he may not yet have reached the top of the scientific tree-a laudable ambition.

docs.full_text: AN IInDIAN ASTROLOGER. The Punjaubce press has been recently lamenting the death of Kanh Singh, a distinguished native scholar. He once occupied the post of Astronomer- in-Chief to the late Maharajah of Cashmere. He translated several works in astronomy from English, Sanskrit, and Arabic, and he had perhaps the finest astronomical library in India. He was so much esteemed as an astronomer that the Maharajah was anxious to build an observatory for him, but was pre- vented by the great expense. He wrote an analytical work on Urdu grammar, and also some lyrical pieces. He has left behind him an autobiography which cannot fail to be interesting. During the mutinies of Delhi lie was in command of a native force, and showed himself to be both a loyal and a brave subject of the Queen. Subsequently he took an active part in prison, educational, arid other reforms in the native State of Puttiala, as well as in the Punjaub. The history of Kanh Singh, who, although a Sikh warrior by birth, gained so many laurels in the walks of peace, is full of instruction. It is worthy of remark that he gave to an American missionary the credit 01 his education.

docs.full_text: COOKING AND MATRIMONY "A girl who deliberately marries without understanding the art or cooking is," says Home Citat, committing a-well, the law of the land doesn't call it a crime, but the unwritten law of the home does certainly constitute it a crime. Especially is this true of those in modest circum- stances who cannot employ efficient cooks. Burnt fingers, sour bread, scorched roasts, leathery steaks, wisby.washy coffee, and disorganised stomachs are not conducive to the happiness that one supposes the honeymoon should be SUed I with. There art; so many reasons, logical and philosopmcal, way cooking should be included in the accomplishment of young girls that it is useless to enumerate them. Cood cooking is the basis of happiness, health, and success in the home life. One may thoroughly understand arb, music, architecture, science, and philosophy, be familiar with astronomy, mythology, the mva. teries of evolution, politics, and literature, yet. if the chemistry of a loaf of bread has been nejt. lected, the education is sadly incomplete, so fat as the 'house mother' is concerned."

docs.full_text: DEATH OF PltOFSSSOS PRTTCHAnD. Professor Charles -'ritchard, Sivilian Prof sor of Ast" n my at Oxford University, died at Oxford on Sundi". Professor Pritchard, D D., was born in 1808, and was, therefor- in his 85th year. Hd graduated at St. John's College, Cambric!-re, in 1830, and appears earl e to have dFvoted him -elf to the study of astronomical science, in whi h lie acquired considerable, renown, lie wrote many treatises upon his favourite study, some of which were first published in tl.e "Transactions of the Astronomical Society." Re also contributed to th-^ "Encyclopedia Britanr.ica" and the "Biblical Dictionary." In 1890 a collection of his writings was published under the title of "Occasional Thoughts of an Astron mer on Nature and Revela- tion." Dr. Pritchard was pr"sillem of the Royal Astronomical Society in loG: was elected Hu'sean Lecturer at Cambridge in 1867, and Savilian Pro- fessor of astronomy at Oxford in 1370. He had, therefore, held the post for 22 yezrs. It was on his representations that the university built the observatory, and provided lecture-room* and appliances for astron< mirai irstruction and res^rrch. He received the gold medal of the Astronc mical Society in 1886 for his Uranometria Nova Oxoniensis," and was elected an h< norary Fellow of his college at Cambridge. Dr. Pritchard, who pre- served his faculties unimpaired till the last, died surrounded by all the members of his family. He had been lecturing this term, and his death was unexpected.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY OF WALES The Astronomical Society of Wales eomrnenot. its half session at the University College, Cardiff, on Friday evening. Mr Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S., presided. A large number of ladies and gentle. men were elected members of the society, and five candidates were proposed. Mr Charles T. Whitmell, M.A., H.NLI., submitted and ex- plained an interesting model of an equatorial stand, which he had devised himself, and which, was practically tested by the members outside the building. Mr Whitmell also gave some interesting data, such as the length of the local degree, the time taken by the sun in apparently sweeping across Cardiff and the like. A discussion ensued. A short paper on "Solar Observation," con- tributed by Miss E. Brown (director solar section, B.A.A.), was read* and much appreciated, and, in the course of the conversation that followed. Mr Waugh (headmaster, Cardiff Higher Grade School) mentioned that be was in the habit of getting his elder scholars to observe the BUB. through the school telescope, and plot down on prepared discs the progress ot the spots from day to day. The scholars took much interest in th4 work. A series of drawings by members Waf handed round, and observations reported, includ- ing a meteor seen in Pembrokeshire, which made, a crackling noise. Professor Tanner kindly con- sented to give members who desired it an insight; into the elementary mathematics of astronomy. It was mentioned that the Cardiff Exhibition authorities would like a telescope and bouse to figure amongst the exhibits next year.

docs.full_text: THE SWANSEA •• RAPHAEL." Concerning the painting entitled The Recon- ciliation of Philosophy and Astronomy," which, as announced a few days ago, has been found to be in the possession of Mr Vignoles, of the Lon- don and Midland Bank, Swansea, and is valued at an immense sum, the picture has been lost sight of for 370 years, but there is little doubt as to its genuineness, for it agrees entirely with the description given of it in Vazari's Lives of Cele- brated Painters," but no artist could have painted it from that description, from which the details of Raphael's marvellous mass of allegorical represen- tations are missing. It is perhaps the most beau- tiful piece of spirit-painting in existence. There are in all 70 figures in the work, including the Apostles, the Virgin, St. David, St. Michael, and St. Joseph. It was the fact that the National Gallery authorities gave £ 70,000 for the Marl- borough Raphael that induced the owner of the I- Reconciliation to investigate the history of his treasure.

docs.full_text: THE CELTIC FRINGE. TO THE EDITOR. SIR,—Jusb now, when so much is being said iu disparagement of the Celtic fringe, it may be well to recall the eulogies of impartial critics. Emerson, speaking of the ancestors of the Eng- lish—Celtic, German, and Norman-says, "They are of the oldest blood of the world—the Celtic. Some peoples are deciduous and transitory— where are the Greeks ? Where the Etrurians ? Where the Romans ? But the Celts, or Sidorides, are of an old family, of whose beginning there is no memory, and their end is more remote in the future, for they have endurance and productive* ness. They planted Britain, and gave to the seas and the mountains names which are poems, and imitate the pure voices of nature. They are favourably remembered in the oldest records of Europe. They had no violent feudal tenure, but tbo husbandman owned the land. They bad an alphabet, astronomy, priestly culture, and a sublime creed. They have a hidden and pre- 'carious genius. They made the best popular literature of the middle ages in the songs of Merlin, and the tender and delicious mythology of Arthur." This is only one of many eulogistic references to < the Celts. It is rather late in the day, therefore, to attempt a serious disparage- ment of the fringe and above all to endeavour to arouse dormant racial antipabhies is the name -of a spurious Unionism.—I am, &c., PHIL. Cardiff, 20th July, 1895.

docs.full_text: A SELF-MADE ASTRONOMER'S CAREER. A remarkable figure has disappeared from the scientific life of England. Mr Lanerdon, the self-made astronomer," as ha was known throughout Devonshire, was the son of a farm labourer. His education was acquired in the Sunday school. However, he wat a young fellow of remarkable diligence, and while work- ing in Jersey as a blacksmith be obtained an excellent knowledge of French. He sought many vocations, but at last he settled down as a porter in the employ of the Great Western Railway Company. Bristol being the scene of his first year's service. How his thoughts were directed to astronomy was a mystery he him- self could never understand. However, all his life beeame centred in the astronomical science. A man of resource, he, being unable to purchase the necessary tools, made them. While still a switchman, he produced a telescope live feet long and six inches in diameter. This inspired his inventive genius, and he soon produced an equatorial reflecting telescope and a remarkable camera fitted for instantaneous photography. Presently Mr Nasmyth's attention was directed to him, and he showed him bow to make his tools. The railway man was never rendered ambitious by his success. He obtained a singular reputation in the astronomical world, and he became known as one of the most accurate of our observers but he remained through it all a railway man, and he died station-master at Silverton, a quaint little place near Exeter.

LECTUFEE ON "THE USAGES AND CUSTOMS OF THB EISTEDDFOD."—On Saturday evening last a lecture was delivered at the Athenaeum Hall (In the above subject, by Mr Robert Evana, better Ibownin bardic circles by the name of Glan Gonwy. The chair was occupied by Mr David Bowen (Deheufardd), who, in introducing the lecturer, made a few remarks on the use and abuse of the ritual of the Eisteddfod. The lecturer delineated the various forms and customs connected with the gorsedd and urdd, and referred to the severe examination the ovid and bard had to undergo in olden times. Before he was introduced to the gorsedd for ordination he had to pass aa. examination in language, arithmetic, masic, astronomy, mensuration, and astrology. The term ovid in the gorsedd circle was similar to mattes of arts, and the term bard to-that of doctor of divinity; the bard being Looked upon as a person proficient in things spiritual. Iu the course of his address, Glan Conwy gave specimens of the poetry of several Welsh bards. El)eua.rdd's description of The destruction of Jeru- salem," and Caledfiyn on "The storm," were very well rendered. A vote of thanks to the lecturer was proposed \y Mr David rilihipx, md seconded P7, leg.

docs.full_text: LLANARMON, PWLLHELI. PENNY READINGS.—On Tuesday, another of these meetings took place at the Schoolroom, under the super- vision of the Rector of the parish, the Rev. St. George Armstrong Williams. The chairman opened the meet- ing with a few remarks on the Importance of Knowledge, and mentioned the fact that most Welsh localities re- ceived their names from some tradition connected with the spot, and in illustration read a translation of the ballad Llewelyn and his Dog." This was followed by an interesting paper on astronomy, which was very well delivered by Mr. Robert Griffiths, of Cae Newydd, and the successful prize essay on the Relative duties of Masters and Servants has again read by request. Se- veral songs and glee3 were very well sung by some of chose present, and Mr. John Jones, the schoolmaster, read some very pretty verses composed by himself on the death of a little girl in the neighbourhood. The meeting terminated with a few more remarks from the chairman, and the singing of the National Anthem.

docs.full_text: Sir William H. Preece on the Charms of Sclpnce Sir W. H. Preece, F.R.S., late engineer- in-chief and electrician to the Post Office, paid a visit to Llangollen, when he ad- dressed a crowded and influential audience in the Assembly Rooms. Mr Everitt pre- sided. Sir William met with a flattering reception, and delivered an interesting ad- dress on "The charm of Science." Science, he considered, was divided into three great classes, firstly experimental, embodying chemistry and electricity; secondly, and the most important, styled observational, and thirdly the branch known as applied science or engineering. Regarding me- chanics he considered the bicycle or tricycle the most beautiful scientific apcaratus. He commendetl the study of astronomy, and drew special attention to the shower of meteors to be noticed on November 14th, 15th, and 16th next. Referring to the wonderful application of science he traced the construction of roads, railways, tele- graphy, and the telephone. Regarding telegraphy, he said it was truly marvellous the'way in which news was disseminated all over the world, as instanced by the daily press, particularly when by its means on the Thames Embankment thousands of persons on the previous day were enabled to view an exact reproduction of the great yacht race in America. He hoped the' pre- sence of the telegraph wires between here and the Cape would bring some petople to their senses, as everyone hoped war would be checked and peace restored.

THE WEATHER PROPHET OF HOLYHEAD. —In answer to a correspondent respecting thefRoberts' family of Holyhead, R )li, i-t Roberts was a son of John Lewis Robens, or Shon Robert Lewis, according to his bardic name. He was also an astronomer, poet, and preacher with the Independents. He was the composer of the two first verses of the well-known hymn, Braint, braint, Yw cae! cymdeithas gyda'r Saint." His son, Robert, wrotea book on geography and astronomv, and went about the country lecturing on astronomy. He ex- hibited the working of the solar system by a machine which he had himself invented. He was a well-educated man, and had been a tutor in an academy in London before settling in Holyhead. Any other particulars would be gladly received. J. ROBERTS. SARN MYXACH.—With reference to the recent enquiry in your "Past Days'" coiumn, permit me to say that Penysarn ought to indicate the direction of the Crossing, and to me it seems most probable that the Monks of Maenan regularly travelled to Rhos Trillo, just as those of LI tnddwvn Abbey crossed the Menai and conducted regular services at Clynog. Of course, it is admitted that a strong portion of the Conway flowed through the Vale of Mochdre. B. A.

docs.full_text: LLANLLECHID. NIGHT SCHOOL.—A night school in connexion with the National day School has been established, in which the elementary subjects are taught. But to make the school more suitable for adults, a monthly lecture forms part of the routine to which tbe public are admitted free, nd they ha,e likewise the privilege of bringing with them a I to hear tbe lea?ife, The course f lectures will embrace various subjects such as electricity, astronomy, and physiogmany; tbeae will be treated in a simple, intelligent manner, at once instructive and enter- taining. The various clergymen and several other gen- tlemen in the neighbourhood, have kindly promised their assistance, and it is to be hoped that the vast number of young men who have much time to spare will take advantage of this opportunity to improve themselves. Last Friday evening, Dr. Hughes, Bethesda, attended the school, and delivered an address to the scholars, in which he adduced several examples of men, who, by employing their Leisure Hours," rose to great emi- nence, and therefrom be drew the inference, that what had been done, other things being equal, might be done again. The address was attentively listened to. At the conclusion, the Rev. J. Evans, the rector, pro- posed a vote of thank< to the lecturer, and expressed a wish that Mr. Hughes would favour the scholars with another lecture, which Air. Hughes kindly promised to do.

docs.full_text: LLANLLECHID. I LECTURE.—The Rev. J. Price, M.A., the newly ap- pointed Vicar of Bangor, delivered an astronomical alec. ture in the National School-room on Tuesday evening last. The lecture was illustrated by a powerful magic lantern, and the views were altogether excellent. The rev. gentleman spoke of the various theories respecting the revolution of the heavenly bodies, and alluding to the opposition which Copernicus met with for asserting that the earth revolved round the sun. He said that the Bible was written not to teach astronomy, geogra- phy, nor any other science, but the way of salvation to man. The lecturer spoke for nearly two hours, and throughout the whole of the time the large audience was very attentive. The Rev. J. Evans, the Rector of the parish, proposed a vote of thanks to Mr. Price for his able lecture, which was heartily responded to. We understand that this is the last lecture which Mr. Price will deliver in these parts as Incumbent of Glanogwen, and that the lecture was delivered to keep a promise made previous to his promotion. The rev. gentleman had already delivered his farewell sermon to his own people on Sunday evening, but up to the last his labours have been unremitting, and he leaves the neighbour- hood with the warm wishes of the people amongst whom he has so successfully laboured for a number of years.

docs.full_text: THE MEN OF '89. The French Republic is about to do honour to the men of '89 by the erection of a monument in memory of the Assemble Constituent. The monument is to take the form of a stately column surmounted by a statue of the Republic, and at the four sides of the Butile are to be placed statues of four typical leaders of the Revolution. Bailly comes first, time honoured historian of astronomy, ancient and modern," whose serenely beautiful moral philosophising, with its soft moonsbiny clearness and thinnell," shall be at length commemorated, and that last Hell-day," with its trembling—though only for cold-atoned for. Next comes the greater image of Mirabeau, the wild Gabriel Honor6, flower of the Arighetti or Riquetti family, the "Pharos and wonder-sign of an amased Europe in those days of '89—the greatest of all its figures then, and certainly the greatest still, far out- shining the three companions who are to stand by' him in effigy. Curiously alternated comes next the Abb6 Sieyes, the system builder and Constitution monger-general," who, still said to be alive in 1834, is honoured now by such great companionship Last comes Lafayette, whom Carlyle nicknamed Cromwell Grandiaon." A strange quadrilateral-perhapl not unhappily'"expressive of the strangely divergent elements in the politics and the people of the first year of the French Revolution.

docs.full_text: PHOTOGRAPHING THE SKY. The map of the heavens which the international astronomers, now assembled at the Paris Observatory, are taking steps to prepare, will be composed of from 1800 to 2000 sheets, and will give an exact impression of all the groups of stars. A new impetus will thence be given to the science of astronomy, and it will be possible for astronomers to study the distribution of the stars and perchance the constitution of the uni- verse. So Admiral Moucbez and his friends are thus, it will be seen, engaged in a most important work, the value of which may be gathered, in a great measure, from the fact that they will be able, by means of the new and improved instruments which are used at the Paris Observatory, to diagnose, if such a term can be employed, the 100,000,000 of stars which, according to the statistics compiled, exist in the firmament. Admiral Mouchez states that, with the aid of the immensely improved apparatus, heavenly objects were plainly visible, such as Maia, one of the Pleiades, which had hitherto escaped the observation of astronomers and it is hoped that the same instruments will enable further progress to be realised, and that accurate and clear photographs will be taken on an extensive scale.

docs.full_text: GERMAN BOOK PUBLISHING, The official account of the publishing trade in Germany shows that during the year 1880, the num- ber of new works or new edition published within the Empire was 14,941. This includes 300 maps. The increase on the previous year was 762 and for the three years 1878-80 the increase over the production of 1877 was 1,016, or a little over 7 per cent. Educational literature of all kinds in 1880 included 1,950 works; politics, law, and statistics, 1,557 theo- logy, 1,390; belles lettres, 1,209; "works for the people," 657; philosophical, 125 map, 301; mpdical and veterinary, 790 the natural sciences, 787; litera- ture for the young, 496; antiquities, ancient classics, and Oriental philology, 533; modern languages and old German literature, 506; history and biography, 752; geography,^ 356; mathematics and astronomy, 201; military science and the management of horses (they are included in the same category), 353; trade and manufactures, 583 architecture, mechanical en- gineering, railways, mining, and shipbuilding, 403; forest culture, hunting, &c., 112 domestic economy and farming, 433; the fine arts and stenography, 627 freemasonry, 20 miscellaneous, 423.

docs.full_text: PHOTOGRAPHY AND SCIENCE. Tennyson's words, the fairy tales of science," applied by him to the discoveries made in the natural world more than h<*lf a century ago, are most aptly descriptive of the information furnished by Pror. Dewar, in his lectures on "Chemical Action of Light," delivered to juveniles at the Royal Institu- tion. Professor Dewar, in his concluding exposition, chiefly dwelt on certain phenomena in connection with some solid bodies after their subjection to the action of light. Brilliant and successful as was the series of experiments performed to illustrate one of the most remarkable discoveries in the pro- gress of modern science, those points in the lecture were not more interesting than the lecturer's state- ments respecting the beautfull practical applications which had been made of the discovery. It bad, and would, greatly enlarge the resources of photographic art, and facilitate the arrangement for taking photo- graphic pictures, and would be of peculiar value in etching and printing processes. In drawing attention to the more recent and subtle developments in photo- graphy, Profeasdr Dewar took occasion to point out its services as an auxiliary in the investigations of the student of science. This feature in the history of the art was fully illustrated by the lecturer, who indi- cated the obligations of science to it, respectively in astronomy, electricity, optics, and even physiology, as evidenced in the photo pictures which have been obtained of minute organisms in living bodies, and believed by more than one eminent scientist to be germs of disease.

docs.full_text: THE BISHOP OF EXETER ON ASTRONOMY. The Bishop of Exeter presided at a lecture delivered in Victoria Hall, Exeter, by Mr. Proctor, on the Solar System. At its conclusion he remarked that it was one of the greatest gratifications a rational being could enjoy to hear the works of God so described. Snch studies as these gave man a fuller and deeper sense of the majesty and power of the Father whom all worshipped, and a deeper sense of tha greatness of him who had created these things and allowed us to enjoy a knowledge of them. He trusted that, as time wen ton, studies of this character would flourish, and tha I God would unveil more and more of the greatness of His works, and more and more allow the minds of men to partake of the enjoyment of His wonderful majesty. The discoveries of recent years were wonderful, and the sights now revealed raised man in the scale of being, making them better under- stand themselves and Him who was the source of all things.

docs.full_text: THE BRITISH ASSOCIATION. JUBILEE MEETING AT YORK. The jubilee meeting of the British Association, celebrating its fiftieth anniversary, was ojiened on Wednesday at York. Sir John Lubbock, the president, in his inaugural address, dwelt upon the progress of different branches of science during the past half century. Over and above the im- mense accumulation of facts, we have, he pointed out, the theory of evolution, and no one would question the immense impulse which Darwin had given to the study of natural history. We now know that the stripes of the tiger have refer- ence to life among the jungle passes, that the lion is sandy like the desert, and that the markings of the leopard resemble spots of sunshine glancing through the leaves. Man's I existence has been carried back to a distance of time which changed our view of ancient-history. Great light has been thrown on the correlation of forces, and the conservation of energy and in astronomy the spectrum analysis is discovering t-o us the composition of the heavenly bodies. He dwelt on the innumerable applications "f science dwelt on the innumerable applications "f science I a i J Up 1 a limit tn the \'Ci\)lHl1l'Lu.. or c- H:'C\l'H eU"l ) l' n H I\ i.\t l 1 "1 of man. docs.full_text: COOKING AND MATRIMONY. "A girl who deliberately marries without understanding the art of cooking is," says Home Chat, committing a-well, the law of the land doesn't call it a icrime, but the unwritten law of the home does certainly constitute it a crime. Especially is this true of those in modest circum- stances who cannot employ efficient cooks. Burnt fingers, sour bread, soorched roasts, leathery steaks, wishy-washy coffee, and disordered stomachs are not conducive to the happiness that one imagines the honeymoon should be filled with. There are so many reasons, logical and philosophical, why cooking should be included I in the accomplishment of young girls that it is useless to enumerate them. Good cooking is the basis of happiness, health, and success in the home life. One may thoroughly understand art, music, architecture, science, and philosophy, be familiar with astronomy, mythology, the my teries of evolution, politics, and literature, yet. if the chemistry of a loaf of bread has been neg- lected, the education is sadly incomplete, so far as the 'hottse mother' is concerned."

docs.full_text: THE OLDEST PICTURE BOOK. The oldest picture book was designed nearly 5,000 years ago by a people dwelling somewhere between jEgean and the Caspian, which domesticated the bull, the sheep, the goat, the dog, and the horse which bunted the beat, the lion, and the hare, and used the bow and the spear. Yet a peoplanoii merely nomadic, but either, liinntiine themselves or a« least acquainted with the ocean aud with navigation. They had mode not a little progress in astronomy, for they had; determined the length of the year, and bad carried the soience of observation so far that they could recognifce the position of the sun relative to the various ecliptic groups of stars. Their religion, says a writer in the Nineteenth Century Magazine." involved the erection of altars and the rite of sacrifice. They were acquainted with stories of the Fall and of the Deluge substantially the same as those preserved to us in the early chapbars of Genesis, and they- devised many of the constellations to give appro- priate and permanent record of them, no doubt because they wera included, as with ourselves, in their sacred history. The people was an >organised one, having seme definite and recognised authority, whether kiug, priest, patriarch, or Council does not appear but of that authority the work of constellation-making received beyond doubb the expressed sanction.

docs.full_text: CARDIFF'S NEW F.R.S. It is a notable distinction to be a Fellow of the Royal Society, and Cardiff has felt proud of the fact, that, for some years now, one of its most valued citizens, Principal Viriamu Jones, be- longed to the fellowship of the oldest scientific society in Great Britain. It is our pleasing duty to record that another Cardiff man has been similarly honoured. Mr H. W. Lloyd Tanner, F.R.A.S., professor of mathematics and astronomy at the University College of South Wales, has just been elected F.R,S. We believe we are correct in stating that Mr Lloyd Tanner is the only mathematician of the year to have thus attracted the appreciative notice of the Council of the Royal Society. We congratulate the Professor upon his well-earned distinction, and the University College of South Wales and Monmouthshire upon possessing two Fellows of the Royal Society in the ranks of its officers-a. unique record for any scholastic institution in the Principality. It is interesting to know that the Royal Society of London for Improving Natural Knowledge—to gi /e the association its full title- was founded so far back as 1645, the charter of incorporation passing the Great Seal in July, 1662. The Royal Society holds the foremost place among the scientific bodies of England, not only from the number of eminent men included in its fellowship, but also from its close official connection with the Government. =-

docs.full_text: UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF SOUTH WALES AND MONMOUTHSHIRE. SWANSEA LOCAL LECTURES. PROFESSOR TANNER'S REPORT. The following report was laid before the Senate of the University College at their last meeting — In accordance with an arrangement made by the Senate. I delivered a course of lectures on Astronomy at the Soyal Institution of South Wales, Swansea, during the Lent Term. An examination was held at the end of thecourse. Upon the resulis of that examination, and taking into account the class work shown up, I recom- mend that the College certificate shonld be awarded to each of the students whose names are given below in alphabetical order :Mr. F. J. U. Carulla, Miss Agnes Cawker, Miss Adelaide Hall, Mrs- Huxham, Mr. Coamore Johns. Miss J. A. Madge, Miss S. Madge, and Mr. W. Terrill. The classes preceding the lectures were largely attended, and several students, besicies those who took the examination regularly, did the class work set from time to time. The work thus shown up was most satis- factory, and it was evident that considerable time and thought had been given to the exercises. In conse- quence of this I was able to carry the work to a higher stage than would otherwise have been possible. The examination has fully confirmed the impression derived from the class work. H. W. LLOYD TANNER. April 21, 1886.

docs.full_text: -+ The public will experience some difficulty in understanding the position taken up by Mr. Stan- ley, tho Radical candidate for Eddisbury. He informed a Dodleston audience on Friday that he was "not yet a candidate. There was a challce- it might bo only a chance—that the Executive Committee of the Eddisbury Liberal Association might in the future, when the General Election came, adopt him, and he might come forward as the Liberal candidate." But the "Chester Chronicle" announced on January 23rd, 1904, that the Executive Committee of the Eddisbliry Liberal Association had that week "unanimously adopted tho Hon. Arthur Stanley as candidate at the General Election." He has been treated ever sines aa tho adopted candidate, and no after- thought of sophistry will avail him to wriggle out of the awkward position. His election expenses date from the day of his adoption, more than twelve months ago; that is the penalty ho and his supporters pay for their bungle. Mr. Mond, we suppose, will be turning round next, and assevera- ting that he was never "adopted" by the Radicals of Chester. Radical candidates are, we know, very wonderful people, but they cannot alter facts, and their mere assurance that the moon is made of green cheese would not seriously affect the settled principles of the science of astronomy.

docs.full_text: Death of "GwUym lago." Author an« Astronomer. t By the death of Mr. William James ) ("Gwilym lago"), who passed away cn Sunday, last, at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. Edwards, Pembroke Stores, Bargoed, the Rhoudda has lost one of its oldest, best-known, and <nost interesting characters. Dot-eased, who was in his 90th I year, was horn at Aberdare, but the family removed to Dinas, Rhondda Valley, when he was a child. For many years he w orkcd as a carpenter at the Dinas Colliery, owned by the late Mr. Walter Cbmn. Mr. James was a man of parts, exhibit- ing considerable literary and scientific abilities. He wrote a number of volumes, including Hanes Dafydd Terry," 28 o Hen Gymeriadau Owm Rhondda," and Hanes Dechreuad yr Achos yn y Dinas." His studies included that of astronomy, to which he devoted great attention, and upon which subject he lectured for years with the aid of what is described as a wonder- ful piece of machinery "—his own inven- tion—which pictured the movements of the heavenly bodies. He enjoyed a wonder- fully retentive memory, and recalled the Chartist movement and other stirring events of long ago. For over 40 years he was a. deacon at Ebenezer Calvinistic Methodist Church, Dinas, where his in- nuence, particularly on the young men, was great. He* was associated for many years with the Good Templar and temper- ajice movemeuts. The funeral took place on Thursday, at Lethrddu Cemetery, Treaiaw, bL I

docs.full_text: JtlABD-WORKED BCHOOLBOY8. The Chinese schoolchildren have instilled inte them at an early age habits of hard, steady study. At the age of five a boy begins his schooling. At daylight he rises, and, after dress- ing as quickly as possible, he starts brcakfastless to school. He is given a task, and after it is completed he is allowed an hour for breakfast. Again, later, he has an hour for luncheon; but he is at his study nearly twelve hours a day, seven days in the week. All his time, when he is not reciting his lessons, he is studying aloud at the top of his voice. He is under the eye of his master, both in school and on his way to and from school. The lad is taught rudimentary astronomy, physics, and natural history, but greater stress is put upon writing and his lite- rary studies. A Thousand Letters," a poem, is the study that forms the backbone of his lite- rary education. In it are taught the duties of children to parents and all such matters. What- ever the study may be-history, classics, of science—every lesson is learnt and repeated word for word.

docs.full_text: Concert at Barry. On Wednesday last a concert was held at the Presbyterian Hall, Barry. The Barry Glee Society was in attendance, and rendered in fine style several pieces of music. An excellent programme was gone through as follows :— "Come, live with me," Glee Society; bass solo, entitled The Soldier's Dream," Mr J. Sherwood; song, Snowdon," Mr J. G. Rogers soprano solo, When the Heart is Young," Miss Daisy Hammett song, The Lifeboat, Mr. Lewis glee, Dwynwen," Barry Glee Society recita- tion, "Astronomy made Easy," Mr Derrick; duet, "Peace and War," Messrs T. Lewis and G. Phillips; selections, including "The March of the Men of Harlech," and the Belphager March on handbells and different instruments by Mr Powell and party glee, "Comrades in Arms," Glee Society. The proceedings were closed by singing the Welsh National Anthem, "Hen Wlad fy Nhadau." The solo was sung by Mr D. Farr, the conductor of the Barry Glee Society. The chairman announced at the close of the meeting that this was the first of a series of entertain- ments to be held during the winter months. He hoped that this one was an earnest of the successful entertainments which were to follow.

docs.full_text: REMARKABLE DISCOVERY I AT SWANSEA. A SUPPOSED REAL RAPHAEL FOUND. THE PICTURE VALUED AT I £ 12,000. A Swansea contemporary says Information reaches us that one of the most valuable paintings in the world is at present in the possession of Mrs. Vignolles, wifo of the manager of the London and Midland Bank, being none other than" The Reconciliation Philosophy, Astronomy, and Theology," which was painted by Raphael for one of the Popes. It has been viewed by the best known English art connoisseur in the trade, and by him its minimum value is placed at E12,000, at which figure he is prepared to treat as its reserve price. There is a history attaching to the painting, which was for a long time looated in Spain, and has since been 200 years in the family from whom Mrs. Vignolles acquired it. We understand that Mr. Vignolles is willing- even anxious-to afford his fellow-townsfolk an opportunity of viewing this magnificent specimen of the great Italian master before it is removed to London, and it has been proposed that it shall be exhibited in the public library gallery but this, we believe, will not now be done, a more suitable room being required.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMY IN WALES. I LAUNCHING OF THE NEW I SOCIETY AT CARDIFF. I The first zeneral meeting of the new Astro- nomioal Society was held at the Hotel Metro- pole, Cardiff, all Wednesday evening, Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S., presiding over a good attendance. The officers and council for the year were elected, there being an exceptionally strong list of viee- p xesiden t8,represent i ng Wales and Monmouthshire, the local names include the Veu. Archdeacon Bruce, Principal Viriamu Jones, F.R.S.. Professor Tanner, F.R.A.S., the Rev. W. E. Winks, Mr. C. T. Whitnjell, M.A., and Mr. W. Edgar Nioholls. It was decided that the society be called "The Astro. nomical society of Wales." The rules were adopted, after which the President delivered his inaugural address, explaining the objects of the society, and pointing out the useful work which members could do whether in pos- session of telescopes or not. It was resolved to print the address in the journal which the society intends issuing monthly. The mem- bership is already about eighty strong. The next meeting will be held on January 30, when an address will be delivered by the president on "Lunar Charting and Delinea- tion." with numerous illustrations. The see- retary of the new Agronomical Societv is Mr. X. Lattey, Memb. B.A.A., Dinas Powis.

docs.full_text: EDITORIAL COMMENTS. I The Astronomical Society of Wales is a newly-constituted body which hafl As headquirters at Cirdifif. Its first meeting has just been held, and, judging by the number of aatronombrs Who turned up, the wctety may look to the future with CÖtl- fidiftce. Now that sconce of evfery kind becomes common property a society of this character meets a real want. In Wales there existed nothing of the kind befdrfe. There were several persons who made astro- nomy their chief study, but, like the stark abdv^, each turned in his own orbit, retard- IdSfc of the movements of his neighbours. Now they may be brought together into a system, which is only another word for society, and by their united efforts they will be able to prosecute their studies to a much better purpose. The president of the new mdremeOt is Mr. Arthur Mee, who is a Fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society, and one of the vice-presidents Principal Viriamu Jones. All who feel interested in the work of astronomy are invited to join. The roll of members has already reached eighty, and, as the subscription (two shillings and sixpence) is small, there is no reason why the institution should not receive general favour.

docs.full_text: A LOST VOLUME. I TO THE EDITOR OF THe WESTERN MAIL." I MR,—Lan any of your numerous and intelligent readers give me the author's or publisher's name of a geography I am going to describe ? It was the most interesting of the kind, and fullest of inform- ation about the construction of the globe, &c., I everread. It Was full alsooi figures: the position, for instance, of each of the planetsof our system in relation to the sun was given. As to size, it would he a little larger than Cornwall's "Geography for Schools," and somewhat smaller than Ewing's "Geography and Astronomy." Judging from its size and cover, it would be a two shilling book. The title-page was gone when I had the loan of it. I feel prdtty sure that many of our students in colleges, and schoolmasters especially, have seen and read it. If anyone will furnish me with the name of the publisher, or sell me the little book, I should feel, greatly obliged.-I am, dec., tunnarthen. COLUMBUS.

docs.full_text: TO-NIGHT'S GREAT METEOR I SHOWER. If this (Tuesday) evening be clear, our readers may possibly be rewarded by the slight of a brilliant shower of meteors—at least, so we barn from No. 4 of the "Cambrian Natural Observer," the issue of which has followed with something like meteoric swiftness on the heels of No. 3. The "Observer" contains valuable papers on the Leonid shower by Professor John- stone Stoney, Mr. W. F. Denning, F.R.A.8., and Mr. Cardake Thompson (preiidezit of tite Astro- nomical .Society of Wales). There is some doubt as to whether the Leonids will be bril- liantly seen this year, hecause it is next year I they are really cluc, and also because, as the earth cuts through the swarn, our hemisphere may not be to the front, and so we shall miss the display. Still, if the weither be clear, there is a chance. Watch should be kept after eleven o'clock to-night, principally towards the east. Careful notes of the meteors seen. of their number, and the direction of their paths may be of some service to astronomy.

docs.full_text: TUESDAY NIGHTS ECLIPSE. To the Editor of the "Western Mail." HJr,-I hia a boautiful view of the eclipse last night at 11.53. I had been looking several time; during tho evening, but the c,<)uds pre- vented my seeing the moon. At the haar stated above I went out for the last time, and I was surprised to fin 1 the sky beautifully clear and tiJ. stars shining brightly, just like a frosty night. No! a cloud could be seen tho moon was there, but ht gave no light. It appeared to me, with only a field glas«, that the colour was coral pink, being deepest at five o'clock—taking the dial of a clock for illustr.v! 1.' on-the colour from this point to the opposite point íc even o'clock; getting paler. I do not know if I have made myself understood, as 1 know nothing f astronomy, but I merely describe what I saw, and as it appeared to me, as üne not versed in sui h things, it was a most beau- tiful sight. Many people, no doubt, missed it. and I thought I would ive you my observa- tion, To see the moon of such a colour and ivmg no light would be quite enough, M you say in your leading article to-day, to make 'the untutored savage' look upon it its an omen of ill-luck. docs.full_text: MORE METEORS. Mr. Arthur Mee writes:-One hesitates to draw attention to another meteor-shower after' the way in which the recent one fell tlat. How- ever, if cloud intervenes and the meteors are not visible, that is not the astronomer's fault, though some people write and talk as though it were! Well, another considerable meteor- shower is expected, and we are told that the best timo to watch is in the night between Wednesday and Thursday next. This parti- cular meteor-swarm is known as the Andro- medes, because its members appear to radiat-a from a point in the constellation Andromeda that lies near Cassiopeia (the W group). These particular meteors have a very slow movement (different from the Leonids), and are, there- fore. mncli more easily observed and recorded It seems almost superfluous to add that meteors are shooting-stars, but at the time the Leonids were due, though the skies were hlank. iots of people at Cn rdjff stated how much they enjoyed the "display," which turned out to be the distant glare of the Dowlais and Melin- griflith When the sky is overcast, no astronomical observations of any kind are pos- S'ble. By th:- way, when the "Daily Tele- graph" spoke of every available telescope being brought to bear on the shooting-stars, it did not display it knowledge of astronomy to con- spicuous advantage. Astronomers no more study meteor-showers through telescopes than the public read their papers through pint bottles with the bottoms knocked out

docs.full_text: COWBRIDGE. I POLICE COURT.—On Tuesday (before Messrs. T. Llewellyn and Edward Bradley), David Bdwardes summoned Thomas Thomas for assaulting him. According to the evidence, the affray, which took place in the High-street on the 20th inst., arose from a difference of opinion on the merits of the beer brewed at an adjoining establishment, and the pai ties came to blows over the argument. The case was diemicaed.- (Before Messrs. G. W. Traherne and Rev. T. Edmonds.) Thomas Church was fined 1:1 and costs for tiding without reins. THE GRAMMAR SCHOOL. The Rev. F. H. Browne, B.A., of Wad ham College, Oxford, has been appointed to the second mastership of Cow- bridge School; and Mr. J. J. Dyson, B.A., of 10ains College, Cambiidge, has been appointed assistant master in the same school. Mr. Browne was a scholar of Wadham College, and gained a first-class in mathematics before moderators and a second- cless in the final schools. He was appointed by the Profcisor of Astronomy to accompany the Go- vernment expedition to Spa'n, in 1870, to ob-.et;re the ecVpse of the sun. He has since hr'd the appointment of head mathematical master at St. Paul's College, Stoney Stratford. Mr. Dyton was senior scholar of ^Caius College, and was fifteenth in the first class of the classical tripos this year. A new boprding-house has been opened this term at Cowbiid'je, and there are now 65 boarders. The head master intends building additional rooms to one of the boarding bouses dunrj the vacation.

docs.full_text: The Badge of the Gentleman. Repose and cheerfulness are the badge of the gentleman—repose in energy. The Greek battlepieces are calm the heroes, in whatever violent actions engaged, retain a serene aspect as we say of Niagara, that it falls without speed. A cheerful, intelligent face is the end of culture, and success enough. For it indicates the purpose of Nature and wisdom attained. When our higher faculties are in activity, we are domesticated, and awkwardness and discomfort give place to natural and agreeable movements. It is noticed that the considera- tion of the great periods and spaces of astronomy induces a dignity of mind, and an indifference to death. The influence of fine scenery, the presence of mountains, appeases our irritations and elevates our friendship. Even a high dome, and the expansive interior of a cathedral, have a sensible effect on man- ners. I have heard that stiff people lose something of their awkwardness under high pilings, and in spacious halls. I think sculp- ture and painting have an effect to teach us manners and abolish hurry.— Emerson.

Newport has. from the commencement, been a tower of strength to the Astronomical Society of Wales, and the local members are already preparing a plan of action for the coming winter One or two observers have telescopes of con- siaerable power, which they are cheerfully placing at the disposal of their fellow-students and m some enthusiastic quarters a nublie observatory is talked of! On Wednesday even- mg there was a pood attendance of members and tke general public at the Town-hall to hear an address from the president of the '• parent" society on Lunar charting and delineation." lhe Rev Arthur J. Jenkins (vice-president), who ?!tW°xTked most eamestly for the furtherance of the Newport branch, was m the chair and spoke of the progress astronomy was ma kine- in Wales and Monmouthshire. Mr. Arthur Mee then delivered his address, which was illustrated by maps and photographs, including fine speci- mens from the Mount Hamilton and Paris ob- servatories, and the admired enlargements of Professor Dr. Weinek, Monsieur Prinz, and Herr Jirieger, which were afterwards carefully inspected by the audience. A vote of thanks to the lecturer, m.ved by the chairman, seconded Grrallain White, and a similar compliment to Mr. Jenkins, closed the proceedings.

docs.full_text: I VALUE PLACED AT £ 12,000 More About the Supposed Real Raphael Found at Swansea. •, A Swansea contemporary saye :—Information reaches us that one of the most valuable paintings in the world is at present in the possession of Mrs. Vignolles, wife of the manager of the London and Midland Bank, being none other than The Reconciliation Philosophy, Astronomy, and Theology," which was painted by Raphael for one of the Popes..It has been viewed by the best known English art connoisseur in the trade, and by him its minimum value is placed at Cl2,000, at which figure he is prepared to treat as its reserve price. There is a history attaching to the painting, which was for a long time located in Spain, and has since been 200 years in the family from whom Mrs. Vignolles acquired it. We understand that Mr. Vignolles is willing— even anxious—to afford his fellow-townsfolk an opportunity of viewing this magnificent specimen of the great Italian master before it is removed to London, and it has been proposed that it shall be exhibited in the public library gallery but this, we believe, will not new be done, a more suitable room being required.

docs.full_text: FAME WON IN SPARE TIME. It is interesting to note bow many men of genius have utilised their spare moments either to attain knowledge for themselves or to give it to other-. Hugh Miller taught himself geology whilst working as a mason. Frank!in, while engaged as a. journeyman printer, pro- duced his "Dissertation on Liberty and Neces- sity, Pleasure and Pain." Bloomfield composed "The Farmer's Boy" in the intervals of Qlloe- making. Elihu Eurritt. while plying his voca- tion as a village blacksmith, actually made himself acquainted with ten languages, in- cluding Greek Hebrew, Persian, and Syrian. This remarkaole man. when a lad. only had six months' elementary education. Carey, the mi&aionciry and Oriental translator, mastered the rudiments of Easterrt languages while em- ployed in making and mending shoes. Fer- guson taught nimseli astronomy while tending sheep in the service of a Scotch farmer. Coli- bett learned grammar in the leisure moments at his disposal as a common soldier. Baxter wrote his "Saint's Everlasting Re^i" on a bed of sickness. D'Aquessau, the famca-i French Chancellor, observing that his wife was always ten minutes late at dinner, began and com- pleted a learned work of three volumes fwhich went through several edition-) solely during those "wasted" minutes at the dinner table. BnnY:1.D wrote his "Pilgrim's Progress" in his leisure hours in Bedford Gaol. The late Mr. Gladstone mastered Greek and translated liomer almost entirely during his journeys by rail—time that most folk allow to run to waste.

Hugh Miller taught himself geology whilst working as a mason. Franklin, while engaged as a journeyman printer, pro- duced his ".Dissertation on Liberty and Neces- sity, Pleasure and Pain." Bloomfield composed "The Farmer's Boy" in the intervals of shoe- making. Blihu Burritt. while plying his voca- tion as a. viUage blacksmith, actually made himself acquainted with ten languages, in- cluding Greek Hebrew. Persian, and Syrian. This remarkable man. when a lad, only had six months' elementary education. Carey, the missionary and Oriental translator, mastered the rudiments of Eastern languages while em- ployed in making and mending shoes. Fer- guson taught himself astronomy while tending aheep in the service of a. Scotch farmer. Cob- bett learned grammar in the leisure moments a.t his disposal as a. common soldier. Baxter wrote his "Saint's Everlasting Rest" on a bed of sickness. D'Aquessau, the famous French Chancellor, observing that his wife was always ten minutes late at dinner, began and com- pleted a. learned work of three volumes (which went through several editions I solely during those "wasted" minutes at the dinner table. Bunyan wrote his "Pilgrim's Progress" in his leisure hours in Bedford Gaol. The late Mr. Gladstone mastered Greek and translated Homer almost entirely during his journeys by rail-time that most folk allow to run to waste.

docs.full_text: A CLEVER BOY. Adolphus Dolfer seemed a clever boy— And clever people are so very few!- He did not care for tart, or care for toy, How cornd he, when such cleverness lie knew? He sat and brooded in a corner far. He counted to a hundred, clever chap! He said he knew a moon, he knew a star, He knew a sun, a comet, too, mayhap! He said he knew all rules of 'rithmetic; Yes. he could write, but did not care to try; He knew that throw a brick would rhyme to "stick"; He knew potatoes boil. and bake, and fry. So science, 'rithmetic, astronomy, Prose, poetry, and all the kindred arts, Adolphus knew, and cooking, though, you see Too clever far to eat his mother's tarts. But oh! one day a dreadful question came, Asked by Jemima Jones, who lived next door; And then Adolphus Dolfer lost his fame. He did not know that two and two make four. For when Jemima Jones popped out her head, And clasped her hand, with mischief all a;.ive, "Two plums in each, how many?" then he said— Oh, poor Adolphus Dolfer That makes five!" CHRISTIE DEAS. —From "Little Folks,"

docs.full_text: BACK OF THE MOON. Speaking with strict accuracy, instead of pre- senting an unchanging face towards us, the moon appears to be never still, but always rocking backwards or forwards, falling towards us or away from us, and by the amount of these variations-small, it is very true—regions of the hemisphere turned away from us are dis- closed. They are placed, unhappily, in the situation best calculated to defeat curiosity. We are permitted to take just a glimpse of "the other side," but to bring away only the mini- mum of information as to its condition. Per- haps it is rash to say we shall never know more of the "other side" of the moon, so marvellous have been the recent advances in astronomy. Some day, perhaps, new discoveries after the manner of Rontgen rays may enable us to get a photograph through the moon. Short of that, we must needs wait for some stray visitor from outer space to come into collision with the moon and turn it round, in order to enable us to satisfy our curiosity; and patience may well be stimulated by the knowledge that the results of such a collision, should it ever occur, would in all probability be- not less disastrous to the earth than to the moon itself.—"Windsor."

docs.full_text: TRANSIT OF MLRCURY. The Rare Phenomenon Visible in Wale This Afternoon. Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S., writesThat somewhat rare phenomenon, a transit of Mer- cury, took place this aft em con, commencing a few minutes before four o'clock, unfortunately near to sunset. With an opera-glass or non- inverting telescope (protected, of course, by a darkened glass) Mercury was noted as a tiny black dot just indde t.he left edge of the sun, and a third of the way from top to bottom. I shall be glad, as I mentioned in my astronomical notes of Tues- day. to correspond with any persons interested in astronotny who would assist in the formation of a working society at Cardiff. Several friends have already expressed to me their interest in such a movement, and we have a number 01' gentlemen here identified either with the Royal Astronomical Society or the British Astronomical Association, whilst the ivimber of the general public interested more or less in the science must be large, judging from the continuous run that exists on the astrono- mical works at the Cardiff Free Library. Let it not be thoug-ht that only those having tele- scopes would be eligible such a society as I have named would welcome all haviing an inte- rest in astronomy, no matter wha.t their instru- n ental moans.

docs.full_text: THE i NOVEMBER METEORS. Late this (Tuesday) evening, if the sky be clear, observers should see something of what are commonly known as the November meteors. Modern astronomy (thanks to the patient and unwearying researches of Mr. Denning, Bristol, and some others) has classified the various meteor shoyvers, and it has been also proved that there is a close relationship between comets and meteors—in fact, if the earth were to pass through the tail of a comet we should probably witness phosphoric glows and brilliant showers of shooting stars. The meteors of November 13 move in an orbit. and are more condensed in some portions of it than others.; when, then, the earth crosses such a deJIse region we have a brilliant shower of meteors, at others a less marked display. These par- ticular meteors are called Leonids, because they seem to radiate from the direction of the bright star Gamma Leonis, which, be it :s,oted. does not rise till midnight. Sometimes (but somewhat rarely) meteors reach the ground in the form of huge masses, jorne of which are in our museums. We have to thank our air that it acts as a friendlv cushion—protecting us from what would otherwise be an aerial bombardment of terrific violence. ARTHUR MEE, F.R.A.S.

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMY IN WALES. The Launching of the New Society at Cardiff. The first general meeting of the new Astro- nomical Society was held at the Hotel Metro- pole, Cardiff, on Wednesday evening, Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S., presiding over a good attendance. The officers and council for the year were elected, there being an exceptionally strong list of vice-presidents,representing Walpa and Monmuthshire. The loca.I names include the Ven, Archdeaoon Bruce, Principal Viriamu Jones, F.R.S., Professor Tanner, F.R.A.S., the Rev. W. E. Winks, Mr. C. T. Whitmell, M.A., and Mr. W. Edgar Nicholls. It was decided that the society be called "The Astro- nomical Society of Wales." The rules were adopted, after which the President delivered his inaugural address, explaining the objects of the society, and pointing out the useful work which members could do whether in pos- session of telescopes or not. It was resolved to print the address in the journal which the society intends issuing monthly. The mem- bership is already about eighty strong. The next meeting will be held on January 30, when an address will be delivered by the president on "Lunar Charting-and Delinea- tion," with numerous illustrations. The officers and council for the year were elected, there being an exceptionally strong list of vice-presidents,representing Wales and Monmuthshire. The local names include the Ven. Archdeacon Bruce. Principal Viriamu Jones. F.R.S., Professor Tanner, F.R.A.S., the Rev. W. E. Winks, Mr. C. T. Whitmell, M.A.. and Mr. W. Edgar Niiholls. It was decided that the society be called "The Astro- nomical Society of W;ales." The rules were adopted, after which the President delivered his inaugural address, explaining the objects of the society, and pointing out the useful work which members could do whether in pos- session of telescopes or not. It was resolved to print the address in the journal which the society intends issuing monthly. The mem- bership is already about eighty strong. The next meeting will be held on January 30, when an address will be delivered by the president on "Lunar Charting and Delinea. tion," with numerous illustrations. The sec- retary of the new Astronomical Society is Mr. N. Lattey, Memb. B.A.A., Dinas Powis.

docs.full_text: STUDYING THE SKIES. MR. WHITMELL TALKS OF PBQ- GBPSS IIf ASTBONOMY. The usual meeting of the Cardiff Naturalists' Society was held at the Queen-street-hall on Thursday evening. 3%. R. W. Atkinson, B.Sc. (the president), occupied the chair, and there was a. good attendance. Mr. Charles T- Whitmell, M.A., read a paper on "Recent Progress in Astronomy." illustrated with a series of excellent lantern slides and lunar photographs. Mr. Whitmell dealt ably and comprehensively with the condition of Mer- cury, Venus, and the Moon, also referring- in an interesting manner to some problems con- nected with our own earth as a planet. At the close of the paper, a cordial vote of thanks was accorded Mr. Wliitmell, on the motion of the Chairman, seoonued by Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A-S.-r-Mr. JJ. Seward. F.R.I.B.A., then read a lucid report as delegate to the corresponding societies committee of the British Association.—On the motion of the Chairman, a hearty vote, of thanks was accorded Mr. Seward, and the meeting closed. -1.0

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMY IN CHINA. MANDARINS ATTRIBUTE AN ECLIPSE TO A FUNNY CAUSE. An account of the way in which a rceent eclipse of the sun was observed in Shanghai appears in the OOlUIllIlS of the "North China Daily News." On the appointed day the man- darins assembled in the court-room of the magis- trates' office, and gathered round a tabl". on wihoh were burning tapers and joss papers. When the sun began to darken the officials, conformably to an Imperial degree, bowed thrice before the table, and touched the earth with their foreheads nine times in succession. Then they arose and -vent into the hall, and the soldiery and servants having been summoned, the whole mob sought to make as much noise as possible with various instruments, musical and unmusical, fiereworks being meanwhile ex- ploded, the idea being to drive away the Celes- tial monster which had seized and was trying to devour the great luminary. The mandarins' efforts were successful, for by degrees the demon released his hold, and the darkness passed away. The mandarins repeated the genuflexions with which the ceremony started, and the proceedings terminated in the usual manner.

(president of the society), read a paper on "Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune," and gave a most lucid and comprehensive description of these bodies and their phenomena. At the close the Chairman expressed deep regret at the forth- coming removal of Mr. Whitmell. Mr. Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S. (ex-president) moved a vote of thanks to Air Whitmell, which was seconded by Mr. N. Lattev (secretary) and supported by Mr. Geo. A. S. Atkinson, F.R.A.S. (librarian), *nd Miss Rule, all the speakers testifying to Ihe high merits of tlie paper and to tiie grave loss the society and the town were suffering by the removal of the president. Mr. Whitmoll having feelingly replied, it was resolved, on the motion of Mr. Lattey. that the president and secretary sign a memorial (submitted to the society by the corporationj in fay-our of the locating at Cardiff of the offices of the University of Wales. Mr. Atkinson reported an interesting truncation of the terminator of Venus, and also showed a photograph of the Orion nebula, secured by himself. Next Friday night will take place the second of the series of educational lectures on siemeatoxy astronomy.

docs.full_text: TO-NIGHTS GREAT METEOR SHOWER. If this (Tuesday) evening he clear, our readers may possibly be rewarded by tite sight of a brilliant shower of meteors—at least, so we learn from No. 4 of the "Cambrian Natural Observer," the issue of which has followed with something like meteoric swiftness on the heels of No. 3. The "Observer" contains valuable papers on the Leonid shower by Professor John- stoue Stoney, Mr. W. F. Denning, F.R.A.S., and Mr. Carslake Thompson (president of the Astro- nomical Society of Wales). There is some doubt as to whether the Leonids will be bril- liantly seen this year, because it is next year they are really due, and also because, as the earth cuts through the swarn, our hemisphere may not be to the front, and so we shall miss the display. Still, if the weather be clear, there is a chance. Watch should be kept after eleven o'clock to-night, principally towards the east. Careful notes of the meteors seen, of their number, and the direction of their paths may be of some service to astronomy.
