docs.full_text: "EVIL SPIRITS" AND A MODERN EXORCIST Superstition Rampant. A story which came out last week in the course of a fortune-telling prosecution at Bradford is (says "Truth") worthy of potice as an example of the survival of superstition in the twentieth century. The defendant was a venerable imposter, named Sam Haraker, and it appeared that, besides telling fortunes -or, as he lweferred to put it, "prdgnost.icat- ing by astronomy"—he has done a lucrative .business as a professional exorcist. The police mentioned that in one case an •-Id man of means at Knaresborough had been for many years deluded by the prisoner into the belief that he was beset by evil spirits. The prisoner was engaged to drive away these evil spirits, and he went to the old man's house once a week, and at the witching hour of n. id- night boiled a beast's heart and liver and various herbs in vitrol and' performed an incantation. His credulous victim supposed that this weird ceremony kept off his super- natural enemies for another seven days, and for this valuable service Hardaker is said to have been paid £1 or more a week for about twenty years! It. was a very comfortable job, but thore are not many of the kind to be had nowadays, and the business suffers moreover from the drawback that those who practise it are liable to three months' imprisonment as rogues and vag-a bonds.

W. E. Winks will deliver an address on How I Commenced to Take an Interest in Astronomy."

docs.full_text: Astronomical Society of Wales. The adjourned annual meeting was held last evening at the Y.M.C.A., Station-terrace, Cardiff. Mr. Norman Lattey, the president- elect, in the chair. The report tnd accounts for the year were presented. From the latter it, appeared there were 135 men) hero, many living in England, and two so far away as India. Seven candidates for membership were adopted. The proposal of a life subscrip- tion was discussed, and. on the motion of the Rev W. E. Winks, F.R.A.S., it was decided to submit same to the general body of members. Varioua questions were gone into, including the purchase of a. lantern. A most able paper, read by Mr. Arthur Mec, was contributed by Mr. W. E. Piuraraer, F.R.A.S., director of the Bidston Observatory, on the subject of astronomy as a popular pursuit. Mr. Plummer depit with the theme in a lucid and masterly manner, making as a special feature the encouragement of those who have a desiro to observe yet possess no instruments. The paper was listened to with deep attention, and at the close, on the motion of Mr. Winks, seconded by the president, a hearty vote of thanks was accorded Mr. Plummer. On account of the lateness of the hour the president's address was deferred. At the next meeting an address will be given by Mr. A. Taylor, R.Y.I.S., entitled "Recent Research in Spec- troacoDio AaLrojiunix."

docs.full_text: DEATH OF MR E. J. C. MORTON, M,P. The late Mr. Morton (the account of whose death appears in Page 2) had represented Devonport since 1892, was one time secretary to the Home Rule Union. He was born in 1856. and was educated at Harrow and Cam- bridge. He was called to the Bar in 1885, and was a member of the North-eaatern Cir- cuit. He was also one of the university extension lecturers on astronomy. Tke news of Mr. Morton's death was received in his constituency to-day from Miss Morton, who announced that her brother had passed away at her residence in Gloucestershire. Mr. Morton had been suffering for a long time from dropsy, and not long since was a patient in St. Thomas's Hospital, London. The news of Mr. Morton's death has caused deep regret in Devonport. The Conservative candidate for the constituency iB Mr. J. Lockie, of Stone- house, who was defeated by Mr. Morton at the last general election by a narrow majo- rity.

docs.full_text: DEATH. OF Mil. E. J, C. MORTON, M.P. Mr. E. J. C. Morton, M.P. for Devon port, died at Amberley, Gloucestershire, on Friday night. Mr. Morton had represented Devon- port since 1892, and was at one time secretary to the Home Rule Union. He was born in 1856. and was educated at Harrow and Cam- bridge. He was called to the Bar in 1885, and was a member of the North-eastern Cir- cuit. He was also one of the university extension lecturers on astronomy. The news of Mr. Morton's death was received in his constituency on Saturday from Miss Morton. Mr. Morton had been suffering for it long time from dropsy, and not lqng since was a patient in St. Thomas's Hospital, London. The news of Mr. Morton's death has caused deep regret in Devonport. The Conservative candidate for the constituency is Mr. J. Lockie, of Stone- house, who was defeated by Mr. Morton at the last general election by a narrow majo- rity, the figures being:- Kearley (the senior member' (R.) 3,626 Morton (R.) 3,538 Lockie (U.) 5,458 Goodheart (U.) 3,3%

docs.full_text: A CURIOUS WELSH BOOK. About 50 years ago there was published in Llanidloes, Montgomeryshire, a. remarkable contribution to Welsh literature in the form of a book which explained in Welsh the prin- ciples of astronomy and geology. The author of the book was Edward Mills, who came from a, distinguished Montgomeryshire family. By trade he was a weaver, his knowledge of as- tronomy and geology being obtained by study in his spare hours. The most curious part of the book is the illustrated plates explaining the solar system. There are in all 86 plates, the work of the author's own hands. He made his own tools, which, although crude, succeeded in illustrating exactly what he wished to explain. The illustrations, showing the circular and other motions, were made out of tin. cut type high. and bent to the desired shape by home made tools. The maps of different parts of the world were also done in the same manner, a long ribbon of tin being twisted and turned over and over again, until a faithful representation of the country he desired to illustrate was obtained.

docs.full_text: DEATH OF MR. A. A. WILLIAMS CARDIFF. The death is announced of Mr. A. A. Williams, Board of Trade surveyor, Cardiff, who passed away on Saturday, after a long and tedious illness. Mr. Williams was a man high in the esteem and respect of his col- leagues, and his loyalty to the service kept him at his duties long after mortal illness had seized upon hia frame. He was a genial and faithful friend, and much sought after by a large circle of acquaintances. He was also a staunch and uncompromising Church- man. Mr. Williams took the deepest interest in scientific pursuits. For some yeare he devoted himself to astronomy, and distin- guished himself by the care no less than the variety of his observations, and by the beauty and correctness of his drawings, for he waa a- facile and expert artist. He was a member of the British Astronomical Association and of the Astronomical Society of Wales, and did active work for both associations. Mr. Williams was a clever photographer, and very ingenious in the manufacture of home- made apparatus. He delighted to go to the root of things, and had his valued life been spared he would have distinguished himself in many directions. Mr. Williams leaves a widow and two sons, for whom widespread sympathy is felt in their affliction.

The author of the book was Edward Mills, who came from a distinguished Montgomeryshire family. By trade he was a weaver, his knowledge of as- tronomy and geology being obtained by study in his spare hours. The most curious part of the book is the illustrated plates explaining the solar system There are in all 86 plates, the work of the author's own hands. He made his own tools, which, although cruie, succeeded in illustrating exactly what he wished to explain. The illustrations, showing the circular and other motions, were made out of tin, cut type high. and bent to the desired shape by home made tools. The maps of different parts of the world were also done in the same manner, a long ribbon of tin being twisted and turned over and over again, until a faithful representation of the country he desired to illustrate was obtained.

docs.full_text: I A PLEA FOR ASTROLOGY. I Before the Astronomical Society of Wales at Cardiff City-hall on Wednesday evening, Air. Arthur Mee read a paper entitled, The Story of Astrology." Mr. Mee gave a state- ment of the personal reasons which hfid impelled. him some time ago to admit that there was a great deal of truth in this ancient science, and then proceeded to give its history from far-off Chaldean times until the present. The speaker deplored that astrology had been condemned without trial, and said that in the cyclo- paedias and elsewhere grossly misleading statements were made by people who had no acquaintance with astrology whatever. He replied to various popular objections, and quoted a few reqmarkable predictions that had been made alike by ancient and modern astrologers. He hoped, he said, that scientific authorities could yet be induced to give an impartial investigation to astrology. There was nothing occult about it whatever-it was founded on principles which in their essence were easy of comprehension, and as firmly established as those of astronomy itself. Much harm had been, done to the art by its exploitation at the bands of people who knew little or nothing about it. The number of competent astrologers in this country was really very small. After the lecture observations were made by the Rev. W. E. Winks, Dr. James Mullin, J.P., Miss Hagerty, and others. Mr. Mee was cordially thanked, on the motion of the chairman (Councillor Kidd), seconded by Mr. Heath.

docs.full_text: Bishop and the Bible. —— m SAYS IT IS NOT THE WORD OF GOD" Bishop Charles D. Williams, of the Epis- copal diocese of Michigan, in addressing the members of the Young Men's Christian Association at Detroit yesterday, declared that the Bible was not the word of God, and that teaching to the contrary was one of the most prolific sources of unbelief. He said that nowhere the Bible declares itself to be the word of God. yet we were told that we must accept it in its entirety. But the young man reading Genesis found it impossible in geology, astronomy, and enthnology, and the only assistance the Church was able to give was the advice, "Manipulate it until it fits the sciences." The result was that the young man. if honest, must either abandon his belief or stultify the reason. "The Bible," said the bishop, "needs a square deal. When we represent it to be the Word of God we use it like a. heathen fetish which the wicked misuse as a good human book."

He said that nowhere the Bible declares itself to be the word of God. yet we were told that we must accept it in its entirety. But the young man reading Genesis found it impossible in geology, astronomy, and enthnology, and the only assistance the Church was able to give was the advice, Manipulate it until it fits the sciences." The result was that the young man, if honest, must either abandon his belief or stultify the reason. "The Bible," said the bishop, "needs a square deal. When we represent it to be the Word of God we use it like a heathen fetish which the wicked misuse as a good human I book."

docs.full_text: A DUTCH LAVENGRO. The Dutch papers print a curious story about a telegraph messenger, living at Breda. The man is about 50 years of age now, and has been able, by self-study only. to roaster an unusual num-ber of languages, being able to speak amd write in the follow- ing tongues—English, French. German, Danish, Spanish. Italian, Arabic, Latin, Greek, Hebrew, and Sanscrit, besides being able to decipher hieroglyphic and cuneiform inscriptions. Further, he possesses no mean acquaintance with cosmography, astronomy, physics, the history of art, and various other sciences. The reports say tha.t this simple man, who spends his long working day by carrying telegrams to their destination, is often oon. sulted by other linguists on various subtle questions. He is also alleged to possess the rare gift of writing Greek poems. There is -now a movement to find this extraordinary man a career better suited to his oa/pacitics thaln that of postal messenger, and it is meeting with general support.

docs.full_text: "LIFE IN OTHER WORLDS." This was the title of an address delivered before the AstronomioaJ Society of Wales on Friday evening by Mr. Arthur Mee. The meeting took piaoe (by permission) at the Western Mail-buildings, and the chair was taken by Mr. Caxslake Thompson. Mr. Mee sketched the history of his theme, and then gave as succinctly as possible the evidence as afforded by modern astronomy. Special reference was made to Flamxn&rion as the principal living exponent of the doctrine of a plurality of worlds, and to Dr. Alfred Russel W allace, who.&e recent work contains the ablest plea. that has appeared on the negative side of the question. The conclusion oome to was that there is no oerlain evidence of life on any planet of the solar system, and as regards the resit of the universe the matter remains in abeyance. At the close an inrte- resting discussion took place. A vote of thanks was accorded Mr. Mee on the motion of the chairman, seconded by Mr. T. Pugh Jones. Miss Rule (secretary), Captain Jut- sum. F.R.A.S., and Mr. Stephens aiao spoke.

docs.full_text: DEATH OF LORD GRIMTHORPE The Yorkshire Evening Post" to-dap announces that Lord Grimthorpe died 8t Bitchwood, St. Albans. this morning. Deceased, who was a son of Sir Edmund Beckett, Bart., was born in 1816. He suc- ceeded to the baronetcy in 1874, and was made a peer in 1885. He its suooeeded in the peerage by his nephew, Mr. Ernest Beckett, Conser- vative member of the Whitby Division of the North Riding of Yorkshire, for which be has sat since 1885. Lord Grimthorpe was well known for hia restoration of St. Albans Cathedral and otlier churches there, and was the author of several publications on clocks, architecture, and astronomy. The announcement this morning: of the death of Lord Grimthorpe, whose successor is Mr. E. W. Beckett, member for the Whitby Division, has caused much excitement throughout the constituency. The Li-beralt have no candidate, Mr. Beckett's seat at Unionist member having been coneiderec impregnable. The Conservatives have now U look out for a candidate, a contingency foi which they were unprepared. Lord Grimthorpe's deatoh was gudden though expected. About a week ago his lordship had a fall, and this occasioned a shock. He was attended by hie local medical adviser, who called in a specialist. On Friday Lord Grimthorpe was in a partially comatoee con- dition, and he died, as stated, this morning from heart failure, no member of the family being present at the time.

docs.full_text: I BRITISH ASSOCIATION. I The members of the British Association on Wednesday met in the City-hall and the African College at Cape Town. The papers read were those by Mr Haddon, in the anthropological section, on the indigenous peoples of Africa; Sir Richard Jebb, in the educational section, on university education and national life; Professor Forsyth, in the mathematical and physical section, on the discoveries of the la-t three centuries, more especially in astronomy and physics; Rear-admiral Sir W. J. L. Wharton, in the geographical section, on the importance of geography in the life of to-day; The Rev. Dr. Cunningham. in the section of economic science and statistics, on uncon- scious assumptions in economics; Mr. Boulenger, in the zoological section, on the distribution of African fresh water fishes; Colonel Johnston, in the geographical section; Mr. Bernacchi, in the same section, on the Discovery Antarctic expedition; Professor Phillips on seaweeds; the Rev. Mr. Clarke, of South Africa, on education; and Sir Lander Brunton on the effect of climate on health.

docs.full_text: A correspondent of the "Morning Post" makes a suggestion that penny stamps should be perforated down the middle and each half be usable as a half- penny stamp. This is very ingenious, but it is not new, and, of course, it has the obvious drawback that used stamps obliterated on the one half might be de- tached and the other half used, thus rob- bing the Post Office. Still, if this could be safeguarded, the new idea would be an undoubted convenienée. The late Dr. Andrew Common, F.R.S., was one of the many examples of eminent men who are not at all successful on the platform. Like the soldier, "deeds not words should be their motto. Dr. Com- mon spent himself and his wealth for the advancement of astronomy. His kind- ness was shown locally on more than one occasion—notably when iia sent a fine mirror of his own make to the Cardiff Exhibition. His sudden death is a serious loss alike to mechanical and physical science.

docs.full_text: FUTURE OF THE TELESCOPE I Mr. Arthur Meo lectured at St. John's Church Schools, Canton, Cardiff, on The Telescope, and What It Shows Us." Mr. W. P. James presided. Mr. Mee (who illustrated his remarks with nearly 90 lantern slides) said that, no doubt, the mighty telescope of th- future would be constructed on the reflecting rather than the refracting prin- oiple. America, which had for many years taken a lead in this matter, had been very suspicious of the reflector till the late Dr. Common's great instruments went over there and the scientific Uncle Sam was convinced against his will. Now Dr. Common's scienti- fic assistant and adviser was Mr. Albert Taylor (at present one of his Majesty's Welsh inspeotors of schools), and it was he who made the great five-foot mirror that helped to convert American astronomers. It was pleasant to think that a scientific man living in their midst, and who took a deep interest in the Penylan telescope and the Astronomical Society of Wales, had a hand in moulding the future of the telescope which would have so mighty an influence on the astronomy of the coming age.

docs.full_text: HAVE YOU SEEN THE COMET ? I Sir Robert Ball, Lowndean, Professor of Astronomy at Cambridge, stated yesterday that the great daylight comet first discovered at Johannesburg on Monday was almost cer- tainly a new comet. It was not one of those known to astronomers to the best of their present belief, but until a few more observa- tions had been obtained of it they could not say decidedly. It takes three ob- servations of a comet to show exactly its orbit," Sir Robert remarked. and until thajt, is obtained the identity of the comet is uncertain. The tail of the comet last night was 2deg. long, which will perhaps be more easily understood by saying that it appeared to be about four times the diameter of the I full moon. Sir Robertaid that the comet most oertainly could be seen with binocular glaesets. The observer should look at Venus, now so unmistakable an I object in the twilight sky at sunset, and at the horizon under Venus, and then along towards the north.

docs.full_text: FAMOUS ASTRONOMER. I v SIR WILLIAM HUGGINS DIES II IN LONDON. Sir William Huggins, the celebrated astrono- I mer, died on Thursday at the residence of Dr. Dudley Bishop, Lavender Hill, Clapham Common. Sir William Huggins was removed from his home on Wednesday for the pur- pose of undergoing an operation, but on his arrival at Dr. Bishop's house it was defemed unwise jto perform the operation, as the putient was found to be suffering: from bron- chitis, and the heart's action had been weakened by the complaint. In fact, Sir William's symptoms, as he became worse during the night, were very aliin to those of King Edward on Friday last, and his end was due virtually to the same cause—heart failure, following the bronchial affection. Sir William, who was knighted in the Diamond Jubilee year, was barn in 1824. At his house at Tulse Hill Sir William built a private observatory in 1856, and devoted him- self to the development of spectroscopic astronomy work, in which be received great assistance from Lady Huggins. He had filled many scientific offices, including those of president of the Royal Astronomical Society, president of the British Association, and president cf the Royal Society. He received many honours, among them the Order of I Merit in 1902.

docs.full_text: CUNLIFFE AND MAIDIE SCOTT One of the most interesting programmes seen for some time in Newport will be presented during the coming week at the Empire, where two of our greatest stars of the variety world- Whit Cunlifff's and Maidie Scott-will be the chief attractions. The dashing comedian has a large assortment of new and popular successes, which he will render in his own inimitable style. Miss Maidie Scott is undoubtedly one of the most popular comediennes on- the variety stage with Newport audiences, and her new songs should prove a great draw during the coming week. The famous De Wynne Bros., the sang-froid athletes, are also on the bill, and accompanied by their canine friends they will perform a number of clever and interesting feats. W. Fulbrook and Co. will appear in a comedy concoction entitled Astronomy and Kathleen O'Hanlon Trio will be seen in their original musical vocal-terpsichorean scena —" Romps in a Drawing Room." Other artistes of note on the bill include Bugler Carr, who gives a number of wonderful balancing feats with regulation bayonets, Hans and Lux, comedians, Mike Nono, the well-known Irish comedian and dancer, and the very latest sub. jects of general interest on the Bioscope.

docs.full_text: THAT MESSAGE TO MARS I To the Editor of the Evening Express. I Sir,—Mr. Mee, who, I admit, is an expert in astronomy, in his an-9ww to my letter re Message to Mars states • that he doubts whether Professor Pickering was serious I when he proposed to communicate with the planet Maa-s, and adds that we had better Jet these distant orbs alone, as we ane not at ) peace on this earth yet. UolumhUis, who is now famous in our books for his disco-very of America, WM L-hrd at when be proposed to sail across the ooean in search of la.nd 1'eopte in those days said that he would sail so far u-s to fall over the edge of the earth. We now learn what result came through his ambition. i Maybe it will 00 the ræult in aM?ron<),m' ? mTestiga? tion. We have still a lot to lea,! I am. &c., Ormparc. Aug. 11. T. MORGAN. I

docs.full_text: Science of the Heavens. ¡ REVIEW OF MR. ARTHUR MEE'S WORK ON ASTRONOMY. HOW PROCESS BLOCKS ARE MADE IN CARDIFF. [BY THE REY. W. E. WINKS, CARDIFF.] A pretty close acquaintance with the large mass of popular literature devoted to the fascinating science of astronomy had prepared the writer for pleasant surprises in the way of cheap books on this subject. But he hardly expected anyone, even in these days of science for the million," to supply as much material for the money as Mr. Mee has done in this second edition of his Observational Astronomy." When the first edition appeared the question went round among readers who knew something of the cost of production in connection with books of this kind, How can it be done at the price except on principles that are benevolent rather than business-like ?" It was no solution of the difficulty to be told in the words of the old lady who informed her customers that the multiplication of individual losses beyond a certain point amounted to an aggregate gain, i.e., as she put it, We lose by every one, but it's the number that pays." Still the wonder grew," and grows yet more and more with this second edition. For here we have additional matter, and I know not how many fresh illus- trations, from the clever design which adorns the cover down to the charming little thumb- nail portrait sketches of astronomical worthies. I cannot say t/hat the latter are always flattering (what do the admirers of Dr. Ball think?), but they are as unmistakable as the drawings of Jupiter, Saturn, and Mars in the portrait gallery of the planets. While the illustrations are under notice it may be well to pay our tribute of regard to them as a whole, and pass on to speak of the contents of this admirable and useful vade mecum for the astronomical observer. First of ail, these illus- trations, take them as a whole, are a vast im- provement on those of Edition No. 1. Some of the latter never satisfied anybody, least of all the editor, who is known to be an excellent draughtsman and a severe critic upon his own work and its reproduction. Now that they are gone and the field is clear, we have scarcely any- thing in this marvellously cheap little book that is not very. good of its kind. Some of the process blocks are delightful. I am told there is no better half-to le work done in any office in the kingdom than that which is often turned out in the photo-engraving department .¡f the "Western Mail." With such specimens as the five blocks which make up the handsome fron- tispiece before me, I can well believe this assertion. Look, for example, at Weinek's photographs and drawings of the lunar craters Hansteen and Gassendi; at M. Antoniadi's and Mr. Pratt's photographs of Saturn, the one showing the Northern and the other the Southern Pole of the planet, and the upper and under side of his rings. In addition to these, let the reader examine the delicate fea- tures of the photographs reproduced on pp. 7, 9, 17, 45, 46, 55, 57, 62, 65, and 69, &c. Cer- tainly, the "Western Mail" deserves well of all those who take pleasure in downright good artistic work. It is, surely, matter for con- gratulation that we have no need to go to London for book illustrations when process printing can be executed in such a. style as this in our own town. The reader will be pleased to note, in addition to these capital illustrations, the clear type and good setting of the letterpress, and the pleasant appealance of "Ile book generally. H is a comfort to handle a book of this kind, and the reading of It is made as easy as may bs Îor eyes that have seen their best days. On turning to examine the contents of the book one must keep its title in mind, and not look for that which the name "Observational Astronomy" does not promise. If the reader wishes for a complete view and acsount of all that goes under the nILme of Astronomy he must look elsewhere; and in doing so he will find ample guidance in this book to other books which d*al with the sun, moon, pianets, comets, stars, and star systems :n a more comprehensive and exact manner. But here one is supposed to be a.n observer asking, What is there for me to look at, and how am 1 to look? Mr. Mee answers these simple questions of the beginner and the amateur admirably. Many a..devoted student of the heavenly bodies who has fought aud worked his way through the first difficulties of this great science will wish that such a book as this might have fallen into his hands years ago. And no one is forgotten in the wide provision offered in these pages. The youth who has no instrument a.t all, and nothing but his own eyesight to work with, is started on his naked patb. The observer who comes into the arena armed with an opera or field glass is pleasantly told how to use it. and what wonders he may see. The aspirant after a telescope is taken in hand next in order, and nourished and brought up after a fashion it does one's heart good to see. The history of the telescope is given him for an appetiser, and no sooner despatched than the proper meal begins. As an encouragement to go on to the end we have a likeness of our kind host set before 11", stand- ing bareheaded beneath his Calver, with one of his most contented guests looking on. What could be better? We see the goal toward which we are being led if only we will take our leader's capital advice. In this we have all we need to know, and much more than we could have ex- pected, anent refractors and reflectors, object- glasses, and specula, and eye-pieces, and tele- scope stands, arid al! the equipments needful for cne who begins with a l £ hi., and works up by varying stages of 2in., 3in., 4in., or Sin. object- g-Iasses; or soars away into higher realms where 6in., Bin., and lOin. or 12in. reflectors hold sway. It is a really admirable piece of work-- this direction given by our author as to the purchase and use of a telescope. As is most natural, Mr. Mee figures best under Reflectors," but no one who loves the lefrac'.or best has any right to complain of neglect. We have in this part of the book some f-xcellent pictures of tele- scopes, which ought to bring many a purchaser to certain houses that have been wise enougn and kind enough to lend their blocks for publi- cvl inn. The special chapters on the moon and the planets are full of interest. Of these we like the moon, Jupiter, and Saturn the best. It is well known that Mr. Mee knows his way about the moon as well as most astronomers of the B.A.A., and is prepared at any time to conduct a cir- cular-tour-party round the solar system as soon as ever the means of locomotion are provirlpd and the preliminaries of peace are settled between us and our Martian neighbour. In securing the valuable cn-r>ne>*3tinn of distin- guished writers in different departments, Mr. Mee has been most fortunate. Captain Noble, Messrs. N. E. Green, W. F. Denning, J. E. Gore, E. M. Antoniadi, Edwin Holmes. &c., have all contributed to the contents of the book after a manner that adds immensely to its value. Their kindness in this matter cannot b3 too highly esteemed and appreciated. It is a pleasure aiso to notice the substantial aid which the author has received from gentle- men of local reputation in Cardiff. Among these special mention must be made of Mr. C. T. AAHiitmell, Mr. Atkinson, Mr. Latt.ey, Mr. J. Duckworth, and Mr. Cars- lake Thompson. The chapter on the ever- memorable Prebendary Webb is invaluable. Its main fault is its brevity. One can never hear !• too much of so good a man, and so exact an observer and so excellent a writer as the dear old Celestial Objects Webb." He is quite as celestial as any of the objects, and, indeed, more so. If there were space and a mind for criti- ciftn I would say that a good deal of the matter under several heads, e.?., "Telescopes," "Obser- vation," &c., might with advantage be differently arranged and made more coherent and conse- cutive. Now and then articles of great interest on a common thpme are separated by a wide interval (see pp. 30-1 and 38-9; and, again, p. 96.) It would have hff»n 1\11 a^vntitage also if Mr. Denniog's invaluable appendix could have followed p. 93 Now and then a line or two of explanation would have been very .welcome. Ta.ke one example only. Lord Crawford's simple method for working an alt-awmuth instrument on equatorial lines—see p. 27—is not made clear to every reader even by means of this admirable little drawing. In the next edition-which we trust may soon appear Mr. Mee will, perhaps, tell his unlearned readers a little more particularly what a micrometer is—p. 31—and give up the mock suns at Llanstephan—p. 6—in favour of the Gegenshein "—p. 7. What the Gegenshein is our kind author does not think it needful to explain: he does not even tell ua tha1- it is "made in Germany." But he does tell us a thousand things we are glad .to learn or to be reminded of, and for his admirable way of telling them amateur students and observers owe him a thousand thanks and much more than half-a-crown in hard cash. To 611 those who are interested in Astronomy and/ thirk of buying a telescope, I would say, Buy'the book at cnce. In its line it is by far the completest and cheapest book in the market. [" Observational Astronomy-a Practical Book for Amateurs." By Arthur Mee, F.R.A.S., &c. Second and thoroughly revised edition. "Western Mail," Cardiff and London, 2s. 6d.]

docs.full_text: lOCAL OBITUARY NOTICES. MR. W. H. TOWERS, SWANSEA. Mr. W. H. Towers, a well-known Swansea ehipbroker, and a past member and captain of the Swansea Rugby fifteen, died on Friday morning from paralysis of the brain. Mr. Towers was only 42 years of age, and was of eoneiderable physical strength. He came to Swansea in 1885 as manager for Messrs. James Wood and Co.. shipowners and brokers, and afterwards entered into partnership with Mr. "Wedlabe as Wedlake, Towers, and Co. He recently had litigation with a tugboat-owning firm for which he had acted, and the non- success of this appeared to have preyed on his mind. He married the eldest daughter of the late Mr. William Thomas, builder, and leaves a widow and two children. MR. JAMES REES, J.P., LLANDOVERY. We regret to announce the death of Mr. James Bees, J.P, of Talgarth, near Llan- dovery, which took place at Grove House, Llandovery, late on Thursday evening. The deceased, who was 73 years of age. had been in indifferent health for some considerable time. He was a zealous member of the Llandovery Board of Guardians and District Council for a lengthy period, being chairman of the latter body for several years. He also represented Cilycwm parish on the Carmarthenshire County Council. MR. F. J. DENDY, CARDIFF. General regret was expressed at the Cardiff Docks on Monday when the news of the death of Mr. F. J. Dendy, of the firm of T. P. Thomas and Co., coal exportere, &c., became known. Mr. Dendy, "ho became partner in the firm some time ago, was one of the most highly eeteemed young men at the Cardiff Docks. He was only 36 years of age. and was formerly manager for j^esers. D. Radford and Co. His death took place at his residence, Addiscombe House, LlandaiF. He was taken ill at the office on Friday after- noon, and was ordered home by a medical adviser. On Sunday night Dr. Fred Evans and Dr. Cornelius Griffiths performed an operation to remove an obstruction of the rtomach, and from the effect of the opera- tion he failed to rally. Mr. Dendy, who was a. brother of Mr. Dendy, wine and spirit merchant, Charles-street, Cardiff, was a. native of Gilwern, near Abergavenny, and leaves a. widow and a. little girl. MR. J. PRICE, YSTALYFERA. The remains of Mr. John Price were con- veyed by the first train from Pontycymmer on Monday for interment at Ystalyfera. The deceased lived at Ystalyfera, but had spent a few weeks at Pontycymmer with his sister, Mrs. Voyle, thinking the change might improve his health. The deceased was 34 years of age. CAPTAIN WILLIAM NOBLE. F.R.A.S. The death is announced, at an advanced age, of Captain William .Noble, F.R.A.S., of ITclffield, Sussex. He served in the Rifle Brigade, but devoted the greater part of his life to astronomy. For 40 years he contri- buted to the "English Mechanic" above the signature "A Fellow of the Royal Astro- nomical Society." His valuable help was ever at the service of students of science every- where, and, as a solitary instance, it may be mentioned that he revised the proof-sheets of both editions of Mr. Arthur Mee's "Observa- tional Astronomy," published by Ike "Wes- tern Mail."

docs.full_text: THE PLANET VENUS. Mr. Arthur Mee writes:—The heavens the last few evenings lia/ve presented a magni- ficen-fc spectacle. I11 e ^rt-h-west waa the faint glow of the Zodiacal Light, with Ventia and the young Moon ehrnir.g radiantly upon it, and Mars and the Pleiades near at hauad. Hig-h in thS sC'Utb( was Jupiter, and further towards the west Orion in hia might," with the sparkling and scintillating Sirius— enough to fill the beart of even a hardened observer, with j^y- ,r- Maunder, in his capital new work en The Astronomy of the Bible," points out sadly how the denizens of towns are getting to see less and less of the heavens. This is a thousand pities, and we must hope that the movement hack to the land" will brin? in its train a revival of popular astronomy- i Venus is at present a resplendent! eight, and the watcher will naturally think she is proportionately more beatul and interest-1 ing in the telescope. 'Tbis is, however, not the case. In a good instrument the Moon' eh owe tus her wealth of craters, Jupiter his evor-varying- cloud-belts, Mars has snorw-polee and continent-outlines, and Saturn his mm. dorful ring. Yenus, however, shows us just now a lovely half-moon, and that is about all. Patient observers are sometimes rewarded by a glimpse of faint amorphous shadings. I have £ «'ii thorn myself more than once with my 8in. reflector, and the late Mr. A. A. Williams, who happened to be observing with me on one such occasion, did the same. But, as a rule, the brilliant crescent presents no detail, and what is eonietimes seen in very small telescopes—two or thfee inches aperture-is usually regarded as fictitious, and with reason. For some time a careful and accurate observer, Mx. M'liarg, of Lisburn, ia Ireland, has been' specially successful in this department, and has published some interesting and remark- able results, which, however, await confirma- tion. The surface of Venue is so cloudy tha/t it is evident we see nothing or next to nothing of its physical details, which is a pity, as Venus is a world nearly as large as our own, and, probably, more earthlike than any other planet, even Mars, as well as being our next-door neighbour." Sthe has no satel- lite, but at times of her inferior our earth must shine in her midnight sky with all the splemdoux of a small moon. Venus will be at greateat elongation the end of this month, and at greatest brilliancy the end of Ma.y. At present her northerly deolina,tion is so great that it is nearly midnight before she extinguishes' her bright lamp beneath the horizon..

E., of Llanelly, which left that port on February 2, coal laden, for Faversham. She must have foundered off the coast, and her crew six in number, were drowned. The bodv of the captain wsa washed ashore at Pondine, on FONE' MONTH FOK A KISS.—George Youd, of Manchester, has paid dearly for a kiss. He met & girl on Ardwick-green and forcibly kissed her. He coolly told the Stipendiary that he was attracted to the girl by the way sh.e was dressed her hat, he said, especially took his fancy. He was sent to gaol'for a month. An average waltz takes a. dancer over about three-quarters of a mile a square dance makes him cover half a mile. THE BRITISH CAMPAIGN IN WEST AFRICA —Earl Spencer, on arriving at Paddington 011 Friday from Windsor was met by a messenger with important dispatches, which it is believed have arrived from Bathurst, Senegambia. His lordship at once proceeded to the Admiralty. —The Press Association learns from official sources that 300 men of the West India Regi- ment from Sierra. Leone landed <1t Bathurst on Thursday evening, and advanced against Fodr Silah on Friday. At the same time Admiral Bedford landed a much larger force. A SPLENDID GIFT.—Sir Heory Thompson, the eminent surgeon, has, the" Observatory Magazine" states, offered the sum of "£5,000 sterling to the nation, through the Astronomer Royal, for the purpose of buying a telescope for Greenwich Observatory. It is not often astronomy finds such a generous patron, on this side of the Atlantic at least, and moreover, one who can so well appreciate the exact needs of the science at the moment. For Sir H. Thompson, foreseeing that the astronomy of the future is to be photographic, and feeling that England should be well equipped in this arm, makes it a condition of his gift th&t I the telescope is to be expressly designed for photo- graphic purposes. So far as the plans are made, and subject to the acceptance of the offer by the Government, the instrument is to be of 26in. aperture, just twice that of the telescopes used for the Photographic Chart of the Heavens—in fact, the instrumeut is to be made from the model of the Astrographic Equatorial, but ofexaotty double the dimensions in every particular. The guiding telescope for the new instrument will be 12jin. Merz refractor with a light tube; and the 9in. photographic objective presented by Sir H. ihompson to the Royal Observatory some years ago will also be carried on the same mounting, for u,e as a photoheliograph, as at present. The wen instrument, when completed, will be housed under the Lassel Dome, on the top of the central octagon of the new Physical Observatory, now being built in the south grounds of the Royal Observatory.

docs.full_text: STELLAR COLLISIONS. Professor Ledger, whose series of Gresham astronomy lectures on "Knocks in their Relation to Astronomy have just been com- pleted, in his last discourse pointed out that j the universe, instead of being fixed, is alive I with motion, each star with its attendant I planets hurrying through space. If star were to knock against star, the intense heat and fierce fire generated by the enormous velocity and vast, momentum of the two masses would be such as to pass human conception. It may be that the sun was formed by the collision of I, two stars. The effect of two such bodies at- tracting each other and meeting would be to reduce them to a violently agitated gaseous mass, which would oscillate, first inwards, producing inconceivable heat, and then out- wards again, ultimately assuming the condi- tion of the sun. The general result would be that the two bodies would revolve round their common centre of gravity—that is to say, round each other—creating a double star. Lord Kelvin has calculatea that, if 2.9,000,000 solid globes, each of the mass of the moon, should be scattered over a spherical surface 100 times the radius of the earth's orbit, they would come together and be raised to a temperature of 100,000 degrees. They would oscillate outwards and inwaxds, reaching to a I less distance each timg and ultimately settling down into a sphere. The nebulae we see around us may, Professor Ledger sug- gests, have been produced by the knocking together of two great bodies rather than by the aggregation of many smaller ones. The collision of two huge suns would thus lead to rejuvenescence nnd the formation of new systems. Phenomena indicating that some- thing very much in the nature of a collision had occurred are the outbursts of temporary stars such as those observed by i ycho Brahe in 1572, by Kepler in 1604, and those of 1848 1866, 1876,1885, and 1892—the last being the new star Auriga, which declined through ten magnitudes, or became 100,000 times less bright in two months. The great increase in the light of a comet as it approaches the sun may be due to a tidal disttu-bauce in the bodies forming it, causing them to knock against each other and thus generate heat and light. In the same way, the twinklin of the stars may be caused by the knocks of the molecules of the atmosphere on the other whose undulations carry light to us! The excessively great and the exceedingly small are all interdependent, and the past present, and probable future of nebulous bodies all hinge on the relations they bear to the knocks of the molecules of their gases I while the knocks of immense bodies depend ultimately on the knocks of their con- stituent atom3. I

docs.full_text: THE ECLIPSE—SEEN LOCALLY. IN no part of our hemisphere could the total eclipse-of the moon have been better observed on Saturday night last than in íSwansoo, yet we fear there were but few, if aliy, local scientific observers of that splendid phenomenon. There are many devoted men of science resident amongst us, buttheirspecialities are metallurgy, mineralogy, and chemistry, and very few extend their researches into the sublime domain of astronomy. With the exception of the veteran scientist, Mr Benjamin Hill, of Clydach, we know of no one in this district who has a well-furnished observatory. Even ] our local learned body, the Royal Institution of South; Wales is wholly unprovided with telescope or spectroscope. The roof of that Institution would form an excellent site for an observatory if such a place could be fitted up, and we feel sure such an adjunct < would redound to the credit of the Council quite as much as the projected Laboratory and much more than the proposed Tennis Court The small party of 1 local observers who witnessed the last transit of Venus 1 from the roof of the Institution will not soon forget the impressive splendour of that sight, which was well r within the range of the unaided eye. From that spot the observer has a very wide and wholly uninterrupted 1 horizon for the most part unobstructed by smoke or i mist and it is to be hoped that ere long the Council 1 will see its way to the erection and furnishing of a 1 compact little observatory on the roof of the Institution. 1 In the absence of such facilities, of course, local observa- tions in astronomy must remain imperfect and unsatis- 1 factory. On Saturday night last, many eyes were 1 directed to the chaste satellite, impatiently awaiting 1 the first appearance of the obscuring shadow. Many i persons fancied it began before it really did, and such 1 an argument as this might have been heard in the < streets: 1 There it is I see it now the eclipse has begun. ] Where ? 1 don't see it. On what part of the moon ? ] Why, on the St. Thomas side, to be sure. 1 No it is not on the east side it is on the north— i the Llangafelach side—of the moon. ] Get along; you can't see it at all; it is on the Mumbles side of the disc." And so the argument went on, in language that may y. io0allv intelligible, but which certainly was not i Then the accounting for the apparent delay of the phenomenon after the predicted time was also a f ^Maowdo^ou'account for its being so late?" asked 1 OD" ™p°s&i(ThS sapient neighbour; Don't you see ? 1 —the wind is against it, and that lessens the velocity of i the shadow?" 1 As the querist didn't return to the attack, it must be < presumed he was satisfied with the reply. t <

docs.full_text: ARTISTS AND ARTISANS.-LETTER V. TO THE EDITOR OF THE CAMBRIAN." SiR,—I think that we maj" safely say that the works of Hume, Kant, Turgot, Comlorcet, Buckle, Spencer, Mill and Comte, have been crowned with success, and that human history proceeds according to ascertained laws There is in the Science of History (called Sociology) Lr greater play of awkwa'd pert jrbatiocs than in Astro- u >my. Yet, though human prediction is far more splendidly successful in Astronomy than ever it can be in Sociology, yet we are more than amply consoled by the compensation that the course of Sociological facts is highly amenable to human effort, while the course of Astronomical facts :'s highly unamenable. We cannot lengthen or shorten a day we r yn hasten or lettrd the rise or fall of human institutions, such as Serfdom. Catholicism, Monarchy, Tyranny, Republicanism. Still we do in Socialogy detect hw in spite of perturbation. We d. see the rite of the human intellect through superstitious Theologies to baseless and Fruitless Meta- physics, and thence upward to sound science. We d) see the human intellect constructing the Sciences one after another, bringing them to the positive stage in the order of decreasing generality and increasing complexity first Mathematics, the science of number and extension then astronomy, concerning the Heavenly bodies then Physics, concerning the forces at the earth's surface, altering the states of materials; then Chemistry, dealing only with such changes in the state of matter rs alter the nature of bodies then Biology, which deals only with living bodies, or with those chemical combinations and decompositions which are self-sustaining and self- renewing; then Sociology, which deals with the progress of the great united, continous. self-recording organism, formed by the stream of human generat'ons through ages and ages. We do see the natural succession in Action as well as in thought, namely, the fact that human society goes naturally through the stages of offensive warfare and defensive warfare to Industrialism. We do see that there is a law of evolution of feeling correspond- ing to the laws of intellect and action, namely, that family-feeling under Fetichism broadens into civic feel- ing, under Polytheism, and thence into general bene- volence, uuder Monotheism. We can understand the use of Slavery as following and improving upon the slaughter of captives, its development into serfdom, which develops into free labour, which again will doubt- less develop more and more into Organised Labour. AV, e can in Sociology prophecy with moderate success, and we can also work with moderate success tows-rds or against the fnlfilmentof such prophecies. We must first consider, then imagine, then act. Practically, we are all anxious for human progi-ess,-that is to say, we want something better, which we can get; but we don't know exactly what it is like, nor bow exactly to make for it. The very case for the Artist! He must have a good ground- ing in science and in the practical experience of a varied and daring life then he has a good notion as to the powers of Reformers. Then his artistic powers must come into use, and he must construct with full imagina- tion of detail, of the turns of events, the crabljdness of things, the humbug of hyprocites and turncoats, the quarrels amongst the best-intentioned, the questions of money, the cold-shoulder of a suspicious ajd often- fooled world, and the untamable strength and valour of confident heroes. The hour must be described the man must be described, and also all the preliminary hours and preliminary men. Artists must describe Utopias not Utopias which men cannot reach, but Utopias which they bl can, and probably will.—Yours, &c., C. G. H.

docs.full_text: A SERMON AT THE CHAPEL ROYAL. Mr. Kingsleyhadanimmenaecongregation to he a r his sermonat the ChapelRoyal, Whitehall, London, on Sun- day afternoon, the Bishop of London as well as a great many peers and members of the House of Commens being present. The preacher, taking his text from the words in the Epistle to the Hebrews, Yet once more, and I will shake not the earth only, but the heavens," declared that the prophecy was being fulfilled once again now, as it was in the first, the fifth, the eleventh, and the sixteenth centuries. All systems of ethic. theology, and science seemed changing, he said. Some talked of .this- as the glorious nineteenth century, the age of progress, the eve of a new reformation, of all sorts of blessings to humanity others spoke of it as the unhappy nineteenth century, the age of scepticism and atheism. Both parties were right and both wrong. God was shaking not the physical world only, but our conceptions of the spiritual world. With increased knowledge had come not increased doubt ('' tha.t," said Mr. Kingsley, "I deny"), but increased reverence, and the truly irreverent time was the middle ages, with their system-making and their system-mongering, and their cosmogonies framed in the cloister, when the earth was supposed to be a flat plane (the notion of antipodes being unscriptural), heaven above it with the good people in it, and hell below it with the wicked —what could be clearer, since Virgilliaid so? when Tartarus, Styx, and Phlegethon were recognized Christian entities, and Tartarology was as firmly be- lieved in as astronomy now. Astronomy had shaken the theories of the size of the earth, geology those of the age of it. Again, in an age which hated torture reformed criminals, and hesitated, rightly or wrongly: about continuing capital punishment, people asked whether Scripture really endorsed all the middle-age notions of future punishment—whether such phrases as "outer darkness," "the undying worm," "a Gehenna of fire," were to be taken as implying torment hereafter, or as the sure punishment of sin in this life —whether heaven might not be the moral world full of goodness, beneficence, and purity, in which God reigned, and hell a condition of hatred, malice, im- purity. If men were to believe in the same theories of religion as men in mediaeval times believed, when cri- minals were racked, heretics burned alive, and every Mussulman slain by the crusaders was consigned to eternal torture, fearful times were coming for the Church and the people. What, then, remained for us? Surely not an unchangeable cosmogony or ethical system, or dogmatic theology, but an unchangeable King, an unchangeable kingdom. If we believed in that kingdom, surely Christ, the King, who governed it, knew how to govern it better than we did. He it was who was shaking the earth and heaven, changing opinions, burning the cbaff and stubble from about the one foundation of Truth. The Reformation was a change back to apostolic doctrine—might not the new Reformation be still more so?

docs.full_text: DR. LARDNER'S CABINET CYCLOPAEDIA. We select the following interesting passages from the 43d volume of Lardner's Cabinet Cyclopaedia a well-written trea- tise on astronomy, by Sir J. Herschel:— Is TIlE lVIOON INHABITED?—Telescopes must yet be greatly improved, before we can expect to see signs of inhabitants, as manifested by edifices or by changes on the surface of the soil. It should, however, be observed, that, owing to the small density of the materials of the moon, and the comparatively feeble gra- vitation of bodies on her surface, muscular force would there go six times as far in overcoming the weight of materials as on the earth. Owing to the want of air, however, it seems impossible that any form of life analogous to those on earth can subsist there. No appearance indicating vegetation, or the slightest variation of surface which can fairly be ascribed to change of season, can any where be discerned. THE FrxED STARS. -Now, for what are we to suppose such magnificent bodies scattered through the abyss of space ? Surely not to illuminate our nights, which an additional moon of the thousandth part of the size of our own would do much better, nor to sparkle as a pageant void of meaning and reality,'and bewilder us among vain conjectures. Useful, it is true,' they are to man as points of exact and permanent reference but he must have studied astronomy to little purpose, who can suppose man to be the only object of his Creator's care, or who does not see in the vast and wonderful apparatus arround us provision for other races of animated beings. The planets, as we have seen, derive their light from the sun but that cannot be the case with the stars. These doubtless, then, are themselves suns, and may, perhaps each in its sphere, be the presiding centre round which other planets, or bodies of which we can form no conception from any analogy offered by our own system, may be circu- lating. SATURN'S RINGs.-The rings of Saturn must present a magni- ficent spectacle from those regions of the planet which lie above their enlightened sides, as vast arches spanning the sky from horizon to horizon, and holding an invariable situation among the stars. On the. other hand, in the regions beneath the dark side, a solar eclipse of fifteen years in duration, under their sha- dow, must afford (to our ideas) an inhospitable asylum to ani- mated beings, ill compensated by the faint light of the satellites. But we shall do wrong to judge of the fitness or unfitness of their condition from what we have seen around us, when, perhaps the very combinations which convey to our minds only image's of horror, may be in reality theatres of the most striking and glori- ous displays of beneficent contrivance.

docs.full_text: PROFESSOR PRITCHARD DEAD. The Rev. Charles Pritchard, D.D., F.R.S., the Savilian Professor of Astronomy at Oxford, died at his house in Oxford on Sunday morning. In spite of serious illness of long duration he paid his visits to the Observatory almost to the last, and it is not long since his astronomical work obtained the highest pos- sible recognition. Dr. Pritchard was a Fellow of St. John's College, Cambridge, where he took his degree as 4th Wrangler in 1830. For many years he was headmaster of the Clapham Grammar School, and various men of distinction-the Dean of Westminster and others-owed to him their early training. In 1870 he was elected to the Savilian chair of astronomy at Oxford, and from that date he superintended with unflagging zeal the new Observatory in the Parks, which, through his enthusiasm and thanks to the munificence of Dr. De la Rue, has had an ample share of the endowment of scientific research by the University of late years. Dr. Pritchard was made a Fellow of New College in 1883, and hon. Fellow of St. John's, Cambridge, in 1886. He was President of the Royal Astronomical Society in 1866, and in the same year he was awarded the gold medal of that society for recent valuable discoveries in stellar photometry. He was Hulsean lecturer in 1867, and was select preacher both at Oxford and Cambridge and five times he preached by request before the British Association at their annual meeting. Many treatises from Dr. Pritchard's hands have appeared in the Transactions" of the Royal Astronomical Society. Among these may be mentioned "A Treatise on Statical Couples," "The Figure of the Earth," The Conjunctions of Jupiter and Saturn," and a paper on "An Improved Method of using Mercury for Astronomical Purposes." He was the author of one of the most interesting articles in the Bible Dic- tionary "—namely, The Star of the Magi" and several articles in the 9th (or last) edition of the Encyclopaedia Britannica" were written by him. In 1886 he was awarded the gold medal of the Royal Astronomical Society for his Uranometria Nova Oxoniensis." Many of his writings have been col- lected into a volume entitled Occasional Thoughts of an Astronomer on Nature and Revelation" (1890). He did not forget in the midst of his Uni- versity life the time which he had spent at Clapham, for in 1886 the Old Boys of that school invited their old schoolmaster to dinner, and the result was a little volume, called Annals of our School Life," addressed to his former pupils. Professor Pritchard was in his 84th year at the time of his death. In spite of his great age he was in full possession of all his faculties to the last.

SAD DEATH OF A CARDIFF LADY.—We regret to announce the death of Mrs Jane Barwell, wife of Mr Henry Barwell, of 29, Kinraig-street, Roath, Cardiff, and mother-in-law of Mr D. Roberts, shipping superintendent, Barry, which occurred oa Wednesday, the 21st ult., as the result of an accident. The deceased lady was interred on Monday at Cardiff Cemetery. i THE PRESBYTERIAN HALL.—A first-class enter- tainment, followed by a coffee supper, was provided at the above hall on Tuesday evening last. Mr Sun Griffiths presided over the entertainment, ia which the following took part:—Messrs J. 7, Sherwood, J. Davies, Master Edwards, Mrs Janes, Mr Mead, Mr R. W. Dyer, Mrs Williams, &c. A KIND VOTE OF SYMPATHY.—At the annual dinner of the Barry Male Voice Party, held at the JKarry Hotel on Saturday evening last, upon the thoughtful recommendation of the chairman (Mr R. Evans, the general manager of the Barry Company), a Vote of deep sympathy was passed with the president of the party (Mr D. Roberts) and family upon their recent bereavement, the vote being passed amid respectful silence. YOUNG MEN'S BIBLE CLAgs.-At the usual weekly meeting of the bible class in connection with the Parish Church, to be held this evening (Friday), at the Parish Hall, the Rev J, Price, St. Paul's, will deliver an address.—An able and instruc- tive lecture, entitled 1* Astronomy," was delivered by Captain W. B. Whall at the Church Hall, Barry, on Thursday evening last. There was a good attendance, and the Rev J. Du Heaume occupied the chair. Captain Whall's remarks were listened to with much interest, and questions were also I asked and answered at the close, a hearty vote of I thanks being accorded the lecturer for the enter- taining evening he had provided. THE GRAND CONCERT AT THE MARKET HALL.— We beg once more to remind our music-loving I readers of the grand professional concert (in aid of the funds of Tabernacle Welsh Independent Chapel, Holton-road) to be held at Barry Market Hall to-morrow (Saturday) evening, when a truly first-class programme will be presented, the artistes including the following well-known and talented singers :—Soprano, Miss Emily Francis, Penarth contralto. Miss Mary Thomas, gold medallist, winner of the Westmoreland Scholarship, R.A.M.: tenor, Mr William Evans bass, Mr Gwilym Thomas, Ynyshir. Professor Richard Howells, of Aberdare, will be the accom- panist, and Alderman Meggitt will preside. The Press speak in the highest terms of praise of the artistic merits of the singers named.

docs.full_text: CARDIFF CITY OBSERVATORY. J Mr Frankten Evans's Gift. I The formal opening of the Cardiff City Observatory on Penvlan Hill took place on Saturday, the ceremony being performed by the Lord Mayor. The observatory has been erected within the grounds of the city water works, and. though unpretentious, it is well built, and the most scrupulous care has been taken with the foundations. It is on the Berthon model, with revolving dome and shutters, whilst the telescope itself, the gilt of the late Mr Franklen G. Evans, F.R. A S., to the city, is of massive proportions, and the largest instrument of the kind in the Princi- pality. It, has been mounted on an equatorial stand, and furnished with a driving clock. A large company, consisting of several mem- bers of the City Council and of the Astro- nomic*! Society of Wales, had gathered in the observatory grounds when Councillor Kidd, the chairman of the Telescope Com- mittee, asked the Lord Mayor to formally open* the observatory., He first of all warmly congratulated the Lord Mayor upon his recovery ,and pointed out that this opening ceremony would have been performed long ago bad it not been for the Lord Mayor's unfortunate illness. Councillor Kidd then pro- ceeded to explain the circumstances under which the telescope had been presented to the city, and on behalf of the Telescope Committee he warmly thanked tha members of the family of the late Mr Franklen Evans, the donor, for the great interest they had taken in the matter. Mr Franklen Evans's idea when he gave this instrument was to hw!n those thousands of people who had made astcdy of astronomy and who had not the wherewithal to look through a large instrument, and to see the heavenly bodies as they ought to be seen. He had also to thank the members of the Astronomical Society of Wales for the great interest theV had taken in the matter, and Mr Arthur Mee, Mr Atkinson, and Mr A. Taylor for the vror-k they had put in in putting the instrument in order. (Hear, hear.) The Lord Mayor, iu formally declaring the observatory open, said that at one time the members of tbe Corporation did] not realise the importance of the telescope to a large maritime centre like Cardiff. From an educational point of view it should prove invaluable to students. and he sincerely hoped his fellow citizens and his fellow countrymen would come to the observatory, which would be always open, under certain conditions to improve their knowledge of the heavens: (Applause.) Car- diff was again to the fore, and was the only municipality in Wales that could give its citi- zens this opportunity. &n(j this was quite in keeping with its being the leading town in the Principality. He sincerely hoped the instru- ment would he well used by those who took an interest in astronomy. (Hear, hear.) Mr A. Tayior, F.R..A-S.. then delivered a short address on the value of the telescope as a powerful educational factor and invaluable to students and teachers. Major-General H. H. Lee proposed a vote of thanks to Mr Taylor, and a similar compliment was paid to the Lord Mayor, after which tbe company were entertained to tea.

docs.full_text: COMMON SENSE" ON ASTRONOMY. The author of a book called "Common Sense" is a superlative joker, and his friend Parallax (whoever he may be) belongs, no doubt, to the same facetious school of philosophers. The author of this very amusing and not altogether uninetractive essay endea- vours to laugh us out of all that modern science has taught us on the subject of astronomy. The alleged discoveries of Copernious and Newton- Pure intelligence, whom God To mortals lent to trace his boundless works, Through laws sublimely simple-" are no discoveries at all. They are mere assumptions and idle theories; in fact, the Newtonian system is an execrable superstition." Onr author boldly contends that the earth is not a globe, and that there are no antipodes. He maintains that the earth is an extended level surface, on every hand raised above the one grand level of seas and oceans;" a horizontal plane; that it is immoveable; that if it travelled at the speed assigned to it by modern astronomers, everything it -and b.a ,aonfid<yitly appeals to the as to the fixity of the earth (which he denies to be a planet) and the motions of the heavenly bodies in con. firmation of his assertion. He treats with supreme contempt and denounces in the strongest-were he not joking, we would say the most offensive—epithets, modern astronomers and their theories- Those earthly godfathers of heaven's lights That give a name to every fixed star, Have no more profit of their shining nights Than those that walk and wot not what they are." Indeed, he affirms, with confidence, that the notions of the rustic vulgar before the Copernicau system waa developed are true, and those of the philosophers false. With the exception of the assertion that the earth is a plane or level surface (the inequalities of hills and mountains being inappreciable in comparison to the vast size of the body), the author's philosophy is- purely negative. He does not attempt to construct any system which will afford an explanation of the phenomena we perceive; his purpose is simply de- structive. He endeavours to overturn the arguments advanced by eminent writers to prove the globular form of the earth, and in some casea he is excessively happy in the manner in which he takes advantage of unguarded expressions and amphibolia. He is always amusing and playful, but nothing can be more mirth- moving than the affected solemnity with which he puts himself forward as the advocate of truth—even though he should be a martyr — in opposition to all the astronomical theorists. Throughout the work the author displays abundant evidenoe of deep thought and a nicely discerning mind, but his love of fun and irony never forsakes him. He banters, ridicules, jeers, scoffs, and chaffs the philosophers in a manner that would be merciless if it were not so humorous; and what puzzles us, is that some of his reviewers should have attempted to treat him seriously. As a specimen of the author's pleasant logic, let the following suffice. Dr. Mann, in an argument to prove the convexity of the earth, says, that mankind having invented ships, went "to sail in theni on the sea.. They then went further and farther, until at last they found they could again reach the spot they started from without turning back at all." To this our author replies, "Here we find that the ship went further and further, and got back again, nevertheless; and that, although they got back again, it was without turning back at all. So they came back, then, or returned." It is not likely, notwithstanding the challenge thrown out in the preface, that any of the "theoretical astronomers," to use the author's phrase, will seriously vouchsafe an answer to a work written in this pleasant vein.

docs.full_text: ABERAYRON. LITERARY AND DEBATING SOCIETY.-Tbe debate on the subject. That cheap printing is not beneficial to the community," which took place on Friday last, was the flattest listened to for many a long day. Mr C. J. Hughes, B.A., took the affirmative of the proposition as it stands, and Mr William Williams the negative. The speeches of the openers showed that they had given little thought to the subject and they expressed what they had to say in a weak manner, their speeches occupying together about ten minutes. The other speakers were:—On the affirmative, Miss Scott and Mr David Williams; and on the negative, Mr Dew- hurst, Mr Seex, Mr E. Lima Jones, the President, Mr Tom Davies, Mr Occie Davies, Mr Lee Davies, and Miss Olive Jones. As was naturally to be expected after the feeble opening speeches, all the various speakers showed up poorly. The debate lacked the enthusiasm which generally charac- terises the proceedings of this Society. READING ROOM.— Verily it is no wonder that the Reading Room does not pay its way. It is every evening filled with a crowd of rowdy boys, whose conduct at their games of draughts and chess is hardly conformable to the rules which one might expect to find adhere4 to at a reading room as such. For several days recently several of the papers, notably the "South Wales Daily News," have been removed from the table by somebody. COUNTY SCHOOL.—This week the number of pupils has gone up higher again. The entertain- ment arranged by Miss Scott and Mr Williams for the benefit of the library funds will come off this day fortnight. It will consist of three parts:— Christy Minstrels, Mrs Jarley's waxworks, and a laughable farce entitled, My Turn Next." The entertainment will thus provide a great variety of good things, each section being of an^exceptionally taking character. About twenty of the school- boys will form the troupe of Christy Minstrels. BRITISH SCHOOL.—Miss Gretta Rees has passed her third year's pupil-teachership examinations, obtaining the mark "well." Miss Elizabeth Davies, Gwalia House, also another of the staff has com- pleted her first year creditably. THE TOWN LIGHTS.—The authorities of Aber- ayron are nothing if they are not promoters of education, and that of the highest type, especially scientific and technical education. The truth oi this statement may not be apparent at first, but if one looks into the root, into the cause as it were, of various curious customs prevailing in our town, one has to admit the truth of this assertion. For instance, upon first aquaintance with the town, the stranger cannot understand, and, therefore, as usual in such cases, misunderstands, why it is that in the case of the town-lights, the lamps should be all lit when the moon is at its full, but that when the moon is wholly hidden there should be no lighting of the lamps at all. But the truth has suddenly flashed out, even as an inspiration comes at times. The new theory is this :—The lamps are lit when the moon waxeth strong so that we may have light whereby we may carefully study the, moon, and the starry firmament on high, thus promoting the use- ful and instructive study of astronomy. Again when the moon is not seen, what is the need for lamps? For the proper study of astronomy and lunonomy one must be able to see the objects studied. Also a perfectly dark night is conductive to the making of poets, and to the forming of the heroij strain in men. Who, after these, explana- tions of one of the misunderstood—and this is only one-actions of our town authorities, will say that they—the authorities, not the actions-are not actuated by the highest regard for the public welfare and progress ?

TO THK KDITOlt OF THE WKSTHHN MAIL SIB,—The learned world lias long suspected that the Twelve Battles of King Arthur mean, like tlto Twelve Labours of Hercuie. the sun passing through the Twelve Signs of the Zodiac, nnd that, therefore, "Arthur" was cno of thll titles of the sun in Cambro-British Druidism. We know that the Great Bear (Ursa Major) is known in the Welsh language ns Arthur's lllougli (Aradr Arthur). The lyra is called Arthur's limp iteivit Arthur). Many an old circle of stones in Wales and elsewhere is called Arthur's Quoit (Coiten Arthur). The last name has greatly puzzled antiquarians. Now, the names Araar Arthur (Arthur's Plougii-Ursa ftiajor—Great Hear) and Arthur's n'lrp (the Lyre) on astronomical signs would themselves indicate some strange connection of "Arthur" with astronomy. We know that the cirole of twelve stones of the Goreedd of tho Hards (Exalted Throue of the liards) signi- lies the circle of the Zodiac, with its twelve signs around the globe, and, therefore, that the Cromlech, and uiso the Logan Stone -sometimes it is the one and sometimes the other which is found in the centre of the circle-dignifies the globe of the earth. The Hocking Stone (Logan Stone) and the top slab ot the C'roinlecn both signify the earth as the repository, throuh the winter months, of the seed germs amun? the general deu%y. As cGnsequence, this repository i. ltëm.1>l'utdbm An:h yr H?ut (Ark of the Sun), hence the old creed u?)ned"H?t)o-Atkito." It seems that the Gorsedd was named by the ell- lightened old Druids Coiten .<1rlhur" (Arthur's Quoit) to imply the insignificance ot the srlllbul iu comparison 10 what it .symbolised, viz.. the sun's apparent circle around the earth and the globe itself. 1 now come to what I think is a most startling and important di^coveiy. ^'ennius, in his Ilistorv of tho Britons, p. 403 (Bohn'sed.), states thatKin? Thomas rriw ?"CdL-i..? lm.iQawe" ) pj>iuls OUl,! think conclusively—'bore oil liia shield the Image of thu Holy Virgin, Mother of God." (7; Libra, (8; Virgo. Geolirey of Monmouth, in his" British History," tells us (p. 234) that the name of Arthur's shield was" Priwen (1'rydwen), or Britantiiu. It is deeply interesting thus to find the Holy Virln Mary and Britannia, the goddess of til* West, mistaken one for the Llier by L)??til Neeinius aud GeolTrey of Alonmouth. docs.full_text: SOME OF THE MAGAZINES. We have received the first number of Sir Robert Ball's Story of the Heaven3," a magnificent work, published in fourteen monthly parts by Messrs Cassell and Company. Sir Robert Ball is the Lowndoan Professor of Astronomy, Cambridge, but he is better known to the average person as a very interesting lecturer in connection with the Gilchrist trust. The Story of the Heavens is accompanied by very valuable plates, and in the early chapters Sir Robert, describing how much the beginner in astronomy may observe for himself, says Let us suppose that the observer is provided with an opera- glitss and is about to commence his astronomical studies. The first step is to become acquainted with the conspicuous group of seven stars called the Plough, or Charles's Wain, but astronomers prefer to regard it as a portion of the constellation of the Great Bear (Ursa Major). There are many features of interest in this constellation, and the beginner should learn as soon as possible to identify the seven stars which compose it. Of thjse the two at the head of the Bear are generally cailed the pointers." They are of sptcial use, because ,hey serve to guide the eye to that most important star in the whole sky, known as the pole star." Fix the attention on that region in the Great Bear which forms a sort of rectangle. The next fine night try to count how many stars are visible withiu that rectangle. On a very line night, without a moon, perhaps a dozen might bt perceived, or even more, according to the keeness of the eye- Dut. when the OpCLa.lcb3» la ILITOCTCIL to the same part of the constellation an astonishing s;ht is witnessed. A hundred stars can now be seen with the greatest ease. But the opera-glass will not show nearly all the stars in this region. Any good telescope will reveal many hundreds too faint for the feebler instrument. The greater the telescope the more numerous the stars so that seen through one of the colossal instruments the number would have to be reckoned in thousands. We have chosen the Great Bear because it is more generally known than any other constellation. But the Great Bear is not exceptionally rich in stare. To tell the number of the stars is a task which no man has accomplished but various estimates have been made. Our great telescopes can probably show at least 50,000,000 stars." Cassell'a Mayazinc for this month is set off with a very interesting cover picture, entitled, When Jack comes Home," wherein Jack is depicted with his wife, and carrying his little daughter along the atteet. There is a very instructive article on The building of a great telescope," founded by Mr Charles T. Yerkes, at William's Biy, Wisconsin, U S.A. Some idea of the siza and tremendous magnifying power of this enormous instrument may bo gathered when it is stated thaz it is twenty-four yards long, and weighs, with its iron pedestal and masonry, seventy-tive tous, and was built at a coat of iE250,000 Still more interesting perhaps is the article, entitled Town a.nd Gown Rows at Oxford." AU who have read history must know of the street fights between 'I the undorgrK-dukd and the townsmen. For ,? to-i,;n,irien. 1,'or w o r- than six hundred years," we are told, every Oxford man felt it his bouaden dntv on the 5th of November to sally for.h from his college and break the skull of some townsman, or have his own broken, as the case might be." But now bonfires in the quads seem to be the only recognised method of keeping the 5tn." Liners in time of Witr is an acceptable item. Tho contents also include seven complete stories.

docs.full_text: NEGROES KILLED IN A FIGHT. A fight took place at Wildwood, Florida, where a negro was recently murdered. The fight led to a riot on the part of the negroes, which was only quelled with some difficulty. Two days later a posse of troops sought to arrest the murderer, and the negroes on their part endeavoured to protect him. A fusillade was opened on both sides and continued for some time, the blacks finally being driven off. Four of the negroes are known to be killed, 15 are wounded, and a large number have been arrested. The negroes throughout the whole district are reported to be organising, and the governor of the State has consequently ordered reinforcements to the district. These are already en route to tl, appoin To be li. The x Under-Secr To be C.B.: Mr. C. N. Daaion, Local Government Board. .Mr. C. E. Gifford, Secretary tv in-Chief at Portsmouth. Mr. T. Norman Lockyer, F.R.S., Astronomy in the Royal College of Science. Mr. W. H. Preece, Engineer-in-Chief to the G.P.O. Mr. Lyell, one of the new baronets, is member for Orkney and Shetland, and nephew of the late Sir C. Lyell, Bart., the eminent geologist, whose baronetcy became extinct at his death 10 years ago. Mr. Theo- dore Fry, the other new baronet, is Liberal member for Darlington. Of the new knights, Mr. Roe is Sir William Harcourt's colleague at Derby, and has for some 20 years rendered yeoman service to his party while Mr. Macfarlane is the member for Argyllshire. The Hon. Robert Meade is Permanent Under-Secretary at the Colonial Office, and figured prominently at the recent Behring Sea Fishery Arbitration in Paris. Mr. C. N. Dalton in his capacity as assistant-secretary to the Local Government Board has done good service under several Governments. Mr. Gifford is a known authority on affairs naval, as are Messrs. Lockyer and Preece on astronomy and engineering respec- tively. The Queen has also conferred the honour of knighthood upon the following gentlemen: Mr. Fielding Clarke, Chief Justice of Hong Kong. Mr. John Winfield Bonser, Chief Justice of Ceylon. Mr. Hartley Williams, Senior Puisne Judge of the Supreme Court of Victoria. Mr. William Patrick Manning, Mayor of Sydney. The Queen has also given directions for the follow- ing appointments to the Order of St. Michael and St. George: To be K.C.M.G.: Mr. Neal Porter, Colonial Secretary of Jamaica. Hon. Jenkin Coles, Speaker of the Legislative Assembly of South Australia. Mr. Westby Brook Perceval, Agent-General for New Zealand. The Queen has also approved the following pro- motions in and appointments to the Orders of the Star of India and Indian Empire: To be K.C.S.I. Sir Henry Mortimer Durand, K.C.I.E. To be C.S.I. Mr. Richard Udny. Mr. Jervoise Athelstane Barnes. Mr. William John Cunningham. Mr. Thomas Salter Pyne. To be K.C.I.E.: The Maharao Raja of Bundi. The Maharajah of Karauli. The Maharajah of Orchha. Prince Jehar Kader Mirza Bahadur of Oudh. Colonel John Charles Ardagh. Colonel Lord William De la Poer Beresford. Mr. James Llye Mackay.
