docs.full_text: A SERMON AT THE CHAPEL ROYAL. Mr. Kingsley had an immense congregation to hen his sermon at the Chapel Royal, Whitehall, London, on Sun- day afternoon, the Bishop of London as well as a great many peers and members of the House of Commons being present. The preacher, taking his text from the words in the Epistle to the Hebrews, "Yet once more, and I will shake not the earth only, but the heavens," declared that the prophecy was being fulfilled once again now, as it was in the first, the fifth, the eleventh, and the sixteenth centuries. All systems of ethic- theology, and science seemed changing, he said. Some talked of this as the glorious nineteenth century, the age of progress, the eve of a new reformation, of all sorts of blessings to humanity others spoke of it as the unhappy nineteenth century, the age of scepticism and atheism. Both parties were right and both wrong. God was shaking not the physical world only, but our conceptions of the spiritual world. With increased knowledge had come not increased doubt ( that," said Mr. Kingsley, "I deny"), but increased reverence, and the truly irreverent time was the middle ages, with their system-making and their system-mongering, and their cosmogonies framed in the cloister, when the earth was supposed to be a flat plane (the notion of ant podes being unscriptural), heaven ab"ve it with the good people in it, and hell below it with the wicked —what could be clearer, since Virgil said so ?—when Tartarus, Styx, and Phlegethon were recognized Christian entities, and Tarrarology was as firmly be- lieved in as astronomy now. Astronomy had thaken the theories of the size of the earth, geology those of the age of it. Again, in an age which hated torture, reformed criminals, and hesitated, lightly or wrongly, about continuing capital punishment, people asked whether Scripture really endorsed all the middle-age notions of future punishment- whether such phrases as "outer darkness," "the undying worm," "a Gehenna of nre," were to be taken as implying torment hereaftrr, or as the sure punishment of sin in this life —whether heaven might not be the moral world full of goodness, beneficence, and purity, in which God reigned, and hell a condition of hatred, malice, iin- purity. If men were to believe in the same theories gf religion as men in mediaeval times believed, when cri- minals were racked, heretics burned alive, and every Mussulman slain by the crusaders was consigned to eternal torture, feSrful times were coming for the Church and the people. What, then, remained for us? Surely not an unchangeable cosmogony or ethical system, or dogmatic theology, but an unchangeable King, an unchangeable kingdom. If we believed in that kingdom, sur. ly Christ, the King, who governed it, knew how to govern it better than we did. He it was who was shaking the earth and heaven, changing opinions, burning the chaff and stubble from about the one foundation of Truth. The Reformation was a change back to apostolic doctrine—might not the new Reformation be still more so?

docs.full_text: IN THE PUBLIC EYE. THE SECOND BARON. Lord Hamilton of Dalzell, who will be one of the suite in attendance on the Duke of Connaught at the opening of the first Union Parliament of South Africa, has been to that country before under very different I circumstances, for he served with the Im- perial Yeomanry in the war. Lord Hamilton is thirty-seven years of age and a bachelor. His father was Liberal member for Falkirk Burghs for some years, and on his defeat in 1886 was rewarded for past services with a peerage. Later on he served as a Lord-in- 'I Waiting, as the present holder of the title does also. Both father and son began their careers in the Army. Lord Hamilton has a beautiful seat in Lanarkshire, which i belonged once to the Earls of Carnwath, but passed to the Hamiltons by a marriage in I' the seventeenth century. o: A LABOUR MEMBER. Mr. James Haslam, this year's president of the Trade Union Congress, is member for the Ches- terfield Division of Derbyshire, which he has represented since 1906. He was returned in that year by a substantial majority of 1664, and when he again went to the poll last January his constitu- ents showed their confidence in him by sending him back to I the House of Com- mons with a majority of 2,5H over his Con- servative opponent, I Mr. Haslam was born in 1842, and went to the village school, i He is general secre- tary of the Derby- shire Miners' Association, and -is a magistrate for Derbyshire. He has had experience in local government, having once been a member of the Chesterfield Town Council. He is a member of the Parliamentary Committee of the Trade Union I Congress. -:0: 1 THE NATION'S TIMEKEEPER. Mr. Frank Watson Dyson, F.R.S., now Astro- nomer-Royal of Scotland, has been appointed to succeed Sir William Christie as Astronomer- RoyaL For eleven years before going to Scotland in 1905 Mr. Dyson had been chief assistant at Greenwich, where he now returns. He is the son of a Baptist Minister, and is forty-two years of age. He had a dis- tinguished career at Cambridge, was second Wrangler in 1889, Smith's prize- man, Isaac Newton student, and Fellow of Trinity College. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1901, and has pub- lished n umerous papers on mathematics and astronomy. Mr. Dyson, as Astronomer Royal, becomes re- sponsible for the nation's time. From Greenwich signals are sent all over Great Britain, and this forms an impor- tant part of the daily routine. The observatory also takes its part in mapping the heavens. A photographic record of the sun's face has for some years past been kept, and the Astronomer Royal and his assistants engage in researches into every branch of astronomy.

docs.full_text: DRUIDISM. To the Editor of the "Llangollen Advertiser." Sir,—Thanks to your correspondent for his full and prompt reply to my questions. Of course, he will understand that I sent the questions more in the interest of your readers, who might be anxious for further information than mine own. I felt in reading J. S. G's. letter that the difficulties of the subject were hardly grappled with. It is evident that he had not consulted the best and latest Oriental and Celtic authorities. There are difficulties which his letter, good as it is, gives rise to. If the system was not pagan, nor Christian, nor a mixture, what was it? Of course, I use the word Christian not in a New Testament, but revelation sense. They had an idea of a supreme god, but was he the personal and spiritual God of revelation ? If so, how was their belief in the revealed God consistent with their idol worship ? In all pagan systems we find the worship of the one in the absence of belief in the other. Again, we learn that astronomy formed a large element in the religious systems and beliefs of the Orientals, How then was its introduction into Druidism consistent with the statement of your correspondent that it was the purest form of primitive religion ?" We do not find astronomy or astrology forming a part of primitive religion until it came in contact with and was cor- rupted by the religious systems of Egypt, Assyria, and Persia. I have an idea that Druidism was largely moulded by Eastern paganism, tinged perhaps by Grecian and Roman philosophy in its passage from East to West. Again, my third question had no reference to Druidism as an established religion. In using the word "state" I did not refer to anything political. If the magisterial and civil power, as well as the religious, was vested in the different Druidical grades or classes, what state was there apart from the Church system ? Your correspondent writes that they sat as magistrates, deciding all questions of law and equity; at the same time they were subject to the civil power." What civil power apart from themselves and their ecclesiastical system? They had power to excommunicate, which put the offend- ing party out of the pale of the law excommunicate from what ? The pale of what law, religious or civil Was there any difference between Druidism as a state and ecclesiastical system and the papal system dur- ing the period that the pope was vested with temporal power? Again, if the Cromlechs were Druidical altars, as suggested by your correspondent, what reason can be given for their appearance in Scandinavia and other parts of the continent ? What reason can be given for the predilection of the Druids for the oak when the same tree played such a prominent part in Aryan mythology? Lastly, present Celtic scholars have proved, I think, beyond a doubt, that the original religion of the Celt was a sort of Aryan polytheism. Whence then comes Druidism ? It is Christmas time, so I am not able to devote much time and thought to this intricate subject; yet I did not wish the kind letter of your correspondent to pass by unnoticed, even for a week, Wishing you, your correspondents, and readers a very happy new year, Yours truly, Dec. 31st. WM. FOULKES.

docs.full_text: Amateur Astronomers. I Their Ignorance and Impertinence. I According to a weekly paper, whose representa- tive has interviewed -the Astronomer Royal of Dublin, the amateur astronomer is the greatest trouble that Sir Robert Ball has to contend against. Asked to tell something of queer people and their still queerer ideas of astronomy, Sir Robert said Generally speaking it is quite uneducated folk-in fact, folk who cannot under- stand their own ignorance-who write to me in relation to the discovery of heavenly bodies, and no matter how ridiculous their notions may be, if I tell them that their views and mine do not coincide they very often become abusive. As a rule, they regard it as a conspiracy that is to say, if a man has some preposterous idea of communicating, say, for example, with the sun, and I take the trouble to point out the mistake to him, he immediately becomes possessed with the idea that there is a sort of astronomers' trade union which will have nothing whatever to do with wonderful discoveries. I remember a man once saying that he had succeeded in squaring the circle. He, too, I believe, went away with the notion that I was conspiring against him. TI Signal Mars. I 44 There has been a number of crack-brained projects for communicating with the stars. Here is one which I recall at the momenb. It was a scheme for communicating with Mars, and what the inventor proposed to do was to turn all the gas in London simultaneously up and down—to beat time as it were. Ho imagined we should got a response, of course. I daresay the efifect would be seen in Mars, but what would be the use of it? I am perfectly convinced that man, as we know him, inhabits this planet, and this planet alone. Tliere may be other beings in the heavenly bodies, but there are no human beings. Man is an animal just fitted for this globe." How Mars Might be Signalled. I On the question of signalling Mars, Sir Robert Ball thus expressed himself If a flag as large as Ireland, placed at the end of a pole 500 miles long, was waved it would just be visible from Mars. As I have said, we can never hope to make any intelligible signals, but the sentimental star dreamer disagrees with me. "Some time back a man came forward with the startling intelligence that the propositions of Euclid must be known in every place where, people exist. His idea was to describe colossal triangles by means of lights in the great desert of Sahara and thus transmit the propositions to every region inhabited by human beings. A grocer's assistant once sent me a lengthy epistle, saying that he was completely thrown away in the cheese and rasher of bacon line. My talent and genius,' so ran the letter, 4 show that I am marked out to be an astronomer, Thinking that perhaps there might be something in the gentle- man I read on, but my intelligence received a rude awakening when I read 4 For my mind finds no rest for the sole of her foot save on one of the heavenly bodies.' I really felt compelled to advise my correspondent, not only in his own interest, but also in my own, to stick to the grocery business and give up astronomy."

docs.full_text: THE WORD AND WORKS OF GOD. In the evening the service was conducted by wx> ^ev_ Robert Harley, Hon. M.A. Oxford, L!.JV.O., F.R.A.S., a native of Liverpool. The rev. gentleman, who is an eminent mathematician, received his theological training at Airedale College, Bradford, and was for 14 years pastor of the Congregational Church at Brighouse, York- shire, and also occupied the chairs of mathe- matics and logic in the college where he had been trained for the ministry. He was after- wards elected pastor of an important Congrega- tional church at Leicester, and became president of the Literary and Philosophical Society, there, besides devoting much of his time to pubhc work and with the various movements for the social and intellectual improvement of the people. He was elected a member of the first School Board at Leicester, and of the Executive Com- mittee of the National Education League. In 872 he was appointed vice-principal of Mill-hill ? T, „en years later he became principal u l j^ ld College. Iri 1886 he took charge of the leading Congregational church at Oxford, a position which he resigned in order to devote himself to scientific research. He is one of the very few Nonconformist ministers who have been admitted to the Royal Society, and lie is also a fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society. He is the author of numerous papers, chiefly on questions on pure mathematics or symbolic logic, and has made several important discoveries in connection with this science, and in consequence of his well-known abilities has been associated with the foremost scientists of the day. He has also been long recognised as an eloquent preacher. His discourse on Sunday evening was based on the 19th Psalm, the 1st, 2nd, and 7th verses— "The heavens declare the glory of God." He first dwelt on some points of contrast in reference to the Word and works of God, showing how the teachings of the one need to be supplemented and interpreted by the teachings of the other. Both were divine revelations, and necessary to man's intellectual and moral culture. The study of the stars was sublime. It served to expand their intellect and lift their thoughts to God; but the Bible was a revelation entirely adapted to man's moral necessities. The external vast- ness and magnificence of the science of astronomy served to make it one of the most sublime and fascinating of all the natural sciences. It was God's revelation of Him- self in external nature; but He had given them another revelation in;the.Gospel. They could do without astronomy, but not without salvation. They could do without the natural sciences, but not without the knowledge of Christ. All know- ledge was valuable, but this was invaluable. "Therefore," he added, "let not the philosopher glory in his philosophy let not the wise man glory in his wisdom but let him that glorieth glory in this, that he understandeth and knoweth God."

As a rue, they regard it as a conspiracy that is S some preposterous idea of j T i '1^ say< for example, with the san, ?n hi L trouble to point out the mistake *h« irlo'i diately becomes possessed with union wbinVi ^1* i? Sorfc ,astrononiers' trade with wonderful r| V8 .notl,'nS whatever to do Jvint I remember a man S.: h? £ £ 'i w,>h" FKOH T n "jeye, went away with the n0:. nUre lir ilCOnSP,r'nS i. r en. a number of crack-brained projects for communicating with the stars Here is one which I recall ab the moment It was a gas in London simultaneously u and down-to beat time as it were. He itaagined we should get a response, of course. I daresay the effect would be seen in Mars, bub what would be the use of it* I am perfectly convinced that man, as we know him, inhabits th.s planet, and this planet alone. There may be other be.ngs m the heavenly bodies bub there are no human beings. M™ ;= animal just fitted for this globe." On the question of signalling Mars, Sir Robert Ball thus expressed himself If a tlilg lar-ge as Ireland, placed at the end of a pole 500 miles long, was waved it would just be visible from Mars. As I have said, we can never hope to make any intelligible signals, but the sentimental star cireamer disagrees with me. "Some time back a man came forward with the startling intelligence that the prrpositions of -buclid must be known in every place where people exist. His idea was to describe colossal triangles by means of lights in the great desert of ^ahara and thus transmit the propositions to every region inhabited by human being?. A grocer's assistant once sent me a lengthy epistle saying that he was completely thrown away in the cheese and rasher of bacon line. My talent and genius,' so ran the letter, show that I am markud out to be an astronomer,' Thinking that perhaps there might be something in the gentle- man I read on, but my intelligence received a mda awakening when I read For my mind finds no rest for the sole of her foot save on one of the heavenly bodies.' I really felt compelled to advise my correspondent, not only in his own interest, but also in my own, to stick to the grocery business and give up astronomy."

docs.full_text: THE ASTRONOMY OF THE A-NCIENTS.-Frofessor Mitchell, in his lectures on astronomy, related a very remarkable fact. He said he had not long since met in the city of St. Louis, Missouri, a man of great scientific attainments, who for 40 years had been engaged in Egypt deciphering the hieroglyphics of the ancients. This gentleman had stated to him that he had lately unravelled the inscriptions upon the coffin of a mummy, now in the British Museum, and that by the aid of previous observation he had dis- coverea me Key to an tne astronomical knowledge of the Egyptians. The zodiac, with the exact positions of the planets, was delineated on the coffin, and the date to which they pointed was the autumnal equinox in the year 1722 before Christ, or nearly 3,500 years ago. Professor Mitchell employed his assistants to ascertain the exact position of the heavenly bodies belonging to our solar system on the equinox of that year (1722 B.C.), and send him a correct diagram of them, without having communicated his object in so doing. In compliance with this the calculations were made, and to his astonishment, on comparing the result with the statements of his scientific friend already referred to, it was found that, on the 7th of October, 1722, B.C., the moon and planets had occupied the exact positions in the heavens marked upon the coffin in the British M useum. TRICKS OF TRADE.—To disparage a good article for the purpose of selling all inferior, or a bad one, is not an un- usual practice with a certain class of tjaders. This highly censurable course, according to the statements of medical men and thier suffering patients, has been pursued-it is hoped with little advantage-by some apparently respectab le but not over-scrupulous chemist, and druggists towards that invaluable remedy, Dr. de Jongh's Light-Brown Cod Liver Oil, in lieu of which an inferior Pale, Yellow or Coarse Brown, so called, Cod Liver Oil-either passively inert and useless, or positively and actively perniciouis-is often secretly substituted or intrusively recommended by these parties. This exceptionable conduct proceeds from too obvious motives of cupidity to need explanation but its exposure is requisite, as well to guard purchasers against decept;on, injury, or disappointment, as to maintain the reputation of a remedial and salutary agent of estimable value. The rewards bestowed upon Dr. de Jongh by con tinental Governments and learned societies, the spontaneous encomiums passed upon his researches by the most illus- trious scientific men, the patronage which his celebrated Oil has received at the hands of she elite of the Faculty at home and abroad, have obtained for his preparation too high a public appreciation to be easily affected by the mercenary machinations of some avaricious dealers, not satisfied with the legitimate profits of trade.

docs.full_text: A NONCONFORMIST MINISTER ON THE CHURCH. The Rev T. H. Williams, a Nonconformist minis- ter, responding to a toast, at an Oddfellows' anniver- sary at Welshpool, last week, said that with regard to the Bishop and Clergy of the diocese, he might say that he yielded to no one in that room in his pro- found admiration for the Established Church (loud cheers). Although rocked in the cradle and dangled in the lap of Nonconformity, he had always learned to venerate the matchless Litany, the sanctified learning, and the grand history of the Church of England (loud cheers). It was a grand history. It had seen the birth and death of many systems of I, philosophy. It had seen empires and kings dis- appear and vanish in the shadows of the past: and whatever happened in the future he trusted that— they would believe him to be sincere in what he said —nothing would happen that would damage the influ- ence of that greatest and grandest religious institu- tion in the world (hear, hear, and loud cheers). How- ever, it was hardly necessary for him to praise the Church of England in Welshpool. He begged to thank them for the manner in which they had re- ceived the toast of ministers of other denominations -(hear, hear)-the weaker brethren (lausrhter and applause). Those who, as a rule, were of slow speech and stammering tongue. Those who, as a rule, were like the farmer's cow, grazinsr on the top of the hill—they had a poor pasture, but a fine pros- pect (loud laughter). However, he thanked them for the manner in which they had received the toast. He knew very well that some of them were of opinion that they poor Dissenting preachers took no interest in the social life of the nation (" No, no."). They said those ministers promised them splendid things in another world, but they wanted to make people long-faced and miserable in this world. If such had been the case in the past, he was glad to say that it was not so in the present. It was the duty of every minister of the Gospel to look after the physical and social wants of the people, of course not forgetting their spiritual wel- fare. The Gospel was all very well in its place, but it would not satisfy an empty stomach. They had read of the gentleman who was crossing the ferry. He said to the boatman, "Do you understand Geography?" The boatman replied "No, indeed." The gentleman said What a pity there's a quarter of your life lost." The gentleman then asked "Do you know anything about Astronomy :j" The poor boatman knew nothing about that either, and the gentleman exclaimed Then there's half of your life gone. "Do you understand Geology?" was the next question, and the boatman signified his ignorance of that science too. The gentleman gravely said "Then there's three-fourths of your life lost." By-and-by over went the boat, and the boatman asked "Can you swim?" "No," answered the gentleman. "Well," said the boatman, "there's the whole of your life gone." (Laughter.) They knew that Geology and Astronomy were very well in their places, but when the boat was upset the one thing needful was the power to swim: and he trusted they would not forget the more important and the minor duties of life. They as members of that Society were preparing for a rainy day; they believed in the glorious privilege of being independent. He again thanked them for the hearty manner in which they had received the toast. He hoped the day was not far distant when all those religious differences would disappear; when one would say to another" I am as thou art: I am for making all men greater, nobler, and happier; give me thy hand." (Loud cheers.)

docs.full_text: SIR ROBERT BALL AT NEWPORT. The great astronomical authority was the central figure at the opening of the session of the Newport Literary Society at the Tredegar Hall, Newport, last evening. The subject of his address was the suggestive one of Other Worlds than Ours." The hall was crowded. Lord Tre- degar presided, and was, as usual, an adroit chairman. There was no subject, he said, that tho general public knew so little about as astronomy. No one from the floor to the roof of that building, but all some period of his childhood had repeated the two lines, Twinkle, twinkle, little star; how I wonder what you are. (Laughter.) That, he believed, ended the search- ings of astronomy of the greater portion of the audience. (Hear, hear.) He would leave Sir: Robert Ball to explain what thoso lines meant.— Sir Robert at once plunged into his subject. The' great Lick Observatory on Mounb Hamilton and the large telescope at Melbourne were referred-to as the best of the world's appliances to find out what the other worlds were like. As there were a hundred million stars, ib was necessary to make a selection. Venus and Mars, the two nearest neighbours to the earth, were then dealt with on the happy suggestion that people generally knew more about their neighbours' affairs than the neighbours did themselves. The phases of Venus, the iacb as discovered by the last transit, that' Venus has a robe of air surrounding it; its continents and arctic .iZiovvs were dealt with, and the suggestion offered that there was life on the planet, probably of a most luxuriant character. Venu was noli favourably situated for observation because when it waa nearest its light waR obsoured; notso Mars, who showed Ins ruddy faco to the earth when nearest to it. The continents of Mars, the Arctic regions, the seasons were glanced at, and the remarkable canals of the planet, probably" 2,000 miles long and 50 or 60 miles wide, were placed on tho screen, by the oxy-hydrogan light./ The extraordinary thing about them was pointed'] out—namely, that they were In duplicate. The Manchester man's explanation of this fact served to raise a laugh. Jit was that everything was done with such energy and business spirit on the planet, thab when a railway or ship canal was constructed it was made in duplicate, apparently to get rid. of the superfluous energy. The moons of Mars and their rapid progress j around the planet were afterwards glanced at, and Sir Robert, reasoning from the analogy of the highly-organised life of this earth, wonderfully adapted to its environments, whether it was in the I deserts of Africa, tbe solitudes of the Arctic regions, j or the deep sea where scarcely a ray of lights penetrated, said it was possible to believe thab all i the glorious planets were hung up, so to speak, for man to look at and admire. Each, he asserted, probably contained types of life specially suited to the conditions which the particular globe had to offer. A vote of thanks to Sir Robert brought j the proceedings to a close. (

docs.full_text: Social and Personal. T LORD HOUGHTON. LORD HOUGHTON. Our portrait of Lord Houghton, the new Lord- Lieutenant of Ireland, is from tho Daily Graphic. PROFESSOR BARNARD. Professor E. E. Barnard, of the Lick Observatory, now famous as the dis- coverer of Jupiter's fifth satellite, is only about 40 years old. Only a few years ago he was earning a scanty living in a photo. graph gallery in Nash- ville, Tennessee. Being very fond of astronomy. he devoted his spare time to the study of it. He was so poor that it was a long time before he could afford to purchase the smallest telescope. Through the influence of a gentleman who recog- nised his ability, he became assistant instructor in astronomy at the Vanderbilt University. He there gave up his rights to the study of the heavens for comets,and he has probabiy discovered more than any living astronomer. When the Lick Observatory was opened he was given the place ot assistant observer. PROFESSOR ANTOINE. Professor Antoine, pre- sident of the French debates at the Birkbecb Scientific and Literary Institute, opened the first of the series which are to take place every Monday evening during the winter term. His subject, "The Economic Aspects of Pro- duction by Machinery." was keenly debated. He argued that machinery was the cause of over- production, consequently slackness of work for the workmen, and hence poverty. PROFESSOR ANTOINE. I NTWMAN HALL'S SUCCESSOR. The Rev. F. B. Meyer is a Londoner, and com- menced life in a commercial circle, but afterwards menced life in a commercial circle, but afterwards REV. F. B. MEYER. became a student tor the ministry. Having taken a University degree he began his ministration in 1869, when he became assistant pastor to the Rev. C. M. Borrell, of Liverpool. In 1872 ho accepted the pastorate of the Baptist Church, York, where he was eminently successful. In 1874 he took charge of Victoria-road Church, Lei- cester; but in 1876 he resigned his post to set on foot a movement, which should roach the masses who slay aloof trom all places of worship. The outcome was a great mission work carried on in Melbourne-hall, a building capable of holding 1,400 persons, which was alwuy- crowded to its utmost limit. In 1883 Mr. Meyer accepted the call of the congregation meeting in Regent's Park Chapel, where he was quite recently the recipient of a handsome presen- tation on accepting the important post he has now entered upon. LORD TENNYSON'S PHYSICIAN. Dr. iD ibb. the Isle of Wigiit physician who attended Lord Tennyson during hia last Ulnes?, is well known in theatrical circles as a facile drama- tist. who has once or twice produced pieces of considerable merit. docs.full_text: Astronomical Notes for September, [BY ARTHUR MEE, F.R.A.S.] People everywhere are taking a greatly iucreased interest, in astronomy, and though many absurd things get into the papers (as witness some of the recent statements about Mats), yet public atten- tion ia excited, and that is the main thing, and headers who wish to know more can betake themselves to sources of in- formation specially intended for those who ultivate the study of amateur astronomy. I wish in these simple notes to give some idea of the celestial phenomena for September, many of which can be followed with the naked eye, though, of course, a telescope vastly enhances the interest. It is scarcely necessary to add, the larger and more perfect the instrument the better, though a really good glass of only 2 £ in. or 3in, aperture will do 2 useful work as well as afford its owner an almost endless fund of amusement. Moreover, silvered- glass reflectory are so cheap nowadays that no one with any means to speak of need be long ere he obtains a trustworthy tetescope. Astronomical pheii^neua resolve themselves into two classes—those capable of exact predic- tion and those whose occurrence is more or less uttendod with uncertainty. The former class includes the movements of the Bun, planets, and the like; the latter includes the apparition of comets and meteors, which, if capable of predic- tion at al1, can only be so approximately. Many of these phenomena are governed by laws which astronomers are gradually getting to understand, and the time may come when most ot the pheno- mena now comprehended in the second class will be transferred to the first. THE SUN.-We commence our notes with the sun, the first astronomical object to attract the attention of mankind, and the material source of our oomfort, nay, of our very existence. This tremendous luminary, distant from us some 92,000,000 miles (the exact figures have yet to be ascertained), is no less than 2,400,000 miles in cir- cumference. On his glorious disc appear from time to time spots of varying magnitude, which are easily seen even with a small telescope by letting the sun's rays fall through it and then focussing the resultant imoge on a piece of note paper or cardboard. These spots represent gaseous eruptions of stupendou- luagnitude, compared with which the most fearful catastrophes of earth are but as the bursting of ;■ bubble. In some mysterious way solar outbursts arc said to influence auro'se, to interfere with the weather, regulate harvests, commercial panics, and so on. There may be some truth in the least wild of these aesertions, but the whole subject obviously demands a vast deal of further investigation. What is certainly known is that sunspots have a period of about eleven years, their size and frequency waxing and waning in that interval of time. This was discovered many years ago by Schwabe, who thus earned scientific immortality solely by pertinaciously watching the sun and keeping a careful record of his observations. At the time of writing spots are of frequent J < JUPITER. 1

docs.full_text: ASTRONOMICAL NOTES. Jupiter is now Rapid!y Coming to the Front. TBY ARTHUR MEE, F.R.A.S.] As the yeax draws to a close the brilliant constellations we are wont to associate with the winter sky make their appearance in the even- ing heavens: glorious Orion, preceded by AIde- baran and the Pleiia-de-s, and followed by Fro- eyon and by Sirius, most splendid of the fixed stars. Of the planets. Jupiter is now in the ascendant. Mars still holds a conspicuous plaoe in the heavens, but is getting very decidedly smaller, ana. therefore, less interest- ing, in the telescope. So far as I cftn ascertain, the so-called "oanals" have not been generally seen in England this season, but they require good instruments, and. above all, good air. and the latter has for some time past been conspi- cuous by reason of its absence. Mars, to the general observer, is, after all, disappointing, and he turns with pleasure to Jupiter and the glorious disc that he presents in a very ordinary telescope. The great red spot that some years ago was so conspicuous in the southern hemi- sphere of the "giant planet" still lingers as a faint, yellowish stain. Mars just now crosses I an the meridian. about 25 minutes past- eight: Jupiter at a quarter-past one, but he is beauti- ful high in the ea-stern heavens long before the average public dream of retiring to rest. Neptune is now in opposition in Taurus. near the small star "iota," buc the other planets are not worth looking for. The moon is full on the 12th inst. Two (very faint) comets are at present visible. The movement, for an astronomical society for Wales, with headquarters at Cardiff, is making good progress: it has the sympathy of such scientists as Principal Viriamu Jones, Professor Lloyd Tanner, Mr. Franklen Jbvans, and Mr. Whitmell, and has already a considerable mem- bership, comprising numerous beginners, a., well as practical observers. A meeting will be called in a few days, and intending members a.re requested to communicate with the writer at 41, Hamilton-street, Cardiff. ASTRONOMY AT CARDIFF. TO THE EDITOR OF THE EVENING EXPRESS." Sir.—In such a centre of learning as Cardiff one naturally expects to find each branch of science strongly represented, and I was very glad to hear that a movement was on foot to band together the astronomically inclined in your district. Perhaps, in no study is associa- tion more beneficial than it is to the devotees of this chilly, yet beautiful, cult, and in a country like ours, where good observing weather is scarce, all that is possible should be done to foster amateur endeavour in each locality, so that every suitable moment may be utilised. The individual find." perfect opportunities all too few. but a. society such as is suggested for Cardiff may accomplish "cod work by increasing the number of workers. Our ex- perience in Chester may be considered decidedly encouraging. Each year has seen a steady increase in our numerical strength, and. what- is more important, a vast improve- ment in our astronomical results. Of course, a fair amount of self-sacrifice on the part of a few of your leading scientists will be needed, but. headed by my friend Mr. Arthur Mee. I am sure that a band of earnest- workers will soon place the movement beyond failure. After three years of steady inrrea.se Chester can re- port enthusiastic and ii,telligent use of the many telescopes that its society commands. If your success in Cardiff is proportionate to your achievements in other fields, astronomy will be the richer for your labours, and with a hearty wish that this may lie so.—I am. Ac., F. W. LONGBOTTOM. Queen's Park. Chi-ster.

docs.full_text: THE SKIES OF JUNE. I ,-By ARTHUR MEE, F.R.A.S.] 1 Though most people like to read about the heavens, the number of those who apply themselves to their study is extremely small, and the reasons assigned are usually these— that astronomy is a science of ultra-abstruse- ness, that it is of no practical value whatever, and that it is so difficult to identify the stars, which shine in myriads overhead that it is perfectly useless to attempt the task. Each of these ideas is absolutely erroneous. Astronomy is divided into two great sections, the first of which is concerned with the nature of the stars, the second with their whereabouts. This last department is, indeed, abstruse, but with- out it navigation would be almost impossible, and the world would be robbed of its present means of obtaining absolutely correct time, j But we have no need to concern ourselves with this department, when the first is displayed invitingly before us. Here is no need of mathematics. All that is required is a, good eye and an opera-glass or telescope, and the desire to learn something of the wonders and beauties of the universe. To the studv of this department — observational u-stronomy — the reader is invited, and he or she will find it, if persevered in, one of the most fascinating of pursuits. As for the hopelessness of learning the stars, let us examine it a little more closely. Look up at the sky at nine o'clock one of these early June evenings, and you will find I that but very few of the stars are of any con- spicuous order of brightness. Indeed at this 1,, ->a non1." three of the most brilliant are I above the horizon—Capella, Vega, and Arc- turus. By reference to our little map (a very rough one, be it noted), the reader will iind A returns, a fine orange star, high up in the southern heavens, whilst the electric gleam of Vega. is instantly descried in the east, and Capeila low down in the north-west. Gither stars>, conspicuous enough, but less bright than this grand trio, will be noted, such as Castor and Pollux, Spica, Regulus, and the seven stars of the Bear the latter are most useful as guides—the Bear's ta.il always guiding the eye to Axcturus, whilst lines through the square of stars, forming the body of the plough or the hind quarters of the bear, point in one direction to the pole- star; in another to Vega, in another to (Japella, in another to the Lion, and so OD. Thus, step by step, we advance to a. knowledge of the stars and constellations, a knowledge winch may be further developed by that most delight- ful of books, Dunkin's "Midnight Sky" (a few edition of which was published lately by the Religious Tract Society), and the more advanced atlases of Proctor and Rail. The bright star, Spica, which is to be seen in the south ip our map, is an excellent guide to Saturn, which shines to north of it with equal brilliancy: the ring system of Saturn renders it, as everyone knows, one of the most striking and conspiouous objects in the heavens. Of the other planets, Mercury and Uranus are evening stars, Venus a morning star, and Mars, Jupiter, and Neptune in- visible. The moon is new on the ?rd, full on the ISt-h.

docs.full_text: NATURE NOTES. [BY ARTHUR MEE, F.R.A.S.] THE PLANET VENUS. Every one of these c'ear eveninss after sun- set a bright star may be seen shining above the W.S.W. horizon. This is the planet Venus, which aa the weeka pass will become a more and more brilliant and conspicuous object in the evening heavens. The gradual increass of her brightness and the shitt of her position amongst the star3 are well worth watching. now FAR DOES SOUND TRAVEL? It is interesting to note the very varying behaviour of sound. From my oor the bells of Llandaff Cathedral (distant about a mile) are sornstimes loud to a startling degree; at other time., (with apparently similar atmos- pheric conditions) not a s-und can be heard. Why is this, I recollect reading somewhere that Carmarthen bells have be:n heard at Llan- d:!o, twpive or thirteen miles distant; but, surely, this roquires confirmation. Of course. the great distance at which cannon can be heard is well known. Cannon cfT Milford have been heard as far as the confines of Hereford- shire! I should much like to hear tho opinion cf correspondents on these matters. NAKED-EYE OBSERVATION. So many peqpie have a rooted idea that no one can do a useful astronomical observation without, optical assistar.c?. that it sjives me much pleasure to draw the attention of such to the interesting series of articles on Astronomy Without a Telescope," now ap- pearing in "Knowledge," from the able pen of E. Walter Maunder. Doubtless, the idea alluded to is one of the principal reasons why astronomy is not far more widely taken up. May Mr. Maunder do much to dissipate it. In the January number of the same valuable and attractive journal the Rev. J. M. Bacon discusses some results of his recent aerial voyage, and there is another article of local interest, on "Explosions in Coal Mines." NOTABLE METEORS. Mr. Norman Lattey (Cardiff) states that on Thursday evening, about 9.23, he saw the most magnificent meteor he had ever witnessed. Its flight, which lasted three or four seconds, was from near the star Gamma Andromedae to below the square of Pegasus. The meteor was fully six times as bright as Venus at her brightest, and was somewhat the shape of an Indian club. The thickest part (the head) was a pale bluish green, intensely bright, iae "ail tapered off to a point, was of a deep red. fringed with violet, and followed by a smoky train. Did any other reader see this object? Mr. ,T. F. Young fLlanolly) describes a meteor seen by him on October 13, at C.15 p.m. It left behind it a straight, jilvery, broad streak of considerable length, for some 18 seconds.. The observation was corroborated by a friend.

docs.full_text: XATU RE~N OTES. [BY ARTHUR MEE, F.R.A.S.] THE PLANET VENUS. Every one of these E'ear evenings after sun- set. a brisrht star may be seen shining above the W.S.W. horizon. This is the planet Venus, t which as the weeks pass will become a more and more brilliant and conspicuous object in the evening heavens. The gradual increase of her brightness and the shift of her position amongst the stars are well worth watching. HOW FAR DOES SOUND TRAVEL? It is interesting to note the very varying behaviour of sound. From my loor the bells of Llandaff Cathedral (distant about a mile) are sometimes loud to a startling degree; at other times (with apparently similar atmos- pheric conditions) not a sound can be heard. Why is this? I recollect reading somewhere that Carmarthen bells have been heard at Llan- d'io, twelve or thirteen miles distant; but, surely, this requires confirmation. Of course, the great distance at which cannon can be heard is well known. Cannon off Milford have been heard as far as the confines of Hereford- Ehire! I should much like to hear the opinion of correspondents on these matters. NAKED-EYR OBSERVATION. So, many people have a rooted idea that no one can do a useful astronomical observation i without optical assistance, that it £ IVE3 me much pleasure to draw the attention of such to the interesting series of articles on "Astronomy Without a Telescope," now ap- pearing in "Knowledge," from the able pen of Mr. E. Walter Maunder. Doubtless, the idea alluded to is one of the principal reasons why astronomy is not far more widely taken up. May Mr. Maunder do much to dissipate it. In the January number of the same valuable and attractive journal the Rev. J. M. Bacon discusses some results of his recent aerial voyage, and there is another article of local interest, on "Explosions in Coal Mines." NOTABLE METEORS. Its flight, which lasted three or four seconds, was from near the star Gamma Andromedse to below the square of Pegasus. The meteor was fully six times as bright as Venus at her brightest, and was somewhat the shape of an Indian club. The thickest part (the head) was a pal bluish green, intensely bright. :-Lie 'ail tapered off to a point, was of a deep red. fringed with violet: and followed by a smoky train. Did any other reader see this object? Mr. J. F. Young (Llanelly) describes a meteor seen by him on October 13. at 8.15 p.m. It left behind it a straight, silvery, broad streak of considerable length, for some 18 seconds. docs.full_text: ATLHE NOTES. [BY ARTHUR MEE. F.R.A.S.] THE PLANET VENUS. Every one of these 'ear evenings after sun- set a briyr/it star may be seen sinning above the W.S.W. hcrison. This is the planet Venus, I which as th. weeks pa-s will become a more and more brilliant and conspicuous object in the evening heavens. The gradual inereas3 of her brightness and the shift of her position amongst the stars ;ire well worth watching. HOW FAR DOES SOUND TRAVEL? It is interesting to note the very varying behaviour of sound. From my foor the bells of Llandaff Cathedral (distant about a mile) are sometimes loud to a startling degree; at other times (with apparently similar atmos- pheric conditions) not a sannd can be heard. Why is this? I recollect reading somewhere that Carmarthen bells have been heard at Llan- d:lo, twelve or thirteen miles distant; but, surely, this requires confirmation. Of course, the great distance at which cannon can be heard is well known. Cannon off Milford have been heard as far as the confines of Hereford- fhire! I should much like to hear the opinion of correspondents on these matters. NAKED-EYE OBSERVATION. So many people have a rooted idea that no one can do a useful astronomical observation without optical assistance, that it gives me much pleasure to draw the attention of such to the interesting series of articles on "Astronomy Without a Telescope," now ap- pearing in "Knowledge," from the able pen of Mr. E. Walter Maunder. Doubtle8. the idea alluded to is one of the principal reasons why astronomy is not far more widely taken up. May Mr. Maunder do much to dissipate it. In the January number cf the same valuable and attractive journal the Rev. J. M. Bacon discusses some results of his recent aerial voyage, and there is another article of local interest, on "Explosions in Coal Mines." NOTABLE METEORS. Mr. Norman Lattey (Cardiff) states that on Thursday evening, about 9.23, he saw the most magnificent meteor he had ever witnessed. Its flight, which lasted three or four seconds, was from near the star Gamma Andromedas to below the square of Pegasus. The meteor was fully six times as bright as Venus at her brightest, and was somewhat the shape of an Indian club. The thickest part (the head) was a pale bluish green, intensely bright, file "ail tapered off to a point, was of a deep red, fringed with violet, and followed by a smoky train. Did any other reader see this- object? Mr. J. F. Young (Lanelly) describes a meteor seen by him on October 13. at 8.15 p.m. It: left behind it a straight, silvery, broad streak of considerable length, for some 18 seconds. The observation was corroborated by a friend.
